RATING: 9
Rating after watching 1 game and playing 2.
Fantastic!  Easy to learn, compelling, fun, co-operative without 1 player dominating, great balance, excellent ability to make the game more difficult, edge of the seat tension, "we'd have won if only.....", quick to play, "lets play again"-ness, cheap, cheering on the viruses!  What more could you want in a boardgame?

RATING: 5
I really dig into the theme, but the QB issue has finally sucked some of my enjoyment out of the game. The second problem I have with it is that the setup and mechanics of the game, while complimenting the theme, ultimately are more tedious to the game than what I'd prefer. That said, I'll totally play this over Forbidden Desert (again, technically sound, but less interesting) or Forbidden Island. Like many coops, the problem space is limited once a solution is found. Pandemic sort of, but not entirely, avoids this with the multitude of variants at your disposal in the expansions (and I think both On The Brink and, less so, In The Lab are sort of required for that reason). Oddly enough, the Legacy game does avoid this as the basic premise changes in subtle ways so you don't see the entire problem space each game.

RATING: 8
Pros:
Unique and interesting theme. The tension cranks up as the game goes on. Streamlined rules and smooth game mechanics. New gamer/family friendly. Games are always close. If you find it too easy you can crank up the difficulty level. Good component quality (I like the transparent plastic cubes). 

Cons:
Might get repetitive. Alpha gamer issue (not a problem for me as I'm the Alpha gamer!).

N.B.
Mum always saves Sydney, Australia even if it only has one cube on it. Not sure the game needs expansions as it plays fine on its own.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 6
[i]tl;dr - It's Pandemic. I have problems with the alpha-player tendency (which the game does nothing to curb) and the repetitiveness, but it's a favorite co-op for a reason.[/i]
[COLOR=#CCCCFF]____________________________[/COLOR]

Alisha loves this one, so I finally caved and bought it. What do you want me to say about it, it's Pandemic? I won't play 2-player with her, though. 

I am finding Pandemic Legacy to be a whole lot more interesting, because your decisions carry over from game to game, and it communicates the tension of the theme more effectively. Base Pandemic is just absolutely boring. I think that the base game needs a random deck of 'objective' cards (similar to how you face different objectives in Pandemic Legacy) to spruce it up and keep it fresh. 

Beyond that, something that I dislike in all of Matt Leacock's games is the alpha player tendency. I know I can be this kind of player myself, and I hate that the game doesn't do anything to smack me down and keep the collaboration even among players. While it is intensely satisfying to dream up a last-ditch effort to save the world and win the game, it's frustrating that the game doesn't force you to come up with that plan together.

RATING: 6

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 3
Played twice. So far I don't quite see why some of my friends hold this game in such high regard. But since it is a friendly and relaxing coop experience I'm glad I have it in my collection. Rules are easy to teach. What worries me so far is the apparent lack of depth. I didn't get a sense of having interesting choices when playing. What to do and when seemed rather obvious. But that might very well change after some more plays.

Edit: Some more plays has confirmed my earlier worries. Both my wife and I consider the game rather pointless. There is little strategy, and thus victory or failure is mostly a matter of luck, not tactics or skill.

RATING: 9
The rules state that you loose a game when one of the four diseases spreads to the point you cannot add more cubes of the particular disease to the board. During a play we nicknamed one of them 'dickhead syndrome'. And yes, we lost the game to this disease because we couldn't stop it. How ironic.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7.5
Core Game Rating 6/10: An aethetically well presented game highly suited to solitaire play owing to a small board size and the absence of hidden moves. Designed for cooperative play, it is easy for a player to "cooperate" solo whilst playing a number of roles.

The core game however, is overly dependant on luck, to the point that the number of starting colors (diseases) on the board, the draw frequency of epidemics and the draw of 4-5 color disease card suits will determine victory more than any player strategy.

The game offers multiple ways to lose with only one way to win. The degree to which gamer's agree put up with this form of negative reinforcement will determine their overall attitude to the title.

DYO Game Rating 8/10: That said, given the ability to design one's own scenarios, the rating for this game rises substantially. Having designed the scenario "A Swine of a Flu" simulating the 2009 spread of the H1N1 "Swine Flu" virus, I found a game I now liked in offering multiple ways to win.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

A fairly simple cooperative game, which fails to really immerse because of the global theme. Flash Point Fire Rescue offers up a similar experience with a more personal story attached. Still, this is a good cooperative puzzle.

RATING: 7
Deck and Dice mai 2009
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 9
“Clear!” (Bu-Bump!) That’s the sound of Pandemic paddles bringing the stale, crusty heart of board gaming apathy back to life. If you, like many people, are under the impression that board games can be categorized into Monopoly, Scrabble and Clue… than let me suggest a double dose of Pandemic. It has a board, cards and pawns, but it plays nothing like its predecessors. This is a game about saving humanity from the ever growing threat of infection and life threatening outbreaks. The mechanics provide a constant drip of impending doom as players race cooperatively around the world to save humanity from extinction. This is a great game for couples and for introducing people to the hobby. The cooperative play is a unique element to new gamers, and the theme of saving the planet from disease is something most people can get behind.  A player’s turn will see them traveling to all parts of the world, beating back outbreaks and establishing research stations to cure diseases before they reach a Pandemic state. In addition, your team will activate crucial events like air lifts, government grants and sanitation that add an often needed shot of moral as you battle outbreaks in the most remote parts of the world. Like many other games, prescribing individualized roles for each player is what truly what gives this game a heart.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

RATING: 9

RATING: 8
The gold standard of coop games pandemic is as close to a flagship game as comes to mind for zman. It has spawned a gazillion expansions and new games under its brand. Ultimately, this is a great game about a team of specialists trying to stop a series of diseases from wiping out humanity. They usually lose. I recommend this game for people that prefer collaborative problem solving over competitive play. Avoid playing with alpha gamers who need to micromanage/quarter back unless you are a bottom sort of fellow.

There's also the usual problem of having one dictater who knows the game really well, or playing with people who just can't communicate and do a co-op.  General criticisms though that shouldn't detract from one of the best co-op games out there.

RATING: 8
If I were a virus, I would make sure to show basically no symptoms in the first weeks. This way, nobody would notice  I'm even there, and all your logistics experts would sleep happily in their beds and dream of their ugly girlfriends, not giving a damn about planning new CDC research centers. 

If I were a virus, I would show an evolutionary preference for certain climatic conditions (officially, I don't even qualify as life form, so don't you dare call me a racist). This way, your quarantine specialist wouldn't even know where to start when I suddenly pop up at all the end-of-the-world-places that take him so much time to travel to. 

If I were a virus, I would mutate a lot. This way, your scientist lady at the WHO would need so many more samples of me before having the slightest clue how I even look like. 

If I were I virus, I'd get you all.

Pandemic teaches as lot about viruses. How lucky I am not a virus.

RATING: N/A

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 9
I ADORE this game. To me, this game is the king of anxiety-inducing, tense, edge-of-your-seat experiences. The co-op nature truly builds comraderie, and each person feels useful and helpful in averting Armageddon.

The art is excellent, and the bits are all well-constructed and designed. The pace of the game is amazingly fine-tuned, and you'll always feel one step away from defeat. This is a GOOD thing, as the game is intended to simulate a world-ending outbreak of diseases. If you didn't feel constantly under pressure, the theme wouldn't shine.

I highly recommend getting the On The Brink expansion. The vanilla game is awesome, but once you add in the fifth disease, new event/epidemic cards, and the option to have a player be a Bio-Terrorist and play AGAINST the rest of the group, Pandemic really takes off.

This game is a go-to game for my family, and I think anyone who is intrigued by the premise will love it.

RATING: 7
Sleeved
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 9
Pandemic is a co-op game that is not that hard to teach to non-gamers. This is the kind of game you want to play again and again until you beat it together. If you finally do that it feels really rewarding. But it is not an easy game. There are different levels of the game, but even the easy mode is hard enough the first couple of games.  

The game is both thematic and engaging. Every one of your actions can be crucial for the entire group. So you have to be careful and think through what to do. I've heard some complaints that this makes the game suffer from the alphaplayer problem, which is that one experienced or leader-oriented player are making all the decisions. I have not found this to be much of a problem in my different gaming groups I've played it with though.

This is a wonderfully designed game that I almost always enjoy playing. The mechanics are so connected and the game is well balanced. If I would have to pick one co-op game to keep in my collection, this would be the one.  
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

The game works, and is a great co-op game, but working together is normaly not my cup of tea.

RATING: 8

Also, while the short playing time can be seen as a good thing, it is also sort of anti-climatic, especially considering the amount of planning that goes into playing the game itself. Basically I think Arkham Horror is too much and this is maybe too little.

EDIT -- After a few more plays, I am addicted to this game and really appreciate how well it is designed.

RATING: 9
A fun cooperative game.  Rating may improve with more plays.

Further comments (6/30/09):  None of my gaming groups really got into this one.  Yes, it's fun, but it plays out in a similar manner each game and the biggest differentiation is in which role you have this time.  In addition, there's a distinct potential for a leader or dominant force to arise and take control (though this can occur with almost any coop).  Still, it's a fantastic coop and a great game (which is why it rates so highly for me).

Definitely worth checking out.  I'm glad I own a copy, even though I don't play it very often.

RATING: 7
The game is pretty good and I enjoy trying to save the world (and being defeated quite often).
However, and although it seemed like a positive aspect, the fact that it's a cooperative game can lead to a very uncomfortable experience. I've played it less than 10 times and that's been enough to see how some players can feel like they are not playing at all. I mean, when it's their turn, they usually do what someone else tells them to do, either because it's their first time playing or because there is an alpha gamer.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 6.5
I played this game just three times, so these are mostly impressions that may change after multiple plays.

Pandemic is a fine game. It's clearly very well designed and it's simple enough to be a gateway/family game... but I wasn't particularly impressed by it, maybe also due to the hype that surrounds this title. Concerning the production, while both components and artwork are very high quality, I don't particularly like the overall look of the game on the table. It's not bad of course, but it doesn't really meet my taste... especially for the strong blue on the board, that after a while almost hurts my eyes. 

Gameplay-wise instead the action points system is simple and quick enough. I like it, but on the other hand I don't find it particularly interesting or exciting. My biggest problem with the game is instead the strong luck factor. This might still be a wrong perception, given my limited amount of plays, but I feel like winning or losing depended too much on the card draws. I'm not saying of course that the players play no role in the result of the game, but if the cards come out in the wrong order, it doesn't seem that there's much to do about it. I really don't like that.

I think that Pandemic really deserves credit for innovating and bringing life to the cooperative genre, when it came out. It's a nice game with a cool theme and simple mechanisms, that make it perfect for families... but it's not the amazing game I was expecting. I like it enough that I wouldn't mind to play it again every now and then, but that's about it.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

One of the few cooperative games that I enjoy. Some character combination seems to work much better than other and luck plays a very important role, but losing can be also fun.

[b]Affordability[/b] - [microbadge=39229]
[b]Functionality[/b] - [microbadge=39228]
[b]Originality[/b] - [microbadge=39227]
[b]Quality[/b] - [microbadge=39227]
[b]Reusability[/b] - [microbadge=39226]
[b]Variability[/b] - [microbadge=39228]

:thumbsup: The different roles are unique enough to keep each one interesting with various synergistic strategies to pursue.
:thumbsup: The rules and mechanics are very easy to learn and understand, keeping every play flowing smoothly.

[microbadge=30754][c] [/c]There is no set path to victory and the game is quite a challenge, even at the lowest difficulty setting.
[microbadge=30754][c] [/c]The theme is a bit depressing, yet it feels somewhat disconnected from the mechanics.

:thumbsdown: The size of the pawns is a little too large for the game board, which makes locating specific cities difficult at times.
:thumbsdown: Luck is the true driver behind each play, and outcomes can only be influenced or improved in rare instances.

RATING: 7
I thought this was a keeper the first few times, because it seemed to be the ideal gateway game for my family. I now think co-op games are better played among more hardened gamers, both because it's too easy for one person to boss everyone around in a gamer+non-gamers situation, and because non-gamers can find the savage punishment 'we're all going to die' nature of a co-op a real downer.

Among gamers, this is way better.  My most enjoyable games of Pandemic have come when all players are autonomous planners, card information is not completely shared, and a kind of brains trust emerges.  But having said that, I am a little concerned that in a game where player interests are perfectly aligned, it seems irrational not to be just laying our cards down to show each other right away...

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7
The shuffling mechanic which causes certain cities to reinfect repeatedly (and gives you information about where the diseases will be coming from) is brilliant.I like the short length, which is much better for a cooperative game.  I also like how this game is not about just learning the strategy of what you need to do (how you need to spend your resources), and then having the person who knows the correct strategy dictate to the others what to do.  Rather, its actually a complicated tactical puzzle, one that actually benefits from having more than one brain thinking about it, and discussing it.  This game made me realize that cooperative games need to be promarily tactical, not strategic in nature, and need to be tactically difficult enough that anyone is going to need help from their partners in figuring it out, thus leading to true cooperation, not just the experienced player dictating moves to the rest (like in Shadows and in LotR).  
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8
[i]2017/05/08 6 plays 2-5p[/i]

One of the best introductions into contemporary boardgames. The consensual and simple theme can be understood and embraced by everybody : let's save the world from diseases!

The cooperative nature allows one to help players with the rules during play, and creates a lively discussion around the table about strategies.

The game has a spatial element which reminds of risk, each player has a role ensuring that s/he will play an unique and important role during play. The game has great pacing, with escalating stakes, and plays in under one hour. The game mechanics are simple and can be played by kids, who are really grabbed by the theme.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7.4
Pandemic is about players combined their efforts to save the world from 4 diseases.  Players can be one of the 5 characters which has their own individual abilites.  Players may draw epidemic cards which will hasten the spread of the diseases.

It is a race against time to save the world.  Players have to find the cure of 4 diseases before 8 outbreaks of diseases, depletion of city cards or one of the disease cubes has been depleted.  

Good points:  It is a easy game and players can learn the game easily.  Players can increase the difficulty of the game by adding more epidemic cards among the city cards.  The game can be exciting when players draw epidemic cards and hasten the spread of the diseases while players frantically tries to treat the diseases.

Bad points: The game can be exciting, but it can also be boring.  The excitment of the game really depends on the time, the epidemic cards appear and the appearance of which infection cards that affects the cities.  Sometimes, from the start of the game, players are able to determine the outcome of the game.  Only at times, the game is an even match and entertaining to the players.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

2010(?) Hexer Von Salem does the same job ten times better.

Pandemic is a perfectly likable and easy to learn cooperative game, but the maths just isn't hidden well enough and as a result the theme just doesn't shine like that later rival.

Given the choice between the two I would never choose Pandemic

UPDATE 2013: I have changed my mind - certainly with the expansion(s) Pandemic is much better than I remember. There's also no substitute for a game simple enough to teach in this short time 5>7

ANOTHER UPDATE 2014: I have never been so wrong! 7>8.5

YET ANOTHER UPDATE 2017: As I sail past 50 plays, plus 18 plays of the first season of legacy, this game represents probably the most inaccurate first impression I have ever had. Defines the genre, for me.

RATING: 7
Very well done co-operative game - very enjoyable. Recommend easy mode for new players. The strongest role is Dispatcher, the most important role is the Medic, the Scientist is the least needed role, and the Operations Expert and Researcher are medium important. Normal mode with four players is quite challenging - lost 2 of 2, with the second loss by 1 player turn only. Finally won 1 game in normal mode with 3 players, the Medic, Scientist, Researcher, and lucky disease setup with most diseases in blue and yellow regions. Easy mode with 5-players challenging for newcomers - next time, pick roles since new player had dispatcher and found it complicated. 2015 UPDATE: Still a great puzzle game with a good enough theme. A classic!

RATING: 9.5
Routinely play this with family, and we're not a board-gaming family. The cooperative nature, fun puzzling aspect of coordinating each other's moves, easy to like theme with broad appeal (not too nerdy, but not boring), and ease of learning contribute to it being a big hit. We never play just one game. Even without expansions, it hasn't started feeling repetitive. I've managed to get people who don't care much for board games interested in playing this one.

Months on: I love ramping up the difficulty in this game.  It is regularly brought to holiday gatherings and replays are often requested. I still do not have the expansion, and it's still my favorite.

RATING: 7.4
I like it and everything, but this is the opposite of a gateway game for me.  I love teaching games, but I do not like playing this one with people who are new to it.  I either have to watch as the game kicks their butts, or I have to basically play solo (telling others what to do), which is no fun for anyone.  So, for me, I only like playing this with those who at least have an idea of how the roles work together.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7.5
I had played Pandemic a total of two times in 2009 before picking it up at a post-holiday sale in the mall for $18. The two games I had did not really give me a fair representation of the game. The first game was a learning game in which all the players involved were new to the game and struggling the rules. The second play was months after the first and I had to re-learn the rules again, so it was more like a first play. Both times I played I saw some potential in the game; I loved the Epidemic mechanic, and the fact that players had to interact and plan together in order to be successful, but I didn't like it enough to buy it.

I bought the game because I love playing games with my family and this seemed like a nice fit for us. It seemed light enough for my parents to handle, hard enough to keep us coming back, and the fact that it was co-op meant that I could play with my family with out stressing them out with my "play to win" attitude.

After a few plays of this game, I can say that I am sorry I didn't pick up this game earlier. This has taken a seat along side Ticket to Ride, Carcassonne, and Settlers of Catan as one of my family's favorite games to play. The variability in difficulty is great, because I can set it to easy for my family and harder for when my girlfriend and I play this two player. I can see this game getting a lot of play in 2010. It deserves it. For a game that can be knocked out in 45 minutes it accomplishes a lot.
********FIRST HEROIC WIN***********
2 Player, Medic & Dispatcher 02/15/2010

RATING: 6

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 6
I understand why this game is a strong gateway game, but I've noticed that both Zee Garcia and Rahdo have this as their favorite game, despite the thousands of games that they have played, and that rather mystifies me.

The general complaint with many games is that they are insufficiently play tested and unbalanced by certain cards/dice rolls/etc. Pandemic, I would argue, is a game that suffers by being too well play tested. It feels, as you play it, like everything was carefully measured out so that the game play would happen exactly like this every time you play it:

1. The players act freely, doing the obvious thing, without really needing to put much effort into coordination or thinking.
2. Until the very last round, when *gasp* we can't win!
3. And then everyone puts their heads together, and *gasp* exactly 50% of the time, there is a special card or special power which allows them to solve the problem. And they win if there is, and lose if there isn't.

I enjoy stage 3, and would play a game that is stage 3 throughout the whole game. But 95% of the game is stage 1. The whole game ends up being an elaborate randomizer to determine the state of the game on the last round, and it has been so finely tuned to be this way that I don't feel like there will ever be a game which doesn't play out exactly as said. You could set your clock to the thing.

From a mechanical, perfectly crafted "thrill the non-gamers with a well-themed coop" sense, it's a great game. It knows what it needs to do to appeal to the average person and will do it every single time. But I'm not part of that audience. If I'm playing a co-op, I want to have to coordinate with my team and come up with solutions through the whole thing, not just once.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8
Finding this less and less fun, but still an excellent design.

RATING: 8
2-5(3,4)

It's a great implementation. The theme, components, and design are all very slick (I don't consider it to be "dry"). There can be a significant "leader bosses everybody around" component, but if you're cognizant of this you can avoid that. Scales well (harder with more players!) and, though it feels like a puzzle, retains its fun and challenge.

The pacing is really slick also, with the game starting out almost too slowly, but once an epidemic comes out it generally cascades into chaos such that endgames are legitimately tense. A great design.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8
A fairly quick cooperative game, and probably a good one to get non-gamers into the hobby.  The mechanics are simple, but the game can still be challenging.  I'm not sure if this is because a certain number of games are unwinnable due to sheer dumb luck, or if this is because to frequently win you have to be somewhere on the learning curve that I haven't reached.

Either way, it's still enjoyable, and seems to work well for a variety of people, so I'd assume it will work for most groups.  

There is some imbalance between the characters, which is unfortunate, but in a cooperative game it's less of a big deal.  There is also the issue of do-what-the-strongest-player-says, but it seems like this is almost a universal feature of cooperative games, and Pandemic isn't necessarily worse than the others.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 5
Terra has a similar theme plus a tension between acting in your own interests or playing cooperatively, Shadows Over Camelot has the traitor.  Both would have been much less fun as purely cooperative games.  Pandemic is a purely cooperative game.  

Pandemic models the spread of disease quite well and generates some tension through the infection and epidemic cards.  It is about making use of the various character specialisms as efficiently as possible.  Increasing the number of epidemic cards in the deck allows less room for sub-optimal play.  All perfectly competent, but I don't find this puzzle very interesting and there's nothing else going on.

RATING: 7

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 10
PROS: 
- A simple and yet entertaining game system. 
- The games are exciting and fast-paced. The game length is moving at around 25-45 minutes. 
- Very cleverly elaborated topic. 
- Variable difficulty. 
- It is necessary to cooperate. 
- Fun and playable in even 2 or more players. Solo play is also possible (the player will play several characters).  
- Entertaining even after many games. 
- It can take a rare players as well as experienced players. Quickly explaination of rules. 
- Some game material is somewhat minimalist (wooden cubes and classic wooden figures), but for this game it fits.
- Sympathetic size of box and the board (game does not need much space). 
- The influence of chance is adequate for gameplay, fun and thrill of the game. 
- Set up of the game is quite fast. 

CONS:
- Dominant players can theoretically take the reins of the game (but it never happened in our case). 
- Some cities on the map are shown somewhat confusingly (mainly in Asia), so sometimes the site is looking a while. 
- Some of characters are more powerful than the others.

CONCLUSION:
Best cooperative boardgame I've ever played. A brisk, exciting (sometimes it's really adrenalin), fun... and yet rules can be explained in a few minutes. Pandemic clearly belongs to our most popular games. And I highly recommend the expansion.

RATING: 7
At first I enjoyed this game, but after around 10 plays I have gotten concerned that: 
1) The game is too easy to win (even on heroic setting). 
2) A dominating player can overrule the decisions of other participants, because the game is more a puzzle with one solution than a true coop exerience.

As a puzzle for 10-12 year old kids I rate it a 10, but as a coop game for grown-ups I can only rate it a 6.

RATING: 8
I consider this game as a standard for all cooperative games. It's a brain burning game that is driven by some randomness, but nothing you really can't take into account. It's a hard game to win with many difficulty levels. 

It doesn't scale perfectly, as it becomes more hard with more players. Totally soloable game, even in multiplayer solitaire, and really enjoyable.

I like the new disign, and the components are of incredibly good quality. It's a pleasure to adds those translucent cubes, even if they mean you will lose soon.

RATING: 6
Pandemic is an excellent game, and particularly great for introducing player to co-op board games.
Personally, I find the base game lacks a degree of variety.  I liked it from day one, but almost never wanted to play it because you knew what to expect every game.  In my opinion the expansion "On the Brink" is almost a requirement.  It honestly fixes every issue I had with the game, plus adds better, more manageable components.  With OtB, Pandemic is an easy 9 for me.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 10
This is the game that started it for us. Well, in reality, it was the first episode of TableTop we ever watched. We started watching TableTop when a link to it showed up after a webisode of Felicia Day's FLOG. And we've been board gamers ever since.  WHEAAAAAAATOOOOOOON! (Any Big Bang Theory fans out there?)
Anyway ... this has to be one of our top 5 games. A thinky adventuresome puzzle that has you sweating from start to finish. You never know what will happen next. Never assume you've won until that last disease is cured! Just when you least expect it Pandemic can leave you a quivering bloody mess (figuratively speaking) on the lab floor. Wash your hands and expect the unexpected. 

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 6
This is a more advanced and decision driven version of Forbidden Island/Forbidden Desert style game. For those who enjoy cooperative games I think this is one of the "must haves" due to it's length (20-30min) depth (mild but decisions are important/key), and unique medical theme.
 
This game also has plenty of expansions and intricacies to keep it entertaining for the long run. At this point there are at least 3 expansions adding additional diseases, player competition, and disease mutations.

RATING: 9

It is a very fun cooperative, and has its own difficulty level adjustment.  There's a lot of card shuffling for such a quick game, but that's part of the suspense and what makes every game different.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 9
Amazingly clever cooperative game that brings tension and challenging decisions on every turn. Tough decisions include treating disease to avoid outbreaks, trading and saving up sets of cards to find cures, and building research stations to set up easy movement for future turns.

Great thematic design with the outbreaks and epidemics. The Intensify stage during Epidemics in which the discard pile gets shuffled and placed back on top of the draw pile is genius.

RATING: 7
As a collection of game mechanics, this is one smart design.  Its tight, clean, and challenging.  The various characters are interesting enough to give each a bit of variety.  They could use more.  The short coming in this otherwise very good game has to do with people.  The game can easily be dominated by one person's leadership direction.  When this happens, the other players are going through the motions of moving the pawns in someone else's game.  The rules don't have teeth to prevent this from happening.  That said, I'm not sure what the solution to the problem is.  It's not likely the fault of the game.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7
A great game but requires the expansion after a few plays.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7
A classic that I will include on my list of gateway games. This is one of those games that you can talk most newcomers into playing by asking them, "Do you want to save the world?" Pandemic is a co-op where all players work together towards a common goal - save the world from rampant diseases. Everyone picks a character card with a unique ability, and the four viruses are set up to begin infecting the human race at an incredible rate. Your job is to stop the epidemics and save humanity. It's pretty cool. No one has to feel the pressure to compete, but as with most co-ops, winning the game is not so easy. With this game, you get simple rules, quick playthroughs, and lots of player interaction. 7/10
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

RATING: 4
Co-op games are a strange beast: Usually one person knows how to play the game.  Either that person dominates the play for everyone, or the person knowingly accepts poor strategies from the others.  In the former case, the newbies don't care for the game; in the latter, the experienced person resigns himself to lackluster play.

RATING: 6.5
I liked this but didn't "love" it.  The gameplay seemed very mechanical.  I also didn't like that (unlike, say, in Arkham Horror) it seemed like you weren't really playing your own role.  Each move was a group collective decision and usually there was one move agreed upon as being "best" in any given situation.  There was never a time for independant thought or action.  I realize it's a "group cooperative" game, so part of it is working together, but this was more than just working together.  It was like a group puzzle solving party.

RATING: 7.5
First of all, a million thanks to wifwendell for this wonderful gift! It's the first board game I ever receive as a gift, and what a wonderful game it is!

Now, for the game itself. Having played only a couple times with my wife by now, I can agree on all it's hype. It's a great game, full of very interesting decisions. The fact that there are those random card draws make the game play every time completely different, and the roles really add up to the experience. I'm looking forward to play it with more people, but for now, it's a solid 9.

UPDATE: I still like it a lot, but no longer want to play it all the time. Down to an 8.

RATING: 8
One of my favorite Co-op game so far.  It's got an engaging theme that appeals to a broad group of people.  It plays fast and furious with little downtime (most games will play to completion in an hour).  

It's also a pretty finely tuned game.  The difference between winning and losing seems to always come down to one single turn.

recommended.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8
This is more a solo game than a cooperative one because each player has a hand of cards but unless you show your cards to others there's not much cooperation at all, so you have all the information laid open on the table.
You can play solo and use 2 to 4 roles. The 2013 game version has 7 roles (the original game had 5).
You move on the board trying to cure the 4 diseases while at the same time not letting these expand too much.
Maybe the roles are not completely balanced, the medic seems the strongest role. Other roles seem weaker, for example the dispacher in a 2 player game. The contingency planner (1 of the new roles) can reuse an event card, if the event cards come later in the game, this role is almost useless half of the game, whereas the medic or the scientist (cures with 4 cards instead of 5) are always helpful throughout the game.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 9
Get ready for the next big gateway game. Pandemic has the same approachability as Ticket to Ride but has the potential to be an even bigger hit because of: a) the more thematic, cooperative and immersive experience; b) quick pace (~30min); c) 3 levels of difficulty; d) tons of replayability with both the combination of role cards as well as seed conditions; e) potential for expansion maps and roles. This is the 1st cooperative game I've played where dialogue and clear communication among all players was key to solving the game. Matt Leacock's latest published design is an elegant, streamlined and well-crafted masterpiece.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

RATING: 8.5

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7
Great game to introduce someone to co-operative play. The theme interacts with the mechanics excellently - the way epidemics and outbreaks occur feels like a disease spreading which not only keeps players engaged but also makes it easier to understand and react to. 

If I had never played the expansion, I may have rated this game higher. The lack of game modes and relative lack of role cards really hurts it by comparison, however; I find that after playing the base game a few times in a row everything starts to feel "same-y" for lack of a better word. Every one reaches the same conclusions about strategy because there are only a few differences each time; it's only possible to gain and lose one role, and there are no challenges.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8.8
+ Pandemia: Al Límite.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8.5
One of those coop games you don't really know if you'll win till the very last moment. If you want a game to keep you on your toes from boot to finish, this is it. The variable difficulty mechanism is a clever way to regulate tension and max playtime is capped since once the card pile is exhausted, the game ends, something I found very convenient and suiting.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7.5
Great cooperative game, with lots of tension, and very scalable (though I must mention that number of players influences the difficulty, with 2p being the easiest). It's funny for both casual and experienced players.

The deck reseeding mechanic triggered by epidemic cards, causing cities to be infected again and again, is one of the most brilliant mechanics in the whole boardgame world.

One of the most intriguing aspects of Pandemic is the pace of the game: the tension grows with the increasing number of outbreaks, while players race to find the cures, and the finale is often very climatic (even when losing)!

Pandemic is hands down the best cooperative game around (said by a guy that's not in love with coops), with the possible exception of Space Alert (that is on a league of its own, being an ingenious out of the norm design, and that's definitely more a gamers' game...)!
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8
Each time I play this game, I like it more and more.  There are certainly combinations of roles that make the game easier, but even with a 'best case' scenario in terms of roles, things can blow up very fast if you have an outbreak chain reaction.

Simple and fun.

RATING: 6
Pandemic's popularity cannot be denied; and it's a solid medium-weight game. It's heralded as a great gateway game, though I find it better suited for casual board game aficionados curious about venturing deeper into the hobby, rather than enticing new people. The rules and numerous action choices aren't as easy to grasp for non-gamers as many other choices, though cooperative games are always appealing for those who are uneasy about competition. Personally, I find the theme to be a hindrance as well; it evokes the fear of disease epidemics so prevalent in the media, which can be off-putting for some, and for this reason I rarely pull it off the shelf.

I know the randomness of the game is what keeps it replayable, but those chances to just win keep the game a bit lower for me.  Oddly enough, I enjoy the times where we get randomly killed by the game... I suppose because I like the very strong us vs. the game feel Pandemic engenders.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 6
When this was first released I wasn't a big fan.  I played several games that were either terrible losses or easy wins.  Now that I own Pandemic Legacy I went back and played several more of this base game in preparation and had a different experience.  It's still possible to get those swingy games, but player actions have more of an impact than they seem at first.

I think there are some tricky considerations.  1) Some characters play better as teams, e.g., Dispatcher and Medic vs Generalist and anyone.  2) For all players to have fun, they all need to be approximately the same experience level and be about the same amount engaged (which means they all need to be able to contribute equally to this sort of logic puzzle). Otherwise, one player is probably going to dominate everyone's actions in the interest of efficiency/victory.  3) The game's apparent randomness decreases significantly once everyone understands how the infection deck works and specifically how that interacts with epidemics.  4) The game will always be random...if you get two epidemic cards back-to-back, or if every epidemic city outbreaks immediately.

So this is in no way my favorite cooperative game...that might be Lord of the Rings, even though it's so much longer.  There's also Forbidden Island/Desert, which have re-used these mechanics in a much more entertaining fashion.  And if you like the traitor mechanic then those games (e.g., Battlestar Galactica) neatly solve the problem of one player controlling all the characters.  With all that said, I am having a blast with Pandemic Legacy.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 10
My all-time favorite co-op game; Pandemic has it all.  Fast play, deep strategy, unpredictability, and the heart-pounding excitement and stress of so many ways to lose keep me coming back over and over again.  Although harder than Forbidden Island, its rules can be picked up without too much trouble, especially since you can help each other out.

RATING: 9
[color=#959595][size=7]Spiel des Jahres Nominee 2009[/size][/color]
[color=#959595][size=7]Deutscher Spiele Preis 3rd Place 2009[/size][/color]

[i]Posted: 4/6/10, Rated: 9[/i]
{2P: 9, 3P: 10, 4: 8}

[i]Pandemic[/i] is one of those games that gets a tremendous amount of "buzz" here on the Geek.  It is a cooperative title, which means players are working together to beat the game instead of each other.  In this case, it means they are trying to find cures to four globally-threatening diseases.  The subject matter of global epidemics isn't sexy in the slightest, but it very quickly grows on you all the same.

The amazing feature of [i]Pandemic[/i] is how refined it is.  It embodies Albert Einstein's quote, "Make things as simple as possible, but not simpler."  Each player gets four action points per turn, and can choose from a list of basic and advanced actions.  Reference cards are provided, which is always a nice touch.  She can also use her role's special power; there are five roles provided in the game.  You would think that this recipe is bland enough for the game to feel "solved," but that's not the case.  After having played over 50 games online and in person, I am still surprised by the creativity of some players.

The method of spreading disease has been perfectly implemented.  Reshuffling the discard pile onto the top of the Infection Deck after an epidemic does a wonderful job of making sick places...sicker.  You dread the "Draw 2 Player Cards" phase of your turn as you feel an epidemic lurking around the corner.  There is a sense of urgency to do as much as you can to knock down the "hot spots" before the next one strikes.  Two epidemics in rapid succession can be fatal.

The difficulty of the game can easily scale by adjusting the number of "Epidemic" cards in the Infection Deck.  Player-wise, the game doesn't scale as well: the 2 player game is almost too easy (even at "Hard" difficulty), the 3 player game is perfection, and the 4 player game is very difficult.  Hand management is the differentiator: in a 2p game, it is easier for one player to find a "cure" by collecting five cards of the same color, only four cards if you have the "Researcher" role.  In a 4p game the cards are spread out, and players have to use turns trying to pass cards between each other instead of treating infected cities.  Minus one point for this lack of scalability.  Interestingly, [thing=40849]the expansion's[/thing] introduction of a "Legendary" difficulty provides a solution.

Cooperative games resonate with me, because they offer me a chance to teach a game, and also try to win at the same time.  [i]Pandemic[/i] has a theme which allows for a streamlined rule set which also provides a compelling challenge.  You can even [url=http://www.brettspielwelt.de/Spiele/Pandemie/]play it online for free[/url].  Don't be inoculated by all of the hype: [i]Pandemic[/i] really is a game you should try.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

RATING: 7.5
Since I play mostly with my wife and two daughters, a cooperative game is ideal. To this day, we have yet to "master it" and we probably only win about 50% of the time. The expansion, On the Brink, only increases the replayability and variety. I haven't purchased any other expansions yet. The game design is truly a marvel at how well the AI works. I really enjoy the variety of roles available. Also, the different scenario challenges keeps this game from getting old. Not crazy about the time it takes to set everything up and prepare the decks. Also, it seems like some random setups are just not winnable. Finally, the ending can be anticlimatic as you can see that you're about to win or lose a turn or two prior.

RATING: 3
The first time I played this game I thought is was the best co-op game ever. Now that I've played it half a dozen times with different groups of people, I realize that the game is really meant to be played solitaire. If you've got a group of mixed experience the vets will end up "advising" the newbies on the optimal move. The result is the newbies might as well not be playing at all. There has to be better rules on interplayer communication than exist to make this game work multiplayer.
And who wants to play alone anyway.

RATING: 7
This game is brutal. I'm not sure if we were horrendously unlucky, but we went 0 from 6 during our first Pandemic sessions, and that was on easy mode!!!!!

It's a great game of teamwork and should be a must have for any person who enjoys co-op games. The game is fast playing and gets very tense very quickly. As many people have pointed out, Pandemic suffers from the curse of the co-op: Where one player (generally the most experienced) takes control of the group and reduces the other players to spectators.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8
Co-operative game where you and the other players try to save the world from four diseases ravaging it.  For bonus fun, name the diseases!  Scramble to find cures for Bronchial Marmosets, Bloatyhead, Splatterlung, or Zombieism!

When playing co-op, you sometimes wind up with a player the owner of my favorite games shop refers to as "The Colonel."  The Colonel knows the game better than anybody else (or at least thinks he does [and yeah, it's usually a "he"]) and does his level best to turn the game into a solitaire exercise where you're just along for the ride and there to bask in his glory.

Some co-op games have mechanisms that thwart The Colonel.  Pandemic, unfortunately, is very nearly The Colonel's ideal environment.

If you can avoid having that ass at your table -- and avoid the temptation to BE that ass -- this game will easily rate a 9 or 10.  Despite very simple mechanics, it's tense as hell.  Every decision means something, and the next card drawn could be victory or disaster.  It manages to be challenging without feeling unfair, and can make for a great experience.

But if you've got The Colonel at your table ... seriously.  Give him one warning that he needs to stop ramming unsolicited advice down everybody else's throats.  Then when he gets pissy with you for not doing exactly what he told you to do, get up and go play something else, and make a mental note to never play a co-op with this jagoff again.  (And fer Chrissake, don't actually BE that guy.)  Because, seriously.  Fuck The Colonel, man.  Fuck 'im.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7.5
This is fun.  My wife and I have played this a few times.  We quite enjoy co-op games and this is one of the best if not the best we've played.  
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8
Great coop game. Very chaotic.

RATING: 7.6

RATING: 7
[i]The[/i] gateway co-op, and a compelling puzzle of a game, tricky at normal difficulty and extremely tough at "heroic" level. Its mechanics are beautifully simple but quite thematic, and there's a certain morbid joy to be had in watching outbreaks cascade across the continents. However, it can be a bit dry, and without players of roughly equal ability and experience it can suffer from "quarterbacking" syndrome, where one person dictates everyone's moves for them.

RATING: 8.3
Great theme for a coop game and particularly well integrated into the game. Tough decisions to be made throughout the game. Nice buildup to a climax as the game always seems to be close. There are no shortcuts or easy ways to win this one unless you get very lucky. Very easy to adapt for solo play and the short playing time is a bonus also. 

After a few more plays it seems that the challenges presented aren't the same for different player numbers. The difficulty remains the same but when playing with a lower number of players the problem is managing the outbreaks where with more players the problems seems to be to discover the cures. Interesting design!

RATING: 7
The one thing I didn't like was that you don't have an option to do your own thing. This is a very tense co-op game, but you must make decisions by consensus to win. In other co-op games, like Shadows over Camelot, you can sometimes "go rogue" and do something that you want to do that the whole team doesn't think is a good idea and you can still win, but generally, in Pandemic, you all agree on a course of action and then have to follow suit. Still fun, I just didn't like that dynamic.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 10
I will readily admit that I am very partial to cooperative games.  I love the idea of working together as a team to defeat the game.  And this is the most streamlined cooperative game I have ever seen.  Many groups will argue that it is not enjoyable because one person can control the game and tell others what to do.  While this is possible, our group just doesn't work that way.

For me it's almost like a brainstorming session.  People look at their cards and they throw out ideas for what they could do.  The key to the game is allowing all the players to contribute and make their own final decisions.  I love the ebb-and-flow of the diseases in this game.  The way that the disease can be under control and then one epidemic later things are a nightmare again.  We have a fairly good success rate with 5 epidemics, but we usually win with only 1 turn left in the game.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 10
This is one of my gaming group's favorites to play. I played with my family (who don't normally enjoy cooperative games), and they refused to stop until we finally won a game.

RATING: 6
Pandemic is an ok/ good game but more you play it and more demanding you are as a gamer, the sooner you see the game's problems.

One of them being replayability and repetitevness. Yes cards get reshuffled, yes diseases come out elesewhere but it becomes repeating the same process over and over again, not to mention the problem of an alpha gamer or gamers who will in the end possibly be controlling all players to do what they say. To me that is not exactly spectacular. 

Yes it is a solid game, yes objectively speaking maybe even a good game, but I also think objectively speaking it ends there... it is not more than that.

RATING: 8.5
Excellent for newcomers and gaming veterans alike. I've been working to control my personal quarterbacking issues, so that's helped. It's also reduced at a player count of 2, since it's more one-on-one conversation about what's best than outright directing a group.

I love the tension, and how generally I end up one turn away from utter defeat (or more often from victory...) Fantastic balance for something that has strong randomness.

RATING: 9
A wonderful cooperative game that scales really well from 2 to 4 players... though the game does change depending on the number of players (it is a bit more dynamic and challenging with 3 or 4 players).  Those I've introduced to this game like it.  It's easy to pick up and play quickly and it's cooperative.

After 30 plays, I'm finding that we usually win now with 2 or 3 players against the normal game and wins against the heroic game are pretty common with 2 players.  We have definitely improved!  And, I lose at least half the time with 4 players against the normal game.

With more than 50 plays, I still really enjoy this game! I'm now over 100 plays.

RATING: 8.2
Pandemic is a solid cooperative game in which players attempt to save the world by discovering cures for each for four diseases.  Each player plays a unique character with a few special abilities.  Disease cubes are added by a card draw based mechanic.  The theme works well with non-gamer types although the fun of the game depends on how well the group cooperates to beat the game.

RATING: 7
1316
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 9.1
The basic story for the game is that you are scientists working for the CDC trying to cure four deadly diseases sweeping across the world. Failure results in global eradication of human population... so try not to fail.

At it's base it's a cooperative strategy game which plays out more as group puzzle solving. If you don't play well with others then you are going to want to keep moving. 

In Pandemic each player takes their own turn, what they do is ultimately their decision, but the nice part is that anyone can talk about what actions should be taken during each turn. It makes every turn a group discussion which adds a little length to the game but makes it a team effort. If you have a team working well you can knock out a game in about 45 minutes, but on the flip side it can take a full hour and a half if things aren't going smoothly within the group.

This game is difficult, no sugar coating, but it just makes the actual victories that much sweeter. The game does scale to player skill level so less experienced players can play an intro game and people well versed can play at settings that give the same feeling as the waiting room at your proctologist.

A downsides to the game is that it can lead to someone taking over as table captain. Occasionally someone will feel, for one reason or another, that they are the smartest and therefore their suggestions should be exactly what the entire group should do. My response to this is that the meek should speak up! Just about every school I've been to the teacher always said "There is no such thing as a stupid question" and in Pandemic that is absolutely applicable. Your idea might not be the greatest for the situation, but part of your idea might be useful. I've had many games where I thought A+B=C, then someone suggests A+D=F, to which we then come up with D+B=W... W for winning! Bottom line is you should voice your opinions. If you are a quiet talker then use your legs to kick people until you are heard out. 

Personally I love co-op games. I really enjoy seeing how other people are working on the same puzzle as opposed to how I am working it out. Pandemic scratches that itch to the point my leg involuntarily shakes.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8.2
with  'on the brink'

RATING: 9
Cooperative game in which the goal is to cure 4 diseases before they outbreak too many times or time runs out (you run out of cards to draw). Pandemic is extremely tightly designed and very well streamlined, as well as being one of the most intense experiences in board gaming. Without good player communication and team work, there is very little chance of beating the game. Tons of replay value.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 9
Home run.  This game is fabulously fun even if our group has played it to death.  A fast moving game that nails all the 3 important attributes of a good coop game: increasing tension, encouraging cooperation and variability.

The method of accruing disease blocks is inspired, ramping up the urgency as the game continues on while having a great mix of randomness and hysteresis.  The nature of curing diseases and the player powers forces player to work together.  Variability is handled well with the randomness of the disease outbreaks.  While much of a game is block triage, this doesn't actually get old, mostly because Pandemic is quite short.  It's amazing how many sins are avoided by merely making sure a game ends in a timely manner.

If we want a meaty coop game we go for LotR, otherwise it's Pandemic all the way.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7.5
I have a gripe with Pandemic, which I think can be said about other co-ops as well (not that I've played that many):

When you keep your hand of cards secret, it feels like such a redundant thing to do, because everyone is working together towards the same goal.. why keep the fact that you have any given card in your hand a secret if someone else needs it, or needs you to use it? 

That said, play with everyone showing their hands and it can feel like all but one player are redundant, as the game can be (and often is) played solo.

Give me a co-op with a traitor or secret objective - then there's a reason to hide your cards and it doesn't feel so labored.

Don't get me wrong, I still enjoy playing Pandemic and I understand that further expansions introduce some of the above mentioned twists, but for me the base game is just not a heavy hitter.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8.2
Best with 4, but almost as playable with 2 or solo , this co-op game took BGG by storm and rightly so. The mechanics behind the game increase tension as time goes on. There's a card limit - if they run out, you lose. There's an infection cube limit - if you can't place a cube when required, you lose. There's an outbreak limit - too many outbreaks and you lose. There are also epidemic cards which not only cause an instant batch of cubes to hit the board in a new city, but also force all the places already infected to get put back on top of the infection pile, so they'll all be coming at you again from then on. These mechanisms link and compound each other too. The option to vary the difficulty by amending the number of epidemic cards in the deck is clever also. 

My first solo game (with 4 epidemic cards - the easiest setting) saw my 2 players win by curing the 4th disease with 1 black cube left unplayed, 1 outbreak remaining until I lost and only 3 cards left in the draw pile. Pretty close on all counts and quite dramatic at the end!

There was a buzz about this game everywhere and even the people who usually announce "I never play co-op, I'm too competitive" wanted a go at this one.

I've found this to be an immensely enjoyable game, there's plenty of theme here, it just drags you in.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8
I have now played it with my wife a few times and we like it a lot. I even made a role card for her since she is a public health nurse. I always thought that it was a glaring omission not to include the front line pandemic workers.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8
There are some very clever mechanics here which inspire panic and dread as well as any you'll find. There is a real sense of accomplishment when you can solve the puzzle - which had no guarantee of a solution at any time. The theme makes perfect sense with the mechanics though it can make for a bit of a "downer" when another loss occurs. I'm probably in the minority, but however silly it is, it's just more fun to conceive of diabolical, Lovecraftian doom than real doom being visited upon the world population. This is a classic game for a reason and it deserves to be tried by everyone, but I might find myself playing the considerably lighter Forbidden Island when I want to play with the same mechanics.

Update: I've raised this to a 7 after getting some experience with the iPad app. It really is very clean and sometimes I want that. I still feel it's probably best as a solo game because the alpha gamer factor is very high here (a factor addressed well in more recent co-op games)...maybe expansions will mitigate that somewhat in this title; I will have to see.

Update: Yep - an 8 now. A modern classic. Playing Pandemic Legacy (a stone cold 10) helped me see more theme in the original game in addition to its cleanness and elegance. The alpha-gaming issue is still there, but that issue isn't enough to have it less than an 8.

RATING: 6

Gets a lot of "one player tells all the other ones" comments, but I don't mind because ragging on the one guy who was so sure where to tell everyone to go and then loses is fun. Played solo, two, three and four players, played great every time.

RATING: 6

Excellent value in cooperative gaming.

RATING: 6
My wife likes the sound of a cooperative game based around diseases.  "It sounds interesting" translates to a game I want to play with her, and something I want!

We picked this up and have run through it together.  So far, so good, looks like a game we'll enjoy playing together!

This is a very light game, but it can be difficult to win at first.  Took us five games to win, though the fourth game was very close.  It's a good game, but it doesn't scratch my gaming itch quite enough to make it a main event game.  Good filler and something fun to play with my wife when we don't have a lot of time.

The lack of theme with this game bothers us.  I find we end up playing Stone Age or Carcassonne over this title, and I can foresee playing a few other games before this hits the table.

Played some solo games of this, and it was more engaging than I'd thought before.  I don't know that I'll play it all the time or over certain other games, but it made for a quite enjoyable solo experience.  Increasing my score.

Traded away for a gift certificate.  It was not going to get more play, so I might as well turn it into something I enjoy.

RATING: 7
Quite possibly my favorite of the "group puzzle solving" genre.  The Outbreak mechanic is one of the most elegant design solutions I've seen in quite some time, and creates a very interesting dynamic.  It manages to create just the right level of panic and challenge.

As always, the wrong group can ruin this one, though.  As long as everyone has good contributions to the table, it's an amazing game, but it could easily degrade into "one smart guy and his puppets."  So long as you can avoid that pitfall, it excels.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 6.5
This game is a beautifully designed, inexpensive, cooperative game; perhaps still the best in its genre. Below is my argument for this NOT being a gateway game.  

1. The Alpha Player Dominance Conundrum. As an alpha player, there is a lot of flak for trying to control the game. However, new players are so overwhelmed that they end up asking for help anyway. So who's really at fault? 

2. Choice vs Randomness. While this game provides a sufficient amount of actions, there isn't really any room for choice given the level of randomness. You're never going to avoid an outbreak, only to leave and watch an outbreak happen at the city that you just left. Oh wait, yeah you will. 

3. The Percentage of Losing. After 45 minutes and losing, I can't get people excited about this game again. (Usually, "What would we have done differently?" See #2)

4. The Underwhelming Abstract Experience of Winning. Whether you win or lose, the board will still be covered with cubes. Compare it to Forbidden Island in which you escape via helicopter; in Pandemic, you just sort of walk away.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

RATING: 8

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8
This is indeed a very enjoyable co-op game.  Not to mention it is very solid as a solitaire game.  It is, as advertised on BGG, very difficult to win.  However, it can be done so it doesn't get to the point where it's frustrating.  I have only played a small hand full of times so far, so my current rating may fluctuate some after a few more plays.

I do need to mention the components.  Either the board is too small, or the pieces are too big..maybe a little of both.  Either way, the board can get awfully cluttered when an area gets busy.  Often times you will not even be able to see the names of the cities underneath all the cubes, pawns, and research stations.  This forces you to move things around on the board and it is very easy to get cubes of the same color pushed around, thus making it easy to possibly end up with a cube on a city it shouldn't be on.  I suppose after many plays you will memorize the city locations, but at least initially it is quite annoying.

RATING: 8

RATING: 10
What I can say about it: it is hard to understand, takes a long time and makes you think twice until making a move. So, let me explain a little more about this game. Usually, if you want to play pandemic for the first time, play with 4 epidemics and if possible, with a person that already played the game at least once. To be sure that you have a chance for the first time, you can take also your characters because in 2, it's even harder, not necessary in 4. Don't forget about the 7 cards in the hand, it's very important. Look at the game and search for cities that have already 3 cubes on them, you don't want explosions or other infections. Look at the infection deck, remember what cities were infected earlier, what have 2-3 cubes on the table, etc. Read the small rule card that every player has in case you forgot something (usually for transport). It usually takes more then 1h - in case is you play for the first time. Try to find cures, don't eradicate them if you don't have time or cards. I think it's the best game that i have played ever on this idea of cooperative playing. For sure i will take an expansion on it :).
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 9
Pandemic was my first co-op game experience, and it is still one of my favorite all-time games. While it's notoriously difficult to win (I've only won about 1/3 of the games I've played), it's not impossible. Although it's a lot of fun, though, Pandemic is not without its flaws. The two big caveats I would give it are:

- Winning is actually not that much fun. The times I've had the most fun with Pandemic are when my group loses and we instantly want to play another round. This never happens when we win.
- If you're playing with people who are *too* focused on winning and not as focused on letting people make difficult decisions, it can turn into a situation where one player is just telling everyone else what to do, which can be pretty annoying.

Regardless, Pandemic is one of those games I'm ALWAYS down to play, which is saying something. It's easy to teach to new people, but the randomness of events makes it incredibly replayable.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 9
Pandemic is an excellent game that is worthy of shelf space for several reasons:
1) It's very different from the usual Euro.  Co-op play is such a different dynamic.  It is not one that I want all the time, but it offers a nice change of pace, and is also highly suitable for gaming with "non-gamers".
2) The theme is really, really well done.  And it's not set in Renaissance Europe.  Again, a nice change of pace.
3) Plays well with 2, and is, again, a great change from games in which you or your spouse have been a little bit dominant in recent times, leading to a blacklisting of said game.  Hypothetically speaking.
4) The game mechanics that you are playing against offer scaleable difficulty, and give a real challenge.  I think it's probably very difficult to design a game which will give a satisfying challenge to players of all skill levels, but Pandemic accomplishes this admirably.

Bottom line: It's Co-op.  This is good, and bad, but mainly, it's very different.  Pandemic is a really, really well done Co-op game.  If you never want to play cooperatively, this is not for you.  But, for most of us, Pandemic is a great option in many situations, and provides a welcome change of pace.

Expect games to go 30-45 minutes, with time decreasing with experience (and also when you get a brutal draw, and lose in the first three turns).  Replayability is very good.  Suitability for 2 players is high. 

Update: after 10 plays, I've upgraded my rating from 8 to 9: Always want to play.  This comes with something of an asterisk - I think there are many games I would pick over this, if it was just up to me, because I like competition more than co-op, and I prefer deeper games.  But, there are many situations where Pandemic is just the best game for the situation, because of the other players.  And, so far, this one has not worn out it's welcome.  So it's fair to say that, in those situations that call for a gateway game, or a co-op game, or a lighter game, I will always want to play Pandemic.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

RATING: 6
[b]Co-op on a map:[/b] This was the first modern boardgame I bought. Discovering co-op play was pretty rad, and for a while CD and I would always play at least two games in a row. The shuffling and replacement of the discard pile to intensify the infections is brilliant. 

M | 2-4

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 6
A moderately fun co-op. Since I just adore cooperative games in general, I have to give thanks to Pandemic for doing so much to popularize the genre.

I personally don't find the medical theme super interesting, but it does come across pretty well. I really like the world map, which looks great and gives the game a surprisingly epic feel. Another nice thing is that the game is pretty short--four people can easily get it done in under an hour. Setup is a little awkward with the need to seed the Epidemic cards into the draw deck, but still pretty fast.

On the minus side, I don't find the actual gameplay to be super interesting. There is some strategy but the luck of the draw unquestionably predominates. And really, I just don't find the game's mechanic for finding cures (collect a bunch of cards of the same color, then discard them at a research station) all that compelling.

However, Pandemic's simplicity, brevity, and strong theme may make it a good choice for introducing people to the world of co-op gaming (particularly someone interested in medicine or public health). I myself would rather just play Eldritch Horror (a game that obviously owes much to Pandemic, but is much more interesting).

I should note that Pandemic Legacy, by all accounts, fixes my complaints about Pandemic's uninspired gameplay. I hope to try it someday.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 5.5
I had to think long about why this game never took off for me. It's one of friend's favourite games, yet I've never had the impulse to learn the rules (as easy as they are) and I can't enjoy it. This game gave me incentive to learn about why I like certain games, and why I just can't be interested in others. The game is not bad by any means, but it tends to turn my brain off when it gets to the table.

All of the following reasons could be lacking in any game I enjoy, but Pandemic hits a critical mass:

The world and atmosphere: Jerry Seinfeld once said about sitcoms, that people will enjoy watching a show if they want to be there. When I see the Pandemic map and I think about flying to Atlanta or Ho Chi Minh City, I lose interest. 
The decision-making then becomes mechanical, superficial, and homogenized. This may be biased, because I may overlook this in a game that has a theme I enjoy. And I can see how others find the depth and simplicity in a card driven game. 

Rules are streamlined and the game flows well with good tension.

RATING: 8

The pressure is on for the players as outbreaks escalate the need to find cures quickly before the world is overwhelmed with disease. UPDATE: After 30 plays, reinstating the 8 rating for the excitement factor, even at the Normal Level of game play.

RATING: 9.1
This is an exciting game. I love it. Oh, sorry, we love it.:D Because it is the first game that my wife discuss the strategy with me! What a surprise! A definite wife-friendly game! It can turn your non-gamer wife into a gamer.

Easy to learn!
Easy to grab the strategy!
Easy to feel the tension in 30min!

An Easy game, but really hard to master!
That is what we called, Awesome!

RATING: 9
The grand-daddy of the cooperative games.  This game is perfectly balanced between the game and players (especially at 4 players).  Most plays (and they have been numerous) come down to the wire.  Win or lose; the tension is always there.  It makes you feel like each decision you make matters.  Definitely susceptible to alpha gamers, like many other coops, so choose your play group wisely, and enjoy the team-building that working through the tough decisions brings.

[29/01/2016] Rating: 8
Un juego cooperativo muy interesante, a priori un juego solo con cubitos de plástico y un montón de cartas podría parecer que tiene la temática algo pegada pero en cuanto empiezas a jugar sientes como las epidemias se extienden en cuanto te descuidas un poco. Es el primer juego cooperativo al que he jugado y estoy encantado (además lo he jugado bastantes veces en modo solitario).

Es sencillo de explicar pero tienes que llevar muy bien la estrategia cuando juegas en MODO HEROICO (6 epidemias) y aún así es posible que el mundo muera a pesar de todo. Como pega, creo que algunos personajes son muy potentes (sobretodo el GENETISTA)

RATING: 9
I just picked this up today(2/22) from my FLGS and I'm glad I ventured out to get it!  Initial rating based on solitaire play.  This game is very cool and very tense.  For me, tension is one of those high qualities in a game and this one works well, even if you're all alone! :)  I'm curious to see how it will play with others but, unlike other card games, this one does seem to work well solitaire.  My game ended with the red cubes exhausted and all I needed was one turn to get the scientist to Tokyo, do the cure with his four cards and boom, there was still a chance!  But alas, it was not meant to be! :cry:  Somehow, I think I'll be playing this one quite a bit over the weekend!Update:  I finally won! :D  However, it was on the intro. setting and I had only three cards left in the deck, the next one being the fourth epidemic! :gulp: :what:  After 14 plays, I am a dismal 3-11, :shake:  but that is part of the appeal of this game: the challenge of beating the system!

RATING: 6.5
We were very excited for Pandemic, mostly because of the theme.  I was a little disappointed at the implementation, mostly because it's a little more abstract than I would have liked.  After many plays, though, I'm not so down on it.  The abstract nature of the theme lets the game play in just the right amount of time - longer would be too long.  It also is a good gateway, and we've had friends enjoy it even when it kicks our asses (the cooperative aspect helps its gateway nature).  My sole complaint these days is how damn tough it is - I like a challenge, but this is right up there with Arkham Horror!  We rarely won, and somehow losing in Pandemic is more depressing than losing to the Old Ones.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 10
A nearly perfect game. Beautiful board and components, cleverly designed card play, and not easy to master (but not too hard either).

I love how the epidemic cards are evenly spaced throughout the deck (giving you a way to predict them roughly) and think the reshuffling and reincorporation of the already-infected cities is a brilliant touch. Plus, the cooperative element means that no one gets resentful toward the other players. Haven't worked up to six epidemics yet, but look forward to it.

The medic is a little too strong, IMHO, but otherwise a wonderful game. 

UPDATE: "On the Brink" makes it even better (and significantly harder!).
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

===========
Good co-op game that doesn't break any new ground other than it plays to completion in 45 minutes, which is quite nice...and the epidemic triggering the recycle of all the previous infection spots is sweet too.  I don't think I've seen anything like that before. The different player powers help to foster an environment where each player is able to make some decisions on their own rather than one player dominating the team and telling everyone what to do (like often happens in the co-op Lord of the Rings).  I like it, but after about 10 plays I'm ready to trade it.

RATING: 9
Very good.  The mechanisms work in an interesting way to present you with a real challenge - so much so that in our first game we were badly beaten.  But the game was still so appealing that we all wanted to play again immediately and this time we won - though not without teetering on the edge of disaster before doing so - which made victory all the sweeter.  Having the medic in play the second time seemed to make things easier, though we also worked together better. Looking forward to another go but finding it hard to envisage how you can win on anything other than the easy setting!  Further play makes the medic look essential and even easy look hard.  We seem a long way from heroic!  Further plays help, as experience helps you better exploit the benefits of co-operation - still not easy though.  

On the Brink is a nice addition - see comments there.
