[/c]
[b]TOTAL = 428.0/50 = 8.56[/b]


:thumbsup: [b]POSITIVE POINTS:[/b]

++ Great co-op gateway game that is usually really tense until the end.
++ The use of the infection deck that reuse the cities' cards in which infection has already occured to propagate diseases in a thematically and mechanicaly sound manner that still include a bit of randomness (by shuffling the discard pile and putting it back on top of the deck).
++ The game user-chosen variable difficulty depending on the number of "Epidemic" cards uses (and can range from easy to nearly impossible).
++ Good replayability because of the randomness of the setup (both for the disease cubes placement but also the "Special cards" used for the game and the varibale players' roles.
++ Variable players' power (role) assigned randomly at each game.
++ Great game insert which hold everything in an orderly fashion (base game and expansion, and you can use the OtB expansion insert to store everything in just one box).
++ The "On the Brink" expansion adds a lot of replayability and also challenge as the game difficulty can be enhanced greatly with more "Epidemic" cards, the "Virulent Strain" and the new Purple Virus.
++ There are expansions available for this game (which is useful to refresh the game when we have overplayed it).


:thumbsdown: [b]NEGATIVE POINTS:[/b]

-- A bit long to set up at the beginning of the game.
-- Being a co-op game, it is prone to the Alpha Player Syndrome (where an experienced player can dictate other players everything to do to ensure a win).


:arrowE: [b]OTHER GAME INFO:[/b]
[b]
Game Weight = 2.4-2.6/5
Release Date = 2008
Number of Player = (1)2-4
2-player length = 45-60 min.
Player Count Preference = Best at 2, recommended at 3 and 4! :thumbsup::thumbsup:
[/b]

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 10
Hey! I can finally rate this game I've been playtesting on and off for a couple years. I really like Pandemic, it's the best cooperative game I've played since Lord of the Rings. The key is in the pacing; the game successfully ratchets up the tension as infections spread and outbreaks pop up all over the place, and the players fight a race against time to conquer the various diseases. The game is just a perfect length, about 45 minutes, and the endgame tension is just right - the game doesn't end before it's over. The different roles give the players significantly different prisms through which to look at the game, which is helpful in cleanly driving table-talk and discussion without phony artificial restrictions like Shadows over Camelot had. All in all, this is finally another good cooperative game that gamers can enjoy. It's not as deep as Lord of the Rings, but it's also simpler and shorter and should be accessible to a wide variety of players.

Gamers should probably bypass the "easy" game and go straight to the standard game.

If you'd like to tweak the difficulty a little bit without going straight to Heroic level (which can be pretty tough) try starting the infection rate marker on the second or third space.

RATING: 8
I normally enjoy coop games well enough, but this one is really good stuff!  Lots of fun figuring out how each player's special actions can interact most efficiently, and a lot of good tension as the players race to control the spreading diseases.  There's tension galore, and the different combinations of special abilities that can be dealt from game to game are fun to figure out how to best utilize.  Theme also adds a lot to the fun, as it actually feels like you're travelling around and fighting the different diseases.  Woohoo!

RATING: 7
my final evaluation is based on playing the game without On the Brink Expansion.  I enjoy Pandemic more as a solo game probably more than as a coop game where I feel the weight of other people's influence on my decision making.  Controlling four or 5 roles isn't that difficult and the game becomes a thematic puzzle as you struggle to control epidemics and cure them. Without On the Brink the game is still good, but with the added roles, events, virulent strain, and mutation, everything is intensified and the theme really expands.  And I love that the theme is particularly relevant these days.

RATING: 8.5
A very good multiplayer co-op game probably second to only Betrayal IMO. I haven't played it with a ton of different people but the "one person takes over and tells everyone what to do" doesn't seem to happen very often.  I can see it happening if played with a group of non-gamers cuz they just trust you know best but amoungst gamers it seems to work well. The role cards play a key part in this IMO. It promotes everyone giving their input and asking the group if they agree its in the best interest of the group to do X. The mechanics of the game as well really give you the flavor of epidemic outbreak.  If an outbreak happened in a particular city. Its going to continue again and again. Haven't played it solo as of yet but with the different levels of difficulty.  I could easily see it being very fun.

Not a bad game by any stretch, just not something I feel the need to play regularly.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 5
This game suffers from a common issue that plagues many coop games - its only fun when you are on the edge of loosing. Any moves you propose are discussed/approved by the entire group, which makes all of the moves near perfect, but also make the game very dull. You not really in a control of your own character - the group is in control of all characters at once. After a while it becomes a situation when you can safely go out for a drink/smoke/pizza, and the group will keep managing your character to the best of its ability without any real need for your participation. And yeah you can play this game completely solo.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: N/A
If you win, less people die. What a cruel and bizarre theme for a "game". That it is one of the most popular titles and available everywhere is a sad testimony to the state of modern society; how will people feel about owning this when the next massively fatal and contagious disease hits?

I have nothing against science or reality based games - for a title which is far less morbid there is Stop the Germs (PNP): https://www.boardgamegeek.com/boardgame/142902/stop-germs and
Virus! https://boardgamegeek.com/boardgame/180020/virus

There is also Healing Blade:

https://www.boardgamegeek.com/boardgame/179322/healing-blade-defenders-soma

Pandemic is a perfect example of what unfettered capitalism and mob mentality inflicts on all of us - there are many ways to make a game about the same subject matter (I live not much more than walking distance from the CDC and count many epidemiologists there as close friends) morally and in a way that respects life - in the case of Pandemic, simply changing fatalities to number of infections would be a start. Infectious diseases do not exist outside the context of global politics and society and Pandemic's crass and banal approach to the inequalities of our world is simply repugnant. 

It's also a poor game as pointed out by many other reviewers. Barnes and Noble, how I loathe thee for popularizing such thoughtless "games".
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

RATING: 6

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 10
Conceptually I love how I'm playing the role of someone trying to save the world from disease. It's massively heroic.

Gameplaywise, I really enjoy how my role alters my perception of what the best course of action is. Somehow the best plans, as far as I can tell, make use of my special abilities. If I'm not the only player at the table who sees things this way, the result is a variety of plans to choose from.

Between that and the players occupying different spaces on the board, the game manages to create a team game composed of individuals, as opposed to a solitaire game played by a group.

Game designwise I love how the Epidemics cause the used cards to go back on top of the pile. It's a simple mechanic that both showcases how epidemics tend to rise and fall in the same places over and over again in the real world, while also giving information to the players so that they can plan ahead.

The art is very realistic (I own the original Z-Man edition, not the recent Filosofia remake with Montréal instead of Toronto). It passes on the feel of the world I live in to me. Women,  men, people of colour, whites, all in the same workplace.

For me, this game is the gold standard. Great game, great theme, great presentation, heck, even the rules are well-written. It is my most played game and if I could I would rate this game an eleven.

Note, the latest version is the same game, but it is a huge step back for playability. The darker busier board with white lettering makes finding cities harder. The plastic cubes are smaller and harder to count on a full board, as well as being cheaply made so stack poorly. 

To top it off, the art is dull and uninspiring and looks more appropriate to fighting future crime than disease.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 5
Chaos management, look-ahead co-op. Pandemic stresses me the hell out, and like many co-op games, it can get bogged-down in bossy-pants, lets-argue-for-fifteen-minutes-about what-is-the-best-plan-of-action-for-Kabul (or whatever) syndrome. Do I game with assholes or am I the asshole? (Note to self: analyze the possibility of my own assholeishness later, and less publicly).

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: N/A
Thank you Secret Santa, 2011!
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8
The first co-op I truly, truly loved. The base game is a little easy unless you're playing on Hero (where luck is obviously the determining factor), but goddamn if this isn't a well-designed game.

First off, SAVING THE WORLD FROM DISEASE! is a fun theme that feels appropriately epic and heroic. Watching the board get overrun by disease and losing feels uniquely disappointing (I mean this as a positive).

Pandemic perfects the "randomized puzzle" style of co-ops for me. Sometimes I just want to try and solve a puzzle with my friends. Trying to figure out the best way to optimize your turns as a team is fun. There's heaps of tension, and the way Epidemics (specifically the Intensify step) works is just downright genius - allowing you to see how the game mitigates some luck and makes things even more scary in the process is just fantastic.

Some people hate on co-ops because they play with jerks who like to dictate everyone's turns for them. Pandemic is a game that certainly would allow you to do that, so if you play with jerks stay away. BUT even if you don't play with jerks... it is true that it is very, very difficult for someone new to the game/genre to play with an otherwise super experienced group. Even if your group allows everyone to vocalize their opinions, etc., it's hard for a newbie to contribute anything meaningful in a group of seasoned players and that can ruin the experience for them. For that reason, it's really best played with people of equal skill level.

Update: Upgraded this + OtB both for aesthetic purposes (I think we can all agree these blow the original out of the water under THAT criteria) but mostly to be compatible with In the Lab. Worth it!

Update: Years later, this is still my favorite co-op. Ghost Stories is pretty equally fun to base game Pandemic, but I have to give Pandemic the edge just on the basis of expansions - so far they've managed to release universally excellent expansions that only improve the base game.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8
This is a great example of a Euro-style co-operative game and still one of the best in existence, despite a subsequent plethora of lesser imitators (eg. Flash Point: Fire Rescue).  Combining action point allowance, variable player powers, set collection, and hand management with a tight, thematically-cohesive game "AI", Pandemic is nevertheless easy to teach to new gamers, thanks to the streamlined rules presentation in the rulebook.  The eye-catching graphic design and production (by Canadian talent, Josh Cappel) also add tremendously to the enjoyment of the game.  While some have expressed concern that experienced players can easily take over a group and direct the actions of other players, this criticism could apply to any co-operative game; if this occurs, it is an indication of problematic group dynamics rather than a failing of the game itself.  In summary, a highly-recommended game and one of the first that should be taught to any Euro gamer new to co-operative games.

Yeah luck is more contained and this should be a big advantage in my book, but here, it just makes the game a bit too easy. It is nice to play but it doesn't really challenge us.

[u]December 2010:[/u] Changed my rating system, the game is now rated 6.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 6.5
Pandemic is a cooperative board game where players take on the roles of various CDC workers attempting to stop four simultaneous disease oubreaks across the world.  It's a race against time to find cures for all four diseases.

Gameplay is a straight-forward set-collecting game with a few twists.  To find a cure to a disease players must collect (and discard) 5 cards of the same colour as the disease.  Players can trade cards with each other under limited circumstances, and have to abide by a seven-card limit.

Each player's role gives them unique abilities that need to be coordinated to ensure victory.

The base game is pretty good, but it's vastly improved with the On the Brink expansion.

RATING: 1
Played the boardgame once, was told what to do by the game owner. Typical boring alpha player co-op, and very dry, lacking theme, mechanics have no relation to theme or reality. "I'll give you this research data on Lagos but only if we both travel to Lagos first and are there at the same time." What? Is this game set in 1930?

Bought the app to give it a second chance, which allowed me to control four characters and play solitaire, quickly. Became obvious game is random garbage. First game, I lost on the second turn. Second game, I lost on the first turn, before two of my characters even got their first turn. Never seen a design so flawed before. A game where a player can lose before they even get to go?

The kind of game that makes you remember that other people's criteria for a good game can be quite different from your own. 

Would never play the physical game again.

RATING: 7
Awesome game for those who enjoy coop games. The rules are fairly simple, the difficulty is easily scalable, and the components and game board are attractive and elegant. Made much better through expansion. Like other coop games, "quarterbacking" is a key issue that I notice during Pandemic; one more strategic or experienced player directs everyone, and the creativity of all is stifled. I have inadvertently been that person before, and realized how crappy it is for all.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7
[b] Logged plays split between base game and On the Brink expansion[/b]

Rated "8" after one solo play. Curious to see how this rating changes when playing with others. I lost first time through... this is harder than I expected! And, I found myself getting a little angry--in a good way. There's a pressure that develops to "beat the clock." As a true collaborative or solo game, it's more about puzzle solving than playing other players, but at the same time it's a pretty darn intriguing puzzle.

I like the challenge. But, if I keep losing and never win, I'll get angry--in a bad way!

Update: Yay! I finally beat it as a solo game. I can safely like this game now. The strategies are becoming more apparent. I'll be curious to see how many plays this game offers before it becomes a bit repetitive. That's certainly not the case yet.

Update after 25 plays: every play has been solo so far, and I still enjoy this. At some point, I might pick up the expansion to breathe more life into this, but this is much more mileage out of the game than I expected. If only every game held up for 25 plays!

Update: My 50th play, and it was the first time playing with other people. That's a bit tricky, as a pure cooperative game is hard to play if there is great disparity in people's familiarity with the game. I still had a good time, but 49 solo plays means that I have to restrain from bossing others around. Still, Pandemic is easily the only game I've enjoyed playing solo, and for that reason alone, I'm happy to own it.

Update: traded it away along with the expansion for Thebes. After 50 plays, I called it quits. This for me was a great solo game, but I never wanted to play it with a group because of the risk of the "bossing others" factor. It's still a solid game, and I certainly don't regret the purchase! If only every gamed yielded 50 quality plays. But now, I think it's time to "pay it forward."

RATING: 7.5
12+ games 3 player
8 games 4 player
12+ games 2 player

A very good game, flawed by the poor component quality indicative of Z-Man's Chinese imports.  Mis-sized cards are hard to shuffle, cubes come in a variety of sizes and shapes and boards warp and buckle.

I could care less about problems with the insert, but if riff shuffling in a card based game is difficult - you notice. I love the gameplay, but hate the components, enough so that I've avoided subsequent Z-Man releases.

The game scales well and can be played solo but can suffer from one overinvolved individual dictating the play. A must for your collection.

If you are looking for a way to reinvigorate the challenge I would recommend picking up one of the many expansions.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7
:sugar: :) :D :D :D The only co-op or semi-co-op game I've ever really enjoyed, unless you want to torture the definition of semi-co-op almost beyond recognition in order to include Republic of Rome, and quite possibly the greatest gateway game ever invented.  Pandemic is extremely lean in terms of rules and smartly designed to deliver a tough but not unfair challenge, plays quickly, and is almost as much fun as a rehash as it is play experience. More than any other type of game I know (with the possible exception of party games), co-ops require the right crowd to be fun, so one hallmark of a good co-op is that it's highly adaptable. Pandemic has this in spades -- it's easy enough to learn that you can teach it to people who aren't gamers by nature but are people you enjoy spending time with (my wife and parents were enchanted by it when I brought it home last Christmas), and it's hard enough to win that gamers won't scoff at it as child's play. I totally get skepticism as a default approach to co-ops, but this is one that should get a respectful look.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

RATING: 7
A co-op game that is easy to learn for non-gamers too, but which can easily be dominated by one player. This also means this game is very suitable for solo play, though.

The starting order of the cards (of both decks, though mainly the Infection deck) can make it impossible to win. With a bit of bad luck, this can even happen with Easy games, several times in a row. There are quite a few instances where there is no way the players could have prevented disaster.

UPDATE March 24th, 2014: score lowered from 7.4 to 7.
This game has definitely lost a lot of appeal to me, because of the afore-mentioned flaw of making it impossible to win. Not even the update solves this.

RATING: 9.75
This was another game that we played in hospital (so it felt really thematic!) that helped kill a lot of time when we had to wait for doctors etc - the board is quite small so it was workable on the hospital food tables that they give you to eat your food.

This was an introduction to co-op gaming for my boyfriend and I and we love it. We have played this over and over in a single evening. 

This game is perfect for us because we are pretty much even when it comes to strategy etc so neither of us dominates the game. I think it would be much less enjoyable with someone who isn't great with regards to strategy etc but i guess it'd present another challenge!

Previously I rated this game an 8, but I have now given it a higher rating because of how much we like to play it. Many games you have to be in the right mood for, but pandemic fits most situations (if you have the right number of players). Everyone wants to play this when they come over and they talk about what a great game it is, and somehow we're not sick of playing it.

This game is great, though we did find that after a while we rarely lost - until we added the expansion. This is an awesome game.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7
This may displace Lord of the Rings as the best cooperative game (of course, in my opinion) and I still really like LOTR.

The theme here works extremely well. The rules are tight and not complicated. The graphical representations are very intuitive. I really felt like we were fighting epidemics. Nicely done!

You'd think that being able to tell people pretty much exactly what you have in your hand would distill the game down to a puzzle that any lone person could solve. The danger with a coop game is always that one dominant personality (or person with more experience) is going to start dictating to others what to do...and then, why are the others playing?  I thought that might be an issue here, but it was not. There was enough dynamic stuff going on that each player could contribute to the overall plan.

But what really makes Pandemic shine is the variable player powers. Firstly, you KNOW one of the powers is not going to be in the game. Secondly, there are natural activities each person can do better than the others. Finding a way to work as a team was a very enjoyable challenge. It also gives a sense of ownership to the actions, even if someone else suggested the move...it was ONLY your character who could do it.

Finally, the whole package fits easily under an hour. And its not easy to win. I'd like to add this one to my collection....and I think it will appeal broadly to casual gamers.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8
A great example of a game that doesn't wear out its welcome. You will win or lose this one in 45 minutes or less, and often want to play again immediately. I love the reshuffle mechanic and the outbreak mechanic. I have some component issues here(HUGE pawns), but overall I think this is a winner for the co-op fans out there.

RATING: 8
Game play-wise, this is clearly one of the best games ever made. I've never played a game that will make you want to stand up and cheer quite the way "Pandemic" will on occasion. Still, I don't quite love it. Maybe it's because it can almost make you want to smash the table sometimes, like when an unlucky starting draw results in your losing via chained outbreaks by turn four. Maybe it's the relentless difficulty or the fact that it's just too pressure-filled to feel like a relaxing good time. And let's not forget "Alpha Gamer Syndrome," where one pushy player can start bossing everyone else about. Still, I love that the game encourages players to talk and strategize. It really is a great game. I just wish I loved it more.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7
Pandemic is the newest in the recent fad of cooperative games, and seems to be one of the more promising entries for fans of straight Euro games.

Pandemic presents a deceptively simple concept: the board is seeded with disease cubes, and after each player's turn, more cards are drawn which create or amplify the disease issues. When an area would have more than 3 cubes placed into it, an outbreak occurs, spreading disease to the surrounding areas and generally causing chaos. The game is based on cooperation, and each player has a special ability that can allow them to combat the diseases in a slightly more efficient way: for instance, the medic allows a player to completely clear a city of disease for 1 action rather tha the 1 cube rate of the other characters.

Over the course of the game, players are also collecting city cards in the 4 coloured suits of the game. When someone has 5 of a colour, they can cash them in at a research station to cure the disease, and then it's just a matter of stamping it out on the board. If that is done successfully, then any cards representing that disease are ignored.

The thing that makes this game insidious is the epidemic mechanic. When an epidemic card is drawn from the "good deck" (which each player receives 2 cards out of each round) then all hell breaks loose on the board: a card is drawn from the bottom of the deck, and that place becomes triple diseased, and then the discard deck and that card are reshuffled and placed ON TOP of the negative deck. What this means is that the same cities keep reappearing, and when you combine that with the negative impact of having more than 3 cubes in a given city, the game can get ugly quickly.

So in terms of concept, this is an interesting game, certainly one of the best coops that I've played. The game is essentially one long puzzle game where each player has 4 action points to spend, and in-depth strategy discussions tend to break out as regularly as the diseases. The game is challenging enough to be interesting as well, which is a key for long-term interest.

The downsides, however, primarily do relate to the difficulty of the game. Though difficulty is partially dictated by the number of epidemic cards that are seeded into the positive deck, the game's difficulty also hinges heavily on how the negative deck ends up stacked. If one area's cards are all clustered at the top of the deck, a single early epidemic card can absolutely ream the players before they can even get going. Conversely, a very dispersed card distribution in the negative deck, or a run of the same colour early in the positive deck can make the game fairly relaxed, as a run of the same colour from the positive deck will result in an easy early cure or two, and dispersed diseases, when they occur, rarely will lead to outbreak chains. This isn't to say that the game is easy to win even given these circumstances, because the end can sneak up on you, but the ideal game experience seems to be somewhere in-between, and I'm not sure if there's a way to artificially manufacture that while still keeping the uncertainty that makes this game interesting.

I think my final feelings on this are pretty positive though. It's a short game with some interesting decisions, and some funny moments. If I'm in the mood for a game in this style (hourish co-op), it would probably be my first pick pretty easily but it's not exactly sitting in a crowded niche, and in a longer time frame I would prefer Knizia's LotR or (with 2) Arkham. 

As of 2016 I'd have to say this is great as a couple's co-op title, but that the Legacy version makes it a pale a bit by comparison.

As an aside: nice component quality: big cubes, thick, weighty cards, a sturdy but not overly glossy board. Kudos to Z Man for the job that was done on this one.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

This game is politically correct.

RATING: 9

My only gripe with it is that victory can feel a bit cheap when you get all four cures but the diseases themselves are still rampant. It's a "win" but it just doesn't feel right to me.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 6
One of a couple games that Katie and I have wildly varied opinions on.  This was one of our first cooperative games and I enjoyed it quite a bit at first.  As time has gone on though, I now find it rather dull.  It seems, from the games we have played, that there must be an extensive amount of discussion and debate on who should do what in order to be successful in this game, and that causes the game to drag on much longer than it ought to.  I have found that I would rather rush through this game and lose than draw it out for a long while and win.  I'm also not a big fan of the board and components.  Ironically, I quite enjoyed the variants introduced with Pandemic's expansion pack, but Katie and others have not.  In the end, when it comes to fighting cooperatively against wooden cubes, I much prefer Flash Point over Pandemic.

Great game so far. It sucks you in to thinking it will take it easy on you then bam. Epidemics and outbreak chains go out of control. 
I love the balance of this game. Balance of defence (treating victims) and attack (researching cures) is critical.

geberus helped me get this by holding a copy for Kami at Source Comics and Games in Minneapolis when it was off the shelves faster than orders could be made almost. Thanks.

After watching games with Hayden, I decided to teach my 6 and 7 year olds this game. My daughter loves it.


Second copy picked up from Dean for Mitchell

Victories against legendary in all combinations of 2 characters of the original game. Eradication or lucky card draws is almost necessary to make it happen.

I managed to win a game with 6 Epidemics with no outbreaks and all diseases eradicated with my daughter as the Medic and me as the Dispatcher. Awesome win.

BSW makes Pandemic tedious.

RATING: 6
One of my new favorite coop games. It is the spiritual evolution to Shadows Over Camelot. Same basic concept, the players do some good actions (treat some cities), then do a bad one (infect some other cities). I think my favorite part is being able to adjust the difficulty of the game. Shadows has the advantage of having a traitor though, Pandemic is fully co-op.

RATING: 9
July 28, 2008 -- I was introduced to this last week, and in one session I played four games of it. I was pleasantly surprised to find the game is fun, requires a fair bit of thought and is not easy for the players to win. Its quick play time makes it a clear winner. I must buy this. 9/10

January 15, 2010 -- After eight plays, I finally experienced a win. It was close. We were down to our last turn of drawing cards into our hands, so the time limit was just about to kill us. It was a three-player game, and we had done quite well keeping outbreaks from happening with any great frequency. We'd just barely pushed the Infection Rate to 4. With the medic, researcher and scientist, we barely beat the clock.

I find Pandemic continues to be tense and interesting. Now that my girlfriend has experienced its fun and is asking to play it, I expect it to hit the table a lot more often.

No change in rating. 9/10

RATING: 2.75

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7
Pandemic was the first co-operative game after the venerable Lord of the Rings by Reiner Knizia, and when I first played there was some unexplicable 'click' between me and the design. It took me a few years and horrendous encounters with other co-ops to realise what the reason for this strange alchemy was: the fact that all actions you do as player [i]succeed[/i], with utmost certainty. The game obviously throws quite a lot of random shit at you... but players are always sure about what they are doing. This has since become an absolute necessity for me to like a co-op, and so Pandemic has stayed with me throughout the years.

That said, it took me a while to learn how to play to win, and when I finally did something of the magic vanished. Making the game harder would be tantamout to 'merely' optimising the various semi-strategical paths built into the combination of various roles. While not easy, it amounts to working out the solution to a puzzle rather than creatively gaming oneself out of a tight spot. For this reason I've decided to lower the rate I've given it all those years ago. Perhaps that with the expansions (especially the Bioterrorist one which endows the spread of diseases with actual intelligence, we hope...) the actual game can be redeemed. 
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7
nice and quick, but too shallow
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 5
Probably the best non-Arkham cooperative game, but still not great.  Gameplay is a bit rote (where's the nearest spot the dispatcher can teleport us to where we can exchange cards?), and it doesn't have the thickness of theme or drama inherent to skill checks that Arkham does that makes it all worthwhile.

RATING: 7
Fun cooperative game with interesting plague mechanic. Pieces are simple (bowling pin pawns and infection cubes), but made out of wood and nicely painted. You can play at several difficulty levels, but any above Introductory are brutally difficult. This becomes frustrating when you hit 2 "Epidemics" in the first two rounds of the game, causing several Outbreaks.

Also be sure to watch out for the Alpha Gamer, who may just tell other players what to do. For this, playing with your hand concealed may be necessary. Most groups can get along well enough so that eveeryone can contribute to the strategy of curing diseases.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

RATING: 9
Such an excellent game! I think this game is much more fun to play when there is less groupthink and everyone plays independently and just confirms their plans with the group.  This game is a particular treat in that it plays well with just 2 players and plays quickly.  The On The Brink expansion is a must for repeated plays, if only for the additional Role cards.

RATING: 10
Pandemic is a great game that continues to hit the table. It is a favorite of my nephews and really encourages team work. I have played Pandemic with non gamer friends with much success. The rules flow well and everything fits the theme quite well. It isn't super heavy but it is a joy to play and interact with fellow players. I was actually shocked at how tense it can get at times. I have had several gamers comment on being nervous and it stressing them out; I say that is awesome since the theme is saving the world from disease. I don't think that should be taken lightly. :)

EDIT: (ADD) I believe ZMAN lists the age as 8+ now instead of 13. I would say that a 8 year old with a good attention span should be very capable of playing Pandemic. My 10 year old nephew loves this game and is quite strategic when playing.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 5
It’s a good cooperative game. It has some good game play
	• everyone is involved 
	• replayability is good
	• there are many ways to win
	• its challenging
The downside is that it starts slow. Especially if you are having to stop and read the rules over and over. Controlling the diseases at first seems too simple and arbitrary. Some people, like Walker, have lots of good ideas how to attack the disease. If a player isn't getting the hang of it they can feel like they are just being told what to do and may lose interest. 

Just when you decide you don't like the game, there are several outbreaks and suddenly you lose -leaving you with the desire to play again. It turns out that its hard to beat the game even in its easiest configuration. 

I figure that if we play the game routinely enough we'll keep the rules fresh in our minds and will enjoy the game more. 

Oddly, the goal is to avoid outbreaks but the outbreaks add excitement to the game. When I play I secretly hope for outbreaks. 

The overall experience is that I don't actually look forward to playing it but I enjoy it when I do.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 9
Pandemic is one of the greatest designed games I have ever played.  Co ops are hit or miss with me but Matt Leacock really knows how to dial them up.  The so called AI of the game (which is really just drawing form a deck of cards) works SOOOOO brilliant.  It's one of the most fair AI's I've seen in co op gaming.  The epidemics being shuffled evenly into the deck makes the game even more balanced.  You know when your about to draw one because you haven't drawn one in a while or maybe you drawn two in a row and you know you have a break.  The variability which is created from the epidemic deck/roles you play with is amazing.  Every game is different.  There are so many different strategies you can go with.  Do you do rush to find a cure?  Go heavy on building research stations?  Early trading?  I can go on but man is this game amazing.  
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 10
Challenging, addictive, and my girlfriend will even play it.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

I'll be interested to see if Defenders of the Realm will manage to not be sold. I hear it is similar.

Make it too hard and we can just sit around a table knowing how to min/max the game enough to eek out a win every now and then while we talk all of the chance out of a game. Way to ruin everything.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8

It's still fun even if you lose because it was probably stressful and exciting all the way through.  The game can be tense and exciting, which are strong attributes of any game.  Pandemic is a keeper and is one that can be used to easily gateway non-gamers into the hobby.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7
An extremely clever but curiously soulless cooperative game. The mechanic through which infected cities get recycled back on top of the deck is simple but outstanding; it creates a compelling narrative arc and ratchets up the tension pleasantly in tune with the course of the game. The differing roles help differentiate  options and the constant board changes between turns ensure constant tactical reappraisals and adjustments. And at short and breezy, the length is right too.

On the other hand, mechanically the game is also very much a dry mathematical optimization exercise, with little thematic heft or draw. Nothing within is evocative of any research enterprise, medical field work, or disease epidemic, which robs some appeal from the design. Still, it really is one of the best cooperative games out there, if you play at a reasonable pace and can get past the fact, like all such games, opportunities for true individual decisions are rare.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: N/A
Card Haus $27

RATING: N/A

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 9
Awesome cooperative game. The rules are straightforward so it's easy to learn and to explain to new players. But the tension and also the challenge increases as the game progresses which makes it great fun to play.

The role cards have different special abilities which provides more variability and so you need to work together as a team to make the most of everyone's special abilities.  

This game is highly re-playable and allows for you to increase your difficulty by adding additional Epidemic cards (4 - Beginners, 5 - Normal, 6 - Hard).

I love this game, it's sooo addictive and GREAT value for money.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 4
Components: A disturbing theme, with unsettling art. The cubes are nice, but the board is a bit strange, and the cards are substandard.

Experience: The game's engine is up to the task of keeping players on their toes. It's fun to coordinate our efforts, and decide how to most effectively employ our limited resources. But each game feels very similar, and doesn't tell a story.

First Played: 2008-11-13
Last Played: 2012-01-10
Eagerness to Play Again: Never

Plays (8):
2 players: 3
3 players: 3
4 players: 2

RATING: 10

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7
First time playing the co-op mechanic.  I found this game's theme to be compelling although the game overall did not blow me away.  The common complaint about the "Dominating Leader" is very appropriate, I feel, as I was just learning the rules for the first time, yet had an experienced player on my team.  Of course, the experienced player eventually took over, telling the other two newbies (including myself) where to go, etc. This robbed me of a very important aspect of a game - the learning process.  Ideally, games should have enough depth that the ideal strategies are not immediately apparent - they should be discovered only after many, many plays.  This gives the player "Eureka!" moments that are extremely satisfying and build a love for that particular game.  Unfortunately, what I'd heard from veteran players is that the ideal strategy to the game is not too hard to figure out, so replayability is limited for me if I ever play with experienced players.  However, I do respect the game because the premise of co-op has layed the groundwork for future game designs, and it has a very original theme in and of itself.  
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8
Pandemic
I like the outbreak mechanism.

Pandemic: On the Brink

I generally don't like expansions, but ... This expansion is my favourite game expansion ever and is almost a must to really really enjoy this game. Bought only three days after I bought Pandemic. Highly recommended expansion and the only one I insist buyers who I'm recommending Pandemic to *must* buy.

RATING: 7.5
Really good game. Excellent mechanics and theme, challenging, and a lot of replayability. Only down side is it can seem to be a bit random, and my group tends to win or lose because of the luck of the draw, not the quality of our decisions. We always play on the hardest difficulty now and win about a quarter of the time. When we do, it rarely feels like we played better, but were simply more fortunate. Not a downside for everyone, but for me I would have liked the decisions to count for more than they do.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7
A good co-op game, though I get the feeling after a dozen or so games there may not be a lot of incentive to continue bringing this one out. The game mechanics are easy to learn and it does a good job of building tension but suffers from a general lack of variety that would compel repeated playthroughs. There are also times where luck of the draw can seriously put you behind the 8-ball before you can gain much of a foothold, making the game an exercise in near-futility. Regardless, Pandemic largely succeeds in offering a satisfying and challenging co-op experience that is accessible to just about everyone.

RATING: 8
A fun cooperative that's more intuitive than Space Alert.  We allow ourselves to pick our roles at the beginning of the game, however, instead of leaving it to chance.

The hardcore euro-crowd will hate the randomness, but they forget that without gateway games like this, there would be no new converts to the boardgaming hobby. That doesn't mean you have to like it, but you have to compare it to similar co-op titles and not to, say, Princes of Florence.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 4
This is your standard card game that suffers from the typical card game issue:  card counting

You really have to know what has come up and what to expect in order to play this game right.  Failure to memorize will wipe you out.  In other games (Magic the Gathering) at least you can make your own deck and push %'s.  In this game its pretty much the same thing everytime.

In addition, just like solitaire, you can potentially have a 0% chance to win from the start because fo the shuffle, regardless of your own skill. That kind of sucks IMO.

So with all of that said, this is a game best suited for the 10-16 year olds.  Beyond that the futility of effort probably will annoy you, and the only viable strategy(memorization) will probably bore you.  The younger kids won't realize either of these aspects and probably have fun with it.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 9
2-5 players, 60-90 minutes, medium heavy, cooperative medical game.

Excellent cooperative game, perhaps the best one out there. A lot of fun but very challenging at times, even at the easiest level. Theme is very strong and you really feel engaged to rescue the world from the outbreaks.

RATING: 8

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 5.5
Being able to use drawn cards to either enable passing of other cards or cleanup (by travelling) or directly for finding a cure makes for an interesting tension and decisions.

The various abilities give each player a specialised role and working out how best to exploit everybody's skills is the main issue. This keeps the game exciting - I felt everybody was involved even outside their turn, since so much co-operation was truly needed.

Lost 2x. 2nd time may have been a win if we'd realised players could use action points to GET cards.

Losing by so little (and feeling that we had made genuine mistakes earlier on) meant everyone was ready to play it again soon. 

I can imagine the game losing a lot of its charm when it's been 'solved' and failure rests more upon luck than any mistakes. Until then, though, it's a 9.1. I'm curious to see how easily the other role-combinations will be solved after one has been.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8.5
My favourite co-operative game bar none. Everything about this production seems very polished. 

The game mechanic that constantly recycles already infected cities is genius and really piles on the pressure, making victories feel all the more sweet. I also own Forbidden Island, and while it's a good game, Pandemic successfully improves on everything in that game that I wasn't too keen on. 

Play time is not too long either, although I can see it would need the right team of people to stop one person making all the calls.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 5
Good, challenging game. I enjoy how the game's difficulty can be tailored to the players' desires.  It makes you feel like you've achieved something when you do manage to save the world from infectious disease.

It is a giant puzzle that the group strives to solve.  Sure, one individual could potentially "run" the group, but that won't happen as long as each person is willing to participate in the discussion and planning that takes place.

RATING: 10

This game also has worked perfectly for letting me play with friends who are overly competitive and hostile in competitive games.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 6
Great co-op game of trying to cure four diseases before they take over the world.  Players each play a role of a team and travel around the world performing various actions, all while the diseases are breaking out somewhere on the other side of the world!  Fun game with lots of tension once the outbreaks stat occuring.  Opening the box, however, smells like I opened a paint can.
I like the randomness of the epidemics and infections in this game; it prevents it from becoming too scripted.
I don't think I'll every suggest this game for my own sake, since it's not meaty enough for me.

Edit: Traded away.  While it's a good game, it's not something I'll ever suggest unless I'm trying to convert non-gamers to boardgaming.  In that case, this game shines.

RATING: 4
Solid coop game with a nice theme. The game sadly suffers a lot from the fact (at least with everybody I played with) that a more experienced (even one game vs zero) player either has to keep silent or tell everyone else what to do - this is my major gripe with this game. Because most of the time there is a clear "best" turn for whatever strategy you are following, and at the end of the day it feels like one or two people play a game and the others are just there to execute orders, since all information is open.

I do not get the feeling that there are real options as 90% of time there is a clear 'best course of action'.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 9
A fun Co-op that, despite the deterministic nature of the game, continues to entertain. It isn't the mechanics of the game that are impressive but the overall experience it creates. Trying to save humanity with your friends is fun; figuring out the optimal strategy and running all the calculations on this game will probably reveal it to be fairly uninteresting.

Still, this game is hard to beat for bringing people further into gaming. It introduces a bit more complexity than games like Ticket to Ride and Carcassonne, so it's a nice stepping stone when you're ready to move past those gateway games and start working towards getting people into heavier games.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 9
This is the game that got my wife and I into gaming. Not much needs to be said at this point since it is a very well known game that has been out for quite some time. A great co-op game that allows players to tweak the difficulty in many ways. Especially with the expansions.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7
Not bad for a co-op game. Certainly takes plenty of skill and teamwork, and has some innovative and interesting mechanics and rules. Ultimately, I'm afraid that once a handful of priciples are found, the game will turn into a nearly 100% luck-fest. It is all about priorities; chain-infections need to be stopped at all costs, next is making sure that all of a given kind of disease cube isn't exhausted. Once that is under control, focusing on curing the diseases (the only real way to win) is top priority. The only real question then, becomes if your cure deck will run out before you can cure the 4 diseases... that, in turn, largely depends on luck (although low skill will certainly kill you, as long as you keep your priorities straight, luck will dominiate the outcome).

If not for it being a rare co-op game, I'd rate it a 6.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7
Pandemic is an innovative, cooperative game about the spread of disease across our planet. Each player is given a character with a different set of abilities. Cards are flipped and disease bits, of four different types, are placed on corresponding cities on the world map. When a city reaches critical mass, there will be an outbreak that spreads to all of its neighboring cities, potentially triggering a chain of outbreaks. Players win the game by curing each of the disease types and ridding the world of disease entirely. It's a pretty interesting and exciting game, the first few times, working with your team to figure out the best order of operations as plague is breaking out everywhere. I've played a few games, and my only concerns so far are that the space that seperates "We're doing great!" from..."Holy sh*t, my eyes are bleeding and the world will implode in a mass of ebola monkies!" seems far too narrow on the gauge of effectiveness. Replay value may also become limited, when playing with the same group. For a four player game, I wish there would have been like 8 different random character roles, so the game would be different every time. With that said, it plays very quickly (particularly if you get your arse handed to you), it's innovative, and it's a fun cooperative experience. The production is great too. I will recommend it to all my friends, particularly those that like co-op games, and for me, it is a must-buy. 
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

Quick enough and challenging enough to be enjoyable even though it is a co-op and a little bit shallow.

RATING: 6.6
[March 2015 - 6.6]
My wife and I recently played Pandemic again (after awhile of not playing it) and it left me thinking I was a bit harsh with my initial review. It was a fun game, fairly quick, challenging and exciting. Then, we played it again with some friends soon after ... and my misgivings about this game began to return. That day, we played it twice in a row, and it brought me back to my initial thoughts. People take control, those with the best roles do most of the actions and the rest of the players are left pushing pieces across the board on command. At least the games are fairly fast. I think playing this game two-player every once in a while will keep my interest in it. 

[August 2014 - 6.5]
I'm surprised that Pandemic was No.1 on the Dice Tower's 2014 People's Choice. I'm wondering how many times the voters played the game. From my perspective, the game is pretty good the first few times you play it, but then it begins to lose its luster, especially if you have someone who wants to control the game. That could be said about many co-ops, but I think Pandemic is one or two mechanics away from being a more interesting game. And it would seem that there's an onslaught of new games (eg. Dead of Winter) attempting to take co-ops to the next level. It's good that this one is spreading to the general market though -- I've seen it even in Target.

RATING: 10

Some games, we get blasted in 15 minutes while others go right down to the wire and we win or lose by a thread.  Tense, fun and highly addictive.  Since it plays in 45 mins (max), people always want to keep playing until they win.  And everyone who plays with me seems to run out and buy it.  This is one of the best games I have ever played and I have played quite a lot.  Give it a shot if you have not already done so.

RATING: N/A

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7.5
[2009-11-25 Rating: n.a. -> 7.5]

Overview:
--------------
Pandemic is a cooperative game where 2 to 4 players try to save the world by curing four deadly diseases. The map of Pandemic depicts the world with various cities. After each players turn, some of these cities are infected by placing cubes in it. If the infection rate of one of the four diseases reaches a cube limit of three in one city and this city gets infected again, an outbreak will occur and the disease will spread.
On their turn, a player can take up to four actions. These actions include:
- Travelling to another city.
- Building a Research Station (these are needed to find the cure for a disease and to travel faster)
- Lowering the infection rate of a city by being in it and removing some of the infection cubes.
- Exchanging city cards with other players.
- Finding a cure by being in a city with a research station and discarding a set number of city cards in the diseases colour.
After their turn, the player draws two new city cards and infects some new cities. After this, the play continues with the next player until one of the game endings conditions is met. These are:
1. Players run out of cubes representing one disease.
2. Players have 8 outbreaks happen.
3. Players run out of cities cards to draw.
4. Players find the cures for all four diseases.
Since Pandemic is a cooperative game, all players win the game when the fourth ending condition is met. If one of the other game ending conditions is met, all players lose and the game wins.

Comments:
---------------
* The card mechanism to infect new cities is really clever and well thought out. Because of its implementation, the same cities get infected again and again. While this puts some pressure on you, this also keeps the game from being too random or too deterministic (and thereby solvable). While you don’t exactly know when an infected city will be infected again, you do know that it will happen for sure. So there is some risk management and push your luck built into the game. I like this.

* The cooperative aspect has it pros and cons. What I like is the fact that I can easily get my non gamer friends to join in for a game of Pandemic. Since all players act together, there is no competition and this is quite appealing to them. The drawback of the missing competition is that some of them are not really involved in the game since they do rely completely on the evaluation of the other participating players. An often heard comment in this regard is: "I like this game because I don’t have to think that much. You can tell me what to do". This kills the fun a little for me.

* After playing my first few games I would have rated this game 9. After more plays with some of my gaming friends my desire to play this game cooled down a little bit. I still enjoy the theme immensely, but with experienced players I discovered the puzzle aspect of the game more and more. Basically the game is won if you manage to optimize your action selection. With experience, it is often times quite easy to see the best play and the discussions about the actions to be taken are replaced by a mutual agreement. I have to see if this issue is addressed in the expansion.

* Great replayability thanks to the different role cards and the great infection mechanism.

* I love the theme and it really helps to get new players to join in for a game of Pandemic.


[2008-10-26]
Bought it at the Spiel 2008 for ~30€.

Un jeu excellent !
On peut y jouer en ligne : http://www.brettspielwelt.de/

RATING: 6
A quick and easy game to understand, and a very family-friendly game, that almost anyone in the household can participate in.

The game itself is quite entertaining, as long as you get the right combination of roles. We had a lengthy discussion about whether the roles were imbalanced, which was due to some characters being less useful than others. The doctor is amazing, as well as the scientist guy, whereas the coordinator and the quarantine guy, whom is very specialized. In the end, we reckoned that a way to get around this, if it is an issue, would be to acquire the roles, and then adjust the difficulty. In that way, you make sure that if you get a bad combination or a very good combination, that the game is adjusted for that. 

This is normally only needed if you have a group that is used to playing board games, whereas playing with the family, it might just be hilarious to loose, which is kind of the point of this game I guess.  
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

The main issue is the problem with all cooperative games: that a player or players can sometimes dominate the group's decision making. RATING: 6

You can play it in 20 minutes (and probably lose) or spend over an hour trying to debate and optimize every possible move.  Not really my favorite genre.  I like that they tried to tie it to a cool theme.  But really, there's barely enough meat on it to keep it from falling into the "abstract" category.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 6
Fast, cooperative game where four anonymous diseases (Red Dandruff, Blue Pox, Galloping Mumps and Coeliac Disease in our house) are spreading across the globe.  Players are members of a response team to contain and cure the horrible beasties.  Fairly standard cooperative game (i.e. Lord of the Rings) stuff - first do a little bit of good in the fight (move, research, treat, etc), then advance the bad side of things, possibly triggering consequences.  Tightly designed, attractively packaged (despite the enormous pieces, small board and the fact the game truly reeks of some chemical .... paint?).  Three differently levels of difficulty.  Five games in and we're pretty much done - fast, tight, but very vanilla for a cooperative game.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

RATING: 8
+ It’s a great gateway game that brings people together and everyone I introduced it to enjoys it greatly. After setting the game up, the game plays smoothly without fiddling with tons of components. Other than that, this game can be light on strategy and can suffer from bad shuffles that lead to easy wins. Certain roles can deem very powerful, such as the Quarantine Specialist or the Medic, and can help an easy win become a steamrolled victory.

RATING: 10

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 6.9
iOS
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 10
This is one of my favorite cooperative games. You are tasked with trying to find the cure for 4 different types of viruses/diseases, and you have to work with other players to stop them from spreading and find cures. Each player is given a role card, each role had a different advantage to help the team. Throughout the game you have to work as a team, otherwise you can lose control pretty quick. There are 4 ways to lose the game, and only one way to win. Communication, teamwork, and using ones role advantages strategically are the key to this game.

*My group likes to add to the fun by coming up with names for each virus. For example, black = zombies, red = bird flu, yellow = smallpox, blue = common cold.*

*For an added challenge, if we have a good group and the right roles, we try to eradicate each virus to beat the game. (this is very hard)*

I really want to play the legacy version of the game, as well as all the other versions.

Cons: Players who are not into it and don't communicate or work together. Sometimes we have players who thing this is a competition and go off on their own, which never wins a game.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8
Four deadly diseases have broken out across the globe, and the players must frantically go from city to city treating the diseases and looking for cures.  Pandemic was one of the original co-ops, and the inspiration for Defenders of the Realm and Forbidden Island among others.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

RATING: 7.5
This games overall theme is great. I like that its a cooperative game where the sole enemy is disease. It is a nice change of pace from my normal game night. The play time is also short, so that is always a bonus if you want to play another game on the same night. The game takes about ten minutes to learn and even then you might be doing some things wrong. It takes about five to six plays to really get a handle on what to do. I rank the game lower than I would normally just based on the difficulty of the game. Out of fourteen plays we have only won twice, and both times were a two man game. Now this might be because my group isn't using the right strategy. It is fun and I don't mind playing it here and there, but it is quickly falling out of favor in our group.

RATING: 5
It's good that the difficulty is selectable in this game.  They seemed to have done a good job balancing it.   The tension is excellent, but I think the game will get repetitive quickly.   It also suffers from that fact that it is more of a multiplayer puzzle than a game.  Everybody agrees what should be done, and there is very little opportunity for style or choice.  It's kind of like getting your friends together to change the head gasket on your car.  There's some similarity to Shadows Over Camelot if you look under the hood - move around and collect sets of cards.   That's it.  The movement is a little more important here than Shadows. Still, it's nice to have a fresh co-op style game, but I don't think this game will have any staying power after you have a few wins under your belt.  I suppose expansions will address that needed variability.   Co-ops aren't my cup of tea, so my rating here is on the low side.

RATING: 6
I've had to write this a couple times now, but it's important to understand my view on pure co-operative games: I can't find a way to approach them functionally, as I have trouble with the line between involved player and Alpha gamer. I resolve to simply focus on my own play, leaving me quite disengaged for everyone's rounds.

Pandemic does nothing to alleviate this for me - it's essentially a puzzle that the four of you are attempting to solve. The mechanics are sound, and the board looks nice and all that jazz. 

Biggest problem of all: Pandemic Legacy. Now that I've played Season 1, and am partway through Season 2, I don't think I'll ever be able to play a standard game of Pandemic again.

RATING: 7

I dont like to offer up suggestions for what another player should do because it can be hard to do so without sounding like your not really giving the person their own choices. The game encourages you to interact and plan together though, which is why i prefer to play with just 2, or even on my own! Just my personal awkward hang-ups i guess. I always want people to make their own decisions in games and not just follow instructions. Still a great game even if it is very much luck-dependent on harder difficulties. A good gateway game.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 6
Generally, I’m not a fan of cooperative games.  They strike me as less of a game and more of just an ‘activity’ to engage in with friends/co-players.  Its a case of, ‘let’s all get together to play a game of solitaire’ and Pandemic is no different.  I guess what makes Pandemic better than most cooperatives is that: it is, what it is, in its purist form with rules and mechanics that are fast, clean, straight-forward, intuitive and very streamlined.  
With an average game length of about one hour, I feel that’s about the right amount of time for a this game (as long as it doesn’t go over 60 minutes).  The game is essentially a puzzle, but even to the most experienced player, whether you win or lose is randomly pre-determined based on how the cards are, literally, stacked-against-you or for-you before the game begins.  
There are several options every round, but really there is always ONE option that is undeniably best and inevitably it’s the most experienced player that sees it (I’m sure even if he actively choose to hold back, it would be frustrating from his perspective and truthfully not really beneficial to winning the game in the end).  And thus, like most cooperative games, I don’t really feel I have any personal vested interest in the game and just want to sit back and let the alpha-player do his magic.  Thus the nature of cooperatives makes us ask, ‘do we fundamentally play games to win, or is it the game-play that is solely fun.’  If we play to win, then let the alpha-player take the lead.  If we play to enjoy the brain-burning aspect of figuring out a puzzle to best of our abilities, then best to play as a solitaire game (I’m sure it would be a frustrating time for the alpha-player to sit back and let players engage in less-efficient options).  
Perhaps this game really works best as a solitaire game (a field that I have zero interest in).  
Among cooperative games, I currently like 2010’s “Forbidden Island” best.  That game’s 30 minutes game time hits a perfect sweet-spot for these types of games/activities and the theme there is a bit more flavourful and imaginative to hold one’s attention.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

RATING: 6

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 6.5
Pandemic was one of the earlier members of the co-op trend, and by now has become a little stale.  There's not much I find wrong with it, but it's almost as much puzzle as game.  That leads to people feeling like it can be solved, which leads to playing the turns collectively and analysis paralysis.  I'm at least as much guilty of this as anyone else, but that's how I usually want to play it.  The main thing keeping it back is how much it's been played up to now.
My sole serious dislike is the scaling. With 3, it's harder to cover the globe and more difficult to exchange cards if everyone's widely separated.  But that's preferable to 5, where your coverage really isn't any better, since it takes longer to get back to anyone's turn.  It doesn't do much good to have the medic over in Asia where the black cubes are piling up if 2 more people have to go before him and the cities will outbreak before then.  Worse, the deck is diluted and it's less likely people are going to get sets, so you have to burn more time trading.  The number of turns each player gets is less, since the deck is a timer.  Most of the games I've lost with 5 have been on time, so I feel like it's just a little unbalanced there.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

RATING: 9
A well-designed game with tension at every level: Can we avoid outbreaks this turn? How much risk should we assume before the next epidemic card surprises us? Can we cure all the diseases before the endgame? Being able to customize the level of difficulty allows you keep the outcome close to 50%. As with any fully cooperative game, it's possible for an alpha player to diminish the experience for others.

I compare all other cooperative games to this one. It's my favorite in the genre.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8
My first expeience with a co-op game apart from Lord of the Rings, and I really enjoyed it. Rating is based on a single play and first impression. The game utilizes some very innovative mechanics, not the least of which is when the diseases "intensify" by reshuffling the discard deck and placing them back on top of the draw pile. This is an excellent and clever mechanic that had us scratching our heads at first, until the lightbulb of understanding shone upon us...

UPDATE: I've now played this lots of times, and my rating stands.  It is tense and enjoyable, even if fairly random. The intial placement of 3-cube diseases relative to the players' starting position in Atlanta can have a huge impact, as can the randomly selected player roles, when the first Epedemic card turns up, and when the special cards turn up (if they are near the bottom of the deck, they're not going to be of much help). Despite the random aspects, I still really enjoy it. I think it's one of the most innovative games in years.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 5
Coop game where generally one person who knows what they are doing plays the game all by themselves.  Dull.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8
A must play for people wanting the next step past gateway games (Catan, Munchkin, etc.). It's a challenging co-op game that forces players to combine their unique player ability with smart action-selection to overcome the (sometimes) overwhelming odds. In our first 3 plays, my roommate and I were crushed. We got close, but couldn't quite keep the diseases under control. Then on the 4th try we easily crushed the game. The Epidemic cards were well-spaced in the deck. We got lucky.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

RATING: 9
A great cooperative game, all the players gonna be talking and making a strategy to save the world, is hard to take a roll alone. 

Is a game that has a stressful goal, where if players make perfect in moves, then they can still lose the game. The rules are simple, the enjoyment and thinking is to the top all the time. Is a better game if you play music according to the game situation (just look for one on Spotify).

In the game, every player controls a character that is a specialist and has a unique ability. Your goal is to create a cure for 4 diseases, that are spreading in the whole world. Every turn the disease's growth, and can make a lot of disasters. Your team has to make quick decisions to don't let the diseases go out of control (outbreak), growth more than can be cured or be late. All of those 3 points are the way your team can lose.

RATING: 7.6
Pandemic is a perfect cooperative puzzle game with a catchy theme. Players are health agents fighting to contain epidemics of deadly diseases around the world. The game is brutal and offers very little chance to win or survive and tolerates no mistakes.
Only drawback is that it can usually happen that one player who is louder and more experienced takes command and dictates what others should do. Also base game offers not that amazing replay value, but either way game is a blast.

[b]Update:[/b] Ranked dropped to 7.5 from 8.5 due to not so great replay value.
[b]Update:[/b] Rating modified according to a custom rating system.

[b]Favorite mechanism:[/b] Epidemic. Adding new city from the bottom of the deck to the group of already diseased cities, and then shuffling them and starting from the beginning, drastically raising chances for outbreaks.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 10
Pandemic is simply the greatest board game ever. There isn't one thing that this game doesn't do perfectly. The only thing I could possibly say that this game does "wrong" is that its coop, so if you actually enjoy screwing your friends over, then this game doesn't really allow you to do that. I like the concept of the game, and I'm a scientist myself, so its good to see a game depart from the fantasy/sci fi genre and excel. I love that there is no "bad guy" in the game. I have play lots of other coop games, but I always end up having to be the GM or DM or BAD GUYS or whatever. In this game each person takes their turn, then takes a turn for the viruses. This actually works out great, and makes the game even harder for more players, which is how a game should be. The game is very customizable, allowing for easy rule changes, and differing levels of difficulty that should give you a very pleasing game experience. Where I don't LIKE losing a game, sometimes its actually nice to know that you can indeed, lose even in a coop setting. Really easy to learn for non-gamers as well. I also bought the expansion, and although I like some of it, the game really didnt NEED an expansion in my opinion. Although, Bioterrorist game is quite interesting.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 3.5
This game aggravates social dynamics.  

The person who finds the optimal play first always ends up telling the group what that best play is.  The group then feels obligated to go along with it, and it ends up being one person playing the game and pulling everyone else along.  It doesn't matter if the alpha gamer can be gentle and diplomatic about it, rather than domineering and controlling.  They're still the only one playing the game while the rest of the players are just along for the ride.

The danger of this is that if there are pre-existing social dynamics where one player is more strong-willed and another player is more timid, then the gameplay encourages that to be brought out.  I'm a facilitator of games, and I'm concerned with making people feel included in co-operative decisions.  This game makes it harder.

So...if one player dominating a game experience sounds like a good social dynamic to you, or if your playgroup doesn't have any dominant personalities or quick appraisers, then by all means, pick this up.  I'll pass.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 9
This is a hit with my girlfriend because of the cooperative play. We are often playing 2 player games; she can be a sore loser if I beat her badly or frequently. Consequently, she'll only play strategy games with me to keep me happy, but I can tell she would rather not.

This game on the other hand she's happy to play. She doesn't mind losing if we're doing it together. We spent a whole night playing this game with thriller/suspense Quarantine type movies playing in the background. She was suggesting we play another game for once, instead of me. 

Your success/demise is sometimes inevitable based on the card shuffle, but it really is a well balanced game. So while there are a few hopeless situations, most of the time you at least feel like you had a chance -- if only a couple things went your way at the end. 

The different player roles add much needed variety.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7.75
Mechanically and time-wise the best co-op game around.  It could be a little more fun, and thematic though.  
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8
Great game. Even if I don't like cooperative games, this one glued me to itslef :D. I initially thught that it's much more repetative, but randomness in cards makes it much different each time you play. The thing that I didn't like the most is the fact that you can "loose" to the game in 1st turn, without ANY chance. Also, too much randomness in card drawing is the reason why it's 8 and not 9.

Quality of the cards is not really great, because in our first 2 games 2 cards got damaged (yes, we were very careful with the game).

It's not difficult, yet it's not unplayably easy. You don't need any gaming experience to be able to catch this one up, very fast. 

Another great thing is the length - usually ends up in 15-60 minutes. So during the evening you can play several games.

Don't have any expansion currently.

RATING: 6
this is an okay game ... try to stamp out diseases before they over-run the planet, this is strictly a co-operative game, and thereby can be a danger -- the danger is this game plays via committee -- and I hate committees (having had enough of them in real life) ... the strongest tends to take over, and if you are easy-going, you find your moves, are not really 'your moves' .. go here; do this; no, no, WE think you should be over here; -- and so you go for the betterment of the species -- game can be challenging though, as disease spreads faster than the group can stamp it out; so this is good -- but your unique character becomes subsumed to the will of 'the committee' ... and you just knew your own move was the right one after all -- can be fun with the right group, but painful if not the right group -- seeing as co-op games are not my favs -- let me go and make my mistakes (and my total hate of all committees) .. although I would play this if tabled -- tis far from my first choice -- but it is an okay game

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8
This was the first co-op game that I have played.  Picked the game up randomly and played a 2P game with the GF.  We lost miserably the first game but decided to play again immediately.  

The game is a little abstract with the cubes representing diseases (could have used different bacterial strain pieces instead IMHO), but it captures the urgency of racing against time trying to save humanity.  Players must coordinate and balance between containing outbreaks and finding cures for the 4 diseases before time (card deck) runs out.  

Everyone that I have introduced this game to has enjoyed it and usually ask to play it again.  If you like cooperative games, this one is well worth a try.  You can usually find a copy at your local Target.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

RATING: 9
Save the world, or die trying over and over again. One of the few co-op games I'm a fan of. Excellent strategic fun for two, although with four it can get tough to have everyone making their own decisions, as one under utilized turn will lose the game for everyone. I will continue to play this with two and an occasional four player game, although it would be better with experienced players. Never tried the terrorist variant, although the game is hard enough as it is. Stay away from Legacy, it just doesn't hold up to the original. Iberia seems to hold the feel of the original game with enough changes to make it uniquely interesting.

60-90m, 2-4 players. 25+ plays.

RATING: 9
Likely to go up.  After one play, we had a lot of fun.  It takes a lot of time to get through the rules the first time.  It is also a little hard to really see the strategy at first.  We just desided to start moving without trying to over-think it.  All things considered, (one of us is only seven), we did fairly well finding three of the four cures.  Everyone wants to play again.  Also, I love the non-glare finish on the board.  Although, as others have noted, the pawns are a little over-sized and/or the cities undersized.  Once you get into the game, it can be hard to locate the city buried under pawns, research centers, and cubes.

RATING: 6
One of the first modern board games I played and one of the reasons I started getting into this hobby. As I play more I've come to realize that open information, shared goal co-op games are not my favorite. Playing solo or with one other person can be good, but not as much with 3 or 4 players. It will be rare for me to rate this type of game higher than a 7 unless my preferences or situation changes.

RATING: 8
