=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7
This is my revised comments on Pandemic:  The co-op genre has changed quite a bit over the year. If there is one place that I would recommend someone to start, it's here.  Pandemic is probably one of the best games for couples out there being a co-op, as regular life with a significant other can sometimes be confrontational enough as it is without adding 'take that'/competitive games to heat things up.  In addition to that, this game is very easy to learn and not overly long which makes it a perfect gateway game.  Co-ops of the modern day need a way to scale the difficulty levels and Pandemic is one of the best in this regard.  I had initially rated this game a 6 because it lacked the variety to hold my interest and while I still feel this way about the base game, On the Brink has transformed the game to something much more enjoyable and variable.  In addition to that, after having played some other co-ops, I have a much deeper appreciation for the game, even in it's base form. Though, I would never play without the extra roles/events of 'On the Brink.' 

I would rate this higher with the inclusion of at least one expansion. If you're not going to invest in an expansion, you're better off with buying Pandemic Iberia (7 Roles, 15 Events, and included variants).

Breakdown (see expansion for their breakdowns):

7 Roles (5 in the old editions)
5 Events
Normal Challenge

---

Decoding plays...

#E - How many epidemics we used
V - Virulent
M - Mutation
B - Bio-Terrorist
L - Lab
P - Worldwide Panic
T - Team game
Y - Emergency Events
H - Hinterlands
Q - Quarantines
S - Superbug
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

RATING: 9
A great co-op game where you and your friends are trying to eradicate the four main diseases of the world.  While it is a simple premise it is very difficult to win depending on how many epidemic cards you put in your deck.  The spread is semi predictable, but you never know when it will happen and you are always on your toes to see if you will survive until the next round.  Really fun and intense.  This is definitely going to get some plays with small groups.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 5.33
Easy to learn, attractive components, but lacking in interesting strategy decisions.  Luck sometimes overshadows skill - the game should come with a built in system to warn players when no conceivable combination of plays can prevent defeat.  Sometimes you just can't win no matter what you do; other games will be won even with mediocre play; sometimes winning is possible only with good play.  The games of the first kind are frustrating and unsatisfactory because your time is wasted; games of the the second kind are boring because winning is too easy; only games of the third kind provide satisfaction by rewarding skillful play.  In all, I feel my time is better spent playing other games.  Rating based on three plays at the introductory level of difficulty and two plays at normal level of difficulty.  Rating of 5.33 is composite of my rating (4), my wife's rating (6) and my sister's rating (6).

RATING: 6
My first, and for a while my favorite cooperative game. Its incredibly prone to quarterbacking, but generally I've always felt like part of a team.  My biggest grievance is that certain setups can make the game impossible, in a literal way. Its not like that happens often at all (maybe once ever), but the possibility turns me off. Over the years they have added new roles with new mechanisms, but certain roles clearly trump others. Granted, this offers additional challenge on top of game variance, but I rarely view it from that perspective. Also, since the release of the Legacy edition, I will likely never play the base game ever again.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8
My wife and I started our game collection with Forbidden Island. Forbidden Island plays very similarly to Pandemic (mostly because it's designed by the same person, if I'm not mistaken.)
FI is quick and easy to clean up. The game practically cleans itself up as you play. Pandemic is so similar, that we get the rules mixed up ALL of the time. I appreciate with what Pandemic has done for the gaming community by bringing new blood in, but sometimes I would rather just play FI. Still a cool game, but definitely not a favorite. Might change when playing with a full group. I've only played two player.

Update 2/28/14
Bumped score up to 8. Played the game with my wife and two others last night. LOTS of fun compared to just playing with two. Bought both expansions at a good price (mostly for the petri dishes and the cure vials,) looking forward to finally beat the game! Will continue to update.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8
Light co-op game that is easy to learn, but has some nice random and unpredictable mechanics that makes it very tense. I especially like the different roles and how they can interact with each other. You really have to talk with your partners to get things going and make  good use of their vital special abilities. Looking forward to play it with more players and more epidemics.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 6
This game is cleverly designed, plays smoothly, and has been a hit with a number of our friends.  That said, I was a little disappointed with it - it just doesn't have the depth of strategy that I was expecting.  I guess there's only so much challenge you can have without a real human opponent to test your wits against.  By "not enough challenge" I don't mean that we win all the time, but instead that loosing because the wrong cards came up and it became impossible isn't the same sort of enjoyment as loosing because you were outmanuevered by a craftier opponent.  

That said, I do enjoy playing well enough, as long as there are 3 or 4 players and the others are excited about it, so that is what this rating reflects.  2-player I would rather pass on.

RATING: 8
The perfect theme for a co-operative, us-versus-the-board game, because there's no need for the rules to simulate an intelligent opponent who responds to what you do. The diseases just do their own thing with a mixture of predictability and randomness, and you have to respond.

Alas, my wife won't play it as she finds the theme too scary.

Probably my favourite of the games I've discovered so far. (I'm new to the hobby.)

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 6.25
Co-op games aren't meant to be beaten every time.

Pandemic's spirit is akin to Tetris, where you don't really expect to finish the game, but rather see how long you can hold out until the world collapses around you. You would need players that apply computational analysis to the characters and patterns of each play session in order to routinely defeat this board. Even then, the challenge differs with each random assortment of characters and disease-ridden cities.

Despite the rarity of completion, this is a title that will manage to entice less orderly-minds to wade into the struggle for a plague-free world again and again.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8
Really fun coop game and trying to race against the game to beat it. Pretty light and a great quick game.   Starting to fade a little at 10 plays.

This game peaked at a 9 for me.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 6
Co-op games are interesting.  As long as the group doesn't allow one player to dominate all the decision making then it is enjoyable where each player can still have some individuality.  

The fewer the players, the easier the game is.  With 2 players, we have won with all 6 epidemics in the deck.  With 4 players, we have only won with 4 epidemics in the deck.

Edit:  This is a very good game and is such a mixed bag.  Sometimes with two players it is much easier, sometimes much harder.  Depends on the pair of Roles you receive and the initial infection plus Epidemic rate.

Too bad the second run changed the back of the cards and the conversion kit is needed.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 10
[b][thread=469324]The PLAYMOBIL® Legion reviews "Pandemic"[/thread][/b]

(As of [b]16[/b] plays) One of the few games I have played that consistently creates an atmosphere of genuine tension. A great cooperative experience with a refreshingly [i]different[/i] and well-implemented theme. A common criticism is that if one person orders everyone else around for the entire game, the overall fun level decreases, but that has not been a problem with any of the groups I have played with. [GAMEID=40849] expansion provides many ways to shake things up if the base game becomes too easy and/or familiar. This will [i]always[/i] have a place in my collection, as I can see myself playing it for many years, with many different types of people.

[b]Why this is in my Top Ten:[/b] While I had been exploring the wider world of board games for a while, Pandemic was the first game to get me really [i]excited[/i] about board gaming. The cooperative aspect was a complete revelation to me, and one of my fondest gaming memories is playing this for the first time with some of my closest friends. We played it five times before we finally beat it... on Easy. It was such a thrill.

[b]4 year verdict:[/b] I haven't played this nearly enough, due in part to my local gaming group not being that interested, but it remains something I would play at any time, especially with the expansion. It is getting major competition from [GAMEID=100901], though, which my semi-gaming relatives have embraced. I would say that Pandemic is the superior [i]game[/i], but Flash Point, with its lighter theme and increased randomness, just might be the superior [i]experience[/i] in a primarily social sitaution. 
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

RATING: 7
This game is the sweet spot of difficulty when it comes to cooperative board games. At its highest settings, this game is intensely difficult and nail-bitingly tense. Players absolutely must cooperate or there is no chance of success. And, of course, the expansion freshens it up nicely.

Edit: Having played it now dozens of times, I feel like Pandemic is too easy. A good group should always know what to do, leaving the only determinant whether the epidemic cards screw you over or not. It's still fun, but it lacks challenge.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8.5
Pandemic is a co-operative game that reminds you that you can't do everything you want to. Remember that the goal is not to eradicate four diseases but simply to cure them.

Even the 'easy' game provides a moderate challenge. It only makes the eventual victory more satisfying. The game rarely becomes so grueling that you stop having fun.

RATING: 8
Pandemic seemed to be a breakthrough co-op game that definitely delivered.........the first couple games. After players figure out how to beat the game, the gameplay becomes much more predictable and scripted. You have to accomplish certain things every time and as quickly as possible. Also, this game is one of the most Alpha player games ive ever played and this destroys the experience for new players. There will be one experienced player giving advice because the other players simply have never played and don't know where to start. What ends up happening is one alpha player basically playing for 4 and the other players essentially being more arms to move pieces and that's it. Its actually more fun if no advice is given and if a player makes a bad choice than too bad.

RATING: 8
Cooperative game, comparable to Shadows Over Camelot (which is best for 4-7 players), this is good for 1-4 players.  Quick playtime, and also suitable as gateway game.  The interaction between roles is excellent.  The Operations Expert seems to be the weakest.  I like giving the diseases names: black = ebola or black plague; red = small pox or swine flu; blue = anthrax; yellow = typhoid.  May be worth editing the Operations Expert (as revised in expansion card - details [url=http://www.boardgamegeek.com/thread/453298]here[/url]) to make this role as strong as the others.
NB: First edition owners can trade in their decks for a newer linen finished one, details [url=http://www.boardgamegeek.com/thread/426134]here[/url].

RATING: 7
I like this game a good deal and find the stress it brings at times to be really fun. Winning because of good team decisions can feel great. Loosing as a group is a devastating feeling though and I think that aspect makes it stay on my shelf more than it should. Especially because it's often really hard to know where you went wrong in hindsight. Maybe this is just a qualm with full co-op games, but I feel like a good designer could mitigate this somewhat.

Unlike many coop games, you don't feel that you are always one step away from disaster -- although sometimes you are!  You really do have the sense that you are in control and that there is a good chance to win.  The teamwork element in this game is much better than any other coop game I have played.  And the balance... it's perfect.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 6
A landmark game that kick-started the cooperative game genre. Sure, I know there were some big names out there before this one came along, but this is the one that created a sensation and started a flurry of other designs. I played the game dozens of times (on table & online) and enjoyed it as a group puzzle, but I think other designs have surpassed it. For example, despite coming out several years before Pandemic, Knizia’s LOTR coop game gives players much more interesting decisions with their cards -- and thus a chance for individually creative contributions. 

Flash Point: Fire Rescue, in particular, offers a similar experience but with many maps to choose from and the ability to swap roles during the game. Other cooperative games give players more individual decisions than the group puzzle laid bare on the board here. 

At this point, I can’t say I’ve much interest in revisiting Pandemic but I’m happy to have played it as much as I did. I’d rather play Flash Point or some other type of cooperative game, preferably one that gives players more individual decisions such as LOTR TCG or Gears of War.

And then comes along Pandemic: Legacy and shoots up to #1 on BGG with raves from all my friends who’ve played it. Looks like I need to try that one. 

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7
Credit where credit is due, long after the hype I have finally got around to playing Pandemic and I can objectively say, the hype was real, it is a solid co-op game.

Pandemic is a game that rewards over-analysis and collaborative thinking as you need to get things done, you need to get them done quickly and you need to get them efficiently, because if you allow small problems to snowball the shit coming off the fan hits pretty quickly.  Team-work is a must; find symbiotic relationships between the different roles to play most effectively as even then it won't be an easy, nor guaranteed win.

This is a nice escalation in the difficulty of Matt Leacock's work (Forbidden Island > Forbidden Desert > Pandemic).
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

RATING: 7.875
I love, love, love:
- the simplicity of the puzzle
- the asymmetric player powers, so everyone can contribute in their own unique way
- the cooperative nature

I dislike:
- the theme doesn't really feel that particularly strong

Final verdict: A classic co-op game that got me (and hubby) into the hobby and will never leave our collection.

RATING: 3
The most I can say about Pandemic is that the board and components were made of high quality in the original edition.  The game itself plays like a dentist pulling teeth, only without the Novocain.  The more players added to the game rapidly decreases the ability to win, and the game has a serious 'quarterback' issue.

If you like to order people around to do what you think they should, then you should play this!  I'd always rather play Forbidden Island/Desert instead.

RATING: 4
Very overrated game. Glorified solitaire except with your buddies. The expansions do improve the game a little. In co-op games like Arkham Horror, you at least have a character card with adjustable stats and there are enough things going on in the game that having additional players makes sense. With Pandemic, you just have some blah ability that you will probably spam for most of the game. There is no character development, story or boss to fight, just some diseases that don't seem to go away until the very end if you're lucky. I can see how it would be fun to explore different role combinations, but if I'm going to to that, I'd rather do it in a game that isn't reduced to a bunch of cube pushing.

RATING: 9
Guilty as charged - another co-op game that I am fond of.

Great components with a vibrant board along with great looking cards.  I enjoy the co-op aspect where you can play with yourself, another person, or a small group.  You can even play along with younger ones and teach them the game rather than a head to head type game.  The variable difficulty allows you to really challenge yourself if that is what you want to do.

In my experience, I view this as the most difficult co-op game out there where you should not be ashamed of getting beat because it really can be difficult.  While I consider it the most difficult, I also consider it the most well designed co-op out there.

A more challenging version of Forbidden Island.

Nothing beats the physical components though - the sense of desperation when you get a chain outbreak and have to place those little cubes out on the board is just great.

Positive :
  -Clean mechanics and rules
  -Very simple to teach
  -Relatively quick
  -Cooperation game
  -Difficulty lvl is adjustable
  -You can add themes and giggles by choosing what the diseases are. 
Negative :
  -Can be too simple
  -Gets old fast if you play too much (The game gets better when you add more expansion though.)
  -Frustrating to play with 'alpha players'
  -Frustrating to play with 'bad players'
also very boring to play alone compare to other coop games.
Above average game = 7.

RATING: 8
I find this game different every time based on the deck and when things come up.  I love the tension in the game and how I really feel the world is depending on me.  I think this game is harder to teach to non-games/new gamers than Flashpoint because in Pandemic the theme and actions you take (use cards to fly) is less intuitive and more abstract.  I find the roles do not specialize your characters much and on most turns your role does not dictate/suggest what your actions should be.  I find this can sometimes lead to people telling other what to do because there are a lot of options for new players.

RATING: 8
My first game seemed to go very easily, until a forgotten rule was recalled - you can only make the cure in a lab. D'oh! That makes it harder and we didn't have time to start over, so we really want to give this another go. Very interesting game design, proper choices, a hard game system to beat and a genuine feeling of watching the diseases reach dangerous levels before your eyes. I moved this up to Love To Have on my wishlist, a definite buy. *** Played again properly, WE LOST BY ONE CARD! We should have used the 4th player more towards getting the last cure, instead of hovering up. But that may have caused an outbreak.... oh the humanity. *** Played again with new people, won the Intro game easily, played the normal game, lost badly. Oh the disease. Definitely want my own copy now. *** Played again and this time using all the rules correctly. Originally, I put the shuffled discards to the bottom of the deck. This results in cubes spreading everywhere. The real rules are actually correct, a small set of infected cities keeps pushing disease into outbreaks, making it much more realistic. We won too, only just! *** Played again with the proper rules, as a 3player game we lost badly early to massive outbreaks. I'm inclined to not play this as a 3player game, it seemd too hard. But we did waste too much time trying to clear a cured disease. Hmmmm, needs thought.

RATING: N/A

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7
Great co-op game, with pretty high initial replayability because players will keep losing (even on easy, this is a fairly difficult game - at hard, I've yet to win any), and want to play again until they beat it.

And while it's recommended to hide your hand in an attempt to mimic communication difficulties in the real world, it's hard enough as it is to win already, so playing open hands may be wise until people get a good grasp of the game. A possible problem that arises with the latter is that one or two people ultimately become the tacticians, and end up leading the rest of the party.

RATING: 8

RATING: 4
6 Plays. 

I've decided I don't like co-op as much as I'd thought. While skill and cooperation can certainly help you do well while playing this game, "breaking the game's code", is much more beneficial. Other people we've introduced the game to enjoyed it, as did my wife. For me, it's a calculation exercise.

Fine component production. Very nicely laid out rules. Solid gameplay. In terms of objective quality, if such a thing actually existed, I'd rate this game a 8. In terms of my desire to play this game again, I'd rate this game a 3 or 4.

RATING: 9
Played it once, had to buy it.  First and only co-op I've played.  When I sprang it on my mother and she wanted to play it again, I knew it was a great game.  So far it's been the best gateway game I own.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8.5
My personal favorite co-operative game, Pandemic has you playing the role of one of five distinct international medical specialist, whose job is to work with between one and three other specialists to find the cures for four deadly and infectious diseases before they overrun the planet.  This game has just the right mixture of simplicity, co-operation, variety, and tension that gives it near infinite replayability.  While a pretty simple game to get the hang of, it is still incredibly difficult to win at times, and the mounting tension in some games can be pretty intense, so the game can certainly be intimidating.  That said, this is one game I keep coming back to, and provided you play with people who like to work together with others towards a common good, you will love this game.  The apocalyptic biological plague theme, while not laid thick, works very well with mechanics.  Highly recommended, as is the wonderful expansion.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8
I take this on holiday. Perfect as a solo game, perfect as a 2 player game. Not sure above that though. I also love the expandability of it, not just with On The Brink, which is equally great, but also with Jack (The Warp) Reda's excellent expansions.

This is the game I wish I had invented!

Have reduced from a 10, only because other games appear more attractive now after so many plays.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: N/A
After 1 game, I can tell we are really going to enjoy this one!  Looking forward to adding the expansion in the future.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8
Played 20+ times with 1-4 players.
Ratings history: 6|8|8|8|8........|10......

[b]Sharp looking co-op about saving the world from deadly diseases. It presents a challenging, ever-shifting puzzle to the players. I own this and expect to keep the game in my collection.
PROS:[/b]
- easy to learn, tricky to master
- variable, shifting puzzle
- variety of player roles (special abilities)
- well-designed modular expansions are available for purchase
- very attractive graphic design (I even prefer the plastic cubes)
[b]CONS:[/b]
- as much of a puzzle as a game (but I like this)
- could feel samey from play to play for some people (but I enjoy the shifting challenge)
- most gamers will probably need an expansion to keep this fresh (but game + expansion ~=~ $ of good strategy game)
- has "alpha" problem common to co-ops (but I let newbs do their thing)

:star::star::star::star::star: - My rating. 
:star::star::star::star::nostar: - Partner's rating.

1st play: Huh. Well, it is a good piece of design, but I didn't find it that fun. It was just a puzzle with shifting parts. I wasn't at all impressed by it. I prefer Shadows Over Camelot a bit more, and Terra and Lord of the Rings co-op a LOT more.

5 plays in: I like this a lot more than I used to. Really want the expansion.

12 plays in: I bought an expansion and am enjoying this game more than ever before, even without having added the expansion.

15 plays in: Good official solitaire variant.

20 plays in, and I have to say how impressed I am with the skeleton of the game. It is just so clever. The Infecting and Intensifying mechanics are brilliant, the asymmetrical links on the map (Santiago...grrrr). The outbreak mechanics, the decisions to make card passing difficult (and more thematic!). Multi-use cards, a variety of player roles... All of this for an incredibly reasonable price.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8
Quality game.  Excellent rule book & the rules are uncomplicated and straight forward.  Played the novice game with 4.  We came within a turn of winning, but lost to the board game. Play intriguing and want to play again soon.  The theme of the game is pertinent to the play and mechanics of the game. No score.  You either as a group, win or lose.

RATING: 8
Beautiful components and exciting game to play.  I love how the theme shines through.  Can be played solo too.  We were a little confused at first at what a Cure did for the players but by the second game it made more sense.

Combined with it's quick playing times, and often close finishes, this game is often a "repeat play".

In the past, for the few games we won, it always happened very early in the game.  However, we actually had a few games where we won just one turn before it would have been over.

[2013]:  The iPad version is outstanding!

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 9
After almost a dozen plays, we still have yet to beat it on Introductory level. We have, however, won our first game of Pandemic Legacy. We'll see how that changes going forward. The big lesson learned, from Legacy and playing on the iPad, is that outbreaks seem to be our weakness, and controlling them is more key than I thought it was.

Pandemic is probably the most straight-forward and least complicated co-operative game we own (with the obvious exception of Forbidden Island), making it our game of choice when introducing friends to the co-op genre.

We own the first expansion, but we haven't tried any of the variants contained therein, and I doubt we'll be adding any of the other expansions, for a couple of reasons:

1) We own the 1st edition, so we'd have to buy the compatibility packs; and

2) With Pandemic Legacy out now, regular ol' Pandemic may be about to become obsolete, at least in our house. We'll still keep it, though, for newer players and to combine with the Bio-Terrorist challenge in On The Brink.

Really a great game to introduce friends to boardgaming.  Short and tense!  The theme is great and makes you feel like a character from a Michael Crichton novel trying to save mankind from diseases.  It's a game you can have the folks from up the street try out without having them be an elf or an orc- the scientific theme is refreshing.  I hope the success of this game gets us more short cooperative games.  As a gamer I prefer Lord of the Rings as a cooperative because it feels bigger and has more decisions as well as more options as you play.  Pandemic is so short and lean that how the deck is stacked might determine the game before it starts.  Enjoyable and easy, I need to play more to see if it gets better for me.

RATING: 7.5
This is a game you don't just play once each time. A really involved game experience - great gateway game!  

Bonus points: 
+Great fun even with just 2
+Simple to learn
+Enjoyed by non-gamers
+Always gets a "Let's do that again!" response

My fiance and I play this together (online for while he is long distance) to work on our cooperation and communication skills, heh. 

Only problem with this game is: you can only play with people as familiar/unfamiliar as the game as you are, otherwise a lot of bossing around happens. Also while there is some general strategy involved, this is more of a logistics planning game. Works great, but not as satisfying to me as an economic game.

RATING: 6
Over familiarity has robbed this of some of the strength it once has - my girlfriend enjoys playing it a lot more than I do, and sometimes it feels like decisions can stretch out and the game doesn't have momentum.  I suppose I'm less invested in our success than I once was.  A good design, but I much prefer co-op games where the players have more distinct agency - Eldritch Horror, Defenders of the Realm, Flashpoint - and the 'right' move is less easy to be dictated.

RATING: 9

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7
My history with Pandemic is a common one.

This game (along with Settlers of Catan) was the catalyst to me becoming a board game enthusiast. It's a solid, well-constructed co-op and should stand the test of time as a classic.

With that said, the base game is a little lacking in my taste. Now that I own both the expansions and Pandemic Legacy, it's hard to go back to just the regular version. It feels like an amazing foundation with no house built on top of it.

Ultimately, if you like co-operative games, buy Pandemic. Then go and buy the first two expansions. Or just skip the whole lot and buy Pandemic Legacy.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

RATING: 8

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8
This hasn't produced a boring game yet, though I have only played it a few times.  So far, everyone has liked it.  This is the best co-op I have played (in my limited experience).  I believe it is because no one ever has to "take one for the team".  That has caused tension for us in other co-ops.

I really like the mechanism wherein the infected cities are up for further infections after an epidemic.  This just ups the tension level, which is sustained throughout the game.

I think part of what makes this game work is he wide variation in player powers.  This helps give everyone a stake in what is going on, and a real role to play, since no one else on the team can duplicate the role nearly as effectively.

This was definitely a good purchase.

-------------------------
Update:

I am amazed at how close these games consistently are. Having played this nearly 20 times now, games are nearly always close.  This is just a great game.

See my full review at: 
http://sofrankly.com/2011/04/saving-humankind-from-death-and-disease.html

RATING: 6
An excellent co-op game for just about anyone who likes a co-op. Easy to teach and easy to play.

The way the mechanics of the game, in particular the way cities get re-infected, perfectly match the theme of the game is something that you don't see that often. It is really well done and really quite clever.

Just remember to temper the controlling part of your nature and let new players make decisions for themselves. Enjoy the ride.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7
Interesting "automatic game system", the outbreaks are neat and very thematic. Otherwise it's a relatively simple card game with a connection element. This one shares a problem of many coops: the information is (almost entirely) shared and therefore one person always tend to dominate the decision-making process. For some reason, I feel it more acutely here than in LotR. For me, Space Alert feels more novel due to the time pressure and the necessity to delegate.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7
This game is excellent for playing with people that usually don't play a lot of games. Anyone can get into the theme and easily understand the goal of the game. It plays like a puzzle you have to solve. I often feel that the outcome of the game is decided with how the cards come up even if you can of course effect what will happen with your decisions. 

With On the Brink expansion.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8
First cooperative game I really loved playing. It really does force players to cooperate and discuss options - when they don't, disaster usually results. Very nice balance of rules to create suspense and challenge throughout the game.

The only big negative to the game is that the initial conditions vary too widely - it is theoretically possible to lose within a few minutes and no chance to stop it. It is also possible to have a setup so easy that the group coasts to victory. For the majority of games that fall closer to the middle of these two extremes, this game is very enjoyable.

RATING: 9
This game is always a fun time.  The "On the Brink" expansion modules and variable difficulty keep the game fresh.  However, if you're not prepared to buy the "On the Brink" expansion immediately, don't pick this up.  The expansion is absolutely necessary in my opinion.

I should mention that I'm still playing with the older version that's not compatible with the newer expansions, so my experience with the game system as a whole is still partial.  That being said, the game is fun enough as is and I don't feel the need to add additional expansions at this time.

RATING: 8
Fun coop game, but for me it suffers from being so similar to Forbidden Island. I occasionally want to play Pandemic over Forbidden Island, but most of the time I prefer Forbidden Island because it is more streamlined and so much easier to set up.

Pandemic is tough to introduce to new people as well because the impact of your actions is difficult to gauge early in the game. Late in the game, even new players will recognize how important it is to remove those two cubes, but in the beginning it can feel meaningless.

RATING: 7.5
Pandemic was my first coop-game. It was a pleasant surprise to play with my co-gamers instead of against them.

Pandemic's theme is great, it's fairly easy to explain the game to other players and it's a very addictive game. 

The difference between a win and a loss is very small and after each lost game you'll want to get in the game again and try to beat the system this time.

I'm looking forward to all the expansions (I've purchased the first one recently, just haven't had the chance to try is).

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8
Oui, il y a le problème de celui qui dit toujours quoi faire et que les autres suivent, l'écoutant sans vraiment oser lui dire qu'il rend le jeu ennuyeux pour tout le monde. Bon, dans une équipe, il y a aussi souvent un leader, cela dit, mais souvent, s'il impose son point de vue, ça ne dure pas longtemps. C'est d'autant plus vrai si un des joueurs est vraiment meilleur que les autres. Pour contrer le phénomène, il suffit d'introduire des limites à la discussion, ne pas montrer ses cartes, que chacun bouge son pion au lieu que ce fameux joueur ne soit un "Répartiteur" permanent, et de s'exprimer si l'un des joueurs commence à trop prendre l'ascendant.

Il y a aussi la sensation de subir sans cesse le hasard du tirage de cartes qui détermine la victoire ou la défaite, l'impression de n'être pas loin et que finalement c'est le manque de chance qui a provoqué la défaite et la fin du monde. Et puis ceux qui n'aiment pas les jeux coopératifs et qui préfèrent taper sur d'autres joueurs plus réels.

Ça peut gêner.

Mais pour moi, c'est au contraire tout l'intérêt du jeu qui provoque un sentiment d'urgence, de course contre la montre qui est tout à fait adapté au thème de la contamination planétaire. On a vraiment le sentiment, en jouant, de faire partie de cette équipe qui doit enrayer une menace planétaire, on se sent presque à Hollywood (on commence à Atlanta, quand même). Mais à Hollywood, les américains arrivent toujours à sauver le monde. Dans "Pandémie", pas du tout. En fait, chez nous, on perd beaucoup plus souvent que l'on gagne. Parfois à pas grand chose, parfois à cause d'un mauvais tirage de cartes. A moins que ce soit nous qui ayons fait les mauvais choix, utilisé des cartes spéciales au mauvais moment, etc.

Car un jeu coopératif se doit d'être difficile. Un jeu "classique", lui, dépend des joueurs face à nous. Là, le joueur, c'est le jeu, donc s'il est nul, on gagne à chaque fois et ça n'a à peu près aucun intérêt et l'envie d'y revenir est presque nulle. Là, on a souvent l'impression qu'il manquait peu de choses, sans avoir vraiment l'impression d'avoir fait les mauvais choix et avec l'envie immédiate de prendre sa revanche.

Le plateau, lui, est assez sobre et avec peu de nuances, mais là encore, je trouve que l'esthétique générale ne colle pas mal au thème, on a l'impression d'être dans un QG de crise et de gérer la situation depuis ce bureau.

"Pandémie", malgré quelques défauts inhérents à ce type de jeu, est donc un excellent jeu coopératif avec un thème fort, équilibré malgré le côté aléatoire (mais maîtrisé et prévisible) du tirage des cartes : aux joueurs de réagir face à la situation.

Un succès amplement mérité.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

RATING: 6
This game has gotten less enjoyable to me as time has gone on.  The difficulty varies wildly based on the shuffling of the cards, and is usually either too easy or nearly impossible.  Very seldom do we have a close call.  

Still good to play with more casual gamers, as the theme is inoffensive and easy to understand.  The cooperative nature of the game also helps out in this regard, but be careful of allowing a new player's moves to be dictated for them.

RATING: 7
It's probably as good as a coop game would get.  I think I'm just not a huge fan of the genre.  One thing I think a coop game should have, though, is secret information for each player that cannot be shared with others.  That would force everyone to be an essential part of the game.  This game doesn't have that, but I don't really have any major complaints - it's complicated enough to require player interaction, great theme, great playtime, good bits, good interaction, and a good puzzle.  If I wanted a coop game, I think this is the one I would get.

RATING: 9

I had written this game off as being too controlled by the person who knows what is going on, but when everyone knows the game, it really shines. I enjoyed it immensely, even though we lost miserably. It reminded me just how good this game can be and that, possibly, I had been playing too many teaching games.

RATING: 9
This game is a marvel of board game design. Every detail of the gameplay has been well thought out.  The rules are easy to understand. The difficulty can be adapted to your play style. Each player has their own job to do and, because this is a collaborative effort, everyone remains fully engaged even when it is not their turn. 
Buy if you want an engrossing puzzle that you can (sometimes) solve with your friends

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8
So far this is one of the best coop game I have played.

Pros:
- It's fast and easy to learn.
- The strategies are not too complex.
- For once, there is no treator. You all play toward the same goal. (This is great for people who dont like having a bad guy)
- Game play is fairly fast. If you loose one there is always the next one you can learn.
- It's fun.

Cons:
- You can't win them all. There is a fair part of luck in the success of the game. You can only accomplish so much with strategy.(I dont mind it but some people do)

RATING: 9.5
Not without reason that it's a very popular game here on BGG. Play is quite smooth and tense, and teamwork really does pay off. No matter whether you win or lose, the tension alone will keep players alert and very much into the game. Not fun to play with overbearing people, although there are variants to solve that (but also make the game much harder).
Also quite nice as a solitaire game.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8
I enjoy this game a bit more every time I play. That means about a dozen times, mostly two-player games and a few four-player ones.

This is a great game for casual players. It is one of the very few games where you don't have to explain the rules in detail and the others can catch up while you're playing. The theme is awesome, the mechanics are simple but fit very well.

The replayability seems to be pretty good so far as well. I was worried that I will lose interest in a few games. But the games and our overall strategies were pretty different so far, depending on our characters, player count and the cube distribution. Sure, there is a lot of randomness, but not so much that you don't have any real control over it. Or if it is actually the case, then the game hides that pretty well. However, I am a bit worried that maybe there are some general patterns I have not discovered yet and things could get really repetitive if I do.

One negative remark: The colors of the 2013 version are really dark for my taste. The cubes are nice, but I would prefer wooden components, sturdier cards and brighter colors.

But either way. This game is tough to win but easy to understand, is super interactive in a friendly way, and has an awesome theme with fitting mechanics. It's an incredible design.

Update: We have gotten really good at the game. So we tried it with the OTB expansion, but it has lost some of its charm even so. But anyway, it took us a far amount of plays to get here. 
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

RATING: 2
I appreciate the skill involved in the card counting, and identifying key diseases to put resources into curing versus those one waits to align, but that hardly excuses the game's total inability to deal with the alpha player problem.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8
2-4 players, best with 4

Easy to learn, with a randomness to the gameplay that provides challenge and occasional insurmountable difficulty.  I'd probably place it mid-way between Forbidden Island and Elder Sign in terms of baked-in difficulty, Forbidden Island being a relative breeze and gateway gamer game, and Elder Sign often off-puttingly and punishingly difficult.  Unlike Elder Sign, a game loss is just as easily followed by a win, so it doesn't push players away.  Repeated plays may lead to the atrophy of interest with its relative sameness, but the Legacy series have pretty much killed the original anyway.  Play those instead, stay interested throughout the campaign with the ebbs, flows, and tweaks, as well as all the legacy bells & whistles.

RATING: 9
Pandemic is pretty damn amazing.  Apart from the amazing components and immersive theme, there is such a high degree of player interaction in this game.  Because it's co-op, you get into rather deep discussions of strategy.  I'm truly amazed at how perfect the mechanics are, and how engaging this game could be for casual and die-hard game fans.  The average time for play is very suitable as well.  For a game without antagonistic competition, Pandemic is as much a nail-biter as any other well-designed game.

RATING: 8
Quick playing, and tense.  A strong cooperative outing with an interesting theme and quality production values.  The variant player powers offer interesting combinations and interactions.  The built in timer keeps the game at a short playtime, but the end ties in thematically, so never feels gamey.   

UPDATE:  With a couple more plays on heroic difficulty with three players this game shoots up in the rankings surpassing all other co-op games i have played.  Scales very well, and offers a very quick and tense experience.

UPDATE:  Pandemic is my co-op choice when I have less than an hour, but my enjoyment of this game has been surpassed by Defenders of the Realm.  Granted Defenders owes a lot to this marvelous title, but I find the experience for Defenders much more immersive.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 10
I played it once and immediately bought my own copy and have played that more than one hundred times since, and I will still try to start games. The co-operative aspect is great: it has brought in players who are otherwise turned off by the competitiveness of boardgaming. The rules don't take too long to explain to a newcomer. The motif is brilliant for the mechanic, and fun and interesting. The play is interesting and the difficulty level can be adjusted to suit your game. The 5 different roles* make the game more interesting.

It is not without it's faults (although I don't consider any of these faults): particularly that the randomness of the card deck means that sometimes the game is much harder or a bit easier. It seems particularly well-suited to 3 player, although 2 and 4 are both fine (and I play more often in 2 or 4). There's no winner.


*Or 6: it's beneficial and easy to add the Generalist Role from the expansion (it just gives 5 actions per turn).

RATING: 7
It's beautiful how the disease outbreaks develop in this game. I was absolutely floored the first time I played as I watched the world get overrun (and so damn fast!) by a disease we didn't think was even overly-threatening.

The big problem with this game is that it tends to get played for you - there are obvious "best" moves to take, and since it's such a difficult game and you really do want to win experienced players have an incentive to try to tell you what to do. This kind of leads to one person taking charge and that can be dull for some folks, which is a shame, because experiencing that out of control outbreak is a one-of-a-kind moment.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 6
The game is so easy to teach and play. It is tense and animated. I like the outbreak mechanic. I also like how each combination of characters abilities make the game ever green. You can tweak the difficulty to your liking.
On the downside, (1) sometimes it can feel like cleaning the board of little glass cubes, rather than eradicating diseases. (2) I don't really understand how collecting city cards help you cure a disease, from a thematic stand point. (3) it can get very hard with 4 players, which is a shame, as it is only then that you get the full collaborative experience and synergies between characters. (4) the only mechanic to slow down alpha players is that you are not meant to show your cards, which arguably isn't really enough to stop those players. (5) Luck does play a big role in your success or failure. There is no morale choice to make, all choices are related to risk management.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 6
I neither love nor hate Pandemic, however after several plays I've grown rather bored of it. Have recently played Pandemic: The Cure and while the main gameplay is mostly the same, it played in about a third of the time and didn't overstay its welcome. I can't fault the mechanics of the game, it just doesn't feel different enough between plays to make me want to play it much more.

RATING: 8
It might be a little too much of a co-operative game for my tastes, but I guess it just adds to the all-for-one atmosphere.  I'm starting to think it's impossible to win, but I think a lot of that is the element of luck involved in the drawing of cards.  I tend to like the fact that it's unpredictable, but I think some would dislike that.  Whatever...I'd rather have a game that's too hard than one that's too easy.

I think this game is almost played out for me.  Just won a five-player, six epidemic game fairly handily.  Still fun, but wouldn't be my first choice of a game at this point.

Taught a group of eleven year-olds this game and they absolutely loved it.  They really enjoyed the team aspect of it; they found the experience of working together in a board game very unique and different from what they were had previously experienced.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 5
Early when I was starting my gaming collection, this seemed like it should be an auto include.  Everyone online loved it and said it was a great way to get people into gaming.

I was a bit disappointed with it.  My wife and I enjoyed it the first few times we played it, but after you know what to do, everything just becomes automatic and either it works out or it doesn't.  Sometimes the order of the cards is just too cruel and you cannot win, but often just doing the obvious things to do gets you there.

Pandemic also suffers from what I generally dislike in cooperative games.  The guy who owns the game and explains it to everyone knows how to win.  So he gets put in the awkward situation of telling everyone how to win or letting them fend for themselves and watch as the game implodes.  Neither option is very fun for me, and no one has ever played Pandemic with me and gone "Wow, that was a lot of fun!  Let's play again!".
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7
I'm generally open to 1 or 2 games of this, but I can't play it all night or even every week.

RATING: 7
My girlfriend and I love playing this together. It's usually pretty intense throughout the game, a lot of interaction with each other, very satisfying to win, but still fun if you lose. The game can change in the draw of a card. There have been times when we were in the best possible shape we could be in, and a single card lost us the game. So there is a luck factor, but if you've got solid tactics you'll be able to win often.




EDIT 5/22/12
After playing this a couple dozen times, it has been knocked back to an 8. It's still a great game, but the setting up is so cumbersome. And there's no quick way to do it. This coupled with a luck factor that can kill you off in the first few turns has eaten away at the fun factor of it all. The more we play it the more it starts to feel like a chore, the replay ability only reaches so far.

LUCKILY there is an expansion, so we've got it on our radar, hoping it will breathe some freshness into this once great game


EDIT 6/28/12
We got the 'On the Brink' expansion and love it. Adds lots of variety to the game. Plenty of new roles, new special event cards, even new game modes. We've been back to playing it semi-regularly, the expansion is pretty pricey but adds more fun if you're a fan.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

I have trouble with these, as unless I keep very strict control of myself *I* can start to act like the alpha dog.

At this point I'll be honest, this is a great game I am utterly tired of which is why it is rated as low as it is.

RATING: 7.5

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8
So much buzz over this game right now.  Surely this has been hyped up to such an extreme that people are destined to be disappointed.  Cooperative games are few and far between, let alone good ones.  Pandemic streamlines the genre to such an extent that it really feels unique.  Lord of the Rings is a great cooperative game, but it seems convoluted in comparison.  This is a game that really fights the players every step of the way, and you really feel the encroaching doom as diseases continue to spread across the globe.  The buzz is justified.

As for the components though, the production is just okay.  It looks just fine, but I wish a little more effort was spent some better components.  The game deserves it.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 9
A great co-op game, with decent replay value. Once you've played it a lot it can get a bit easy, and some combinations of roles are quite a bit better than others. This is the game most likely to succumb to Follow-the-leader syndrome though so enjoyment will depend a lot on who you play with, and you have to be very careful introducing new players so that you don't just tell them what to do.

RATING: 2
I find the game dull and lacking in engagement. Once you are playing the game well your decision-making ability is locked into just responding to the board condition with no reward for creative or innovative play. There is no risk/reward in the game that is of any consequence. Once you play the game well you are essentially watching things unfold to see if you win. Losing is often out of your control and, with experienced players, has nothing to do with the players, just luck.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8
Very good co-op game. It's a classic for a reason, it's has solid mechanisms and is quite challenging. The expansions add a lot of interesting elements as well. I think I slightly prefer Defenders of the Realm, which gives me more of a thematic-story feel, but really it copies so much from Pandemic that I have to give it the respect it deserves. If you're just getting in to co-ops, you'll find a LOT of other games in the genre have "borrowed" elements of this game. It's almost like "tower defense", but at just the right level.

RATING: 7
The genious of this cooperative game is that you have to keep your hand hidden.  This way, even the more timid players at the table, still get to talk.  "Well, do you have many cards of the same color?" "How many red cards do you have?" "Who has the most yellow cards?"  Placing the cards open ruins this, and you'll have one player dictating the show.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 10
Oh, Pandemic. There are two phases of my life: pre and post-Pandemic. This was the game that started it all for us. My wife and I had been playing Monopoly and Yahtzee and one day in Target, I saw this (the original printing) on a shelf and wanted to give it a shot. We bought it and stayed up until 3am that night playing over and over until we beat it for the first time and oh how rewarding was the first sweet victory. While there are other games that are more fun or inventive, this game will always hold a special place in my heart as the one that opened my eyes to what games have become.

RATING: 9
Bought from Barnardo's charity shop in Brixton for £3.99, in November 2012. (Although we'd played my brother-in-law's copy plenty of times before that.)

One of my wife's favourite games, which helps me love it even more. This and [thing=98778][/thing] fill the co-op niche in my collection and I don't feel any desire to get more.

Pandemic creates tension like nothing else I've played. It plays fast, escalates fast, and if you start getting good at it you can always make it harder...

And you know what? As much as I love abstract games, theme [i]matters[/i]. Saving the world from a series of horrific disease outbreaks? Yes! Makes heroes of all of us!

RATING: 5
One of the better co-op games out there. Despite the board feeling like it was too small the first couple of plays, I feel it's the perfect size for it's function.
My board has warped a bit, but that's always a problem here simply because of the super-dry climate. Other than that, the components are top-notch, and the box is a nice compact, and portable size.

An excellent game for couples since there's no conflict, and it's one of those games that plays wonderfully with just two.

My biggest gripe with this game is the un-inspired artwork. It needs a fix, badly, as the look of the box turns most people off from it right away.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8
Just got this, played through a 2p game tonight to familiarize myself with the rules.  Wow!  The sheer amount of replayability and variety and choice in game setup is incredible.  I bought it with On the Brink for this very reason and I'm blown away at the quality and design of this game.  I can't wait to dig in.

UPDATE: played it 10 times now with 2p and 4p.  Great game.  Lots of variety between each game due to the randomized board layout, shuffle of the deck, etc.  Crumby roles combined with a crumby shuffle tend to result in a loss, but I'm willing to chalk that up to inexperience utilizing all of the roles effectively. Very happy with this purchase.

UPDATE: Haven't really added much from On the Brink.  Just roles and events.  And only attempted In the Lab once, but found it too much and decided there's still plenty of fun to be had in the base game for now, so we shelved that expansion and have been plugging away at more or less base Pandemic.  It's a great game and we'll be playing it for years and years.  There's no rush.  And it's nice to know that there's plenty of room to grow as we get used to the game.

UPDATE: We've added Virulent Strain Epidemics and it's adding some nice flavor to the game.  We win consistently with 5 epidemics but can't seem to win with 6 very often.  

The game is still fantastic and the perfect sweet spot for weight / duration on the nights when we want to play something but we don't have the energy left to do a multi-hour brain burner.  This is concentrated middle-weight thought in a 45 minute package.  Awesome in that regard. I upped it in points to reflect just how much we've been playing it lately.


=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 4
As a cooperative game with perfect information of other players' status and semi-predictable random events, it really encourages strong personalities to dominate the game, making the other players merely their agents. The game balance requires carefully coordinated planning - encouraging analytical or experienced players to make that problem worse with detailed "advice" for less experienced players. I'm pretty bad about that myself.

Most of the loss conditions don't really feel like "failures" within the theme of the game, which some people find annoying; others continually feel they were "so close" and keep trying. (Though often those games only feel "close" because of the theme, not in terms of game mechanics.)

There is a *LOT* of randomness in the initial shuffle, though by 1/4 of the way into the game half of the randomness gets pretty predictable. I'd estimate only ~10% of the shuffles are impossible to win, but many more might only be /likely/ to be won by someone with knowledge of the draw decks (in particular which cards will be unplayable since they are near the bottom of the player draw pile).
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

RATING: 9
Excellent cooperative game with realistic theme, low random chance and challenging game play.

Pros:
+ Theme is realistic and motivating to play (everyone wants to fight diseases),
+ Components are in good quality and they look good (I liked them),
+ Game is strategic, random chance is very low as I saw it,
+ The balance of mechanics in this game is outstanding - everything seems to be balanced,
+ The easiest level is challenging enough not to win game at the first play,
+ The game is really cooperative - cannot imagine how to win it without using qualities of co-operative play,
+ The playing time is very good (about an hour),
+ While playing there is no downtime at all - all players are involved in strategy to win this game,
+ I could not found any cons in this game itself.

I won only the third match from begining (at easiest level).

RATING: N/A

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8
This is an exceptionally well crafted game. Just sitting back and watching the game system work is part of the joy of playing. The masterstroke is the way the discard pile gets shuffled and stacked on top of the deck at somewhat unpredictable intervals. That simple rule generates an amazing amount of paranoia.

With experienced players, I recommend playing with 5 epidemic cards and the infection rate boosted to start on the second space. Other ideas for increasing difficulty include (1) removing some cubes from one or two diseases, (2) requiring the eradication of one of the diseases (either a specific one or a freely-chosen one), or (3) adding the 6th epidemic card. Smaller player counts tend to make for easier games, so it's nice to have an arsenal of tweaks that can be added or subtracted.

If you want to play solo, you can of course simulate any number of players, but you can also try playing with just one character (preferably the Scientist or the Medic).
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

The level of tension that builds is what like the best about Pandemic. I tend to like most co-operative games. (but not Battlestar Galactica though)

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7
I love the theme. I really feels like a race against time to eradicate nasty, flesh-eating, puking death before it consumes the world around you.
However- this game is a puzzle, and you have to play it cooperatively. That means it has two big strikes against it: 
1. Dominating players will end up telling you what to do.

2. They are frequently right.

There is usually "one best option" to take, and if you don't do it, or maybe you didn't see it at first, the game is OVER. 
It's just OVER, and it's suddenly your fault that Aunt Minnie in Chicago died on the toilet along with half the population of North America.

Similar to Castle Panic, Forbidden Desert, Defenders of the Realm, and other cooperative games -if you don't do the "next right thing," you're toast. Or in this case, a quivering, feces soiled, vomit-covered invalid who just lost the game for everyone because you wanted to take that flight to Buenos Aries to cure the black plague. Who knew the red Captain Tripps virus was about to break out in Moscow?
We knew, you moron. 
And you didn't listen to us.

Get out.

Okay, maybe we were harsh with you, but this game does create a real sense of tension, and when outbreaks occur you almost can hear the screaming humanity.
It's difficult to win, but early on, you will win a few times - mostly because you were playing it wrong.
That happens a lot. 
There are so many house rules for Pandemic, I'm sure Z-Man games is trying to come up with a vaccine for them. It can get a little "fiddly" especially if you forget your characters power, or don't follow the outbreak rules just right. Since it is very hard to win, I think that's where all the house rules pop up. This is often the first co-op game many new players experience, and the concept of losing as a team with the game lurching to sudden halt realy surprises them. Look at everyone's reaction on Will Wheaton's table top when they loose Pandemic. Look at Morgan Webb.  
Yes, let's do that for a while.
Mmmmm. Morgan Webb.

I'd like to buy the On the Brink expansion, but I just don't get to play this game enough to justify the expense. If this is the first game you use to expose your friends to co-operatives, then explain to them about the fun of playing without actually winning. 
It may go down as less of a bitter pill when they loose.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 9
So good. A must have for anyone. A thinkers game.

RATING: 8

25+ plays, still enjoy it. Like it best with 2.

Even have the expansion as a potential buy!

RATING: 7
Mechanically a solid game but suffers from the most basic fault of a typical co-op game - the best player making the optimal plan and everyone else just playing according to it. The players have to be of a very similar skill level to play and enjoy this - inexperienced players are reduced to spectators.

With a solid group it is quite fast and enjoyable co-op.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8
My wife is not into board games, but I convinced her to watch Whil Wheaton's Tabletop edition of Pandemic and she was immediately intrigued. Now, the two of us team up and cure the world from diseases at least once or twice a week. It's easy to play and understand, and you can win as easily as you can lose. We are definitely going to pick up the expansion to help add a little more chaos into the tactics we are already mastering. I definitely recommend this game for any kind of player, especially if you want a peaceful evening thanks to the cooperative-only mechanics; no competitive hostility necessary!

RATING: 8.5

This is one of the few games (apart from the smalle card games) that get multiple plays by the same people on the same gaming night.

I play it with the expansion to keep things more interesting. Without the expansion I would rate it a 7.5

RATING: 9
Honestly, the best co-op I have found.

This comes from three things:

First, it easy to explain how the game works so even new players can make good decisions and not just get bossed around.

Second, it plays out fairly quickly, unlike, say BSG.

Third, the 'robot' of the infection deck keeps pounding on the same places, meaning that there is real tension in the game.

RATING: 9
A modern classic!  Pandemic is not as complex as the heavier games I like, but it really plays well.  Each of the characters has their own useful contribution.  There isn't one character that overpowers the rest.  There sure are a lot of ways to lose this game!  (And only one way to win)   It can be very difficult to win.  It takes luck to get a win, and any mistakes are severely punished by the game's mechanics.  It is still a fun game for beginners and families.  This one gets hauled out at Church functions, famiiy gatherings, game nights, A.A. meetings (!!!)  and almost any other setting you can think of.  Our band''s drummer took the board, peeled the top layer off and mounted it on one of those magnetic signs that you stick on the side of a car.  We played it on a bus while riding to shows, using magnets mounted into the pawns and painted magnets instead of the cubes.  It was a lot of fun!

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7
I’ve always thought that cooperative games were kind of dull, but this is a really fun one. This is an efficiency game, where you try to do as much in as little time as possible. You have to deal with immediate threats, but you also have a long term goal. The players form a team in contrary to Lord of the rings and Shadows over Camelot which feels more solitaire and try to cure the diseases. I have played several games where there has been tension to the end. It plays in a quite short amount of time, which is good. After a few plays moves become predictable and you need the expansion to stir things up.

I have played it with two, three and four (and with the expansion five) players. With two players I think it were a little easier than three, but that might depend on the pair of roles I got, but it worked otherwise equally good.

RATING: 6.5
Pandemic belongs on every true gamer's shelf. But when I look at my collection and see it sitting there, I rarely want to pull it down. I just have gotten tired over the years of the Pandemic formula of shuffling the drawn cards back into the top of the deck. I know it creates tension, but it feels gimmicky to me and when I win (or lose), it feels mostly luck driven rather than skill. I can see this one actually falling below 7 over time for me.

RATING: 9
Very interesting cooperative game that uses some elegant design elements to keep the tension high without resort to something like the Traitor in "Shadows Over Camelot."  There are multiple ways for the system to win, so there's an almost constant feeling of tension after the first couple of turns.  I'm not certain the players can win without the Medic and the Scientist in play, but more experience may tell.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 5
Ten plays. A tricky game to rate, because I think it's a good design, but one that just doesn't appeal to me. 

I like the fact that there isn't one puzzle to solve, but rather a broad situation which can be approached in different ways. I also think the mechanism for the spreading of disease is pretty ingenious, and it creates a good amount of tension; everyone holds their breath when the infection cards are turned over. 

Overall the whole package is very well done; the problem is that I just prefer games with competition. On top of that I just feel a bit bored with the whole thing nowadays. So: 5. Fans of co-op games take that with a grain of salt.

Addendum: my enjoyment of the game is heavily influenced by whether or not one player is bossing everyone else around.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 10
The one that started it all... again. Pandemic was our first modern board game and sparked the long lost love of tabletop gaming. Brilliant mechanics, cooperative play, challenging but beatable, intense but fun. We must have played this 2 or 3 times a night in the first few weeks.

Every time we choose to play now I think it's going to feel old because we've played it so much. But as soon as we're juggling treating diseases vs finding cures with our unique combination of roles (we blind pick), and under the constant threat of outbreaks, it just sucks us right back in!

And for every cruel moment there's usually a "phew, we got lucky", plus the option to dictate the difficulty makes this an absolute winner.

RATING: 7
This game builds with so much suspense that it makes immediate replay, in spite of repeated losses, fun. The action-point, variable player power, and card shuffling randomness mechanic make this game what it is. It's excellent and should stand the test of time or spawn newer revisions of its mechanics in differently-themed games, or both.

RATING: 8
Tight and difficult even with experienced co=op game players. The intensification mechanic (shuffle the discard pile and place it on top of the deck) is a very clever way to both focus attention for a given game and to provide a good degree of replayability across multiple plays.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7
I have only one game under my belt, so take all this for what it's worth.

I've played all the major co-op games on the market (Lord of the Rings, Shadows over Camelot, Battlestar Galactica, and now Pandemic). Of those games, Pandemic is probably the simplest design and the easiest to understand. This is a good thing. My friend (who brought the game) plays regularly with his children, which is a Good Thing.

At the same time, I think I prefer the linearity of Lord of the Rings over Pandemic. I think this is because I prefer the sense of handling this particular obstacle (a given board in LotR) then the firefighting of Pandemic.

I also didn't find Pandemic to be nearly as gut-wrenching as other co-ops. I don't know why. Maybe world-threatening diseases don't trip my trigger as much as destroying The One Ring or shepherding the human race to Kobol.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

RATING: N/A
e Gian
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8.5
A really interesting and very different feeling co-op game. I love how the difficulty just keeps ramping up throughout the game and the agonizing decisions about which cards to keep (especially since the cards can be used in several different ways). The effects of an epidemic card and the individualized player powers from the role cards make the game feel really thematic - honestly much more than I expected. I do feel like some of the role cards are clearly better than others, but they're all useful. The production quality is really fantastic, as well. I love the dark color scheme on the map and the transparent plastic disease cubes. The outbreak/infection markers are some of the nicest plastic tokens I've ever seen in a game.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7.5

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 3.5
They say it's a cooperative game... I say it's a solitary one. I don't see how you can play this game with someone else. I've tried it and still don't see how.

Unlike other cooperative games like Arkham Horror where you can do what you want without necessarily losing the game, Pandemic makes you go and do things. You have no freedom... well, if you do what you want, you will lose.

I also don't see what's the big fuss about this game. It's shallow and has little replayability. It's always the same thing over and over again. :/
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8
Just finished my second play of this game, and unfortunately, I think of this game in relation to Eldritch Horror (which I love). How does it stack up? Both games build tension marvelously. However, where eldritch revolves on dice rolls, Pandemic's gameplay is elegant and streamlined. This makes the game somewhat more methodical, and less of a romp, but still feels thematic as the game is simply very well designed. It is also 1/4 to 1/5 the length of Eldritch horror, and so even though the potential for memorable narratives in this game is far lower, and it manages to generate at most frustration as opposed to dread, I have to give this game the better score. This is also a difficult game. I have played Edlritch Horror 11 times and have triumphed over the warped machinations of the old gods 7 times. Of my two plays of this game I have twice been thwarted by the the lowest and most primordial of earthly life forms. Those looking for a challenge will not be disappointed. The one theme breaking element I encountered in this somewhat abstracted game, is at the end of my most recent play (2 player) all diseases were cured, 2 were eradicated, and there was one disease cube of both of the other colors left and we lost because we ran out of cards to draw. I say, give us more character cards to draw (with more interesting resources and events) even if it means also adding more epidemic cards.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8.5
An utterly gripping struggle for the fate of the human race! Players struggle to optimize their reactions to new cases of infection and outbreaks. Whenever the game proceeds without any horrid events for a while, a mixture of hope and impeding doom slowly builds up, only to give way to utter desperation the moment that yet another outbreak occurs. 

Even though both the theme and the mechanisms are somewhat abstract, they work perfectly with one another. Certainly the best abstract co-operative game! (Forbidden island by the same author employs almost all of the mechanisms of this game, and it does not come across nearly as intense as this game.)

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 10
I'm a big fan of co-operative games, and this game really ticks that box for me... probably the best of the pure co-op games in my opinion, especially considering the short duration and the intensity (when the board is loaded with disease cubes and you're 1 step away from disaster).

The card mechanisms are really interesting too.. such as the epidemic cards which come out of the players draw deck, and particularly the "intensification" of the infections, by placing the discarded cards on top of the deck after each epidemic... I love to pause at this point in the game explanation, while the realisation of this settles in.. the Ooohs and Aahhhs at this point are delightful.

Girlfriend Rating: 6
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8
I love puzzles, and Pandemic is a puzzle. Comparing Pandemic to Flash Point, as my friends do, is like comparing chess to checkers. Checkers is less elegant, clumsier, but arguably more "fun" to play. Chess is the better game, deeper and more clever and complex. Same here-- Pandemic is a cooperative puzzle game, Flash Point is basically a dungeon delve. Pandemic has a clever mechanism for seeding obstacles via the infector deck-- Flash Point is lazy and uses dice to do that. Pandemic is Braid, Flash Point is Limbo. One is a majestic marriage of clever mechanics and interesting gameplay, the other is just puzzle-by-numbers with better art and theme. If you like Munchkin instead of Agricola, then yes, Flash Point is the coop game for you. 

And as for the "quarterbacking" problem, my solution is just learn to work in groups. It's not hard.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8
Enjoyed the couple times I played this.
It seems fairly challenging to beat the system, but balanced to be within reach most of the time.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 10
A fun co-operative board game that gets everyone involved and working as a group. Nice to mix in with highly competitive games. The mechanics work well and usually very close to winning when you lose so it always feels nail biting.

The only quibbles I have with the game is its slightly fiddly stacking all the disease cubes when you have a cluster of disease, research stations and pawn pieces. Also the colour of the researcher and medic a little to similar.

Another complaint I have had players say is it can feel a little anti-climactic not having to remove all the disease cubes.

http://unpluggedgames.blogspot.com.au/2013/01/pandemic-review.html

RATING: 9
Amazing game. My wife and I have played this game many times and keep coming back to play it. We typically go through cycles of playing a game once or twice a week for about a month then will cycle through to another game. We keep coming back to this game and highly recommend it! The cooperative play / planning aspect is refreshing when compared to other strategy / economic / resource management games because typically you're working for yourself and are against the other player(s) to a certain extent, where as Pandemic you're on the same team.

RATING: 7
Pandemic is a harsh but fair mistress.  This is a game that you are likely to lose, but even though the odds are stacked against you the game feels fair and balanced.  Every loss usually comes with a "but we were so close" analysis.  It is not the hardest game in the world by any means, but it is challenging enough to keep people's attention and the wins are satisfying when they come.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8
It's Pandemic, my first Coop game. Still great and copied multiple times. This is the gateway to coop games for a lot of people. A realistic theme that appeals to everyone an adjustable difficulty. It's a great design by Leacock.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

RATING: 8.5
First game, like the theme a lot. Won with scientist and researcher, a very good combo for beginners.
Several games down the line, and still:
Not getting a 10 because little wooden cubes are boring and the cure stations are just little wooden house shape that haven't been even painted.
The game is relatively cheap (around $30), but still, these days, games should come up with better playing pieces than wooden cubes.
Difficulty not a major issue. Play at easy level with 4 epidemics, slowly increase to 5 and 6.
Otherwise, love all of it.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 10
Played a half dozen solitaire games and absolutely love it. Every game that I have played with five infection cards has come down to the wire, and I lost my first attempt at six infections with four characters by running out of yellow cubes during a chain reaction outbreak. Waiting to add On the Brink until I get 20 or 30 rounds in. This is a bit too deep for my kids, but great for solitaire and I will play with my wife and gaming group as well. I like this better than Forbidden Island as it has more interesting decisions and deeper strategy, however Forbidden Island is a good primer for this, and I will probably stick with that for play with my kids. The theme in this game is also great. It doesn't feel pasted on at all. 

Update: 20 plays in and this has become my favorite game. I love solving the basic puzzle every time - how to cure the virus with a limited number of actions. It is very basic, but depending on how it sets up and your characters it is always different. 6 epidemic cards has become the norm and I can usually win with 2-4 characters over half of the time. Also, get the On the Brink expansion if you like the base game. It adds some really cool tweaks, and the extra characters are nice.
