=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 9
I really enjoyed the cooperative nature of the game. With a group of people that can get overly competitive when playing each other, it's fun that the game receives other players frustrations. 

Pandemic manages to keep you at least slightly on edge the entire game. By the time you work your way through curing a couple of diseases, the others may be quite out of hand, which ups the excitement and certainly makes you consider how to play the game better the next time. 

The only downside I noticed was that each person has ideas on the best way to win, or even how to make a move during their turn. If there is at least 1 player with strong opinions, you may end up dealing with tension between players. But, that's a great opportunity to work on communication! 

Pandemic skillfully stresses while providing an exciting challenge for you and your friends.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7
Fun cooperative game with great mechanics to control the villain element of the game - the diseases.  The variable player powers add a lot to the game and it is genuinely cooperative, you actually work together, as opposed to games where you all work towards the same goal completely seperately. As an occasional play I think it is probably a big winner but isn't something I am going to want to play very often.

I actually think the rating will probably go down as I play it more.  The more proficient you are at maximizing the efficiency of your turn the less interesting the gameplay is going to be and unlike other games where you will butt heads with other proficient players in this one you will just be agreeing with each other on what everyone should do.  After a while the game will almost play itself and your chances of success will depend entirely on the draw of the cards and how many epidemics you are playing with.  

After many plays, it is starting to feel a little autopilot.  Still a good game but not something I want to buy.  It doesn't have a lot of depth but it is a fun game.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7.5
The first cooperative game that really turned me on to the genre.  I find the mechanic of how and where diseases break out (shuffling the discards and putting them on the TOP of the draw deck, so that outbreaks tend to happen in the same places over and over) delightfully clever.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8
Played it first with 4 players, and enjoyed it.  It uses various mechanics that are different from other games, which makes it fun to play for a change.  Reshuffling just the discard pile of the infector deck is a nice touch -- you have to watch out for what cities were already infected, because they'll be on the diseases' hit list again soon!  Also, player cards are gone forever once played, so it's not good to discard them due to hand limits.

I've played with 2 players and with 3, and it works quite well in both cases.  2 is probably hardest, because you have the least special abilities, and you can't fan out to cover the board.

I've even played with 5 players, and it can be quite hard.  There's a lot of down-time; you may have just drawn enough cards for a cure, but you have to wait for 5 Infector phases (including your own) before you can even attempt a cure.  A lot can happen in 4 draw phases and 5 Infector phases!  Outbreaks are the thing to worry about here.

I tried playing with the Epidemics just randomly shuffled into the deck instead of roughly equally spaced, and it's too easy -- if the first Epidemic shows up after half the deck is gone, then the re-infection risk for any city (and hence the risk of Outbreaks) isn't as big.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 6
I prefer 'Shadows over Camelot'

RATING: 6
We don't actually get this to the table a lot, in neither of my two and a half player groups. Either it's not confrontational enough, or it's theme is not fantastic enough. Funny is that my wife doesn't really want to play this one either. I'll have to go and play it with those friends of whom I know that they enjoy it some time.

The mechanics are neat. Particularly fun is how when you shuffle, you keep the cards you drew before on top, so you know that those troublesome herds of disease will pop up again, and soon. This does make gaming the deck a valid strategy as well of course, and maybe hurts thematic immersion a bit, but adds more strategy to the game.

What I also like is the way the difficulty levels make the game suitable for all kinds of groups.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 6.5
I like coop games, and this one lends itself well to it.  Trying to maximize the entire team's play may be overwhelming for some, who may think the other players are playing for them.  Truth is, players should make recommendations as to what they think the optimal moves are, else this may just has well be a one player game.  With this being said, I liked the game and the folks I played it with, thus I had a good experience and would play it again.

The components are nice, and the epidemic mechanic, where the discard deck is added to the top of the draw deck works great, giving the feel of an epidemic/outbreak.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

I understand that this has been the watermark for cooperative games since, I find that plays become same-y (and I don't mean this in a good way).

RATING: 2
This is the poster child game for the alpha gamer. If you like to tell everyone around the table (or be told by someone!) how to move and who to give the cards to, this is the game for you! Won't play this game again, despite all the hype.

If you are looking for similar co-op game, have a look at Defenders of the Realm. The added luck component due to dice to remove minions eliminates the alpha gamer problem: the best laid out plan can be ruined by the roll of a few dice. Also the game is much more thematic, a clear winner! Never looked back since playing Defenders of the Realm.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 9
Love this game!  Co-operative strategy game in which the players are characters with different abilities, and they have to work together in order to prevent four diseases from doing some significant damage to humanity, and causing a pandemic.

As with many co-operative games, experienced players need to be willing to step back and not take over inexperienced player's characters by only providing options during the player's turn that they would do.  It is not going to interest players if they are basically just going to have to sit back and watch the other players manage their character.  Experienced players need to allow the new players to make mistakes and possibly not end up winning the game.  Also, because there is an app for this game which allows one person to control as many characters as they want to play (up to player max) this is a tendancy that is made worse because in that situation, they really CAN do just that, and those players need to work even harder at stepping back because they often have played MANY times with MANY of the different characters and will be controlling right from the start.

That said, it is a really fun game with the right group of people, and if you have people that are experienced with it and can read others, it is an easy one to get a new player involved in since the group is working co-operatively with no betrayer and can offer up suggestions about what the person can do with their character during their turn and what the impact will be on the other players.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 10
Greatest coop game ever (except for Pandemic Legacy, which is equally great, but different)

5

RATING: 9.2
This is the king of the coop games. Very nicely made game, with great theme and cool components. The only downside is that i don't like coops. The alfa player try to solve the whole puzzle alone and this goes on all the time. I'm sorry but i'm baised and i want to make the best choices by myself. I see great replayability because every game is different and i believe this game has a great price / value. After a few more games with the right group i started to fall in love with this game. The rules are quite easy, but to beat the game is hard as hell. It is so intense, but it lets you believe that you always have a slight chance to win after all. It is so elegant and encourages clever play!

Pros / Cons:
-If you like coops, this game might be interesting to you.
-Great replayability.
-Great price / value.
-Elegant gameplay with easy rules but with deep meaningful choices.

-If you don't like coops you will start to hate them.
-The alfa will be playing alone and you will be just moving your piece on the board while at the same time moving some cubes up and down.

RATING: 10
10-11-09

I kept it at a 9 for so long because it's a little too light for my normal game group, but anytime I play with my parents, it's a blast. It's fun every time and especially with the harder difficulties, can get a lot of tension and excitement.

After getting On The Brink, I realize this is definitely one of my favorite games, well worthy of a 10.

RATING: 8
Pandemic (along with Dominion and Tales of the Arabian Nights) was my very first boardgame purchase after discovering BGG.

This is one co-op game that works really well, although I could see how more experienceed players could more or less drive the actions of less experienced players to the extent ofnon-participation. As long as people play as a team then this is a definite winner.

The theme fits perfectly, the rules are simple and the mechanic governing the spread of the various diseases is absolutely fantastic.

So far: Won one (two player), lost one (three player).  Currently my co-op game of choice. Willing to trade as it's not so popular with my regular opponents.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7.5
A coop game that has feels a lot more like Minion Hunter than LotR or Shadows Over Camelot. Fortunately, it doesn't have the crazy luck element of Minion, so winning the game is more than a pipe dream.

The five special abilities are interesting and make the characters play very differently from each other. It makes the character differences in Shadows and LotR seem like small aftertoughts. This also makes the game feel even more cooperative, since each character feels necessary.

The way the top and bottom of the infection deck are used leads itself to wonderfully thematic results, while leading to euro-like behavior.

As icing on the cake, the game plays quickly, so it can be played over lunch, and is suitable to end a gaming session.

RATING: 7

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8
““Disease is the retribution of outraged nature.” -Hosea Ballou

I found it on the interweb (not verified). I had to look Hosea up but the quote captures the moment.

GAMEPLAY
A co-operative game where the players try to stop the spread of 4 deadly diseases across the globe in the largest cities in the world. On a player’s turn, you may move around the world, halt the spread of a disease or with gathered resources cure a disease. The game works against the players, but each has a special ability to help slow the spread of the disease, move around the board faster, or more quickly find cures. A common issue with co-op games is that they can really be played by a single person. This is a fair comment and I have played it solo several times, its tons of fun. If you are playing in a group make sure that there is not a single player directing everyone, try to allow each player to have space to decide how to play so that everyone stays engaged.
COMPONENTS
The most important game pieces are the infection cubes in four different colors. I was thinking that it would be cool to have microbes of different shapes but the cubes simplicity keeps the board well organized and a quick visual sweep of the board gives a clear understanding of the crisis. The cards and board are of good quality and the art is clear but not remarkable.
THEME
An excellent unique vision for a game. Cinematic gameplay. The first time I played with my brother it felt as though we were flying around the world to hold off the infectious threat. The tension builds throughout the game as outbreaks build. Every time I have played the outcome has been extremely close. This building tension is a credit to the game mechanics and how the theme integrates extremely well with the rules.
WHO IS IT FOR?
Casual, non-competitive play is found here. With the game rushing the players towards the inevitable doom of mankind, its fairly simple gameplay will be entertaining for most. I have played solo and its fun but its designed for 2 to 4 players. Games last about an hour. This game is not heavy and there is a small amount of determinism as the card stack can prevent victory but not too often.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 5
(06/08/2009) Played it at Geekway to the West as a demo. Pretty fun, but like most co-op games can be hijacked by an experienced player.

Update (08/17/10): I don't ever see myself playing this again. Downgrading to a '5'.

RATING: 10
Had this in my collection for a while before I finally broke it out for a solo round. Before long, those solo rounds almost became a nightly activity and before even longer, got it to the family table. 

Wow! This one is about as streamlined as they come. The cooperation, actions, decision-making and options all are creative, simple and extremely engaging. Pandemic is the easiest game I have to set up and take down and can fit on my own computer desk. It is inexpensive (compared to most games) and has a tremendous theme. I'm tired of generic fantasy and dungeon-esque paper mache. I wish more games were this well-rounded and amazing. 

My only quibbles is that this can be tense, sometimes difficult to win and, most unshockingly, be an AG's stomping ground. Active participation and suggestions are key but let players decide for themselves in the end. Jus' sayin.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 9
As Wil Wheaton said at some point " i had more fun losing than game than winning it" (sic). Love the theme, reminds me a little bit of Stephen King's "The Stand" and i would like to play the "On the Brink" expansion at some point. Never won with the six epidemic cards, but almost every time  someone will cry out "let's play again, we will win this time!".

RATING: 9
Pandemic is excellent!  It is my first experience of a co-operative board game and I am rather surprised to report that it manages to be "elegant"!  Having seen people chugging through LotR and BSG before left me to wonder whether it would ever be possible to use the words "co-operative" and "elegant" in the same sentence.  It also seems to appeal to people who would not necessarily be excited by any of my other games (presumably because of the theme), which is handy.

RATING: 5
A fun game and people seem to enjoy it, but it doesn't speak to me like I hoped it would. The game, to me, is a combination of setting up a very long term strategy and executing it with occasional breaks to very short term tactical calculations. The randomness from placing the cubes on the map seems to not deliver the true variety of experience that randomness brings to other games (like the available cards in Dominion or the private hands in Agricola).

RATING: 8
A little repetitive after a fair number of plays.  However, definitely one of my favorite games, and certainly a fantastic solo game.  Recommended as a gateway game for non-gamers as well as for established gaming groups.  The game has a means of varying the difficulty, but the difficulty also varies with the number of players and the roles being played.  I would probably rate the game a bit higher if there were a bit better way of controlling the difficulty reliably across number of players and roles.  Solid theming and more tension than almost any game that I've ever played.  Strongly recommended.

RATING: 6
Starts out fun the first game. Second game still fun, but more familiar. Third game feels like more of the same.

There are not enough variables to keep this game fresh and interesting. While playing, there is usually only one, or maybe a few "optimum" choices for each player to make. And if you're the Dispatcher...woo-hoo, you get to move another player's pawn for your turn. Big fun there! Not.

Defenders of the Realm does this concept much, much better.

RATING: 9
Played this with my Mom, who is in no way a gamer or nerd. She said she had a good time, although looking back I think I made nearly (but not quite) all of the decisions in the game! But we did work together, and I do think she enjoyed spending the time with me. 

As we all know, coop games are GREAT for introducing non-gamers to board games. This game serves that purpose very well. Plus, I randomly have a lot of medical professionals in my life, so the theme is relatable! Overall I am happy with the purchase. I can tell the game can be very challenging, and you do need to strategize. Good compromise between accessibility and replayability.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: N/A
起始設置:
抽九張牌，分成三疊，放置3個、2個、1個病毒至該城市。
起始手牌  2人/4張、3人/3張、4人/2張
洗入病毒蔓延卡 4/5/6 
8個動作選4個 可以重複
移動動作:
1.一次移動1步，沿著相鄰城市
2.打出一張你想到達地點卡，直飛當地
3.打出一張你目前所在地點卡，到達任意地方
4.從研究所移動至另外研究所
5.棄掉一張目前所在地點卡，建立研究所
6.治療疾病(移除一個該地病毒方塊，若有解藥則一次移除全部)，若地圖上沒有該病毒，則該疾病免疫(翻過病毒指示物)
7.研發解藥，必須在研究所裡，打出五張城市卡研發解藥。

抽2張手牌卡
抽到病毒蔓延卡
=>感染標記往前一格
=>抽取感染卡底部牌 放置三個病毒
=>洗混感染卡，放置回感染牌庫頂部

遊戲結束:
▲如果爆發標記走到爆發軌的最後1格。
▲在放置疾病方塊時，沒有足夠的方塊可以放置。
▲在行動後無法抽2張玩家卡。
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8
This game is very engrossing! The game is difficult which just adds to the tension and excitement. That is to say, the game can be VERY difficult on the hardest setting, but since you work as a team the defeat is never taken personally. My friends are often wanting to play this which is a bonus. The only negative is there is a large luck component, but that doesn't bother me too much.

I expected more from this game. It's an easy and fast familiar game... but with too much luck factor for my taste. I was disappointed.
2015/12 No strategy, no emotion, no fun... boring gameboard. I sold it.

RATING: 7.5

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8
I like that you can scale the difficulty of this game based on the number of epidemic cards, events, and player powers. There can be lots of tension to the game which has led to some awesome moments. 

The structure of the game can cause an 'alpha' player to appear but I find that to be a great challenge of the game. It is a challenge to the other players because they need to find a way to communicate with the alpha player. And it is a challenge for the alpha player to stop playing in that manner, which can be a very valuable experience.

Also, I must recommend the On the Brink expansion for the additional role and event cards.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8.25
Pandemic is simply put one of the best gateway co-ops to date. It's easy to teach, as well having a theme everyone can understand. The game always goes over well with pretty much everyone I introduce it too. The base game will give you a decent amount of mileage before needing to worry about expansions, however On The Brink, can be bought with the base and integrated easily, since it mostly adds more roles and ups the player count to 5. 

Speaking of which the expansions  add easy-to-integrate modules that can greatly change up the gameplay for those that want more of a challenge. Great game, one that's becoming a cult classic in modern board gaming.

RATING: 8
For my money this is the best co-operative game to date, although there are too many fiddly rules and oddball mechanisms for this to really be the 'gateway' game that it ought to be given its topical theme. Whether or not you win isn't decided by how well you strategise so much as how favourably the cards come out of the random draw decks and that's set by the initial shuffle. Even as a smoke and mirrors illusion though, this is a worthwhile activity as the game racks up the tension and then teases you by letting you think you lost by a narrow margin. The 45 minute playing time is just right.

RATING: 7
Not the first cooperative game, but the one with which every other one gets compared to. Pandemic truly gives you that epic feel. Starting out at the CDC in Atlanta, you and your team travel the world with the hope of CURING all four disease outbreaks...not stopping, curing. This is a game that definitely ramps up the difficulty. Once you get a feel for how the game works in easy (which can still be tough) the following levels require real...cooperation.
This game can suffer from the 'alpha gamer.' If there is a more dominant person in the room, they usually tell everyone else what to do, rather than work together.

Though the diseases aren't named, you can't help but do so. The black disease is always the Zombie Outbreak in my house.

RATING: 6
Wow, I can't believe a co-op game without any human adversary is so challenging. I really feel like this is a '5', but despite this fact I'm almost always up for a game -- til we beat the damn thing, at least. Pandemic provides a surprisingly difficult experience without being overly frustrating (unless you draw back-to-back pandemics, then that is frustrating).

The main complaint I have is that sharing information is too clunky -- if you play without open hands, as the game rules insist, you need to ask your teammates what their hands are very frequently. It can be boring if you totally cede control of the plays to the most experienced player, but that might be what it takes to win.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 4
For all the hype and praise lavished upon Pandemic, I was underwhelmed once I had the opportunity to play it. Let's get my biggest concern out the way first -- Pandemic has a high luck factor. More so than I expected, at least. Much of the game is quite random and not affected by strategy at all. You can play a perfect game and still lose, all because of something you have absolutely no control over. If I wanted to play a game with this much randomness, I'd have played Yahtzee! What else didn't I like about the game? Well, the outbreak track is ridiculously easy to set off, by no fault or error of your own. What's the point in playing a game where I can just as easily flip a coin to determine if I win or lose? Blah... such a shame, too. I was eager to like Pandemic.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8
First played March 11th, 2008. Taught in ~10min, played in ~45min with 5 payers. Great co-opertive game with good tension. It has great luck/strategy ratio. Player work together to beat the virus'. Each player draws a role: operations expert(build a research station in current city); dispatcher(mover others pawns as your own or to another pawn); scientist(cure a disease with 4 cards instead of 5); medic(remove all cubes in one city for 1AP; administer known cure free) and researcher(may give others a card for 1AP if in same city). There are two decks in the game. 1) Infector city cards and 2) player city, special, and epedemic cards. Each players starts with a certain number of cards. On your turn you have 4APs to: move(adjacent city), flight(to/from city card in hand; discard), move from and to research station, or special actions(build research station(need card for the city you are in; discard), discover cure(discard 5 like color cards @ research station), treat disease(remove 1 cube), share knowlege(take/pass one card matching city both pawns are in). After 4APs, draw two player cards then draw two infector cards(place cubes in those cities). Players win if you treat 4 diseases, lose if you run out of player cards or 8 epedemics. I'd strongly recommend giving this purchase consideration.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8
Highly recommended. The cooperative mechanic was a great addition to our collection.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7
3/10/09
-----------------------------

[i]Pandemic[/i] is a co-operative game where the players are researchers from the Centre for Disease Control in Atlanta, and are attempting to contain the global outbreak of four deadly diseases before the world succumbs to the plague. The game supports 2-4 players, though there is a variant available for a Solitaire game. This game uses networks and a few new ingenious mechanisms to simulate the spread of disease across the globe.

In order to cure the diseases, the players need to collect sets of cards from a deck, and then turn these sets of cards in at research centres around the world. The caveat is that within the deck the players draw cards from, there are special epidemic cards, which intensify the situation on Earth, bringing the players one step closer to their destruction, of which there are three ways that it can happen. These are the players running out of cards to draw from, more than 8 outbreaks occurring, or if there is more disease on the globe than they can cope with, simulated by running out of cubes to put on the board for a specific colour of disease.

[i]Pandemic[/i] is a fun game because of the interaction between the players, and the ideas and discussion that is generated as each person decides what to do on their turn. There have been accusations of [i]Pandemic[/i] being a ‘puzzle’ rather than a game, and I agree, but it is seeing whether you can beat the puzzle with your wits that forms the heart of the game, rather than anything else.  [i]Pandemic[/i] can suffer from one person dominating the game, telling everyone what they should do, and this is a big problem, in fact, one of the main reasons why I do not rate it higher, as it can ruin the discussion that makes this game what it is. It is hard to enjoy yourself when someone, who is usually right, is dictating your every move.

In conclusion, [i]Pandemic[/i] is a game that includes many unique decisions and mechanisms within it, which give it a feel unlike any other game I have played. It is this that keeps me coming back to the game, as well as the immense replayability resulting from the different difficulty settings and variable player amounts. The only problem is the possible domination of the game by a single player, most often occurring with players of varied experience levels.

[b]Pros[/b]
- Variable difficulty levels
- Good interaction and discussion
- Requires good planning and co-ordination

[b]Cons[/b]
- Can be dominated by a single player
- Difficult to play with different expereince levels
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 6.6
Mar08: The first true coop that intrigued me enough to try.  I have to admit, the game play is just fascinating.  The idea to reshuffle the used infection cards back onto the top of the draw deck is amazing.  It's such an organic means on intensifying the infection.

The rest of the game can suffer a bit from the domineering player "you do this, you do that..." syndrome.  I'm not sure you can really avoid that in a coop.  Which is a lot of the reason I'd avoided them thus far.

Still, I've definitely been thinking about it a lot, which is the sign of a good game I suppose :)

Jun08: Wife has pointed out I'm a little too boisterous to play coop games with.  I try to reign myself in, but then it's just not fun.  In the end, just comes down to not loving coop I think.

RATING: 9
Simply put, one of my favorite games of all time. The base mechanics are solid, and open to a broad range of players. With its relative difficulty and theme, it's not usually the first game I go to in breaking in a new gamer, but it's almost always in the first 2 or 3. So long as you can avoid playing with (or being!) a table general and embrace the co-op nature of the game, Pandemic is always a good time.

RATING: 9.5
Pandemic is the first cooperative game I ever played. I always worry a bit with cooperative games because my most common cooperative partner is my wife, and there are many games she finds too tiring or complicated. 

This game is like a big, beautiful puzzle and it wears very well with multiple plays.

I love the variety of roles, the nice cards, the feel of curing a disease with a team, and the way that the game can scale up difficulty to reach simply cruel proportions.

This is a keeper and one of my all-time ten favorite games. Could not recommend more highly. Loses a very small 0.5 because I think it is just a bit too easy, even on the hardest levels.

RATING: 7.5

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8
I always get a little confused when I hear people talk about how impossible this game is while I now routinely win on the hardest difficulty. Indeed a lot of it depends on the roles that you have available, but I suspect people get too caught up in treating the diseases and not enough in curing them. While the game can still occasionally explode out with little I can do about it, I felt the need to pick up an expansion to make it harder and add the option of a bio-terrorist to mix things up.

I also always hear about how these co-op games are a problem when there is an "alpha" who dictates what everyone should do, but I have yet to come across that. Then again, it might just mean I am that person (I am being glib. I don't actually think I am like that).

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 6
I found that the game is easy to teach and quite intuitive, also the actions available on your turn are simple but offer a wide range of approaches to solve any given crisis in the game.  I enjoyed discussing tactics and potential moves with other players and it certainly encourages interaction over solitaire play.  The flip-side of this is that I can imagine it's easy for one player to wrestle control of the whole game and tell people what to do if he/she is that kind of player, which would be a shame.

Played with 2 players, this game can be quite easy but it's possible to increase the difficulty in several different ways.  My girlfriend and I love playing this together and I think it's a fun family game (despite the slightly morbid theme).

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 6.5
What a classic, important board game. You can't help but respect what Pandemic represents. And you should. It's a smart, strategic play with beautiful, well-crafted ideas & components behind it. My big issue with Pandemic is how long it takes to play vs. the enjoyment that is derived from it. There's a massive chunk of the boardgaming community that will love this brain-wracking challenge and lengthy, back-and-forth communication that is required from something like Pandemic before making decisions... Problem is, for our group, you spend so much time planning that you end up stalling all of your plays. Often there's also a few power players that direct everyone else's moves and other players start feeling inconsequential. If a few players aren't happy, the whole group's morale takes a knock. Pandemic is great with the right crowd, it's a masterpiece of a game, but it's just too heavy, lengthy and bulky for most new players. This isn't a game you can just whip out and enjoy with anybody.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 10

RATING: 9

After we are finished I always feel like playing another round. Due to the design, game rarely goes over 45 minutes, so it never feels long or boring - you are always on your toes to see whether you manage to win. The only critique is in regards to roles: some of the have obvious advantage, but others are not that easy to leverage by beginners.

RATING: 5
I'm not a big fan of this game. After about 4 or 5 plays, it's incredibly stale. The strategy is the same for every game despite any different roles or card luck, and thus the "alpha gamer"/quarterbacking problem is a BIG problem. There's not really room for any co-op. It's more of a solitaire game masquerading as a cooperative game. I have had fun when stacking the deck to make it practically impossible to win, and increasing the tension and gloom that way. But I feel even if I kept doing that it would get old again fast. Still, it's not too terrible.

EDIT: the Pandemic: In The Lab expansion vastly improves the game experience for me. I would probably rate Pandemic with In The Lab as a 7, maybe even an 8. I would not want to ever play Pandemic without that expansion.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8
I am not a big fan of co-op, not specially those with alpha-player problem, BUT this is the best of that crop, by and far ahead. 

So, if you like coops this is a tense, fun, and quite random game.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7
Pandemic - introduces co-op and some really clever mechanics not to mention its fantastic looking! So if you are looking for a game that showcases modern board gaming, this is a very good example. It has a very low entry point as most players don't need to know what they're doing at all. And role cards and random disease locations will create some variety for repeat plays. It's main problem as a gateway game is you need to be extremely deliberate about keeping new players involved in each decision or you risk them becoming passengers and not gaining a sense of achievement or ownership. Another issue is that on the one hand you have a risk of the whole group losing, which may not be very satisfying. And of course you could just set the difficulty really low, but then you might give the feeling of there not being much of a challenge. Will best suit group of similar experience or at least people who are equally confident sharing their opinion.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

My favourite co-ops are those that incorporate a potential betrayer in your midst ... check out Betrayal at House on the Hill for a great co-op. For a good lighter co-op I would highly recommend Game of the Year 2013 Hanabi.

RATING: 8

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 6.5
Cooperative game where every player has a unique character with unique capabilities that have to work together (really together, almost no mistake is allowed) in order to defeat the spreading of illness. The game is easy to explain, the idea is very good, I think that the mechanics are may be too general and can be applied to other games (forbidden island for instant, very similar), but the game is fun to play. The biggest issue that I have is that, for me, this game is, in reality, a solitaire game. The complexity is so high that, in the end, one player has to control almost everything in order to succeed.
Positive:
1. High complexity. When you win, there is a real feeling of victory
2. Easy to explain
3. The actions are easy, the difficulty lies in how to combine them
4. Quick to play and quick set up
Negative:
1. More suitable for 1 player
2. The best version, for me, is the digital one (tablet)

RATING: 8

RATING: 8

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7
Co-op:hand management:crisis management:gateway

Very thematic fast playing co-op game, maybe the quickest playtime (45 min) for a co-op to date which is one of it's biggest strengths. Group think is definitey the game, yes a domineering person can spoil this AND that can be said for any co-op, don't play co-ops with those people!  

Decisions being fairly obvious is maybe the biggest flaw, there might be a few ways to skin the cat but the overall "puzzle" really has no depth to it, there is a little planning but its more of a tactical excerise of staying on top of things and it does that very well. It is going to feel very 'samey' fast but will still be worth pulling out once in awhile, especially with non-gamers. More characters or powers could have really helped with this, maybe even a double-sided map, mini expansion to come I suppose but these should have been included.

Great tension, easy to learn and fun are all more strengths, these really make it an excellent game for gateway to hook non-gamers on games, extra points for this. The difficulty level being scalable was sure an excellent inclusion and another strength.  Of course luck of the draw plays a big factor but we are not playing this for the high strategy element anyway, we are playing for the fun aspect which is definitely here in a short game so complaints about luck aren't as big as the others. Will scale well 2 to 4 so extra points for this. 

I would seem due to the missing roles and decreased mobility less players could be harder but the cards in hand when starting are different so I'm not sure yet and have only played two 4 player games to date. 5 Epidemic cards for 2 players is a good challenge at any rate.

RATING: 8.9
Bokkensprong 15/11/2013 met Luc, An, dochter en ik. Coöperatief spel waarin je samen medicijnen moet ontwikkelen om uitbrekende virussen over de hele wereld te bestrijden. Elke speler heeft een bepaalde rol met speciale eigenschappen (vb. dokter, operationeel expert,...). Kaarten uit een trekstapel bepalen at random in welke stad er virussen uitbreken, en van welke kleur. Spelers krijgen aan het eind van hun beurt ook nieuwe stadkaarten waarmee ze kunnen reizen of acties "afkopen". Er zitten wel een aantal epidemiekaarten tussen, die voor een escalatie zorgen van virussen in een bepaalde stad en de steden daarrond. Straf spel, spannend ook; aanrader.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 9.9
Keeper
I love this game. Definitely top five game and not leaving anytime soon. I love the mechanics of this game. While it doesn't have flashy bits (just standard eurocubes), the way infections, outbreaks, and epidemics work, it feels like you are fighting an actual disease outbreak. You can clean a city but in a few turns, more cubes are will be popping back in there.

I like that you do not have to eradicate a disease, you just have to develop a treatment. I also like that, even if you find a cure for a disease, you can still lose if that disease runs rampant and you run out of cubes.

A lot to like in this box. The On the Brink expansion takes it to another level and I don't see this one getting stale anytime soon with the combinations of starting setup, special even cards, and player roles that are now available.

There is also a decent community around the game producing fan made expansions.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

A real challenge to actually defeat where luck plays a factor as much as skill and where you need to really all look together if you want to stand a chance at winning! I highly recommend this game for all!

RATING: 7
Cooperative game where diseases are springing up on the board and you have to work together to race across the globe, keeping the outbreaks under control while accumulating the cards you need to cure the diseases.  Each player has a special power, a hand of cards, and a limited number of actions per turn.  A bit like a group puzzling solving session.  Solid and challenging but a bit repetitive.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 6.5
This is excellent - a lighter team-based game than Arkham Horror, Shadows Over Camelot, etc.  If the most knowledgable player doesn't mind sitting in the background and offering tips only when called on, the easy game is great fun with non-gamers.

But it's also very solo-able - provides a great tactical challenge.

Want to see how this holds up after numerous plays.  For now, it seems like a big winner.

Update: this isn't hitting the table much anymore; Flash Point is just better.

RATING: 6
Pandemic isn't a bad game, I just tend to not enjoy the experience it provides. I dislike the process of discussing possible moves and debating which path is best. This is especially true with a group of new players - one must usually either insist on optimal moves, becoming THAT guy, or watching bad decisions doom the team.

With a group of veteran players that play with an open-mind toward finding the best solution, it can be a very enjoyable experience. The problem is that when I have a group of veteran players, I'm likely going to play something else instead.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8
A co-op game that has good strategy and is not easy.  It only holds up to 4 players, though.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 5
There's a very well designed game here. I see why others love it. Unfortunately, I don't find it particularly exciting.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7
This is the classic co-op!  If you are looking for a co-op, this is a great place to start.  The theme is incredibly accessible and the play is simple yet, ingenious.  

It is quite difficult for us to beat as a group and success seems to depend on the characters your group chooses.  Some combos seem inevitably doomed.  Nevertheless, we are learning to only concern ourselves with possible outbreaks, and not every cube that pops up on the board.

I really like this game and can't wait until it makes it to the table again.

EDIT: Score, Verbiage, Grammar

RATING: 4
Each player doesn't play a separate game.  The way to win is for all players to share information and come up with a strategy together.  If people do their own thing, the team will lose.  Thus, the game is subject to the alpha player problem.  This is really a one player game masquerading as a 4 player game.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 6.5
The game mechanism is very similar to [b][thing=15987]Arkham Horror[/thing][/b] (although the theme is much different), but in Pandemic there is more delegation and less cooperation. Everyone still works together, but it can suffer from a dictator syndrome.

I found myself getting bored with this game. You spend a lot of time reacting to the game and not making choices.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8
Another game that got a rare 7 rating from me after one play.  Actually, after 3 plays, because we played it three times the first time I played it.  Update: after those first 3 plays, it took over a year to play again.  The 4th game was in May 2009.  Once people started bringing it to CABS (and then CABS got its own copy), it became a dime (10+ plays) in 2009.  Update several years later: I've now played it a lot and I have my own copy.  I still like it a lot, but it does seem to be more susceptible to "one player dominates the game" than other cooperative games.  Especially when you play with open cards, as we do.  But if you have closed hands, players are still allowed to talk about them, so it slows the game way down as people talk about their hands to excess.  It's best with new players who don't mind a little coaching or players of roughly equal experience who aren't afraid to give as good as they get.

---------------
Well thought-out cooperative game. Players travel around the world fighting outbreaks of diseases, all the while hoping to come up with cures.

First impression: Light in terms of rules complexity, but with meaningful decisions in most turns. Player roles are good, with each one adding something important to the game. Nicely thematic game and one which I look forward to playing again.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8
Pandemic is a fun co-op game that everyone (at least that I've introduced it to) loves. I definitely enjoyed it a lot the first couple times I played it too.

Thinking about it currently though, I don't really have a desire to play. Maybe I've just been in a weird mood recently, but it has definitely dropped off my radar. The in-game chaos is definitely great, but I think that the progression gets a bit old (at least to me). I really enjoy games that throw me unpredictable twists and, while the placement of the "Outbreak!" cards are somewhat unpredictable, the "Outbreak!" system is really the only bit of randomness you find.

Objectively, I can recognize that I may end up revisiting this game in a year or so, praising it for the exact reason I'm currently knocking it. However, I'm currently looking for a really expansive, complex experience (definitely not the point of Pandemic), and I think it's making me unnecessarily hard on Pandemic since I'm holding it to the standards of this yet undiscovered game.

Sorry for the ramble there though. Pandemic is a great game for just about anyone, I can recognize that for sure. It's also why I rated it an 8 and am sitting here getting frustrated with it. If you don't own it, get it. It's absolutely worth having on hand.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

RATING: 3
2012-05-03

Initial Rating: 6.0 (August 2011)

I like Cooperative games and the theme of Pandemic is so awesome I had no doubt I would enjoy the game. However that was not the case. I cannot say it is a bad game but I had higher expectations. For me, although the game can be very hard to beat, it still feels like a light game and a long one for what it offers.

Perhaps it is too random for my taste,  I feel no real strategy as you only react and react from the cards themselves. I´m not sure why but I don’t particularly enjoy the game, I feel Pandemic is overrated.

On the good side it is a good family game as the rules are easy to explain and have excellent player aids. 

As many friends like it, I will play again but it is not a game I will actively seek out.

Current Rating: 6.0
[hr]
2013-02-28

After another game, I’m downgrading its rating so it matches the BGG rating system with my feelings for the game. Pandemic is a game that I never want to play, but I can be convinced on occasion, so it is now a 4.5 for me. I feel there is no real strategy and the game has more uncontrollable luck that I’m comfortable with. 

There is one caveat though, I’m interested in trying the Bio Terrorist variant. 

Current Rating: 4.5
[hr]
VERY boring game, the decisions are obvious 90% of the time, zero strategy. I don’t want to play this ever again so I’m rating it accordingly. Will only play with the Bio Terrorist variant. 

Current Rating: 3.0
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8
Definitely glad I got this one. Almost a whim... walking past a game shop and "oh yeah Pandemic might be out at last (Australia) and I think people on BGG were saying good things about that one."

The variety and tension seem well woven. This is a very engaging cooperative game.

My wife and I have had several two player games of Pandemic now, and have succeeded each time to avert global disaster. (The Operations Specialist has come up for us every time and has been extremely useful.)

We've also had a three player game with my sister's non-gaming feller, and he loved it.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7
Tense and quick.  The 45-minute timeframe was previously underserved by cooperative games.  The infection deck reseeding is plain brilliant.

The positives:  different random setups and role selections make each game a new experience.  Difficulty is easily scaled to provide a challenge for experienced and new players alike (though possibly not at the same time).

The negatives:  4-player is much, much tougher than 2-player, which is unfortunate because often the table fills.  Sometimes you get a shuffle that just isn't possible to beat.

In the end I'm sold on Pandemic, at least with 2 or 3 players.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

My Intro to co-ops and still tons of fun in my book. So many games go right down to the last couple of cards. Terrific tension.

RATING: 8
My wife and I really enjoy this game. We have only played 2-player at this stage, and feel quite content with it. Easy is just that, fairly easy. Normal really provides a challenge, I don't think we have ever beat it completely following the rules (our first few attempts we unknowingly neglected some rules) and we have yet to attempt Hard.

I've also played this solitaire, and it still provides a good challenge. Really enjoy the game and the concept. Bought Defenders of the Realm simply because we enjoy the mechanic so much. Rate 8.5 because while I'm almost always willing for a game, I can't say I'm ALWAYS willing. Darn near close though.

Good Game, Play Again. (GG, PA)

RATING: 9.5
What good coop game. Its refined, simple and best of all its the kind of game that gives you the sense of building up stress giving you a great feeling of urgency. You never know if you`ll win or not till the end since alot of things can happen that will turn the game around  in a down hill spiral if you dont stop it fast enough.To get the most out of this beautiful game play with people that will be able to concentrate on the game this is not a game that you can talk the whole time about other stuff. You need to have team work and organization and please if your playing with a bunch of people who are new to the game let them think for them selves and dont take over.

RATING: 7.5
No game makes my stomach hurt more...we usually get down to the last few cards and just barely win.  I love the co-op play and shared victory feel.  A shared defeat is OK too.  That just makes us want to try again.  Great conversations come out of the Pandemic experience.  This is one game I wish had a bigger box! 

Own On the Brink and In the Lab.  My rating for Pandemic includes those expansions (minus the Bio-terrorist because we haven't tried that yet).  We love the added roles and special events.  In the Lab is a nail-biting different kind of puzzle.  Also own the role cards from Geekstore.

Update 9-5-16:  We now own 3 sets of Pandemic and On the Brink so we can have Pandemic parties with multiple tables.  It is hilarious as the tables shout back and forth how well the are (or aren't) doing!

RATING: 6
Tense, fun co-operative game. Two plays only, but easily as good as Shadows over Camelot and Lord of the Rings (the two other co-op games in my collection). Less chrome, too.

Players have to work together to win, making the most of the special abilities and the cards held by the group. Play it as a concurrent series of solo games and you'll be toast.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8
2012-08-06 - Pandemic is a great game that is accessible to kids maybe eight to ten and older.  Almost every game has tension in it as you balance the management of regional outbreaks against compiling the cards for a cure.  The one weakness is that an A-type personality can take over the game and dictate play.

RATING: 9

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 6
Well we ended up playing this game 9 times in one setting!  There were four of us for the first 4 games or so then we ended up adding a fifth for the remaining games.  None of us had ever played it before.  The game overall is pretty easy to pick up...think I read the manual twice and had about 90% of the game down (looked over some subtle nuances).  Probably took the rest of the group 10-15 minutes to get a good grasp of the rules and I'd say by the end of the second or thrid game anyone at the table could have taught the game with ease.  

In terms of playing we went 0-9.  I think the first three maybe four tries everyone was really into it and having a good time.  After that though I think some of the guys started to get a little pissed off at the fact that they were getting their asses handed to them by the board game and insisted on playing another game to try and save a little pride.  In the end though our efforts were fruitless and the game prevailed everytime.

For me though overall I had a great time playing in all 9 games.  The game played out quick and rules were simple enough and you really believe the first few rounds that everything is good...or that you have a fighting chance.  But I will say things sprial out of control real quick.  

I strongly recommend that people new to the game play out the introductory lvl at least once if not a couple of times before progressing.  Part of our problem was that we progressed to the heroic after the first game and of course the heroic lvl is as advertised...quite diffcult!

On a final note this game probably won't make our weekly gaming rotation mostly due to the fact that it is a co-op game.  It provides a nice change of pace for the group but we tend to be more competative with each other (I guess I mean to say that we get to much satisfaction out of kicking each others' asses).  That said though I'm sure we'll sneak it in a time or two a month!  

**Edit** Played this with the wife and she seemed intrigued with it...got multiple plays in...also the gaming group was interested in playing again...going to bump this up a little to an 8

***Edit***  Has grown a bit stale.  Suffers from a dominant person or two suggesting all the moves.  Haven't played with the expansion yet so would like to try it. Bumped down to a 6 which is probably were it will stay.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 9
There is something about Pandemic that I can't stop recommending about to non-gamers.

Maybe it's because for a hobby game, it is widely available. Or maybe that it has many modern designs. Perhaps that the playing time is low? But I think the main reason is that when I mention that we are all cooperatively working together to fight diseases to find a cure. People get interested. After years of exposure to classic games like monopoly, life and chutes & ladders, people minds are blown to find that they are not competing with each other, but with one another.

This is an essential and a mainstay in my collection.

RATING: 3
Not very enjoyable. The biggest problem is lack of individual responsibility. New players feel like middlemen, just moving their pawn as the other players command. If you play with anyone even slightly controlling, or even just quicker to arrive at a conclusion, you might as well not even be at the table. The cooperation part of the game sounds great on paper, but in practice, it's somewhat alienating. One person could play the whole game themselves and it'd work out just fine.

RATING: 9
Very nice co-op filler.  The playtime of an hour is GREAT.  The roles, I feel, are balanced and the game is difficult to win (as a co-op should be).  Of course, there is a significant luck factor, but because the entire group is in it, it's ok to lose.  Compared to other meatier (and much longer) co-ops, this one is now my favorite simply because of the non-stop discussion this game demands.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 9
One Year Update:

Played a few games when I first recieved Pandemic. Initail impression was absolute Positive. The game board and pieces are great. The differnt roles are all playable. Easy set up. Play flows smoothly. Plenty of interaction with fellow players. Well suited for solo play also. A big plus for me. Games are all tense and fast paced. Games last as little as 20 minutes up to almost an hour if explaining game to new players, that I seem to do often. Not many of my friends and family have ever played a co op game. 

Once I played Pandemic, I quickly ordered the expansion "On the Brink". More roles and a mutant disease, Yeah!. Also included is different Epidemic cards. Has cute petry dish to keep the different cubes in. The box is now cramp and needs to be larger now.

Said that I would get the three homemade decks from Artscow. On order as I type, one year later.

I did not play too much over the past year with Pandemic, because I was collecting way too many games. Now I have purchased almost all of the games I wanted and starting to replay past games bought. Pandemic being the first.

Still a great game. A perfect 9. 

------------initial reveiw below-------

Lives up to expectations. Incredible play. Will buy the expansion. Will buy from artscow the 3 decks that another BGG user created. Will play at the drop of a hat.

RATING: N/A
****On indefinite loan to family in Oklahoma****

[b][url=http://www.spieldesjahres.de/cms/front_content.php?idcat=8]2009 Spiel des Jahres Nominee[/url][/b]

In Pandemic, several virulent diseases have broken out simultaneously all over the world! The players are disease-fighting specialists whose mission is to treat disease hotspots while researching cures for each of four plagues before they get out of hand.

Players:   2, 3, 4
Time:      45 min
Mechanics:  [property=2001][/property], [property=2023][/property], [property=2040][/property], [property=2078][/property], [property=2004][/property], [property=2015][/property]

RATING: 6
Pandemic is certainly the quintessential cooperative game, but that just isn't a genre that excites me. Its merits are that it forces you to work together and is extremely challenging. RATING: 9

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 10
The best co-op game in our collection, hands down!

Placing the shuffled Infection Discard pile on top of the remaining Infection Draw pile adds quite a bit of angst to this game by giving the appearance of a relentless repeat epidemic in previously infected cities.  I like the option of determining game level during set-up with the player Draw pile too.  At the moment we're having quite a bit of fun with this, both as 2 & 3-player games.   

Expansion owned:
Pandemic: On the Brink

RATING: 10

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 10
Cooperative play stepped forward with this game, as you and your fellow players race against the deck and geography to prevent the world from being overrun with disease. Normal level is hard, and hard level is insane. It's intense, it's cooperative, it's hard to win... and it gets you to want more.

BIG PLUS: intensity, level of challenge
PLUS: ease of learning the game, geography use
MINUS: can get frustrating over time or you move on to other games

HUGE PLUS: there's an iOS version that equals the challenge

RATING: 5

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 6
A quick co-operative game where the team attempts to cure diseases. The stacked decks allow you to know approximately how many turns you can play before an epidemic which causes a city to have 3 disease cubes placed on it. The discarded infection cards are then shuffled and all put back on top of the infection deck. As a result of this it feels like a race to solve the games puzzle more so than the other co-op games I've played (Lord of the Rings and Shadows Over Camelot).

RATING: 8
My first co-op experience, back in 2008 and I think the first game that started the whole craze of publishing co-op games. Still a great game for families and for gamers, as the difficulty can be easily scaled with the pandemic cards. The game always delivers a good tension as plenty of bad stuff happens and players try to think and work together to solve the puzzle of saving the world from a pandemic disaster.

Big thumbs down for Z-man and their [url=http://boardgamegeek.com/thread/1041390/lab-component-vs-1st-edition-components]design choice[/url] of leaving first edition owners in the cold with their release of [url=http://boardgamegeek.com/boardgameexpansion/137136/pandemic-lab]Pandemic: In the Lab[/url].

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7.5
Very good co-op game, with the usual strengths and weaknesses but the big advantage that it plays pretty quick.  A very good challenge which rewards further plays - the correct strategies are not obvious and the different combinations of roles really change the game.  Much better when you play with people of roughly the same experience, otherwise the most experienced player will dominate.  It IS good fun!
Update:  more plays now ... Pandemic definitely suffers LESS from the usual co-op problem of one player telling everyone else what to do.  Played a lot of LOTR co-op recently and it suffers much more from this problem, simply because its very important to know what challenges are coming up.  Pandemic is simple and discussions of tactics are pretty inclusive.  Note that it is easy to alter the difficulty level by changing the number of epidemics.
Update again:  you can play this with cards revealed but you are not allowed to talk about tactics unless you are either in the same city OR spend an action (make a phone call).  Works pretty well.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

Pretty tense game, when you win it's always by a thread but when you lose you're often destroyed. Fun but be careful that everybody is playing evenly.

RATING: 7
Everyone will like this game.  Thematic, tense, and co-op.

If you play games regularly, or are just a smart group, use all 6 Epidemic cards, or it will be way too easy.  The first game will feel close, but after that, you'll lose tension.  This game needs to be hard to stay fun.

My favorite Co-op.  Although I did not appreciate "In the Lab", the additional roles were worth the money.  With a few additional characters from any other expansion makes a good game even better.  
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 9
Rated a 10 with 25+ plays (12/23/08). This is the only co-op game that allows for real teamwork, has almost zero downtime, provides lots of tough choices, and has enough built-in variability to be played again and again. An initial double-header of this is almost mandatory. Pandemic also affords some of the best two-player gaming with experienced players. 

One of the things the rulebook sort of glosses over is that player-number impacts the difficulty nearly as much as epidemic number (with 2-players being easiest). Lately my girlfriend and I have moved onto 2P6E (2-player, 6 Epidemics). We're doing fairly well. I still think my favorite way to play Pandemic is 3P5E. I've tried 3P6E, and even with clear boons of luck from the deck, it usually ends in disaster. It's been 40 or so games since I last tried though. I rarely play with four (I'd much rather play Space Alert if there are four of us), but if I do I usually keep it to 4 epidemics. More often than not, the major threat in 4P4E is running out of time. Because the cards are split four ways, I feel like the luck of the draw (cure sets) has a somewhat higher impact. Every now and then it's fun to play 5P5E (not actually "allowed" in the rules). You need that extra epidemic to make up for the fact that you have every advantage at your disposal.  

Update: An incredible game, but it's so playable and accessible and innovative and fun that it is possible to eventually 'play it out.' I'm still a big fan, but play rarely. I can't imagine downgrading it below a 9, though, having played 150 times. I'm not the one suggesting this anymore, but if an enthusiastic new player wanted me on the team, I'd be there in a heartbeat. 
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8
My family has had a lot of fun with this game. My youngest daughter (12yo), who is only an occasional gamer, will suggest this game on her own. We find it to be a challenging game but will start new games over and over even after horrible losses.

RATING: 9

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8
This is a great game for the kids and I. Move around to various cities collecting cubes that represent diseases. Then collect cards that match the disease color to cure the disease. Players take on various roles with special abilities. Even at 7 and 8 they can contribute something to the strategy. My 8 year old always wants to play the medic. This character does seem to shift the game balance slightly  in our favor. We had a streak of several close losses, so I looked up more strategies on BGG. I think the following helped. After an epidemic stack any threes into a pyramid. They are more likely to outbreak sooner than a newly created three. Put research stations near regions that have the most infections. Do not discard more than four cards of a single color. We had our best game ever following these rules.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

RATING: 7

And the game cost twice as much. But I do like the game. I'm hoping to get On the Brink and maybe that will add a little more depth to push it farther from Forbidden Island.

RATING: 7.5
The only cooperative game I own so far, and I love it. There can be a bit of over-powering depending on who you play with, but I've gotten adept at shutting that down. It's such a well thought-out game and the theme fits the mechanisms perfectly. And it can really be challenging, which is important to me in a cooperative game. When you win, it really feels like an achievement, but when you lose, you really feel like you messed it up, which makes you want to go back for another. Great game.

Unfortunately, even with perfect play, some games just cannot be won, which I think is a fault in the design.

RATING: 8
I have only played this game solo {playing 2 roles at a time} I won on my 4th play. This is an excellent solo game and I'm sure just as good as a multi-player game. It plays very fast which is a big plus for me and does a decent job simulating it's theme. It is luck driven with the cards but you really have to think your moves out so hand management is crucial. Still, a bad mix of player cards and an equally bad mix of infection cards will almost guarantee a loss. The other cool thing is a built in difficulty level so if you find yourself winning to often on easy bump it up a level.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7.8
Number of players: 2-5

Components: (8)
They're simple but work wonderfully. The diseases are represented by wooden cubes. The cards are high quality. All the artwork is simple, but looks nice.
  
Rules: (10)
The rules are well written and easy for everyone to understand. 

Setup: (10)
The set up is easy enough as long as you make sure to shuffle all the cards very well. You'll deal a certain number of cards to each player, then deal out cards to place initial diseases on the board.

Area required to play: (10)
Most everything will fit on the board. You will need a little area to set the diseases that are not yet in play. Every player will hold a hand of cards.
 
Fun: (9)
This is really one of my favorite games. It's the first co-op that I ever played, and I wasn't sure that I would like playing against the game as much as I enjoy playing against other people. I sure did like it, though!

Theme Integration / Mechanics: (8)
This game is about diseases spreading across the globe and the players desperate attempt to cure and eliminate them. I think the theme is wonderful and the mechanics work for the theme. It's mostly skipping around the board to various locations to avoid outbreaks with an emphasis on hand management and set collection. You're not very aware of that when you're playing, though. You're thinking about how to cure those terrible diseases.

Replay Value: (7)
I never tire of this game. If you do (I don't know how) add in On the Brink and play it again!

Storage: (6)
I made tuck-boxes for the cards, which helped. Also, On the Brink adds trays for the diseases while is a plus. Without these things, storage for the game isn't the best. When you buy On the Brink, you'll have two boxes. The components from the expansion will not all fit back in the base box.

Accessibility: (10)
This game is super easy to teach and enough fun to keep everyone engaged.

Over-All/Bonuses/Biases:
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7
A coop game where players are trying to save the world from 4 deadly viruses. Its a good and surprisingly simple game which almost anyone can pick-up easily. The mechanics are streamlined and the epidemic and outbreak system is well implemented.

Unfortunately the simplicity of the game means that it lacks flavor. There is no distinguishing factor for the diseases. They all act the same way and have no names. And because of that, I don't see this game having much replayability.

In short, a fun family game but one which will probably not really appeal to hardcore gamers.

RATING: 9

I don't see that this game solves either problem.  On the other hand, it is fairly short, and it has some interesting elements.

After 15 plays in two days, I upgraded the ratings to an 8.  It is addictive, my wife wants to play over and over again, and it poses some interesting logistical problems.

After 200+ plays.  I upgraded the ratings to a 9.  It is a great solitaire puzzle.  Besides playing over 200 games with my wife, I have probably played more than 200 with the Pandemic iOS app.

That said, Pandemic is short enough that I'll participate if others really want to play it. I'll never suggest it though.

RATING: 9
A solid, solid coop, just deep enough to sink our teeth in it, and just simple enough that we can focus on the puzzle, rather than the rules. A challenge, and a cool experience. As Zee Garcia says, the best part of the game is that moment at the end where we all stop, and go "if you do this and this and that and this, and then I do this and go there and cure twice, and then...", and then someone goes "no, if you do that we'll run out of card", and then someone goes "oh, but I have this special card!". It's a great puzzle to solve as a team.

RATING: 8.5
I really like Pandemic as a piece of design and as an experience, though I have to repeat the warning that is standard with the game: Pandemic is supremely enjoyable with an evenly matched set of players, but can be deeply unenjoyable if one player runs the show.

I was that one player in a game with my partner and a few others, and now she strongly dislikes the game because she didn't feel free to act and decide and think for herself—which is completely understandable, and I feel awful for having ruined the game for her.

So, yes—fair warning. Play with people of about your skill level, and if you feel yourself turning into a quarterback, for the love of gaming and keeping people interested, hold yourself back.

RATING: 9

We loved it so much that we have added all the expansions so we can pick, choose, and combine what game types we want to play.  We even have the custom box from Broken Token to store it all.  We play this game at least a couple of times a week and looking forward to our next challenge with Pandemic Legacy.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 9.5
The rules are simple, concise and clear, with few if any ambiguities. Game play is fluid, and there is considerable interaction between the players with the right group. There is one way to win and there are 3 ways to lose the game, and each of the 3 seems to occur with roughly equal frequency, which means that players must pay attention to three different countdowns. It's agreeably hard to beat, and the level of difficulty is easily adjusted to the level of experience of the players. 

The mechanics - in particular the mechanism for intensifying threat - are familiar from Forbidden Island, but better implemented with a cascade mechanism that adds a little piquancy to the game.

The game is vulnerable to the alpha gamer, and there are no individual goals that might have mitigated that. In the groups I've played with this has not been an issue, so it may be more theoretical than real. 

While the cards and the jewel-like viruses are excellent, I'm less keen on the bland anonymous pawns, some of whose colours are difficult to distinguish in low light. I've replaced mine with small figurines that make it easier for players to find their avatar easily on the board. 

I would recommend this game without reservation to anyone new to boardgames.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 5
After a bunch of plays, I have to conclude I don't like Pandemic. It was OK at first when both myself and my partner were getting to know it, but it was all downhill after we both decided we knew best what the next move was. 

I listened to Tom Vasel's podcast extolling this sort of game last year, in which he suggested that players who don't like take orders should just develop a stronger personality, but you can't win this without extensive discussion and strategy sessions. And in those, you're going to take orders a lot of the time, or issue them. You might talk and talk and talk everything out, but that gets boring and eventually someone has to make a call. Simple as that. 

I think I just hate games that have subordinates built into the rules. I don't play games so that I can outsource my already meagre decision-making capacity to others. 

This is ingenious and fun and an innovative, interesting design - but only insofar as everyone agrees, and as soon as that stops happening, prepare to be either bored or angry.

The board is about a 3, though. The cards are substantial, which helps, but the colors of the pieces don't really match those of the roles. Plus, that sunburst graphic, and the silly looking Hairy Virus around the title? If you're going to put out board games, spend more than half an hour learning how to handle photoshop, eh?

But hey, it set me back £24.99. Not bad.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8
Also own the On the Brink expansion.  Only play the game with the expansion (varying portions of it).

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 9
This is my first board game. I played this at a rpg convention and my eyes opened to the board game scene. It has been 3 years since then and I love playing games more than ever. In this game the tension is growing slowly and then when an epidemic card is drawn it is just a matter of time before outbreaks happen and the game gets out of control. I love the asymmetric tension this mechanic provides. Other than that the hand management aspect is fine but nothing revolutionary. I also like the fact that every character has a fun special ability, when you are the medic you feel good if you clean 3 cubes with an action. Overall, I really like this game and recommend it to people starting their collections and looking for a good filler.

RATING: 5

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 6
This game sorta suffers like Castle Panic...  Although harder, it is still a co-op game with a lot of dictation.  It "is" fun, but just not as fun as competitive play.  There are a lot of things I like, but I feel it is mostly in spite of the things I don't.

I've only played this game with the expansion, but since I only use the pawns and new role cards from the expansion, I don't really consider playing the old game with it because nothing has changed.

I LOVE the roles and the powers they provide.  I love the research centers and the teamwork needed to do spread and conquer.  Still, what I don't like is the lack of satisfaction and climax at the end of the game.

When you win, you feel like you should high five everyone around the table, but it really doesn't come up...  I like the game from the components to the theme, but it just misses the flare when you actually get INTO the game...

I personally think this game by itself should be a 7 at least...  Making it a solid game I would play but not suggest.  However, because of this game and the lack of excitement I get out of it, it has put me off from buying Defenders of the Realm because of it...  I've been eyeing that game for a while and am saddened by this experience so much I've decided to hold off on that purchase and its expansion for the time being...

Seeing as how this game is a more advanced co-op game, I was hoping it would push me TOWARDS a purchase of Defenders of the Realm...  However, because it did the exact opposite, I have to score it a point less at 6 because it has pretty much turned me away from the co-op genre at least for now...
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

Game is super fun at first but due to lack of complexity replay value is just not there compared to other games.

RATING: 7

RATING: 6.6
The theme and mechanics work extremely well together.

I feel like this jump-started the cooperative genre again. However, it doesn't do a good enough job of overcoming the cooperative problem of "the best strategy is to have a single player call all the shots." It tries to fix this by limiting information transfer (other players shouldn't know what cards you have), but this limiting rule is followed with varying degrees of dismissal, depending on the gaming group.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

I wanted to bump up the rating since the last game we narrowly won was exciting, but I can't help but think that I would want the opposite had we lost.

RATING: 3
Player's ability to win isn't determine by how well they play but by the randomness of the card draws. Poor performance can lose the players the game, but winning is pure luck.

This is a common "mechanic" in nearly every coop game, but pandemic feels worse than most.

RATING: 8.5
This is a great "family" game, in a sense... it's not as light as a party game - there's plenty of strategy.  And the rules aren't as easy to explain as say, Ticket to Ride - but it is a pretty simple game to play.  That is NOT to say it's easy!  It's very hard.  The theme and mechanics work really well together, and it's a lot of fun.  Recommended!

Update:  Many, many plays now.  Kind of flat, and tends to be like a 1 player game that is played by committee.

Update:  After playing many other coops, Pandemic is still the best.

RATING: 9

Components are very nice. This game is also a big challenge to win. Great tension as you draw cards to see if another outbreak has occurred !

The Bad: My board is warped. It may be that the strategy will wear thin after a few games, but even if this happens, it is so much fun I suspect I would contine playing.

RATING: 7
Initial rating based on solitaire play to learn rules.

Purchased as a gateway game primarily to interest my wife (an epidemioligist) in playing something other than Cranium and Scrabble.  There's a very nice balance between mechanics and theme. The game seems to be very finely balanced to provide a good challenge with the increasing rates of infections as epidemics come up and the players' abilities to find cures.  Each turn provides players with many choices, and with the random spread of diseases and special events it looks like each game will play differently.

RATING: 8
I don't know how to comment on this game. If I had never played Shadows over Camelot, I would think this is brilliant. It still is, but at the same time it borrows so heavily from SoC that it is hard to consider it all that original. It has some real plusses by comparison -- it is much easier to explain to a new player, and it has essentially the same game experience in a shorter timeframe. On the other hand, it's pretty bland to look at and I never would have tried it if someone else hadn't brought it to game night.

Further plays have actually increased my opinion and enjoyment of the game, even though I think the outcome is primarily decided by the card draws.
