=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7
After all these years I'm still torn on my opinion of Pandemic.  On one hand I cannot like it that much as I've sought out many a replacement be it Defenders of the Realm or even something like Zombie State.  In the end though I've lost interest in those alternatives while still not disliking Pandemic.  I think perhaps my issue is in not having liked Pandemic quite enough to have explored the expansions to which I hear the On the Brink one can be considered quite essential.  Perhaps it didn't exist back when I played it with others who were far bigger fans (and perhaps we suffered too much from Alpha Gamers bossing us around at the time!).

I do know that the base game by itself I don't really prefer vs. Forbidden Desert which also has similar role cards and cooperative mechanics.  My wife also finds the theme of Pandemic very morbid while our son tolerates it when I explain it differently.  I do prefer certain things about Pandemic in the way outbreaks occur and are managed but, at least in the 3 player game, we've found it hard to eradicate a cured virus altogether such that it almost seems not worth the effort.

Overall I think there is now a permanent place for it in our collection though, along with Pandemic Lite (Forbidden Desert) and a Pandemic Thematic (Currently looking at Defenders of the Last Stand).  So I'm hoping to think more highly of Pandemic once I acquire some expansions and view it as more of an Advanced Game version.

Odd to find a place for 3 different versions of the same game in a collection when none of them are particularly my favorite but I guess over time the pandemic sort of gameplay has become not unlike worker placement or deck building or something like that which is easily something you'd have a few different versions of even if not quite your favorite thing.

I really like the new box cover art for the entire Pandemic series.  Nice job there.  The current editions bits looks really great as well and the card quality is perfect.  I think that might have helped my opinion of the game a little bit.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7
Played twice, lost twice but in the second go we were doing better than the first, which I think shows we were getting a grip on strategy.

As a four player co-operative game it is basically a solo game which is split up for multi-player.

There is a lot of luck in the shuffle and draw of the cards but it plays pretty fast so you can try again quickly.

There is a fun dimension to co-operative games as you have to decide strategy by argument and persuasion.

We won our last game. I think we were fairly lucky with the cards.

RATING: 10
An excellent game that captures its theme very well.  Players work together to cure all four major diseases before they destroy the world's population.  Pandemic is very challenging but still fun, and can accomodate from 1-4 players.  There is a nice balance between the different abilities, and the infection mechanic is just brilliant.  It's also highly replayable and quick, usually finishing in around 20-35 minutes.  It's the best game of 2008, and one of my only perfect 10's!

:star::star::star::nostar::nostar::nostar::nostar::nostar::nostar::nostar: [b]5 plays June 2013[/b]

I played this few times with different groups of players but it never worked well. This game allowed me to realize that I don't like multiplayer co-op games at all. To me, co-op games are just dull as I feel like I'm just watching somebody else is playing or I'm playing and there is someone always tells me what to do next. In addition, my wife is also extremely against this game so this will never be played in my house.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 6
Pandemic isn't a bad game at all. The board is great, as usual with a Z-Man game. I just found that this game had some problems. First, each character is a one-trick pony, which makes gameplay repetitious. As with most co-op games, there really isn't much to it. It's a matter of bean-counting and lucky draws. And on top of that there is one fatal flaw: the most experienced player tends to dominate the game, telling everyone else what they need to do. This minimizes its enjoyment, even as a co-op game.

RATING: 10
Great game to introduce people to games with. Great with expansions to play with gamers. In the lab is great.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7
Generally I like cooperative games and Pandemic is one of my favorites.  Though the difficulty level is adjustable, I find its normal play perfectly balanced. Typically my group wins narrowly, but we have recorded a loss or two, which is just enough to keep us humble. 

Word of advice, Pandemic does not play well with all groups, much like any cooperative game. This game relies on interaction and communication among the players. Each person should be invested in trying to win. Passive players, quiet players, and players who have only a half interest in playing will dull the experience.  Don't play this game with those people.  Otherwise, you will be playing for both of you.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: N/A
Community: Best with 4 players

[b]My thoughts[/b]: Not the kind of game you want to play more than 2-3 times in a row, especially after playing it 20+ times this summer, it kind of loses its wow factor; losing over and over sucks when you can't do anything about it.

RATING: N/A
cesco
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8
It's a modern classic for a reason. This coop was groundbreaking in its challenging but still streamlined and quite intuitive mechanics.
The best parts are probably:
* The outbreak mechanic, which has been copied by numerous other coops.
* The way epidemics work is ingenious (in an evil way).
* How powerful the different roles are, and how well they work in combination.
For four newbies it didn't feel that easy even with just four epidemic cards, but I guess it'll get better with experience.
[Tabletop]
{CHMM}

RATING: 6
First cooperative play game I've tried and I liked it!  We won one and lost one on the "regular" setting (5 epidemic cards).  There is some tension in the game as there is usually more things to do then you have actions.  Replayability is good due to different starting situations for each game.  The reinfection mechanic of shuffling the discards and placing them on top of the draw pile is something I hadn't seen before and integrates the theme nicely.  For a challenge play with more players and higher difficulty level.

RATING: 9
Classic co-op
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 10
No of players: solo/2
Co-operative game that sets (right from the beginning) bar really high in this genre.
By using clever mechanisms for changing pace between good, bad and ugly situation on the board, it still gives player filling that nothing is lost until the end.
Instead of just going downhill from one point, it is more like roller coaster all the time. 
More often than not, you'll be in situation to say: "We needed just one more turn, that's all". 
Different roles, event/epidemic/city cards almost ask you to push your luck to the very limit in combination with smart tactic decisions.
Excellent game.
(2015-12-27)
----------------------------------             

For me it is ultimate solo experience. Fantastic game, my personal number 1 and one of the rare games I simply refuse to play cooperatively (it's just a personal preference, for me it feels like a puzzle I want to solve alone). It takes me between 30-45 minutes (with setup) to play full game controlling 3 or 4 characters (with 6 pandemic cards) which is additional plus.

RATING: 8
A cooperative game where the players work together to find cures to four rampantly spreading diseases before the world is overwhelmed. 

This game definitely has some luck in it but for such a quick game it offers an impressive mix of opportunities for long term planning, short term tactics, risk taking and cooperative play. My wife and I really enjoy this best as a two player game where we can work together to solve a problem and save the world. It is also good with more players (so long as you don’t have a dominant personality making everyone’s decisions).

RATING: 7
[PL]
Bardzo dobra optymalizacyjno-kooperacyjna gra planszowa :).

Świetny mechanizm wybuchania epidemii połączony z koniecznością przewidywania przez graczy, co najgorszego może się wydarzyć. Wbrew pozorom bardzo klimatyczna.

Niestety silnie występuje problem "lidera", gdzie jeden z graczy przejmuje rolę głównodowodzącego i narzuca innym graczom, co powinni robić. Jednak jeżeli gracze mają choć odrobinę chęci do kooperacji to gra się przyjemnie i wszyscy się skupiają nad tym, czy nic nie zostało przeoczone w próbach zwalczania światowych pandemii.

Zdarzają się słabe rozgrywki, ale zazwyczaj gra trzyma w napięciu prawie do samego końca.

RATING: 8
Amazing Cooperative game that leaves you wanting to play again, mainly because you lost last game....  It provides a unique challenge integrating ideas to find the best possible solution to a hoard of overwhelming problems.
If you are playing this game right (several small rules often go unnoticed), it's EXTREMELY difficult!  I have played 60+ Times and won only about 20 of those!
Luck does play a small part in this game, but most problems can be foreseen...

RATING: 4
In spite of the hyping of this game, if you have an experienced player he just overtakes the whole gameplay. After a game or 4 i think you won't play it again.

-1 takes up too much table space
-1 it is not so exciting: either nothing much is going on or it is clear that everyone is going to die regardless.
-1 for what you get it takes too long to finish
-1 thematically not great, doctors that teleport all over, camps being built, the character you play does not feel right.
-1 takes much time to set up. The 30 minutes lower bound is a lie.

RATING: 8
Update 2:
This game needs a certain crowd. After playing a two player game. My opponent said he would like to play in teams against each other???  
Clearly this is no such game. If you don't like games where the object is that of defeating the game. Stay away. If you do like such type of games it is one of the best.



Update: Played for a third time a 3P game
What a difference a little rule can make.
I rated it before a 7 (it felt like a 6 but I knew something was wrong)
Upgraded it to an 8.


Important epidemic take the bottom card from the draw pile.


First two games.
Played one rule wrong. In order to eradicate disease you have to go to cities with cubes of that disease an treat them. The action of treating will take one action. So a player can eradicate disease in 2 towns in one turn.
the medic only has to visit the city to automatically cure the disease once when the cure has been found. This works well with the dispatcher.


Only when the final cure is found there is no need for eradication. You win the game automatically.

There is an excellent one page summary of the rules made by Universal head to be found here.

RATING: 9
Cooperative gameplay at its best.  Adapts well to groups of different sizes. The mechanics are smart, direct, and malleable to different strategies. Relatively simple to teach to newcomers, and the difficulty can be increased or decreased to accommodate player experience levels.  Games tend to play out organically, making no two games too much alike.  Quality components.

Nearly a perfect game that is very challenging, but rewarding. Simple enough to teach to new players.  Tons of replay value.

RATING: 3

I find it a pretty stupid ruling that you're not supposed to play with open cards, but can ask others what they have at any time. What's that for other than prolonging the game for no reason?

Given the high rating it probably is a good family game, but there's nothing really here for gamers, at least without the expansions. Those I could try at some point.

RATING: 8.5
A good pure coop that got me back into board games.

Difficult as hell, but manageable if players around are on point.  As with any pure coop game, the game can degenerate into a single player dictating who goes where and does what.  I can see why some options are clearly better than others as it's somewhat built in the design of the game that if you don't go to said destination, then you're going to pay for the consequences.  So in some ways, it may feel "scripted".  But the drawn event cards do give some added chance into the game to make it different from play to play.

I think we've gotten it managed to a point where players will give advice when asked/needed.  That way players can feel like they are individually contributing to the team.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: N/A
In Pandemic, several virulent diseases have broken out simultaneously all over the world! The players are disease-fighting specialists whose mission is to treat disease hotspots while researching cures for each of four plagues before they get out of hand.

Taking a unique role within the team, players must plan their strategy to mesh with their specialists' strengths in order to conquer the diseases. For example, the Operations Expert can build research stations which are needed to find cures for the diseases and which allow for greater mobility between cities; the Scientist needs only four cards of a particular disease to cure it instead of the normal five—but the diseases are spreading quickly and time is running out. If one or more diseases spreads beyond recovery or if too much time elapses, the players all lose. If they cure the four diseases, they all win!
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8
Includes On the Brink.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 10
► Best cooperative gateway game.

The essential cooperative board game and also one of the very best gateway games in general.

[b]Pandemic[/b] has one of the cleanest and most compact yet clever game designs I ever encountered. It still amazes me how much this game offers, considering the few components and rules this game actually has (including an adjustable difficulty). Brilliant.

The theme is also quite unique, interesting and something most people can get into, further enhancing the game's gateway factor.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 9
I love this game. The first co-operative game I've played so the style was new to me. You and your teamates compete against the 4 different diseases that start breaking out over the planet. You work collectively, trying to exchange cards to get one person with 4 cards of the same color disease(diseases are yellow, blue, black, and red) and cure them. This isn't easy, as with each turn, more diseases (card driven) keep popping up and before you know it, epidemics are breaking out all over and eventually your team of experts just can't hold it back. Very cool game.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 9
This is such a addictive coop game! One of the best coop games ever.

I love how the game is set up differently each time, we had games that finished quickly because the game started with the infected cities so close to each other combined with the unfortunate draw of a epidemic card in our second turn. We ended up failing during the first few turns. And then other times our turn/move plans and card draws went so well that we beat the game in only half of what a normal game would take. 

Luck is major factor in gameplay but it is what it is, I like to think that's just how a real world epidemic would have played out. This doesn't diminish how fun this game is, careful planning with minimal wasted move definitely works fine if the cards are not too too bad.

Really love the fact that all players work together to beat a game. So satisfying when flipping over that last vassel and cheers to victory together!

The components and the graphic design are great as well, it's a must have for any modern board gamers.

(Owned Pandemic base game and "On the Brink" expansion. Looking to get some other expansion in the future.)

RATING: 6
In overall the game is interesting and there are some interesting new mechanics. For example, the discard pile which get reshuffle on the top of the infection deck.

Personally, I find that the game ends in the middle of the action. I don't know but I think that when you have all 4 cure, there are still possibilities to have outbreak that will make your life harder. Personally, I would have made sure that you must eradicate a certain number of disease to win the game.

Finally, the role special abilities are almost all useful, maybe perhaps the dispatcher, but I think that if there is no researcher or scientist in the game, it will be really hard to win the game. Because you can only win by finding all 4 cures and those 2 roles are only only ones which helps researching a cure.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7
Solid cooperative game that works well with theme of the CDC basically seeking to contain epidemics and find cures as you travel the globe.  Each person has a special ability which can aid in carrying out actions of your character or another in some cases.  Its definitely difficult to contain the different diseases and easy to get distracted from what you really need to do at times.  Considering that you will often need to use 1/3 of the cards towards finding cures, that leaves you with the last 2/3 of the cards to fend off epidemics long enough to find the four cures and win.  10-2 record with 4 epidemic cards thus far and 16-5 record with 5 epidemic cards and 5-10 record with 6 epidemic cards!  I can see where you might need to start adding the 5th or 6th epidemic card after a few plays to boost the challenge level as people learn to use their roles efficiently.  You can definitely play with 5 players as well.  I must admit that I have no desire to play with only 4 epidemics any more as it is too easy (after losing my first two games with 4 epidemics, I have not been part of a losing effort since).  Even five is starting to become easy.  I do appreciate that this game plays very quickly and I usually find myself playing twice in a row (often able to get both games completed in under an hour!)
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8
Collaborative game with a frantic pace to avoid losing to the pandemic.  The game was very enjoyable on the first play.

RATING: 6

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8
I'm not sure why people are posting comments about this game being too easy... an easy way to scale it a little tougher, and one of the first rules we implemented, was that you could only discover a cure in a research center of that disease's color, rather than any research center. This requires you to build more stations than simply relying on the one in Atlanta, as well as pulls a bit more strategy into the game. 
Still trying to work out some kinks in the way that sharing knowledge works in the game... allowing players to only share the types of cards they have (ex. "I have 3 red, 1 blue, and 1 special"), and list no city names to other players seems to work fairly well, except that it makes the sharing knowledge action, which is already very difficult, even harder (unless you are the researcher).
The fact that it is a cooperative game is a nice change of pace however, and encourages you to try to play until you beat the game. Works best in groups who have self control and are able to discuss strategies as a group without trying to dictate others moves.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8
Classic Co-op. A difficult game that is very fun to try and beat.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 6
This game was quite fun the first few times we played it. We've played this game I believe 5 times, 4 of those times on the highest amount of epidemic cards. This game is quite challenging, which makes it very entertaining. It truly requires all players to work together and plan together to count out every steps for at least the next 2 or 3 rounds. After beating it 3 times, we stopped playing it. It's a game I myself wouldn't mind playing again, but my group is less interested in it as of right now. The replay value just doesn't seem that high, but it's a fun and challenging game nonetheless.

RATING: 6
This game is very easy to learn and fun to play.  However it seems to be very dependent on which cards are drawn for the setup and few rounds of play.  If the locations are close together and an epidemic is pulled then you can lose the game too quickly.  

Also there doesn't seem to be any reason to not show your cards to the other players since you can still tell everyone exactly what you have.  Since this is a pure co-op it doesn't make sense to mislead the other players since it could cause you to lose too.  So really what is the point of not having an open hand at all times?

RATING: N/A
New never opened.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 9
This is probably my favourite game in my collection. It may not be the one I personally like best (that's Agricola currently), but it's the one that the most people enjoy that we get to play most often. It has an excellent balance of complexity, tactics, and fun that lets a new player pick up the game quickly and old players settle in and have fun each time. The expansions add a ton of depth and variation to play. And it's fun to play even with just me and my wife, which is an unusual feature in a game.

NOTE: The best rule we ever implemented was a limited amount of table-talk. This is a game where some players tend to boss around other players. When we're playing with one of those people, we use an egg-timer at the start of each turn. That timer is how long we're allowed to discuss strategy. Once the timer runs out, the person whose turn it is does whatever they want and we're not allowed to argue about it.

RATING: 7.5
1-4 Players
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8
I enjoy Pandemic, and I love how co-operative it is. The roles are enjoyable and none are really that horrible to have. That being said one of our cards ripped our first play before we ran out and purchased protectors. Also the art is decent and everything makes sense. Players need to strategize  or else they will end up not being able to travel or build a required research station. That being said the game can be a blowout either direction far too easily, and sometimes the directions are fuzzy. (for instance how many cards one can have pre-epidemic or what to do with an outbreak that causes a second outbreak) I was super excited to play after watching TableTop. After five or six plays I really enjoy this game with the following in mind: the art is kinda boring, the pieces are just cubes, and a few scenarios or further objectives would be nice, especially with a shuffle of the player deck to continue the game. Now I know that two of those complaints were addressed in On the Brink, but this is only about the core game, not the expansion. All of that being said I enjoy co-op, especially with the girlfriend when we want a shorter, friendlier game. Solid A.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7
Fast... and not in a good way. In both times I've played it it felt like it was over before any real decisions were made, I felt like just running around a map trying to stop random events that you already knew were happening. 
"Ok I'm going to London to stop the disease from spreading", but no, France already burst into flames because you were someplace else.
A good cooperative game builds its momentum to a place where you think you can have it all and in that moment you either go down and loose horribly or win the game in a massive burst of happiness, this game lacks closure. It reaches to the point I'm barely taking things seriously (about 30 minutes into the game) and then it ends abruptely. 

Sorry Santa, this game makes me want to play Lord of the Rings...

I maaay change my rating, because maybe this is one of those games that are interesting after a series of games (like Shogun for me, I found it interesting after the second play). I'll keep playing it...

Edit: Played it two more times and it got a little better with 4 players. I'll play more to investigate.

Edit: Played more. Won once and it was OK. A 7 is fair...

RATING: 9
The whole concept of cooperative games was completely new to us, so when I first heard of [GAMEID=30549], I know I had to give it a try.  I was also motivated because in general, she beats me in most games.  This way, I wouldn't have to lose to her again.

The theme was cool (save the world instead of conquering it!), and the mechanism for the spread of the diseases is a very slick design.  Despite having only colored cubes, they took on an ominous feeling as they began to cover the world.  However, she didn't really like it.  For her, the core gameplay seemed too dry and mathematical.  Plus, she's also pretty competitive and the cooperative aspect didn't sit right with her.  On the other hand, I enjoyed it a lot.  Luckily, [GAMEID=30549] is a good solo game (probably due to being cooperative in nature).  This is one of the few games where our responses were very different.

However, when we brought this home for Christmas, we got the family playing and we all had a blast trying to save the world.  Even my girlfriend got into it---we ended up playing over and over again until we finally won.  I have to agree that cooperative games like this shine with more people---there's more discussion and more people to get involved.  It's adding a key social aspect to it that you just don't get with two players.  It's become one of my go to games for new players---I've had good luck introducing the game to new players who've liked it.  However, while it does work, I would hesitate recommending it for just two until you've tried it first.

Session Reports:  [url=http://www.boardgamegeek.com/thread/307673]A Newbie Couple Catches the Bug[/url]
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8
Wonderful blend of light strategy, thematic mechanics, and a healthy dose of luck.  Perfect blend for a family game.  Very enjoyable to play; even solo is pretty fun.  So far it's been pretty hard, which I like in coops.  I feel like winning vs losing is partly due to luck but mostly due to skill.

Most of the components are great.  Theoretically you could have made them even nicer but they're good as is.  Art and styling is thematic.  Very sensible UI.

Big on extensibility.  There's really no way to complain about this game except to say that it could get samey after a while because it is a rather simple concept, even with the expansions.

RATING: 9

Excellent ideas well executed, very challenging system, great balance between pieces, cards and individual abilities.  Strong theme, real collaboration (though there is always the risk one voice will dominate . . . this so far has not occured in our groups), tension with every turn of the card, (Mr Leacock seems to enjoy stretching players) and great replay value.  Have played enough times to  sometimes be able to take a step back and enjoy watching the group dynamics, and it is clear that the system Pandemic is a perfect platform for a wide variety of groups.  Highly recommended.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8
Much lighter than Red November in mechanics, makes it a much easier game to introduce to a table for the first time. Player elimination is also not a factor, unlike RN which requires you to use the "less deadly dying" rule to keep players in. The disease theme was a little off-putting at first, but the game doesn't overemphasize it. Game length is fixed in the total number of turns that can be taken by all players; while this ensures the game length is relatively regular, each player takes fewer turns as players are added which can make a 4-player game either more boring or more unsatisfying, depending on the players' pace.

RATING: 7
This cooperative game for 4 people finds players taking the role of members of the CDC attempting to contain and develop cures for 4 diseases ravaging every corner of the globe. Use scant resources to treat critical areas while leaving enough to develop the vaccines you ultimately need. This game is great for those who want to work together against a difficult puzzle.

RATING: 9
Although my only play suffered from a significant rules mistake, I still got a good feel for the game, and this is the real deal. A lot of fun, reasonably tense, well-defined rules on communicating about your cards, and a quick pace. Best of all, the rules are clean and easy to learn. The arc of the story is probably even stronger once you have a couple of plays under your belt, as well.

Even though I don't rate it as an elite game yet, I definitely want to own a copy, and i think there is real potential for my rating to move up.

RATING: 9.5

Have played only 2-player and 4-player, but the more people you have the more fun it is. Game has great mechanics; unfortunately, if you don't want to lose by drawing out in a 4-player game, you need to have all 6 Epidemic cards in or you will most likely run out of cards before you can win. It's really different to play a game where everyone works together instead of against each other, and even though The Game usually beats us, we still have a lot of fun losing!!

Pandemic is one of those games where just one game is played in a sitting. More often, the first attempt fails and then multiple games are played with diffent configurations of the agents to try to "win" the game. The game is fairly simple and straightforward and is extremely fun to play.

I have not yet purchased the expansion for this game.

RATING: 6
Regalado a mi sobrina María.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8
A very clever game that plays quickly, yet offers relatively deep gameplay.  The tension in this game consistently ratchets up in a manner that provides a great narrative and story arc to the game.  The rules are easy to grasp and the theme is compelling, which makes Pandemic accessible to a wide audience.  There are very few downsides to this game that I can see at the moment; perhaps with repeated play this will become somewhat tired, but there are many combinations of roles to play, each combination providing a different experience requiring changes in approach, tactics and strategy.  I have felt that as I play more I have gotten better at the game, which suggests that this is a game of some skill that can be developed as one discovers how the game reacts and the uses of the various roles.  Highly recommended.  Review based on approximately 15 plays.  Note:  finally beat Heroic level in 2-player with Medic and Researcher - a very powerful combination.  With a different combination (especially excluding the Medic in 2-player), Heroic level will chew you up and spit you out.  Good fun.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

RATING: 7.5
Quick game (almost a filler!) that can easily be explained to newbie. Even at normal level (5 epidemic) the game can be challenging (especially if the roles don't mech together). 

For a game that quick and easy to learn 3 things impresse me much:
1- it is incredibly easy to have rules wrong. Even after 4 games... See Ekted FAQ post to clear things out.
2- The theme is so well integrated with the mechanics (especially the epidemic way to put the discard ON TOP of the draw deck).
3- It is impossible to refuse to play anither gfame if you just lose. IMPOSSIBLE!

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8
[microbadge=5792]

A fairly slick and concise coöp, probably the most concise since Scotland Yard; not messy or complicated at all.  The game has a wonderful sense of panic when outbreaks and epidemics occur, and I have to say that this particular "progression of evil" is one of my favorites; I get a particular delight infecting cities with disease.  The only glaring flaw of the game is the lack of distinctive players; for all intents and purposes, a single player could run four hands or four players could run four hands, without any significant difference of strategy being made.  This aside, a good game which should only be played on Heroic.

RATING: 10

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 5
Played once, a 3 player game on 'easy'.  While there are clever mechanics here that quite nicely simulate the spread of a disease and the game design can be quite challenging, it does not feel like playing a game, nor quite like a puzzle.  You are not pitting your wits against a sentient thing, as in an opponent in a regular board game or against an AI in a computer game, both of which are much more satisfying.  No, here you are playing against Fate, who delivers its moves through a semi-random card draw (I say semi-random, as there are mechanics in the game to make the same cities come up again).  All you can do is play your hand as dealt the best you can and it is not superior play in overcoming an opponent that allows you to win but random fortune.  And although there is a nice simulation here, I did not feel that I was getting a narrative flow of a story unfolding here but more of a desperate 'do what we can' each turn and hope for the best.  I would not refuse to play it again, nor any other coop game, but it would not be my suggestion.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 5
I generally hate cooperative board games where it's you vs. the designer, but this one is the most entertaining one of those I've played.

RATING: 10
The game that hooked me.  My feelings about it are so strong that I don't know how objective I can be.  But this seems to me to be a beautiful interweaving of elegance and drama.  I love that I can play it solo.  The theme is strong and the production appropriately spare.  The collective panic when a game starts slipping away is something to experience, as is the collective exuberance when you pull a game back from the brink.  Win or lose, the game really does make a team out of the players.  Splendid.

RATING: 8
One of the best cooperative games out there.  Collect color sets of 5 to find a cure for a disease.  You must keep diseases from spreading on the board and you cannot allow too many outbreaks.  However, you have to work together to find cures which means you must be closely co-located.  The game is very well done and very family friendly.  It is a little harder to learn than a typical family game, but with some effort in learning the rules, anyone can learn to play this game.  It is a must own game for any collection.

Previous attempts at coop games have fallen flat for me.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 10
I absolutely love this game. And everyone I have played it with or introduced it to has loved this game. This was my first 'step-up' game after playing Catan and Ticket to Ride and I'm so happy it was. It really cemented my enjoyment in this hobby and I knew I wanted to play more games and get more involved. I was coming into board games like most people I think, with preconceptions about what boardgames were and who they were for based on the games from my childhood. This game shattered that, and really peaked my interest in the hobby.

It has also helped me introduce boardgames to my wife and friends that are not gamers. This was the first co-op game I ever played, and I think that helps so much with non-gamers. We're all in this together. That is such an inviting concept compared to memories of Monopoly that led to sibling fights. 

This might be my favorite game.

RATING: 6
Ordered Feb 2008

Not bad. The cooperative elements seem to be straightforward, optimizing the best moves available then hoping you can execute in time. Like most co-ops, it can have problems with overly dominant players. I like it and I think it will be nice for solo play. Looking forward to getting the expansion.

Update July 2017
Haven't played this in over 15 years, but revisited it and some modern variants in the past year or so, including Cthulhu and Iberia. I really liked it way back when it was one of the first co-ops to appear on the scene. Nowadays I feel like the mechanisms are too artificial...or perhaps the nature of the mechanisms feel obtrusive, less integrated into the theme than could be. I may have been spoiled by Burgle Bros. In any case, I feel like my tastes have changed and the Pandemic mechanisms don't hold up well for me.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7
Very cool co-op game with interesting mechanics.  Everyone is trying to beat the virus, which is a paper machine.  The intensifying action when epidemic cards are drawn is clever.

Re-playability comes from initial set up (which cities and how infected by random draw), roles, and different people you play with.  Otherwise it would feel samey after many plays.  Difficulty is adjusted by the number of epidemic cards you seed.

Very tight game.  Especially at "normal" difficulty level and above, the game is often won or lost on the last turn before a losing condition occurs.

Have not yet played with the expansion, which looks promising.

Would be a great party game. 
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8
7/2008 Played one 4 player open-hand introductory game.  There's really not much going on in the game, still it's interesting and intense.  Its very well balanced; you need to make some good decitions and have a little luck when drawing cards in order to beat the game.  I'm getting a feeling this is a kind of solitare puzzle game that's been tweaked to allow for multiple players cooperating on solving the puzzle.  Definitely needs some more play.

Received 14/9/2012 in Spill-o-rama IX 2012 math-trade

RATING: 6
I can't seem to win at this, even on the easiest difficulty. I'm not sure whether to give up on this game, or keep trying. The problem with losing is that I'm losing against a deck of cards, so it never feels like I've been outsmarted or outplayed in any way. 

I probably wouldn't play this with a group, since co-op games can get a bit dictatorial. The fact that this game is so hard makes me less inclined to share the experience. I think the only reason I'm keeping this is because it can be played solo on the rare occasion when there's no one around to game with, and given all the hype over this, I feel like maybe one day everything will just "click" and I'll start winning.

RATING: 10
Phenomenal. Games often end on the exciting edge of a loss or win. Frequent decision trade-offs, adjustable difficulty, distinct roles, good components, real-world theme.

Regarding complaints of domineering "alpha" players in co-ops: It's the group's job to discourage/resist/avoid this behavior, much like how you would deal with a "ball hog" on a basketball court, a "[url=https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Munchkin_%28role-playing_games%29]munchkin[/url]" in a storytelling game, or a grudge-holder in a negotiation game.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8
This is a great Co-op game. Everyone I have played with has enjoyed it. If playing with new players it is extremely important not to be the alpha - let them make their own decisions and don't let them ask "what should I do?" every turn. 

The mechanics for epidemic cards make the game challenging at all levels, and the ability to adjust the difficulty keeps replayability high. We are teaching many groups with 4 epidemic cards, and that seems fair. New groups almost always lose, but it's a great way to get another game started right away. 

Thinking about picking up expansions, but this game doesn't really need any yet. 
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

RATING: 10
Pre-order: Boards & Bits

I actually have the urge to do something I've never done before on BGG - rate a game before I've played it.  That's how pumped up I am for this one!

Got it today (2/20/08).  I opened it up and the components look fantastic.  I'm going to count the cards as suggested by another BGG user.  Then... time to save the world!

UPDATE:  I had a similar problem with the cards - 2 player cards for St. Petersburg, none for San Franscisco.  I will email Zev to rectify.

I played my first game, and it was amazing!  Tense, fun - I won on my last turn.  I played solo with the Ops Expert and Scientist, at the Intro level.  Very fun!  I'd say it was as tense as LotR, with a more satisfying theme (but then again I am a physician).  I will introduce my wife to it tomorrow - she saw it laid out an was interested, which is a rarity.  I will update how the couples play goes.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7.5
Pandemic was another birthday gift - this time from my parents who heard that this game got great reviews.  It was also my first co-operative game.

The theme is wonderfully implemented, the game is easy to teach and fast paced, and tension keeps building for players to the end.  The only problem is that due to all that well-executed tension Pandemic is really vulnerable the Dictator Effect, with one player taking over and telling the other players what to do on their turns - not that this is unique problem to Pandemic, it's just that for some reason Pandemic seems to have it happen more frequently, and I suspect that thematic tension is the culprit.  No one wants to have the world succumb to killer diseases on their watch!
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8
Fun co-op game.  Not unlike Shadows over Camelot.  A bit simpler to jump in and get going however.  I think I actually prefer Pandemic in many ways.  None of this "stay in character and not reveal your cards" crap.  If you want to tell a teammate you have card X, you tell them you have card X.

RATING: 7.4
A great cooperative experience. It is essential to avoid that one player dominates and decides what everybody should do. The experience is ruined if not.
Play with hidden hands, allow for suggestions of other players but leave the final decision of action to the active player.

The game is quite unforgiving and really hard. It mostly comes down to how the two decks are stacked, but who cares as long as the game is such fun?
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 6
I am not exactly sure what all the hype is about. I mean, this game is ok, but it nothing special. I think that the cooperative games genre is a little waek and so this stands out as a light coop game, but it really is just an average game. It feels very generic, the production quality (other than the texture of the board) is a little weak. The art is basically a photoshopped Google Earth image with that horrible pandemic logo slapped on there. The bits do not really fit on the map and the map design wastes a fair amount of space. All in all its just a very  average game. Maybe a few more plays will charm me, but I doubt it.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8
This game fills a lot of great niches.  It is a fun quick filler, fun solitaire, and a great gateway game.  I've played this a few times with my serious gaming group, which I enjoyed.  But the most enjoyable part was I got my parents (who's board game experience is once-a-year Scrabble) addicted.  And any game I can play with my family on visits or holidays is well-worth the investment.  If you're looking for a serious co-op game to occupy a bunch of experiences gamers, I'd go with Shadows Over Camelot.  But if you need a quick game, or something to play with new people, then look no further: this is the perfect game for you.

RATING: 5
Although the theme, for me, is to die for, I find this game lacking in several ways. The cooperative factor, along with the idea of fighting a pandemic, drove me to this game. But its susceptibility to follow the leader, and its ensuing unfriendliness to new players really turns it off as a family game. And as a pure strategy game, it lacks the variety, with randomness and luck mainly deciding the variety. The expansion improves greatly on that aspect though.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8
Overall good game. It can be easy if four players get the scientist, researcher, dispatcher, and Organizer. However, you can get wrecked pretty quick if there's back to back pandemic cards drawn, which causes outbreaks on cities you just hit and then a whole chain happens (to which, little you can do) and then the cubes run out. Bam done. Happened two games in a row. Yes we shuffled the deck but I guess there's that odd chance that the last card in one deck and the first in the next can be pandemic cards, and those cities could have 5 others connected (using up more cubes). Apart from helpless frustration at times, it is a fun game. It's cool to work together to beat the game. You feel accomplished when you beat it. But this game doesn't seem super special to me, I couldn't see giving it more than an 8.5 but I will change score after more plays. 
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8
Played 8 times solo (with only 1 win!) Enjoy the game very much, but I think the mechanic definitely gets a bit old after multiple plays. Had one 4 player game where we lost as well, and felt that there just wasn't enough player cards to effectively do anything. It seemed like if you made a mistake early in the game then you might as well stop because you'll never be able to keep up with the unrelenting tide of cubes.

Originally a 9, downgraded to an 8, though I do very much enjoy this game.

Feb 14: Still play with my wife on occasion. Still very much enjoy it, though we are definitely much better at it. Using 6 epidemic cards made it more fun

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 10
Pandemic was the first co-operative game I ever played and I loved it right away. The whole concept is great and its implementation was even greater - the outbreak mechanic is absolutely magnificent. Someone might argue that some of the other mechanics are a little odd (notably the movement of players), but I have to remind you that this is a game and not a documentary about pandemics.  

The best description I can give is "a simple, but not easy, family thematic game". Unfortunately, not all my friends from my gaming group share my feelings, so we don't get to play Pandemic as often as I would like.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7.5
Initial rating 7.5, after 8 games 7.5

I like the game, here are some thoughts about it:
+ A group with a unbalanced experience with the game can result in an unsatisfactory gaming experience
+ For my an my spouce the game works perfect while playing the two of us (she loves it!)
+ I like the quality of the cards, but the rest of the components could have been better. The box insert is the worst I've seen so far (Z-man english second edition).
+ I think that the risk of a leader problem is high, that's why I think that it works better as a two player game
+ The game seems to be hard, maybe unfair... but in a fun way!
+ The game is short, and I think that is a great plus
+ I wouln't recommend it as a gateway game, because I think that is not a game for everyone and that in a four player game of non-gamers someone will get bored (at least that's my experience)
+ If the game worked better with four players I'm sure it will be an 8 for me
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 9
Pandemic, I love you, but you're bringing me down
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8.5
Excellent co-op game. Scales well to different numbers of players. I enjoy being able to change the difficulty level simply by the changing the number of Epidemic cards in play.

The expansion On The Brink adds a lot to the game, with the extra roles and three new 'versions' (virulent strain, mutation, and bio-terrorist).  Plus, the petri dishes are sweet!

[i]*Own Pandemic: On the Brink and In The Lab expansions.[/i]

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 9
The game shines at four players - why? The simple reason is that then the interaction between players is the most intense - one has an idea, other tries to help with it, while the third comes with another idea and tries to force the others to follow. This is the "conseil" concept of the game - we try to work out what would be the best moves of the team. Interesting and quite uncommon regarding the most board games.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

RATING: 7

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8
Good co-operative fun. My group of regular board game players are always willing to play the game. A real focus on player interaction, with each player making suggestions and contributing to the common goal. Can be quite challenging, with the odd disappointing loss, but people do come back for more. Like with most games of this genre, it's better when the players expand their own narrative about events during the game. Something that makes them want to talk about the good and the bad and what will draw them back to the table the next time.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7.8
Great theme, excellent mechanism, best co-op game I know. Might get repetitive and challenge solely based on luck, but I guess that's what the expansions are for.

RATING: 7.5

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 5
Thematically cool and a fun simple concept but for me a if i want to like a coop it needs to do something about the dominant player aspect. There needs to be information open to only some players or a traitor etc. that prevents everyone just openly discussing the best play and some players not actively doing much. Pandemic has no such thing which leaves this as only a 1 or 2 player exercise for me and too simple at that. It's just a simple risk calculation which cities to clean up.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7
A fun cooperative game with very interesting infection dynamics.  Amazing how many times you think you have things under control and suddenly a pandemic explodes and you lose the game.  The strategies are pretty straight forward and it then comes down to the luck of the draw in terms of initial infections and how soon the epidemic cards arrive.  So it's a fun game but wins are never guaranteed, and sometimes (it seems) impossible, so not a game to take seriously.  I also feel that once the players have found a successful strategy then there's little point left in playing the game any more so I do wonder about it's long term playability.

A great game for introducing coop games to anyone. Fast setup and easy to play, but not necessarily easy to win.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 6.5
I'm not as in love with Pandemic as a lot of other people, and that's because there seems to be precious few ways to influence events one way or the other.  For instance, during one game, I had the benefit of being able to look at the top few cards of the infection deck and rearrange them.  Even with this advantage, we still wound up with an unstoppable outbreak cascade, due to the way the game stacks the same cards repeatedly.  I'm not convinced that better strategy could have salvaged that game, and that's a bit worrisome.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7
Solid game; I quite like the theme and the sense of looming disaster when there are 2 or 3 cities about to outbreak in a cluster. But it leaves me a little cold: there are optimal moves and I'm the jerk who will tell you what you HAVE to do. For me, the game is more about parking that urge than saving the world. Probably a good lesson and perhaps I should play more often. 

At least the games are quick - we had one blow up on turn 1 (right after player 2): all the black blocks were gone; what a nice introduction to Pandemic for my Significant Other.

RATING: 6

RATING: 4

RATING: 7
Great co-op. Unfortunately the "quarterbacking" issue can take hold, particularly if new players are in the game.

--EDIT-- Having played Pandemic Legacy now, if anything the comparison sheds a somewhat poor light on the original Pandemic, oddly lowering my opinion of the original. Of course it was the blueprint for the polished mechanics under-pinning Pandemic Legacy, but at the same time original Pandemic's biggest flaw; a serious lack of replay-ability due to its formulaic nature, casts an even longer shadow. It deserves credit for the concept, but at this point I very much doubt if an offer to play the original Pandemic would be very appealing.

RATING: 8.5

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7
Pandemic is the game my group played most in 2008, and we loved every single minute of it whether we won or lost -- which is part of the beauty of Pandemic. It's like crack.

Pandemic is easy to teach in an absolute blast to play. Every time we play, we immediately want to play again so we can try a new strategy. Our win:loss ratio is creeping up to even, and it's fun to watch our progress over time.

The components are great, as is the theme -- I just wish there were slightly more to the theme. Not giving the diseases actual names feels very PC, but it robs Pandemic of some easy flavor. We usually go with Black Plague, Pox, Yellow Fever, and forget to call blue anything but Blue.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

DINAMICA SENCILLA E INTERESANTE PARA UN JUEGO NO COOPERTATIVO. UN UNICO PROBLEMA QUE COMO EN EL GRUPO EXISTA UN CABECILLA CON MAS DECISION QUE LOS DEMAS, AL FINAL SIEMPRE HAY ALGUN JUGADOR QUE PARECE ESTAR PUESTO POR EL AYUNTAMIENTO (NO LE DEJAN DECIDIR NADA ENTRE LOS DEMAS). (ES LO QUE TIENEN LOS JUEGO COOPERATIVOS QUE AL FINAL MANDA EL LIDER).ES BUENO COMO SOLITARIO, YA QUE AL FINAL PUEDE JUGAR UNO MOVIENDO LOS CUATRO PEONES POR TURNOS.

RATING: 7
signiert
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8
+ On the Brink expansion
+ In the Lab expansion

Rating based on SOLO play only.

It's like solving a big puzzle whose parameters keep changing and evolving. Great sense of rising tension and good frustration (there's always a feeling of "if I only had ONE more action..."). I find the game design very elegant in how the virus spreads and how quickly the game can change, yet it does so in a very organic way.

Expansion comments: 
-On the Brink: I tend to not use the Mutation and Virulent Strain modes very often because I think the base game is hard enough for me, but the extra role/event cards and the petri dishes (a nice thematic touch) make this a good expansion to have 
-In the Lab: really changes things up and after just a couple of plays I don't think I'd play without this now

RATING: 4
Let me start by saying that Pandemic might be best quality of manufacturing I have seen in a game.  The boards and cards are nice heavy stock, and the print job was nicely done.  I am not one to usually ooze about board quality, but I genuinely appreciate this one.

That being said, Pandemic is not a game that is intended to be played every week.  It's a nice quick game to play when you're feeling really cooperative and have an hour between other games; it does this very well.  I am very happy to have it in my collection, even if it took me quite a while to get to the table.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 6
3 / 5 - Good.

This is one of the better co-op games I've come across - it offers a decent amount of chaos, usually results in a tense end-game and the random role each player gets increases not only re-playability but the sense of individual action. However the theme is silly (cash in five airline tickets for a global cure!) and it's not totally immune from loudest-player syndrome. Review here: http://fortressat.com/articles-boardgame-reviews/4122-pandemic-review

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 10
When I think of Pandemic, I think that it's the perfect game.  It's a co-op, and it brings people together to complete the noblest of tasks: save the world population from extinction by disease.  It does it in such a great way, where mechanics and theme come together seamlessly to immerse players in the narrative.

In Pandemic players take on various roles, each with its own unique powers.  Using these powers wisely in conjunction with other players' roles is the the best chance you have to win the game.  On a player's turn they will move around the board, which is a global map.  They will try to treat diseased populations, build research facilities where cures can be found, gather cards to be used for curing disease, and then actually cure those diseases.  Watch out though, every turn more cities become infected with one of four deadly viruses, which are colour coded. 

To win, players must cure all four diseases.  However, there are many ways to lose.  If any one disease has gotten so out of control that there are no more cubes left in its colour, players lose.  Players will also lose if there are too many outbreaks triggered.  Finally, if the draw deck runs out before all four diseases are cured, that also counts as a loss for the players.

Pandemic is tense right from the beginning, and it only gets worse as the game progresses.  You're immediately thinking, "How can we possibly put out all these 'fires' all over the globe?".  It will take teamwork, skill, and luck to save the world from the Pandemic!


=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 6
It's not bad. But it's basically a puzzly, cube pushing, solitary Euro - nothing special. 

Take this with a grain of salt - I'm not a fan of most co-ops, as I think they're either an argument in a box, or a solitaire cube pusher, depending on how they are structured.

RATING: 8.5

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 10
3rd best game of 2008. 
The grandfather of co-ops.. But expansions have kept Pandemic fresh and relevant too.. Especially On the Brink is a must-have. But I really like In the Lab too, it makes the game pretty complex, but it's all the more rewarding to beat it. State of Emergency has nice balance between the two, it has some essential additions and some that are fun to play every now and then. For lightest gameplay Forbidden Island is better anyway. New edition greatly improved the artwork and components of the game. Highest difficulty setting is very hard and there are tons of role combinations to try. People who think it's too easy: make it hard, if you want it hard! It's a co-op classic that belongs to every shelf. 

2-Player Comment:
* Pandemic is co-op game and works well with two. Some role combos are harder than others though. You can also play with 2 pawns each, but it's not required (and personally I don't like that). Pandemic is very good 2p game.

Expansions:
+Pandemic: On the Brink
+Pandemic: In the Lab
+Pandemic: State of Emergency

RATING: 8
This was, essentially, the game that kicked off my love affair with tabletop gaming. It was one of the first co-op board games I'd ever played, and I really liked the mechanics behind it. With all the different ways you can lose this game, it really feels like the game is playing AGAINST you. This game is EASY to learn, but impossible to master. You could get right down to the wire and BARELY make it through, or you could last a half a round before you get screwed by some bad chain reactions. I would definitely recommend this game to anyone who's thinking of "testing the waters" so to speak. Barring a few clarifications between different classes and their subsequent abilities, I feel like this game really transcends various age groups, and personal interests (ie. non-gamers).

[04/08/2008] 1 4-player game. A trifle slow, and mostly the game is playing you, rather than the other way around. However, if here, and that card comes out, or there, and this card comes out, then we're screwed. Could we have played better - sure. Do I care enough to go play again, not really. I'd probably play it again, at some point, but I wouldn't buy it.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 9.1
The best part of this game is that it's co-operative.  The theme is wonderful, the gameplay is challenging, but it's the interaction and working with the other players that really makes this game fun to play.  

This game could be played Solo, however this makes it too easy.  It's more interesting with more people, as it gets harder to communicate, and explain the best possible route of action, much like the real world, where there are many truths and solutions that are independent of what people know, but it's much more beneficial for everyone to understand than for just one person to understand.  

If you understand exactly what to do in this game all the time, or are more experienced than those you play with, it's better to hang back a little, and learn to communicate without manipulating others turns.  Allowing others to discover the right action without explicitly telling them will actually help them have a better experience.  

I find it interesting because self absorbed people who may be impatient and really smart will feel like they are playing a solo game, and don't need anyone else around, which is true, but that's part of the challenge and appeal... to have to work with others..  and if they play with others who are self absorbed/controlling but smarter, they will feel like they aren't making decisions.. or being pushed around... This game has led me to a lot of personality analysis, and led me to understanding co-operative leadership a little more.

RATING: 6
Take Arkham Horror.  Make these changes: The goal remains the same, the theme is much less compelling (but still pretty good), the playtime is slashed to something reasonable, and the game is several orders of magnitude better.  That's Pandemic.

Like most co-ops, it does suffer a bit from the tendency for one player to take control of the game.

I gave this one away.  I always have a good time playing it, and the game never drags, but it's a co-op so I'm never the one to suggest it.  I like playing other people's copies every now and then, but have no need to own it myself.

RATING: 6
I finally got around to playing this after owning it for close to a year. We played two games back to back with four players each time.

The game is thematic and plays at a relatively brisk pace.

When I tried to learn the rules I just couldn't get them straight in my mind. This put me off. I usually don't have problems figuring a game out, but for some reason I remained perplexed.

When we played it seemed that some rules were a bit confusing and unclear. So based on this first experience I am underwhelmed. I was expecting a solid co-operative game. So far I still prefer Minion Hunter, Lord of the Rings and Shadows to this.

So I haven't been set alight like most of the community here on the geek but perhaps this will change after a few more plays.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 5
As a dissenting voice, let me say that I guess I just don't get this one. I was looking forward to it but, having played it a few times, it just doesn't excite. Leaves me very cold. Girlfriend finds the theme depressing. I read session reports and reviews, each raving about the innovation and tension, but it doesn't work for me, nor for anyone I've so far played with. It's really frustrating to play a game with varied groups in the hope that one of them will say: "Yeah, man. It really works for us." 

Basically, it's a co-operative game with a "ticking-bomb" type of mechanism determined by the turn of a card. Its innovation is that when the "bomb" goes off, infections escalate and the cards that have caused the epidemic are placed back on top of the stack to increase the threat. Wooo. Somebody wake me up.

To explain my problem with the game, here it is: you are reliant on all the other idiots around the table to succeed, and even then it's likely the system will screw you. I think it's because I'm excited by competing against the other players. I've never liked solo games - they're too dry. This is essentially a solo game where you don't get to make all the decisions that lose you the game. Lots of people like this kind of guff. I'm not one of them.

Not my worst game ever, but my biggest disappointment.

RATING: 7
Given that the game is actually a solitaire game against the system, what really makes it then is to set the difficulty level up high & let the tension build as you play against the system. In that event, it's fun.

Best played "in character" letting people make the decisions they think best (although discussion is always good in co-op games) but if someone just dominates & commandeers the game and all actions etc, they're really just playing solitaire themselves against the system & everyone else is just making up the numbers
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8
A game very much like Forbidden Island or Forbidden Desert. I do like the theme, but some expansions might help with keeping the game challenging.

RATING: 8
I had been looking for a small-group cooperative game, and Pandemic fits the bill perfectly.  I've heard complaints that the theme is not very engrossing and that the game feels scripted, but I experienced neither of those with my gaming group.  We have a blast racing around the world trying to keep the diseases at bay while frantically searching for the cures.  The tension is great, and we really feel like we're accomplishing something, which is a feature that Shadows over Camelot always seemed to lack (despite the fact that we love that game too).  I absolutely love this game, and it's probably one of my best game purchases.

Easy to teach and the co-op nature makes it very approachable for new players (they don't feel like they're competing against the more experienced players). RATING: 6
A decent purchase at just the right price, I was hopeful that the game's reputation would match my expectations.

Pandemic plays well, and if you're the type that enjoys plenty of player interaction, this is a title you can consider. The overall feel of the game is tense and urgent, as you coordinate with your fellow players and make tough decisions.

Although my friends find this game highly entertaining, I can't seem to love the game as much as I would like to. I find the necessary planning and talk quite tedious; a single turn can sometimes take forever as you plot out the best course of action. Of course this element highly depends on your player group. Winning is hard, and I'm fine with that, but in those occasions when you do win I find it very anti-climatic. The set pieces are nice, not amazing, and the artwork doesn't blow me away either.

In conclusion, I feel the game is at best average. I just find it hard to have fun when I whip out the box.

RATING: 8

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 4
Playing a cooperative game was a cool experience - as it was the first of its sort for me. This had a very cool mechanic in the "intensify" - where you just reshuffle the cards that have already been drawn and add them to the top of the deck, causing already infected locations to well, intensify.

Not always a consistent challenge, sometimes the game simply decided to break you, with no opportunity to salvage the game after even the first or second turn, other times it rolled up and let you run away with an easy victory. For the most part however, it takes some thought to have a shot at winning - you have to manage your risk level, too conservative and you run out of time, too aggressive and you end up burning out on the outbreak track.

Very simple rules, but also a bit too quick to figure out, and the reward for trying to analyse further (which is kind of fun, since you are doing it as a group) isn't always there since you are talking small percentages (in terms of win / loss %). Played it like 8 - 9 times, which is fine, but then it was a toss-up between getting expansions or ridding myself off it and I did the latter. 
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7
2/16/2008: rated 8 after two plays. It's a pretty good cooperative game. It might suffer a bit without the possibility of traitor but I'm not sure. I like the chain reaction of viruses and the building tension. The first game we lost and the second game was won with only one card in the draw pile. 1st game = no researcher and the second game = no scientist. The researcher and medic seem most valuable, followed by the dispatcher, then Operations Manager (or whatever) and last Scientist. Roles make some interesting combos, especially between Medic, researcher and dispatcher.

I do have a concern that this could become easy. Both games were played with the "normal" deck with 5 epidemics throughout 45 cards. 

2 more games, 4-player: 1 win and 1 loss. The second loss was due to both outbreaks and the red virus running out. 1 more round and the researcher would've cured the last disease.

Update: 2 two-player games with the wife. She likes it. It's very good with two, just remember not to be too bossy.

Update: Settled at 7. It's funny how differently I view the roles now. At first the Medic was King and the Scientist the weakest. Clearly, after a dozen games or so, the big power combo is Scientist / Researcher; however, in a two-player game, the medic is pretty grand in that he can treat diseases every two turns instead of four.

Very interesting game that I believe I've explored quite thoroughly. I still have to play it more with my usual group as most plays were two-player with my wife.

Accurate count is probably in the upper 20s.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

p.s no problem with size of cubes just stack 'em
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 10
Its perfect introduction into what a cooperative boardgame can be. Can also be tuned to offer expert players more challenge.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7
Game in a Nutshell: Co-op game fighting disease outbreaks around the world. Take on a role, collect cards, and travel the globe fighting the spread one action at a time.

Played as: solo (w/ 2 characters), 2,3,4 player

Played with: On the Brink: Roles and Events (3 player)

Pros: Easy game to learn and play fast. The scaling difficulty makes a good intro game up to a tense challenge for experienced players. Simple enough that it should encourage talking and planning rather then individual situational analysis. The infections work in a way that balances the complete randomness with just enough info to help focus your efforts while still remaining tense with each card flip. This game begs to be played until it's beaten. 

Cons: The game can lead to frustration when played with mixed personality types who are forced to cooperate. After a while, the cooperative discussion becomes straight forward and things boil down to how well the cards play out with the theme seemingly faded away. The base game should have included more roles.  

Other: My advice is play this ALWAYS on the most difficult level. The hooks of this game is in the losses; so don't let newbies win. I'm typically a expansion hater, but this game is one that basically needs it to add the necessary variety for anything more then 5-10 interesting plays (especially if in high rotation)... if only for the additional roles alone.  

Best Use: The friendliest of Gateway games for loud-mouths who don't think they're smarter then everyone else.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8
One of my gateway games. A nice cooperative game to play with my family. It appeals to some of my non-gamer friends and family members, but to some the game appears to be difficult because of the many different decisions that can be made and the forward thinking and planning needed to beat the game. I am giving this game an 8 instead of a 9 though because after playing with the expansion, I feel that the base game will get boring fast.

RATING: 8
Category: Light Strategy - excellent co-op game with strong theme.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7.5
The first co-op games I played were Forbidden Island and Forbidden Desert. The thought of working cooperatively with others at the table was foreign to me. My board games roots began with Monopoly and Risk (still enjoy them) so thinking that everyone at the table was there to contribute and work together was mind boggling. Regardless, after the first game I was hooked. What really sold me on Pandemic was when I discovered it could be played solo. I now know that the Forbidden games and other co-ops can be as well but at the time I was coming out of my Monopoly/Risk shell and knew little about the game or hobby in general.

Most Pandemic games I play are solo. It scratches that itch between weekend/bi-monthly game nights with friends. Playing solo or with friends I think the sweet spot for this game is at three players. Two and four both work but something about three seems to just click. With four, the game is more chaotic and I feel that our team is in less control. Too much happens before your next turn. In a two player game, I don’t get that immersive “group think” I do when a third players is added. Needless to say when playing solo I will select three random roles. 

When teaching this game to my family (Uncles and cousin that are part of the Monopoly/Risk group) I had the best reactions I could ask for. We lost our first game terribly. Everyone started shuffling cards and asking for reminders on how to set up the board for the next game. That was the first time I experienced that “Holy crap that was awesome. Let’s jump into it again.” feeling.

15-20 additional games played.

RATING: 9
This is probably my favorite co-op.  It beats others because it's thematic, fairly quick to play, but provides a good puzzle that changes enough with each play.

The downsides are that it really is a puzzle co-op.  It's like an algorithm that needs to be solved, but it's such a good puzzle that solving it is fun.

The first expansion is all I have, and it's all I'll probably buy.  The added roles and events make the replay value huge.

RATING: 6
This game gets better the more I play it, although I'm only up to about six plays, now. However, the improvement is incremental and slowing, so I doubt it's ever going to jump up to a 7. It is, frankly, a bit dry, but not cripplingly so. It's successful for me mainly because, even though it's a puzzle game (and many would argue that there is an optimal move each turn that is fairly obvious), I like the theme and find it the right mix of complexity and playability. It's just a good, solid system that is teachable and playable in a reasonable length of time.

My son and I have played this a couple times. It's not as good as a 2-player, but it's not bad. I'm happy to pull it out now and again.

I've also played it solo a couple times, and it's not bad that way, either.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 9
Incredibly well designed, simple rules non-gamers will pick up quickly, and forces strong cooperative gameplay. Good for those people that don't like 'losing' (my other half, for example), as it's an 'everyone wins' or 'everyone loses' game. A favourite amongst my crowd.

Gets incredibly tense on higher difficulties. For added difficulty, play with 5 players rather than 4. The game works just as well, but now the clock is truly ticking.

Given a '9' due to the fixes included in the expansion.

RATING: 9
We played this out of the box, first time, and remarkably won ... yes, on easy mode and that's not a bad thing for a game like this which has a tremendous amount of ways to lose - and only a few different ways to win. Pandemic is a wonderful cooperative game that we played two-player ... and it's immersive, a little complex at first with all the things happening - but once you get the dynamics down, it's a challenge to meet the conditions towards victory. It's tough though - and we nearly lost it a few times. The game keeps you up on your toes as you try to keep an outbreak from happening. You maneuver your team to various places on the map to help find a cure - while trying not to run out of cards in the process. 

We're definitely interested in the Legacy versions of Pandemic - as we hear it adds a lot to the game play. An ongoing game - even after you play it once, it carries over to other times you play - which is an interesting game mechanism we have yet to explore. Challenging but an incredibly fun game - even if you lose - you ultimately give it your best shot!! 
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

Bottom line - we just don't understand the hype on this game...

RATING: 8
[microbadge=1714]

[u]06-Feb-2013[/u]: I think this was the fist co-op game I played after getting into the hobby, and it has spiraled from there.  First, I do enjoy working together with the other players to defeat the game.  I don't have trouble with the "alpha player problem" since I only play with my family and, on the rare occasion, my two buddies.  Second, I enjoy the puzzle aspect of most co-op games.  That is something that attracts me in games.  And finally, and probably most importantly, I can play them solo controlling any number of players.

So, what about this one in particular?  I think it's fantastic.  I like the theme of fighting against ever spreading diseases around the world.  I like all of the various roles (especially when you include the On The Brink expansion).  The "AI deck" is a fantastic, and brutal, mechanism to play against as it continues to add more and more trouble on the map.  The replayability is very high, in my opinion, as the set up varies from game to game, roles mix and match in interesting ways, the difficulty level can be adjusted, and with On The Brink, three additional options can be added to the base set of rules to really liven things up.

I really can't say anything negative about this game.  However, I think you can give yourself help if you "count cards."  Personally, I don't do that.  Of course, I'll have a general idea of what may be coming up next, but I try not to memorize everything that has happened with the AI deck and what is still to come.  I like being surprised and that tension of not exactly knowing what will happen next.  Maybe that's just me.

[u]24-Jan-2014[/u]:  Man, I can't believe it's been six months since I've played this...what is wrong with me?  Such a great co-op game.  I still hold this one in high regard even though so many co-ops have arrived...and landed in my collection...since.  I would easily recommend this one to any gamer, new or otherwise, interested in a solid, challenging co-op experience.  Oh, and definitely pick up the first expansion for additional options and even more replayability.
