=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7
Pandemic is the only coop game I've ever played.  I never really saw the appeal of coop games until somebody brought this in to work.  After my first play through I knew I needed to buy it.

In Pandemic you and the other players are all trying to cure 4 diseases before they outbreak too much and just become unmanageable.  You will start with 9 random cities with disease cubes on them, the first 3 get 3 cubes, the next 3 get 2 cubes and the last 3 get 1 cube.  The world is grouped into 4 regions (denoted by colors) for each of the 4 diseases.  The starting cities get the color of disease cube for the color of city they are.

Each player now takes a special role that will help them specialize in things that will help out in the game.  Now the players need to build research stations, remove disease cubes, share knowledge, and eventually cure all 4 diseases.

The difficulty comes from the constant onslaught of disease cubes.  After each players' turn the next cities are flipped over and receive disease cubes.  If a city gets flipped over and it is already at 3 cubes it then outbreaks giving one cube to each city attached to it.  Throughout the player deck epidemics are included, as these come up you get a brand new city with 3 cubes.  In addition all those cities you've already been adding cubes to, yes those ones you've been removing cubes from as well, get shuffled and thrown right back on top to add even more cubes.

This is a rewarding game.  It is fun to work together and not have to come up with the strategy all by yourself.  It might be good to play the first few times with open hands, but I wouldn't do that for long.  It might be easier, but it seems like it turns into 1 or 2 people running the whole game.

I gave this a 7 because it is quick to play and offers a lot of tough decisions in that short amount of time.  If you lose, at least it was only 15 or 20 minutes so you can easily get in another game to try and win.  If playing with only 4 epidemics becomes to easy, just add one.  Once you get up to 6, which is the most for the base game, things get really tough, so you will never feel like this game is too easy.  I love this game and I am really looking forward to the expansion On the Brink.

[b]Game Length:[/b] (Short) :halfstar::nostar::nostar::nostar::nostar: (Long)
[b]Complexity:[/b] (Easy) :star::star::nostar::nostar::nostar: (Complex)
[b]Accessibility:[/b] (Non-Gamers) :star::halfstar::nostar::nostar::nostar: (Gamers)
[b]Luck Factor:[/b] (Luck Based) :star::star::star::nostar::nostar: (Strategy Based)
[b]Re-playability:[/b] (Low) :star::star::star::halfstar::nostar: (High)
[b]Value for Time:[/b] (Waste) :star::star::star::star::halfstar: (Worth)
[b]Recommended # of Players:[/b] 3-4

RATING: 8.25
This board game was my gateway game back into gaming. To be honest, I don't remember what made me want to pick it up, but it's been a staple board game in this household.

It's a cooperative board game that gets slightly harder the more players are in it. Different difficulty levels, pretty neat epidemic mechanic, different roles for each player to play as. This game revived my inner board game geek.

LC- "It's easier when it's played by a smaller group. Once it gets more than 3 people, it takes forever to get back to your turn and try to coordinate what each person should do."

RATING: 9
This game is a masterpiece in it's own right. Componentwise, it is a typical eurogame, but the mechanics is hard to define... It's tense, enjoyable, and still not too demanding in terms of time and concentration - it provides just the right amount of choices for it to be involving and not tiring. Depending on the chosen level of difficulty, it can range from being all to easy to being a real nightmare - perfect for an enjoyable learning experience.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7
I'm not big on cooperative games, but this is the perfect theme for it.  Several mechanics that dictate the frequency of bad cards make the game simple genius.  

Better mass appeal than fantasy/sci-fi coop games (if you want significant others / family to play).

We play with each player getting 2 random roles and picking one (this is a game, it's about fun, you might as well spend your hour-ish with a role you can get into).

Expansion (On the Brink) adds a lot of enjoyment!  If you play more than ~6 games of Pandemic, pick this up!  
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

RATING: 7
I have 3 problems with this game.

1)You sometimes randomly lose and there was nothing you could have done about it, period.
2)Of all the games I've played, it suffers the most from alpha gamer syndrome, where one player, usually the most experienced, directs everyone else and tells them what to do. 
3)The expansions are too expensive for what they have. Half of the stuff in each one I do not even want to use, some of the rest is component upgrades or such, but the rest are very well done and give a lot to the game. Meh.

Still a great game though.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 9
The mechanics are very similar to Shadows Over Camelot. Each turn, you do good stuff, and draw cards that produce bad stuff. The game is a race to complete some good tasks, while constantly being distracted having to prevent imminent disaster. Every player has a special ability.

Two aspects make it an improvement over Shadows Over Camelot. One, the board has geography. In Shadows Over Camelot, there is a cost to move from place to place, which means you have to plan ahead before you go somewhere, to be sure you can stay there for long enough to be efficient. However you can move from anywhere to anywhere. In Pandemic, there is a connection graph, so some places are more costly to move between. You have to consider what you need to do in a whole region.

I also think the roles complement each other better than in Shadows. In Shadows, each role has interesting uses on its own, but there are not so many interactions. It seems like in Pandemic, every pair of roles will have some critical interaction.

Follow up:

I've played a lot more of this. All of the things I said above remain true. In addition, I think this game is a lot more tactically challenging than other cooperative games I've played. A really good tactical plan can really save the day. In the cooperative setting, this is great, as the group can brainstorm and come up with the tactical plan together.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7.9
The base game can get boring on replays, but expansions can easily remedy that. State of Emergency and in the Lab are great.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8
Modern co-op classic, even if it is too "puzzley" for some and prone to alpha-gamer syndrome.

RATING: 9
I enjoy cooperative games. This is light and fast. Everything I want. I'm awaiting for the expansion since I'd like to see more roles. 
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 6
Pandemic feels way too light for it's own good. I don't really like the game that much, though I don't run away from it either.

RATING: 6

RATING: 7
Fast moving and entertaining game, although being a co-op the quieter players will tend to not have too much input. The luck of the draw plays a pretty crucial part in whether you win or not, but this is a good game. The only problem is that when you win, it feels a bit empty: "IN YOUR FACE, DECK OF CARDS!". Regardless, this will probably be the best Euro that will come out in 2008. Kind of reminded me a bit of Thebes in gameplay (with the travelling) and in spirit (fast moving, small range of choices that can have big impacts, chaotic, ease of play, colourful and with a good use of theme).

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 6
[size=10][u][i][b]r{Initial Thoughts}r (after 5 plays):[/u][/b][/i][/size]
* One of the quintessential examples of the cooperative genre
* Gameplay is simple to teach/learn, with practically no downtime
* Strategy is basic, but helped by a group that understands that teamwork = victory
* Vets and more vociferous gamers may lead to some bullying, particularly with newbs
* Good for co-op fans and those who prefer great gaming experiences over victories
* Initial rating: [b]9/10[/b]

[size=10][u][i][b]b{Further Thoughts}b (after 25 plays):[/u][/b][/i][/size]
* Base game does get a bit "samey," with the same strategies and roles to blame
* Expansion helps to bring some newness, but starts to overly complicate things as well
* Strange in that, the more a group WINS, the LESS they feel like playing
* Further rating: [b]6/10[/b]

[size=10][u][i][b]g{Advanced Thoughts}g (after 50 plays):[/u][/b][/i][/size]
* "Samey" aspect of the game is beginning to cost it playing time
* Co-ops seem to polarize (either you have a group that loves them or hates them)
* Still more to experience from expansions, but has been mothballed at the moment
* Advanced rating: [b]6/10[/b]
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

RATING: 5
I seriously don't know what people see in this game. After playing it several times, then leaving it on my game shelf before playing it again I really can't say that I enjoy the game very much. The biggest problem for this is that half of the game you spend picking up cards which you then use to infect the specified cities which results in the player waiting half of the game. If you could eliminate this process and somehow (even though this could never work) make the infection process play out on its own without having to do it manually, my rating would go up to seven stars as that way the game would be a lot more interesting.

RATING: 8.5
I just love the whole idea of being at the right place at the right time. Thanks to the important "hand over information" action you have to be with the right person at the right place at the right time, what makes this game a beautiful coop.

And the shuffling of the discarded infections and putting them on top again after an epidemic deserves the Nobel price for game mechanics.

RATING: 8.15
Ah Pandemic, the source of MANY hours of fun and also many hours of frustration. (Written on 4/26/16)
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 9
Pandemic is an example of a 'gateway game', a game that allows new gamers to see what the hobby can be. 

In Pandemic, players work together to eradicate 4 separate diseases from the world. It's very tense at times, and it is always interesting.

As with any cooperative game, there is the possibility for one player to become the de facto leader, railroading the decision making of other players. The best way to avoid this problem is through playing with a group that has the same level of experience. 
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7.5
For me, (as well as tonnes of other people) this was the game that started the hobby for me. Although I have a terrible win record (1 for 25) I still love playing.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8
Absolute fun, the cooperative element allows everyone to have fun equally. Requires a lot of teamwork which really brings everyone together. The game starts off calm enough giving you time to figure out a plan, then the suspense builds quickly and more often than not you have to quickly formulate a new plan. The rules are fairly quickly learned and allows for gameplay to start quickly. Each round takes about 45 minutes which is a perfect amount of time for the tension to build. Overall a great game.

Sértődékeny, egoista hülyékkel azért ne játsszuk, csak olyan partyarcokkal, akik el tudnak négyig számolni és képesek alávetni magukat a közös ügy érdekében.

RATING: 8
Excellent cooperative game.  Have played several times and have only won once.  Every move is important, every action precious.  The one game we won, we won in exactly the maximum number of actions.  If we had gone one more action, we'd lose.  The last game we played, we chose to cure the blue disease rather than take out a single black cube - and that cost us the game.  It's that close.  If you want a nail-biting game guaranteed to make you sit on the edge of your seat until the very end, this is the game for you.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 6
Having played the Pandemic "system" (including Legacy) nearly 40 times now, I'm never excited to reach for vanilla Pandemic anymore. I'm just not that interested in the puzzle-solving underlying the game as a whole, especially when it's hard to know when you've "really" won or lost due to the randomness of the system. To play truly well, you have to be more committed to solving the puzzle than I typically am. Pandemic Legacy did a great job of using the underlying system to drive an experience, but when you're back to the original, it feels too much like an exercise.

As a result, I had Pandemic at a 4 for a while, but a couple aspects of the game are bringing it back onto my radar. First, it remains as solid a gateway game as ever. We probably prefer Through the Desert, but that game isn't quite as eye-opening as Pandemic's interactive, cooperative nature. It's fun seeing others get excited about "saving the world" and puzzling their way through their turns the way we did when we were first starting out. Second, the underlying system has proven to be remarkably customizable, which opens up not more variety through expansions but also opportunities for my own design tweaks. (This is an advantage Pandemic has over its simpler siblings like Forbidden Desert or variants like Pandemic: Realm of Cthulhu.) I've started [url=http://games.mulrah.com/Board%20Games/Pandemic]thinking through some of these possibilities elsewhere[/url], and if I really get into any of them, the rating here could actually go up. But for now, a 6 seems fair: we're fine with this as an introduction to the hobby, but aren't going to be busting it out all that often beyond that.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 10
Awesome co-op, easy to setup and gamepaly goes from beginner to ultimate challenge providing hours of replay value

RATING: 3
I used to dislike Pandemic, until I played it recently.  This games luck factor is through the roof.  If you draw an epidemic card in the first turn, the game is as good as over, and there's almost nothing you can do about it (which is completely random).

Aside from the luck factor, the actual gameplay is basically a semi-interactive simulation.  When I'm "playing" Pandemic, I feel like I'm just watching the game unfold, rather than making influential decisions that effect the game state in any way.

This is probably the least engaging and one of the most annoying co-op games I have played.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 6
A great theme with great tension, and an excellent gateway game, but also the paradigmatic example of how player quarterbacking can ruin a co-op game.

Infection rates rise and fall, but the board itself is static with fixed movement paths.  Player abilities are variable, but all in the open.  The deck organization makes the card mechanics somewhat predictable.  All these aspects add up to a high probability that the loudest player at the table (or the one with the best memory and spatial awareness) is going to lay out everyone else's strategy at the beginning of her or his turn.  I don't want to be too harsh, because the game was so revolutionary, but there are plenty of other co-ops I'd rather play that dodge this problem.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

Very difficult to win if you don't work together.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 9
Old collection

This is our favorite co-op game that also plays well with 2 players. Shuffle more (i.e. 5 or 6) epidemic cards in the drawing pile then though to make it more challenging. The mechanism of the game is really well made: cities that were infected before get a higher chance of getting infected again when the discarding pile is shuffled and put on top of the drawing pile again.

In our games it always lasts until the very end to defeat all diseases or to be defeated by them. And if you defeat all of them, you really feel like you've saved mankind from being destroyed!

RATING: 7
Despite the hype and the high ranking on BGG, this was my main disappointment this year. Everything looks great, the theme is good and we were really eager to give this game a try.

But although we kept on looking, we didn't found a game in there. Draw cards, put blocks, see diseases spreading,.. Sure you can make some decisions but way too little to call this a true hit.

Just like most co-operative games does Pandemic not allow any strategy or deep tactical decisions. Tons of theme but little game. You decide what you want to have fun.

RATING: 9
A big favorite of my wife. Plays great with 2-4 players. We're doing well with 5 Epedemics, but haven't tried 6 yet.

After playing a few games with open cards, we decided to try cards in hand, and it works much better. We talk about what cures each player is aiming for, and where we could meet up to exchange cards. Otherwise, we each take our turns without overanalyzing each other's cards. This not only speeds up the game, but makes it more realistic.

6/24/2010 - Bumped rating from 8 to 9. Pandemic with expansion is now the go-to game for my wife and me.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7.5
+1.5 collaborative mechanics work wonderfully and the PvE elements, feel like a real threat without seeming hollow or like we're playing against ourselves. 
+1 sense of building pressure and impending danger is worked into the mechanics fantastically
+1 difficulty is really well balanced
+1 if you have one player who knows the rules well, it's actually very quick to teach a new player just what they need to know

- .5 sometimes strong personalities can take over. While mostly a player problem, some of the mechanics/characters encourage that rather than prevent it

-.5 luck does play a bigger factor than I'd like

-1 Can feel like you're solving the same optimization puzzle every turn (researcher collects cards, medic moves/cures, operations builds stations etc). characters are specialized enough that it almost hinders choices so it feels like you're just prioritizing different severities of the same task over and over... There's still engaging choices balanced well to create tension - but choices can often seem limited. 

A great collaborative puzzle for 4 people to enjoy, with lots of tension and drama woven in. Not for powergamers though.

RATING: 10
Co-op game where you try to stamp out plagues.

Cubes build up in different cities and you use cards to help combat disease. Players all take unique roles that allow them certain abilities. Basically, it is a division of labor that pits optimization of all roles against time.

RATING: 9

We tried 5 players a few times and that presents the toughest challenge even though all 5 roles are in the game.  This game is quickly becoming one of my favorite cooperative games along with Shadows Over Camelot.

RATING: 10
favorite co-op game - level of play varies with epidemics added... 
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 6
Pandemic is a great game to introduce to new players who may be averse to conflict in games, but are looking for a highly thematic narrative. The tension of the card draws drives Pandemic and causes players to sweat, hoping that any one of a handful of cities on the brink won't topple over the edge into a morass of widespread contagion. There is a bit of a *potential* problem with quarterbacking, where one "alpha player" can drive other players... but a strong host should be able to disarm that. 
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8
Wahrscheinlich das beste Kooperative Brettspiel, ohne Verräter Mechanik. 
Eine gefährliche Krankheit rbeitet sich rasend schnell aus. Die Spieler übernehmen die Rollen von Ärzten, Wissenschaftlern und Logistikern, um eine Pandemie zuverhindern. Die unterschiedlichen Charakterklassen bringen Abwechslung in jede neue Runde. Außerdem lässt sich der Schwierigkeitsgrad anpassen, so dass sowohl Einsteiger, als auch Fortgeschrittene Spieler eine angenehme Herausforderung verspüren.

RATING: 8
A very good coop game in which players battle to contain and eradicate global diseases.

The word 'elegant' is often used in the comments for Pandemic and its easy to see why. The game is genuinely simply to play and at the same time a stroke of genius in working to convey its theme, with a good level of tension and a fair difficulty threshold. Its also insanely popular- nobody dislikes this game, and its popular with hard core gamers and casual gamers alike.

The co-op style of play seems key to this game's appeal, and depending upon the group dynamics you may find this one sails or sinks accordingly. Prone to follow the leader, especially when playing with veteran players. Also not sure victory is possible with some career draws. 

The expansion 'On The Brink' is also fantastic.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8
This was the first super successful co-op game on the market, although Lord of the Rings pre-dates it and would have done ok too.

Players must work together and make use of the abilities that their role offers them in order to save the world from a series of infectious diseases. 

The game works brilliantly on two levels. Diseases have the ability to spread and break out based on where they occur on the board and the deck of cards is constructed in such a way that locations that have seen the disease will appear again within a given timeframe, which can then lead to outbreaks.

It all adds up to an experience where the players know the clock is ticking but they aren't quite sure when the timebomb will go off. They then have to make the right choices to juggle the multiple threats and they only have limited resources with which to to do. 

Brilliant although can be dominated by an experienced player - so get the playing group right and ensure that decisions are made by the group.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

This is a good game, deserves more outings although that problem of the leader and co-ops is a pain.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 6

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7
Cooperative games often suffer from issues like alpha players, scripted gameplay and luck feasts and I seldom see the point in playing against a game instead of playing against humans. However, Pandemic turned out to be a pleasant surprise.

The mechanisms are simple but with many interesting applications: the game board consists of connected cities and cards are used both for actions and for telling which cities are hit by diseases. So far nothing interesting - gather cards and use them to move and fight diseases.

But once epidemics erupt, previously drawn disease cards are returned to the top of the stack, giving all players (even newbies) a fair chance to predict the next wave. If left unchecked, chain reactions will spread diseases to nearby cities with sometimes dramatic results.

The players must constantly balance short-term disease treating (to avoid letting the situation go out of hand) against long term cure researching (to fulfill the victory conditions) and the tension and engagement is high throughout the game. Even lost games are fun and the quick and short gameplay invites repeated plays.

Finally a cooperative game I can appreciate!
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: N/A
First played 2 Nov 2008, Minds Cafe.

Jan 2009: owned.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: N/A
7/2014.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 9
THE gateway cooperative board game for middle to adult players. Excellent mechanics, though definitely more fun with >2 players because there are exactly 2 player roles that just don't make a successful winning combination. Intense, play time not too long, multiple strategies & styles supported, & an excellent not-so-colonial way to teach geography sneakily (as opposed to Risk).

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8
Pandemic can rightfully take a decent hunk (though obviously not all) of credit for the resurgence of board games in recent years. Pandemic was one of the first games to really nail co-operative play in an accessbile fashion. As a team, you play various operatives fighting to keep a global pandemic from wiping out most of humanity. The only way to succeed is by planning ahead and communicating with your team-mates. It's a refreshing change from a lot of games where players go head to head, and a great amount of fun. It's crushing when you realise you can't stop the oncoming tide of the virus... but when the penny drops, and you realise that if you play the next turn in a very specific way you can win - it's immensely satisfying.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 5
The random deck decides wins. More fun than flipping a coin.

RATING: 7
[i]Best with one player.[/i]

En fait, ce jeu fait ressortir les traits de personnalité et le type de leadership des personnes autour de la table. Pour ma part, je sens que je serais plus à l'aise à jouer seul à ce jeu, ou alors, avec d'autres personnes qui le connaissent bien (mais pas trop!). Je n'aime pas donner l'impression d'imposer mes points de vue... ou vice-versa!

Par ailleurs, étant donné que tout le monde joue sur le même plateau, et que celui-ci sera progressivement recouvert de cubes, il aurait avantage à être un peu plus grand.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 9.5
Pandemic is simple to play, simple to introduce, and incredibly challenging. It's also a lot of fun. There's a strong luck component, but unlike games like Settlers, it's somewhat controlled. Usually, though certainly not always, if you know something bad is coming, you're able to address it, or at least to mitigate the effects. Every role has an ability which adds to the whole; there's no real weak thread. I've never picked a role and thought, "Well, so much for this game." Having played it at least a dozen times, it's still a challenge, and still entertaining. The expansions are great too. I love cooperative games, a relatively new discovery for me, and Pandemic is my favorite of those. The .5 points off is entirely for the tray in the box, which is terrible.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 10
This game made me realize that I like 'coop' games better. 

I just can't stop going back to pandemic whenever I have the chance.

RATING: 9.5
The cooperative nature of Pandemic offers a welcome break from the tension of competitive play as everyone joins forces against the game itself. The game engine is a well oiled machine designed to keep you on your toes as your team struggles to keep the constant spread of disease under control. The game plays well with 2 through 4 players with each number providing its own unique challenge. The varying roles make each game different, adding to the game's overall replay-ability. While luck can be a significant factor in determining the outcome of the game, this doesn't seem to matter too much as all players win or lose together. This game is just plain fun.

RATING: 8
Well, I had this at an 8 for some time, but I HAVE to bump it to a 9 now, for the very reason that every single person I have introduced it to absolutely loves it. Including... get this... my grandmother. I enjoy it quite a bit, but my friends and family seem to like it even more than I do. My one issue is that I enjoy losing this game more than winning it - it's much more dramatic. Winning is usually quite anti-climactic, and everyone always sort of looks around and says, "That's it?" Whereas losing always has everyone excited and emotional. Maybe my friends are just weird. I'm  also not so sure about the re-playability, it's starting to feel a bit tired even after 7 plays. Hopefully the expansion will cure this disease! (groan)

UPDATE: Tired is right, bumping it back down to a 8. It's clever, but the urge to play it has almost entirely died. I haven't even tried out the expansion yet, because it just doesn't seem worth it. 8 might be generous at this point.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 10
When this game first came out I followed it closely.  I even listened to a Google Talk that the designer of the game gave.  Honestly, I didn't get it.  I couldn't tell if it was just another one of these co-ops that ends up being *essentially* "Go Fish" (e.g., Lord of the Rings, Shadows over Camelot).  Also, there were reviewers who were writing that every play was obvious and mechanical.  Well, I played this for the first time at GenCon '09.  Z-Man had sold out by the end of Saturday, so I bought a copy as soon as I got home.  It's that kind of game.  In ease of rules to interesting outcomes, I'd rate it similarly to Ticket to Ride.  The rules are incredibly simple, and very, very tight.  What the rules don't capture, though is that ambiguous dimension of tension.  Some games are able to produce it, some aren't.  Pandemic's the latter.  This was true of a bunch of adults (at GenCon), and has been true with my two daughters (11 and 14).  It's a similar feeling to Twilight Struggle: you never have control over the board, and things can deteriorate very, very quickly.  Me, I like that kind of game, and I'd rank this as the best pure co-op that I've played so far.  Finally, it is simple enough that my daughters have pulled it out on their own when their friends have come over.  I think Z-Man has got a "classic" on its hands here. 
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 5
I can't pinpoint it, despite the group I play with loving it, but this one is not my cup of tea. It just feels like a boring exercise and doesn't push my buttons and causes me to feel like I'm really not engaging my brain much at all. Maybe it's the randomness of draws??? I don't know but this one is not a fave.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 4
Great design, but I'm not a big fan of co-op play. I think in order for a pure co-op game to appeal to me it would have to find a way to give each person a piece of the task that they have to do on their own, either because of hidden information or because the entire task is far too complex to be handled by one person.(Or because your teammates may be giving you bad advice because they're cylons! But that's team play, not co-op)

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7.5
In this cooperative game, players take on the role of medic, researcher, operations expert, dispatcher or scientist to combat 4 different diseases affecting the world. Players have 4 actions on their turn, to move, build research station, slow the disease or find a cure. Epidemics can break out and spread around the world. An excellent, fast paced game. A realistic mechanic is where the diseased cities are shuffled back in to the top of the epidemic pile. You feel like you are running around, with hardly any time. 

This is a very fun, addictive game. You keep wanting to play, to improve your play, and win. A side note, our gaming group has three copies of the game, and two of the games have duplicate cards. One of the games has a duplicate Khartoum infection card, and another game has a duplicate Los Angeles draw deck. Check your copy to be sure!
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7.5
Meh... It's good. Great maybe, but I'm getting a bit tired of it.  Clever stuff and quite hard to master.

RATING: 9
This game has provided some of my best ever gaming experiences. It's great when a group of people is brought together over the course of a game and, in the end, are all on the edge of their seat every time a card is turned over. There have been gasps and groans and cheers, and, when we beat the game by the skin of our teeth, sighs of relief. It feels like a real collective achievement when you win, and that's brilliant.

RATING: 7

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7
Pandemic maintains a sense of urgency in the face of growing crisis, and demands closely managed risk.  But you can't control everything, and there's a good chance it will all unravel before the game ends.

Having previously played Forbidden Island, Pandemic plays very naturally as the obvious parent.  Hand management, infection and epidemics have near replicas in Forbidden Island, while outbreaks progress in an obvious (if scary) way.

In Forbidden Island the game mechanisms match the theme - aided by it being an obviously contrived world.  In contrast, landing Pandemic in the modern world suggests a simulation, which it still could be if your knowledge of disease ends in high school and the evening news.

Play is abstracted from CDC operations to the point where the theme feels pasted-on, and you could just as easily be stomping terrorist insurgencies, mitigating the spread of refugees, holding back the collapse of the banking system, or delaying any other clustered anomaly.  This shouldn't detract from the game - unless you're playing it for the theme.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

2–4 Players
Best with 4

RATING: 6
It was an okay cube-pushing game. Cooperative is a neat idea, but I'm not sure its for me.

EDIT: After second play, main issue I have is alpha gaming. If you play with a group that lets players decide a lot for themselves, great. My group had an issue where players kept arguing over best moves and coercing others to follow a certain plan. This created higher downtime for me who wants to just progress and NOT optimize every step.

I wish the game came with a small sandtimer that lasted 3 minutes or something. I don't like being timed and this is a human problem, but it is annoying that you can optimize every step of the way and it drags. Also, epidemics are pretty luck based IMO.

Plays: 2

RATING: 7

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7
Pandemic is currently the only co-op game in my collection. I don't particularly like the genre because I have been indoctrinated that gaming is about beating someone - and that someone is not the game (I came to boardgames through trick-taking card games such as Whist, rather than RPGs, the latter genre would probably have made me more open to co-ops). This means I will never be completely sold on Pandemic, it's not my perfect game. BUT it is a good game nonetheless as there's plenty working for it. It is a short, clever game that has an engaging theme that seems to entice beginners, and it plays very well with two players. I love the short set-up time and the mechanism of how the outbreaks spawn. The downside is that it feels more like a puzzle than a game for me;  it's mostly about tactics with quite little strategy; and after a while it feels a bit gimmicky.

RATING: 8
Such a good game.  Plays great with just two people, easy enough to play the base game solo (controlling 2 or 3 players yourself).  Good way to introduce people to board games, especially since it's a co-op game and the theme is easily understandable.

What I like best is that you can change the difficultly of the game, and more likely than not the game wins.  Sometimes it opens a can of whup-ass and gives you a double serving!  However it's alway enjoyable win or lose and it feels like the game challenges you to beat it.

Can't say I like the new art on the 2nd edition so I chased down a 1st edition, the map looks so much better and I appreciate havng wooden pieces instead of the new neon plastic ones.  Impossible to get expansions for the 1st edition.  However you can buy the new 2nd edition cards to upgrade the 1st edition directly from z-man games.  If you do this you can use the 2nd edition expansions being released now.

If I could get more people to play the game I would buy the expansions, at least On the Brink.

RATING: 10
Pandemic ranks as perhaps the best game I have ever played. The basic rules are elegant and intuitive, the cooperative format is welcoming and friendly, and the roughly 90-minute play time all make the game extremely approachable and convenient. Elements of randomness never feel as though they override good strategy, but demand that those strategies constantly adapt to the changing situation. The difficulty is also quite high, but is widely adjustable (especially with the various expansion components) and ensures that even experienced teams will never find the game trivial. 

Exceptional!
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8
The ultimate gateway game. If you ever have people over and want to get them all playing a game this is it. The new version looks fantastic, especially the translucent cubes.

Pandemic's theme is something everyone can understand and no one will take offence to. People will spend time during their turn and other player's turns talking through what everyone should do. That said it can fall victim to having one or two players simply telling the others what to do, so it's worth mentioning.

I've been playing games forever though and I still love playing this one, with new gamers or experienced players alike. Definitely worth buying.

RATING: 4

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 9
A really nice co-op game, with a refreshing theme: Save the world from four epidemics. Players move around the board, trying to keep the diseases under control, while also searching for cures.
The players use cards to move about the board quickly. However, the same cards are also used to cure the diseases, creating a really interesting resource managing dilemma.

Cards representing the cities on the board are used to spread the disease. As the cards get cycled back ON TOP of the deck, the epedemics keeps getting worse all the time. Brilliant!
Also, this measn different cities will be hot spots in each game, so there's a lot of replay value.

Players also get five different roles to play for added variety.

Like all co-op games, it's quite hard, constantly handing it to us even on normal difficulty. We are barely able to win on normal difficulty, so I can't immagine how the game is supposed to be beatable on hard difficulty...

Having played some more, especially after adding the first expansion, I've decided to:

Increase the score 8 --> 9!
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 6
Looking forward to more plays in the future.

UPDATE:
October 10th, 2009: I'm not as impressed with it anymore. It's not a great cooperative game when people have such similar actions.

RATING: 8.5
Base Game: The best thing I can say is that no one I've introduced this to dislikes it.  Really fun.  

I might actually prefer the base game to the OTB expansion.  The base game has a simplicity and elegance that gets muddled at times by the expansion.

RATING: 4
Initially we found this fun to play but noticed it was more a group planning game than a game, and really there's very little variation in how the game strategy turns out.  The range of easy/boring to impossible/frustrating was a huge turn off.

For our group we had the good fortune to discover Flash Point: Fire and Rescue and it unfortunately for Pandemic we have played it once since owning FP:FR and it confirmed how much better Flash Point was.

This game might be rated higher as a solo game because there's little deviation from the group strategy once it has been established taking a lot of the co-op aspect out of it.  There is zero individuality in it.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7
Pandemic is a great co-operative game with a unilaterally acceptable theme. The integration of theme to gameplay is a little abstracted though, but mechanically very functional.

The only negative factor about Pandemic is the ending, whether a win or a loss, has an anticlimactic feel. The condition for victory being just curing all 4 diseases, rather than having to eradicate them, usually leaves the world roiling with infection even though the game has been won. It feels somehow... unsatisfying. 

Chose to search for a 1st Edition of Pandemic purely because I don't like the pompous cover art on the 2nd edition.

RATING: 4
I find this one boring. I also find Forbidden Island dull but at least there's less hullaballoo in it. My dissatisfaction with these two specific games has to do with either something in the nature of co-ops or in the specific way that the disaster events are actuated by reshuffling the discard deck. I thought it was the former (since I didn't have fun the one time I played Flash Point either), but then I played Hanabi and really liked it. Maybe it's that you can probably play Forbidden Island, Pandemic, and Flash Point as solitaire games (and in a group it ends up being hive mind solitaire), but by its nature, Hanabi must be played with other people.

[color=#117bc0][b]I'd probably rather play:[/b][/color] Forbidden Island, but I don't like that one either.

Unfortunately, games where I'm not dispatcher are not terribly interesting to me now. I loved playing it at first but I am giving it some time before I open the box again. Considering buying the expansion. 

Edit: Giving myself some space helped me value this game more. I think it still suffers from what I mentioned before but I can approach this with more excitement than I did before. I should get the expansion! Sigh.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7
I have played this twice solo to get the feel of the game.  I absolutely love the ramp up mechanism that creates an escalating tension in the game from start to finish.  I won the first, but lost the second, as the Black Death took over in the Middle East (ran out of cubes).

I finally got a chance to play this with other people.  It lived up to my expectations - a really good game that is cooperative and accessible.  The group included what I consider non-gamer types, including my wife.  She likes Hive, but not enough to suggest it during off hours.  The others have played Settlers, but absolutely disliked PR.  They all have biology interests so the theme intrigued them.  We played the introductory game and by the end, were getting the turn rhythm down.  But we lost by one turn!  We ran out of cards.  Everyone wants to play again (especially me!).

Why this is not a 10:
->  I do not want to play this all the time, mainly because it is a cooperative game - I prefer competition a little more.
+ The mechanics are really cool and the theme fits for me.  I have no problem suggesting this, especially because I think I can get a game going with my [mostly] non-gamer friends.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7
I understand why it's already a classic: great theme, easy to learn rules, quick pace, nice components, scalable difficulty, playable with all type of gamers and non gamers...

Still, placing the shuffled Infection Discard pile on top of the remaining Infection Draw is a mechanic that doesn't convince me; I understand it's necessary because othwerise it would be too easy to avoid outbreaks, and it also fastens the pace, but it also creates some non desirable (for me) effects:
-> All the action of the games happens on very specific places; lack of movement through the world
-> Favors the creation of fixed strategies that you'll carry from one game to the next (creation of investigation centers in affected cities to move quickly between spots, etc.). 
-> If 2 epidemy cards are very close one to the other, you'll face a big problem; if this happens twice...

At the end of the day, success on games [for good or for bad] can be determined solely by the [random] placement of the cards.

Still, it's a game I love to play from time to time.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7
A very good, short cooperative game. The theme fits cooperative game perfectly. Deadly diseases are a perfect faceless enemy for a cooperative game. One nice touch is the fact you can make game easier/harder easily depending on players skills. 

Update (13.2.2009): After few games Pandemic feels perhaps a tad too deterministic to play. It's still a very fun multi-player puzzle to be solved and because of a great theme it's one of best cooperative games I've played. Pandemic also suffers from "one player can play game" -syndrome most cooperative games seem to suffer. This isn't as big minus if all the players are about as loud and as "good" in the game.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8.8
Overall, a nice production.  The insert is "meh" at best, but the components and board are nice, so it's a reasonable trade-off.

The game itself is strong, with a lot of things to consider, and a neat card mechanism where certain "trouble spots" keep cropping up again and again instead of random outbreaks everywhere.  Very unique.   

My only complaint would be that the game feels a little too short, and the ending a little bit unrewarding.  These complaints are only a small problem though; they certainly don't destroy the game by any stretch.  

This game deserves the praise it is getting, and you should own a copy.

RATING: 10
Absolutely love this game.  I can understand when people say it may get repetitive and definitely encourages the "alpha" player, but this is still one of my favorite games to play with my family (and we hardly ever win)!

The complexity can be a little daunting to new players, but once you get it, the game really starts flowing.  The theme is amazing, as you always feel like you really are fighting a losing fight for the survival of mankind.

Definitely  recommend picking up the expansion as well.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 9
I seriously don't think I have anything new to say that hasn't already been said about this masterpiece.

My full review is located in the In The Lab review.

So I will say this.  In the Lab improves the base game.  I don't play the base game and refuse to play it without the expansion.  Does that mean Pandemic base game was released 'incomplete' without the devices/mechanics of In the Lab?  Absolutely not.  Pandemic the base game plays very well without it and is very immersive without In the Lab.

That's why I speak so highly of the expansion because it some how pushes an amazing game even higher!  So buy Pandemic.  If you like it then get In the Lab.  [On the Brink is really just for players who want an even larger challenge].  In the Lab can increase the challenge, but really, it just makes the regular play experience better.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 4.5
Non adoro i cooperativi, ma questo titolo mi intrigava. La mia delusione credo è legata anche alla monotonia della partita. Il meccanismo per la verità riesce nel suo intento di ambientare il gioco, il tutto però è troppo ripetitivo. Quattro o cinque azioni a disposizione, il più delle volte suggerite da chi ha più esperienza con il gioco e non troppe scelte da prendere. In sostanza trovo molta poca strategia ma solo un po' di tattica in base alle carte pescate. Il gioco può essere modulato con diversi gradi di difficoltà, generalmente questo può rallentare un po' il successo o addirittura portare ad un fallimento che però è spesso più determinato dal tipo di carte pescate che da effettivi errori strategici. Non il mio genere di gioco ripreso in mano dopo anni solo per ripassarlo in ottica Legacy dal quale mi aspetto in realtà molto.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 4
An excellent co-operative that doesn't feel like the more traditional games of this genre (notably LoTR and Shadows Over Camelot) because of the swift pace and less need for players to confer. Tidy, simple but effective mechanics keep the disease cubes spreading and means that players can't afford to stagnate. Surprisingly tense stuff too as you reach the final stages. It looks like the expansion will help to customise this a dozen different ways for all levels of difficulty and enjoyment.

Further Thoughts: Lacking in longevity, it would seem. We've done all we can with the game, and it looks like we might be going back to Shadows Over Camelot. Downgraded from 9 to 7.

[i]Traded with expansion for St Petersburg and Meridian[/i]

A Co-op? or cooperative? WTF?... so wait... were not playing against eachother?... were playing together against the game? bullocks!

I was very skeptical at first... but the one play i played did sway me... So it seems that the game is tough at first, but  after learning how to "cooperate" you get better, and then can increase the difficulty accordingly... (sweet!)

i heard that the creater created this game becasue he wanted more games that he could play with his wife (great idea).

i recomend this game on the basis that it's different, fun, and "cooperative"... (i also heard that some couples play agricola "solo-mode" cooperatively... i will be trying that out hopefully really soon)

i could play this again, but hopefully it will be at the gaming group when my wifes there (i dont want to buy it unless she likes it... and the upfront rules are a little much to get past, but by no means difficult)

RATING: 9
Pandemic is a strategy game that provides players with the chance to work together to solve the puzzle of curing all the diseases before you fail in one of many ways... 

I truly enjoy the myriad of ways you can play this game, the changes in difficulty from learning to Heroic mode, the different characters, and the chances you have to take to win. Once played through, the mechanics become understandable and teachable to others. This is a game with a lot of potential for repeat play and is easily digestible thanks to the short time frame of around 45 minutes and the cooperative play approach.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 6
[b]Pandemic[/b] is cooperative game where the players work together find cures for four different diseases.  Each player is dealt a different role which all have their own unique special abilities, and each game begins with randomly chosen infected cities on a world map, so each game plays differently.  Games last about 30-45 minutes.

There are three different difficulty levels controlled by the number of "pandemics" you add to the draw deck.  I don't like varying difficulty levels in games.  You don't feel any satisfaction if you can beat the game on the easy levels, and you wonder if you really know how to play the game if you lose at the harder levels.

So far I've played all of my [i]Pandemic[/i] matches at the medium difficulty level and have won less than half of the games.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8
The game that really got me into boardgaming. This game has never been turned down by anyone new to boardgameing. and for that it should get the most praise.

It's just such an inviting combination of theme and mechanisms. Sure there are much better implementations of theme in other games and sure there are better coops. 

But Pandemic just nails the accessibility, so that your non-gamer friends can join in this wonderful hobby!
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

You need the right group of people to bring out the best in this game.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7
The artwork in this game is beautiful. However, don't be fooled by the attractiveness of the rule book's pretty colors: for a game this popular with relatively simple rules, this may be the worst rule book of its kind, starting with reverse type and continuing with a  layout that jumps around the pages, adding to the confusion of an underwritten booklet. 

Don't believe me? Look at the sheer number of rules-related windows on Forums (December 2016), and the unprecedented numbers of videos trying to show how to play. Had to use videos and consults rules questions on BGG to clear up several rules questions. I was able to rewrite the rules for how to play onto one page, with 12-point Verdana, and half-inch margins. But it took hours of viewing video and reading through rules forums to figure it all out. 

On the other hand, having already owned and played the same designer's similar but less complicated "Forbidden Island," I didn't find the game particularly difficult to learn, and, with a handle on the rules, felt I could also easily teach it.

Purchased new for 25% off at local Target, December 2013. I own the 2012 2nd Edition.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8
The co-op game of choice for my table.

RATING: 7
060517
Played twice with 6 year old. Most of the time felt like I was playing the whole game by myself. The challenge was figuring out the optimal moves based on what cards we have in had as well as our individual powers. Lost the first one by making a big risky move and also using two underpowered characters (generalist and Dispatcher). Will continue to review the rating with subsequent plays.

RATING: 10
WOoohhhhh! This is one seriously scary game! Another awesome cooperative style game. You must cure the 4 deadly viruses from around the world (Anthrax, Ebola, Typhoid Fever, and Smallpox) before time runs out. We have now played several games! With 2 players you can win a good bit of the time...but our games with 3 to 5 players are more intense and challenging! There are ways to win under normal or heroic conditions...but you need a fair bit of luck on your side, the right conditions, and a clever combination of roles! Simple!...No way! But always...always a great game, even when we lose!

RATING: 8
規則:
*起始一個實驗室跟所有玩家標記在亞特蘭大，爆發瘟疫軌都在起始位置，感染牌抽九張對應城市前3張放3個病毒標記，在來3張放2個，最後3張放1個，抽出的放在棄牌堆
*每個玩家隨機角色，事件跟城市牌洗勻根據人數拿手牌(4/3/2張:2/3/4P)，根據難度使用(4/5/6)張瘟疫卡，將城市卡平均分成瘟疫卡數量堆，分別洗進一張在疊起，手牌城市人口最多的為起始
*每人一輪分成三個階段，做完換人直到勝利或失敗，手牌上限七張，任何時候超過都要棄(事件牌可先用)
1.做四個行動 以下可重複
A 移動  移動相鄰一格/棄對應城市牌飛過去/棄目前所在城市牌飛到任意城市/兩間實驗室任意移動
B 蓋研究室  棄所在地城市卡蓋一棟，六棟蓋完就變成移動研究室
C 治療 移掉一個病毒標記/該顏色解藥發明後，移掉該城市所有該色病毒標記
D 分享手牌 給或拿所在城市的城市卡
E 發現解藥 在任意研究室，棄五張某色城市卡發現該顏色解藥，移動解藥標記在板上，如果城市都沒有該病毒就放禁止符號面該病毒被根治
*根治的病毒抽到感染牌不會放病毒標記
2.抽兩張牌
*抽到瘟疫牌(不補牌) 先增加瘟疫軌一格>抽感染牌底牌，該城市放三個病毒標記/如果該城市有一個以上，放到三個並爆發 > 棄牌洗勻放在感染牌堆上
3.感染城市 根據感染軌抽感染牌，放一個病毒標記在該城市
*爆發 一個城市某個顏色病毒要加第四顆發生，移動爆發軌一格，相鄰城市都放置一顆該顏色病毒，可能會有連鎖，連鎖爆發不會放病毒在之前爆發的城市
*失敗條件 牌不夠抽/病毒不夠放/爆發軌到頂
*事件卡可以在回合任何時候出，也可在抽感染卡之間出
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

BGG rank 43
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8
Great game!
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 5
It's okay and I'm engaged the whole time. I usually play with 4. I just worry that the outcome may be determined more by the draw of the cards than by smart play or teamwork.

It's more of a multi-player puzzle than a true game. Another thing to note is that with true games, as you get better, your opponents also tend to get better. When you are playing against a random number generator (like Pandemic), it takes the same approach every time (random), it doesn't think and it sometimes coughs up easy combos, sometimes impossible draws. 

This is more akin to playing "solitaire" or "spider solitaire" on a PC. There are different situations you can be in (without knowing it at the start): sometimes you win with no trouble, sometimes the setup is impossible due to the shuffle of the initial cards. You don't know which situation you are in until you play it through. The activity of playing it through can be fun (I occasionally play solitaire on PC while waiting for other things to load), but it doesn't change the fact that whether you win or not is almost completely random- it was based on the cards, not your decisions.

Bought Jan 2009, Sold Feb 2011 after realising I don't like pure co-ops or the randomness.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

RATING: 8
Found it on sale on Amazon for $25, and since my four boys (ages 10-16) and I enjoy playing games I figured it was worth a shot.  One of the best game investments I've ever made, no question - to the point that when I found Pandemic: On the Brink on sale I purchased it for the point in time when we're ready to expand.

My 13 year-old is very particular about what games he likes to play, so he's usually my litmus test.  The only one who didn't like it was my 16 year-old, but he's at the age of not wanting to spend time with me anyway, so I take that with a grain of salt. :)

The first game took about an hour as we figured out the dynamics and game play.  Needless to say the outcome was not in our favor - despite an early eradication we quickly lost ground.  After that we were able to sort through the best way to leverage the various roles' strengths.

This is one of the few games that, even after a rocky start, my boys kept asking me to play - THAT is a win.

The only downside thus far (and it's a stretch) is that role combination can swing things pretty substantially.  But it's a small downside, and if anything makes it more challenging.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

Nice artwork, good theme, straightforward gameplay.

I find I'm playing a lot of collaborative games lately and Pandemic is a great addition.

It gets requested regularly at the moment, and once we start playing it becomes very addictive :-) Great replayability.

We find it a great introductory game for non games. My daughters (aged 11 and 8) also love it - so it has become a regular family game.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8
A Great Gateway game for a multitude of reason into both the hobby and the co-op genre. Co-ops in general make great gateway games because new players are able to be coached along because of the win or lose altogether mechanic, but this game takes the cake. This game is easy to teach and learn because the concept is based in our present day and easy for people to grasp and relate to. The game setups up easily and provides clear instructions for new players to follow. With in mere turns anyone can grasp the game and start making decision for them selves and contributing to the outcome. This game also has a relatively short play time which is always a plus when introducing new player to the hobby or gaming in general for non-gamers. Me and my wife being avid co-op players do not find this game to be much of a challenge but it is a nice escape from some of the more stress inducing mind bender co-ops that we play. I rate this game so highly simply because of its utility as a Gateway game for which it fires on all cylinders. Also this game is readily available via major shopping chains.  
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 9
100+ plays across its various incarnations. The more I play this, the more interesting it's become. It's a collective race against time kind of thing. Do the best you can with the cards you get dealt (literally and figuratively) and you'll either win or you won't. But some nice strategic and tactical decisions along the way, even though you might only be able to tell the best moves in retrospect, and a lot of the decisions are reaching a consensus on the best risk management play. Nice length, with a "next time we'll do better" feel.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 9.5
Wonderful game - great sense of escalation.  It is always a climactic ending for us - whether we win or lose. We can usually find the first cure quickly, and things can be quiet until you find the second one.  But if you feel you've had a break early in the game, things will ramp up pretty quickly after the second cure is found.  Even when  things are quiet, there is tension because you know something big is coming. This is a sign of great design.  This is my opinion after about 25 plays. I feared that it would get stale as a 2-player game, but I am happy to say it hasn't been so.  We regularly play on level 6 with the base game and level 5 with On the Brink.  It is also great with more players.  A little more difficult, as you each have fewer turns and need to coordinate very well. But you have to play with the right group:  don't play it with alpha-gamers or people who are sensitive about others offering suggestions.  It will mar your experience with this game if you play a game like that early on.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 4
First play with 2 players on easy was fun, but we were close to winning. Started over to add third player (normal) and that ramped up the fun and tension considerably. We lost the game within 40 minutes! Can't wait to try again. Never played a co-op game before and this genre hits a sweet spot that is sorely missing from my games and all games in general. I hope designers pick up on this mechanic and run with it!

Update: Our second 3 player game was so tense, such a nailbiter to the end, that I got a stomache ache. I love it! We had one round (six card draws) to figure out a way for one person to give another person the needed cards to cure the fourth and final disease. We threw strategies back and forth, and at one point seemed so close to a solution, but to no avail. The last infection draw of the game caused the final outbreak, and we lost even before we could try for a cure. This game now goes up to a 9, my first 9, based on the excitement of that 3 player game. 

Update: game quickly lost its appeal.

RATING: 9
My favorite co-op game so far. Works well with all number of players and provides a good level of challenge.

1 Player 5 Epidemic - Wins 2 : Losses 2
2 player 4 Epidemic - Wins 2 : Losses 3
2 player 5 Epidemic - Wins 2 : Losses 3
3 player 4 Epidemic - Wins 3 : Losses 0
4 player 4 Epidemic - Wins 2 : Losses 4
5 player 6 Epidemic - Wins 0 : Losses 1

[b]Rating History:[/b]
• Original rating of 9.
• Upgraded rating to a 10 on Jun 21 2013 after 10 plays. The more I play this game, the more I thoroughly enjoy it. I even find it enjoyable to play solitaire, with two roles.
• Downgraded back to 9 on 19 Sep 2016 after 30 plays. That is a ton of plays and I still love the game but it isn't a 10.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8
At first I was completely against the pseudo-multiplayer the Leackock system provides.

Now I feel that there is no game that can replace Pandemic. 

The theme is strong and engaging for players regardless of age, sex, gaming experience and general interests. It's a hit every time. If I have doubts concerning the way my game night will evolve I get Pandemic from my shelf. 

It will never be my favourite game but it seams it will be my most loyal soldier. I believe a must have even if you don't like it that much. It's a great tool.

*** Convince players to hold their cards in their hand, so they are forced into participating in the conversations about how the team will act (sounds stupid but works).

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8
I like this game a lot.  This is probably the ultimate co-op game.  A few of my friends don't like this game for that very reason; there is no individual winner.  You all lose or win as a team.  That's it.
The components are basic, but gets the job done.  It's meant to be a little abstract, and I can appreciate that, especially considering the subject matter.

RATING: 7
10 plays - Nice solid design, though am surprised to see this game so overwhelmingly/ passionately loved by so many. Ultimately, winning will be a mix of good decisions and non-punishing deck draws. The game strikes this balance really well, creating a very nice tension. The different player abilities (and combinations used between games) helps create replay-ability, as does the variable ways the world can become 'infected'. It can become victim to the 'alpha' player, but ultimately I feel that is more of a criticism about who you play this with, as opposed to the game itself.

RATING: 8.5
Excellent group game.  The mechanics for the virus spread are simple but implemented effectively.  The benefits of each player's role weight minimally into the game, but allow for some variation and sightly more elaborate cooperative efforts to leverage those perks.I highly recommend the game to folks looking for something you can play together and cooperate instead of compete.  Both 4-player games we played took about an hour, I would assume less players would make the game go quicker.

By the way, for a relatively cheaper priced game the components are top notch.  The cards and board are of a good weight and the pawns/pieces are all wood.  My copy had some pieces missing, but the company has responded quickly and I assume my replacement pieces will arrive soon.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8.5
This is one of the best co-operative games out there and it can be played by almost anyone. The mechanics are simple as you perform 4 actions a turn to prevent outbreaks and cure diseases. It is great for getting new people into games as it plays easily  in less then an hour and has a great theme. However after about 25+ plays I am at the point where if I play with regulars we win every time and if I play with new players I cannot speak as I will basically play by myself, so to let them figure it out I only comment sparingly. I still think it is a great game and suggest it to others but I no longer need it in my collection. You could get an expansion after a lot of play which does add some neat new features and mechanics.

RATING: 6
Non andiamo pazzi per i giochi cooperativi, ma Pandemic ci piace per qualche buon motivo: ambientazione originale e assolutamente attuale, semplicità delle regole che non diventa banalità nel gameplay, giusta tensione durante ogni partita e durata contenuta.
Per godersi una partita, è consigliabile a mio parere giocare un po' di ruolo: "ho tre blu, chi mi da il quarto?" ammazza letteralmente il gioco. Infine, risente pesantemente del Grande Problema dei Giochi Cooperativi: se tra i giocatori emerge un leader, la partita sarà un solitario con tre burattini e un burattinaio.
Merita comunque una onesta sufficienza.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 10
Don't even start with the Alpha-Player argument! 

As an Alpha,having played this game enough times to buy a replacement, don't be a schmuck-ask players questions,include players, and let players play.  By the 3rd game, most players have found their voice and have caught on to the game.  The only times I have ended up grossly Alpha-Playing is when I teach the game to a whole group of new players.  Don't do that.

The great thing about this coop game is that the randomness is predictable and risk assessment good.  At first, it seems like the cards are stacked against you; but as you master the game, you can make calculated risks and weigh your choices.  This means that your choice has value.  When we loose a game, I can generally point to a choice we made that didn't pan out during the game.  That makes me feel in-control; unlike Robinson Crusoe. Additionally, it is that weight and calculated risk that keeps good-players guessing, there is no standard tactic, obvious choice, or methodological mechanics that makes the game rote for good-players; unlike Castle Panic.  This means that every game is different enough so your choice has meaning and your decision will shape the game.  That is a difficult balance in coop games.

Suggestions for Alphas: 
1) Don't teach a whole group of newbies-they will all look to you for decisions, letting you play the game for them.
2) Introduce the game to a group with another player who has played the game.  Let that player go Alpha, you get to be the Obi-wan of the game and be a mentor.  Hint-Ask questions of the new players.
3) If you are introducing Pandemic, then just introduce to a single newbie.  Play the two player game, it will be quick and you can play again, and again, and again, until they really start grasping the game.
4) Don't be the Scientist, Researcher, or Medic; make the newbies be those characters.  These characters abilities directly affect the game and bring a sense of glory during a loosing game.  Contingency Planner is always a good character to take when teaching the game.  
5) Throw the first game.  If the group easily wins the game, then most players will dismiss Pandemic; probably because someone Alpha-played.  If you loose, those competitive players' aggression starts to come out, and then they want to beat the game.  With a bit wise mentoring, these players can encourage other players' voice.  By the end of the night, you got a group of coop gamers talking over each other. Just lovely.

RATING: 6
Pros:
+Tough game that can be very challenging to win
+Nice map artwork
+Components are nice, wooden bits are fun.
+Interesting theme

Cons:
-Can end suddenly
-Can be impossible to win
-Gets tedious after awhile, needs expansion

Edit: After playing this again after about a year of sitting on the shelf. I actually quite enjoy it. A '6' is the perfect rating for this for me. It's a tough game but the only thing that kills it for me is the "co-op" part of it. It can be very one sided in that fashion. I feel as if I have to be in the right mood for this game. It does play nicely solo though and it's just long enough to keep my attention. Still would like the expansion at some point but it's quite low on my priority list.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 9.5
One of the best cooperative board games of its kind. The mechanism and rules are very simple to understand and it has a theme that is challenging, yet suitable for a family game. If you enjoy such games, you should definitely give Pandemic a try.

A unique characteristic is that it features various "difficulty levels". If you get bored by beating the game easily, try putting in more epidemic cards. Things will change.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 10
I bought this game based on the recommendations of others and a pretty big whim, thinking the cooperative aspect would be something fresh.  Boy, was I right.

Great balance, a fiendish difficulty, plenty of randomization, and an unprecedented level of cooperation make this one of my group's most-played games.  I've played Arkham Horror and Battlestar Galactica.  Both games pale in comparison.

Unfortunately, a couple of factors prevent me from awarding Pandemic a 10.  It is too easy to get lucky or (as is more likely) get screwed over by the randomization in the game.  Also, a lot of times there is a clear path that the players should follow, so you can lose a game while feeling that you never did anything wrong.

RATING: 7
Pretty good cooperative experience. I like the rather high difficulty. Some roles are imbalanced and there is quite a bit of luck. I doubt if I would like playing this with strangers or people who I know little about. An obnoxious personality could dominate the game and end up telling everyone what to do which would be annoying. With agreeable people; however, the game is decently agreeable in that player's must cooperate to shape a winning strategy. Long term planning is usually pointless as the random card draws will often derail your intentions. The challenge is constantly reworking and adapting. The theme comes out in the gameplay fairly nicely.

RATING: 7
This game is responsible for drawing a bunch of our friends into boardgaming -- being cooperative, the new person doesn't feel left out in the cold, or that they shouldn't ask what to do next.  Plus, it's that new person (whether new to boardgaming, or new to Pandemic) that always asks to play again -- the game has an incredible "hook" factor.

That having been said, I fear that with an experienced group the game is approaching being "solved", with the only tension being whether the cards are going to dictate a win or loss by the appearance of the epidemics.

RATING: 7
Not many good co-op games exist but this one is one of the best. A simple game which can be easily explained and therefore played by almost anyone. Players can be replaced easily if somebody has to leave the game.

It's a tough game. Your most dangerous enemy is time (in this game too). But again, co-ops need to be tough. It's fun to lose together!
Also the theme appeals me: curing diseases. Of course it would be nicer to save the world everytime but hey, no one is perfect.

I'd really like to play more, this one was as good as I expected it to be. The only thing that prevents it from being an 8 is the mechanical approach. I'd like a bit more immersive action.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 6.75
Fun Factor: 1 
Components: 7
Theme: 8
Mechanics: 9 
Theme + Mechanics: 9
Replay Value: 9 (This thing wants you to replay it, nay, dares you.  Problem is, is it really worth it?)
Scaling/Players: 8
Subjective:  -0.50  As cooperative games go, I find this to be more of a multi player logic puzzle than a game.  Arkham Horror on the other hand, is unquestionably a game.  Perhaps great coops fall between this spectrum?

I will go down as a martyr here, but Pandemic just doesn't seem like a game to me. Granted, there are decisions to be made and player interactions to be had-- but really it just feels like one big logic puzzle to me. A puzzle does not a game make. Before somebody charges me with co-op rage, I love cooperative games. The active word being "games"  Cooperative puzzles, not so much.

Games differ from puzzles through:
Player interaction.
Dynamism.
No predetermined outcome.
Superior involvement of skill and chance.
A more active agent of antagonism.

I consider Pandemic to have little player interaction, be very static, and have a relatively predetermined framework within which the players muddle about believing that they can control the outcome. Chance and skill are severely muted within the context of Pandemic, and the agent of antagonism doesn't impress me, because after all it is just a sequence of shuffled cards that regurgitate. Sounds more and more like a puzzle.

Read this quote from Wikipedia on "Jigsaw Puzzle Strategy"...
Quote:
The most common approach to building a puzzle is to start by separating the edges from the inside pieces. Once the edges are built it can become easier to move inward. For those new to puzzles, it is recommended to choose one consisting of multiple areas with contrasting designs and colors. This enables the narrowing down of potential portions of the puzzle where a particular piece will fit.

Some people like to use the picture on the box to help solve the puzzle. Once you have completed the edge, if you can find the location of a particular piece on the picture, you can place it down inside of the overall puzzle at approximately the place it belongs. If you do this enough times, you find pieces eventually will start fitting together.

Another approach is to sort the pieces by color, and work on one color at a time. When you get to large areas with the same color (such as the sky in many landscape puzzles), you can go by shape, or you can place all the pieces in a grid and approach the problem by taking a piece that already has an anchor (such as an edge piece) and trying it against all the pieces laid out.
Strange, but this sounds an awful lot like a game of Pandemic.

The worst part is that you might even be working on a puzzle that cannot be won, so Pandemic probably does not fit the standard for even the most sadistic of puzzles. It is like a jigsaw puzzle that you are working on, and when you are looking the other way, the dog comes in and scarfs down a few pieces. Am I going to keep working the puzzle, or am I astute enough to sit up and take notice that some of my pieces are missing at this point so I might as well chuck this whole "Pandemic" thing in the trash and go play a thoroughly enlivened game of Twilight Struggle?

Also:  HOW IS THIS GAME RANKED SO HIGHLY ON BGG?  FOR SHAME.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8
After many plays, this is settling at a 7 for me. The game plays quite well and I love the production, especially the bright disease cubes and the infection cards. The spreading infections and sudden epidemics make for a dynamic and tense experience and the various role combinations tend to require different strategies. I've had great success introducing this game to people. Even folks who groan "cooperative?!?" end up loving it. Highly recommended as a gateway game. I'd pull this out over something like TtR or Carc without a second thought.

It's not an 8 or better for me because I now often have to bite my tongue during games to keep from directing newer players - so much of doing well simply follows from having played enough times to have "solved" the optimization problem the game presents. I do enjoy it, though.

My second favourite co-op game after [b]Ghost Stories[/b].

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 3
There is a tremendous amount of unavoidable randomness. I prefer games to end with the feeling, "I wish I had done this differently," but every game of Pandemic merely ends with, "I wish this had happened differently." Whether it's drawing two epidemics in a row, having an immediate unavoidable outbreak following an epidemic, or having all of the cards of a certain color at the bottom of a deck -- there's just so many factors which can lead to a game loss being completely out of your control.

Besides that, the amount of agency each player has on the game is practically zero. You can go for a 15 minute smoke break and come back and see what players have decided for you to do on your turn. Perhaps in this way it's a "true cooperative" game, in the same way Solitaire could be a true cooperative game. But I strongly prefer cooperative games like Hanabi where players are forced to make their own decisions.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7
[b]A potentially great game where the immersion is ruined by character selection issues due to a lack of all male characters and no way to choose your character.[/b]

Pros:
* Great theme and production quality.
* Great board that gives the game a nice tactical layout.
* Variable roles with different abilities makes you feel like an actual team trying to fight a pandemic.

Cons:
* [b]-1 for potentially being forced to play as a female character.[/b]
* -1 for not having any choice of your character at the start of the game.
* Forced limited rounds by running out of player cards is lame.
* Petri dishes should have been included with the original game to store the virus tokens.
* Without any expansions the game gets very repetitive, [url=https://boardgamegeek.com/boardgameexpansion/40849/pandemic-brink]On The Brink[/url] is an essential expansion.

I only recommend getting the latest edition (2012) as the component quality is phenomenally better than the original.

---- Update ----
This game is not for the competitive at heart! I can't get them to like this game as much as I like. The desire to bring this out is less and less.

---- Update ----
Traded this in a math trade because can't hit the table at all with my brother and sister-in-law and I am tired of this "puzzle".

RATING: 3
I really don't know why people love this game so much. I find it pretty underwhelming. First off the player(s) that have played before pretty much have to tell new players what to do, so the new players are just extra hands at first. Second, I'm just not afraid of cubes spreading and don't know why we just don't call this a game of set collection, with maybe a loop or two. I can't see why we don't ignore the outbreaks for the most part and just focus on set collection, since that is winning the game mechanic. Finally, had I realized the game would end with the deck, I simply would have asked for the total number of cards in play and divided by the number of players, so people would know the exact number of turns available to collect the card sets. I can see how this would have limited interest as a solo-play game, but it just doesn't grab me like it does so many others in my game group. It may partly be the theme, but it is also the game mechanics - I don't really like Forbidden Island either, which I understand is by the same designer and has the same sort of feel only a lot shorter.
