RATING: N/A
One of the few cooperative "race against time" type games that never ceases to be fun.  I tried "Pandemic Legacy" but didn't enjoy all the extra fiddly bits and the destructible game pieces, so I came back to the original.  An hour spent saving the world from superbugs (or failing to do so) is never a waste, and the game design is brilliantly balanced, with most games remaining tense until the last moment.  I can't count how many times my friends and I have barely won within a turn of running out of cards - or lost because we were only one turn too late.

RATING: 6
Interesting mechanic for a game, but difficult to find the right group of players (without a strong alpha).  In my family, everyone has an opinion and everyone wants to approach the situation their way.  I don't get to game that much, but when I do, I want to be able to select a strategy without having to settle for an inferior one or having to fight to defend a better one (so I guess I fit right in).

It is also difficult to find just the right difficulty level - it seems that the game is either too easy to beat or impossible to beat (with On the Brink).  There aren't enough games in the middle where different play would have made the difference between winning and losing.  After the game ends, I never find myself saying, if I only moved to Rio...  

Rating for first few plays: 7.5, Rating for subsequent plays 6 (once the uniqueness of cooperative play and having the recently used infection cards return to the top of the deck wore off for me).  But, my family still enjoys it.

RATING: 10
This game has rapidly become one of my favorites.  Quick and simple, but very tense.  Pandemic overcomes most of the problems that other cooperative games have (too much randomness, swingy challenge levels, etc) to produce a fun and elegant game experience.  Have never played it with anyone (from newbie gamers to hard core vets) who didn't enjoy it.  I have the first expansion and it adds a ton of replay to an already excellent game.

UPDATE: After a dozen or so more plays, continues to stand up and be interesting.  Excellent gateway game, excellent depth for the hardcore gamer.  I've bought the second expansion but haven't even played it yet, there's so much to do in the first one.  One of the best games in my collection.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7.2

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 9
Pandemic pits the players against four diseases (blue, red, black and yellow) spreading over the world. The goal is to find cures for all four before time runs out, the diseases become too widely spread or too many outbreaks occur.

Players need to collect and discard sets of five cards of each different color, one set for each disease. Given that there are twelve cards of each color, a hand limit of seven cards and limitations of trading cards accumulating those cards can be tricky. The cards can also be discarded for faster travel and to build research stations which further reduces the available cards. Players start with four cards each in hand and draw another two from the player deck at the end of their turn. If a player has to draw cards and the player deck is empty, players lose.

The diseases spread each turn by drawing from an infection deck, placing more disease cubes on the map. If the infection cubes of any disease runs out, players lose. Infections can also lead to outbreaks, when a city that is already at three infection cubes is hit. No cube is added to the city, but all cities connected to is are infected, which can lead to chain reactions. If eight total outbreaks occur, players lose.

Apart from the city cards, the player deck also contains event cards that provide benefits to the players and epidemics (5 for a standard game). If an epidemic is drawn, the infection rate is increased, leading to more infection cards being drawn each round. Then an infection card is pulled from the bottom of the deck and infected with the maximum of three infection cubes. Lastly the infection discard pile is shuffled and placed back on top of the infection deck. This means cities already infected will be drawn again.

If the players on the other hand manages to clear all infection cubes of a cured disease, that disease is eradicated and cannot infect again.

The players have to weigh multiple priorities over the course of the game. Treating infected is important, but so is trading city cards between players. Should a player hold on to a card or use it to build a research station or travel by plane to a city threatening to outbreak? What color to hold on to?

Despite being a fairly simple game, it has enormous replay value. At the time of writing I have 77 logged plays and I'm still not tired of it.

Make sure to try it as soon as possible!
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7.5
A game that so far has lived up to its hype for me. Fairly simple to learn, but with an elegant and well thought-out design that keeps you coming back for more. Love the balance of elements...eg, clean cities now to prevent a possible outbreak or move to another section of the world to hand over a necessary card to discover another cure? And, as discussed in another thread, the "intensification mechanic" is brilliant.  After an epidemic, to have to reshuffle the discards and place them on top of the deck, moments before having to draw multiple cards AGAIN, raises the stakes tremendously and creates a beautiful tension. Love this game!

RATING: 8.5
Awesome cooperative game with a similar feel to the Lord of the Rings coop game, but a much more appealing & approachable theme. Also has clearer & simpler rules, but is more enjoyable & somehow more gripping than the LotR effort.

The varied roles & adjustable difficulty level are superb and should ensure this game remains challenging for a long time.

The components are decent, although the board is too small for the pawns/buildings, and doesn't quite want to lay flat.

WARNING: Appears to be common for copies from the first print-run to have missing/duplicate cards (my copy had 2 missing/duplicated - sorted with publisher).

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7
Several games played with most of the games being close wins or losses. Upped the rating from 7 to 8 as it is socially enjoyable with 2. Probably the best introduction to the attitude shift involved in co-operative games, better than say Scotland Yard in that:- a)the short playing time allows a repeat to improve and consolidate performance; b)the problem of 1 player wanting to dominate the proceedings is tempered by what the held cards allow, which encourages everyone to socialize; c)more tense countdown elements and one use only cards to consider. One thing that comes to mind is that I complained about 2 chaotic subsystems in La Citta recently, and here they are again, but I can tolerate the card draws as amongst the team we can "discuss" a workable route through the chaos. Update: I was alittle concerned about replay value, but after a dozen plays it is still a fun, tense and quick experience, so up the rating.

RATING: N/A
Co-op game: work together to save the world from deadly diseases. Collect sets of cards to find cures and treat the afflicted.  Control the disease population to prevent outbreaks and stem the tide of epidemics.

Cure all four diseases before the cards run out or you all lose the game.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7
Although you could find this game rather depressing, you shouldn’t give up just yet.  We must act NOW and we might have a chance to save humanity!
To eradicate this pandemic, we will have to stand together: we need to put in place a strategy to take advantage of our special abilities. Easier said than done… And the clock is ticking.
The game is quite balanced although having the doctor in your team is a significant advantage. The board, cards and pawns are nice.

Certes, au premier abord le contexte du jeu pourrait sembler déprimant... Mais l’heure n’est plus à dépression, il faut agir : êtes-vous capables de sauver l’humanité ? 
Pour venir à bout de cette pandémie à temps, les valeureux joueurs vont devoir faire preuve de solidarité. Mettre en place une stratégie qui tire profit des capacités spéciales de chacun n’est pas si évident, et l’heure tourne… 
Le jeu est assez équilibré mais compter le médecin parmi son équipe donne tout de même un net avantage. Le plateau de jeu, les cartes et les pions sont de bonne qualité.

RATING: 8
[floatleft][ImageID=1029048][/floatleft]Pandemic is the king of cooperative games. Players must utilize their individual powers and work together as a team to stem the tide of the infections before a global outbreak grows out of hand. Despite falling to the pitfalls of being a cooperative game such as the 'leader' factor, Pandemic rises beyond that to be a great game. Pandemic also has one of the greatest expansions of all time, [thing=40849][/thing].

RATING: 9.6
P: 2-4, T: 45 min, SdJ-N
Probably the gold standard of co-ops. Appeals to a wide audience; simple enough to be a gateway but challenging enough to satisfy others. 

Unique player powers and scaleable difficulty. Game generates palpable tension as players puzzle out short and long term needs without running out of time. 

It will eventually get a little stale, due to limitations of the variable setup, but there are a couple really good expansions for distinctly different scenario type play.

RATING: 6
I like that i can play Pandemic with new gamers, but the amount of autonomy and tactical input the game affords players who don't know the rules so well is so minimal, that it's hardly worth them playing at all.
In addition, playing with more experienced gamers really just involves deciding on a strategy, and then waiting to see if lady luck gives everyone aids or not.

In theory this should be true of most cooperative games, but play Battesltar Galactica or Arkham Horror, and you'll see that it doesn't have to be.

My favourite thing about Pandemic is deciding what to call each of the viruses and diseases..

RATING: 7
2009
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 9
This feels almost more like a cooperative puzzle than a game. A lot of the fun is figuring out how the game systems work and trying to delay the losing conditions just long enough to meet the win condition.
It's hard to play just once, especially if you lose, since every loss feels like "Oh, we just had to do two more actions and we would have won!"

The expansions add a lot to this game, and I love how modular they are. Pure co-op games are at risk of going stale as you figure out how to play the system effectively, but you can always add a different mix of the many expansion modules and you have a slightly new spin on the basic game to think about.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 6
Sort of lost interest.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8
8 - I was really suprised by this game, I tried the Matt Leacock co-op trilogy at PAX and walked away with Pandeminc AND Forbidden Island.  Pandemic grabs me the best, it's a solid theme that's simultaneously serious and lighthearted.  Most games I play I find myself running short on time because of the player deck, with 4 players you end up with ~12 turns each time flies by quickly and all of a sudden you realize you won't get another turn after this one and the viruses overrun everything.  I find it a challenge and actually enjoy this with 2~3 people way more than 4~5 but still try to play it with new people whenever I can.  It's a nice gateway game because it breaks several molds at once; it is totally cooperative, it has a fixed turn count thanks to the player deck, it's fairly randomized without any dice, and it has a good amount of strategy "we don't need to worry about mexico since it just came up and we had an epidemic last turn, so lets focus on europe a little more."  
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

One of my absolute favorites, since it's also one of the few cooperative games I own. Incredibly hard to beat, but still fun.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8
Can you win the race for the cures before outbreaks catch up with you? 
Fills the cooperative niche with a simple focused design.

The epidemic mechanism makes the game since outbreaks will reoccur in the same areas. Must be able to fight a delaying action on treating (removing) the diseases, while also working on the cure - keep you eye on the prize - that is finding cures.

Makes it tough by using the cards for movement/building centers but also need them for the cure. The roles for the players provide a different experience when playing fomenting some discussion.

Finally my wife really enjoyed, she usually can't play just one session.

While not thematic looking - the game play is true to its theme.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 9
This game is widely praised for good reason. It's beautifully designed with respect to its themes. There are so many genius mechanics that ties well into the thematic elements, such as epidemics and outbreaks. The game is not too complicated and it fosters a good sense of teamwork without any secret agendas. If I were to point to problems, finding the right challenge is tricky with regards to number of players, number of epidemic cards and roles. Speaking of which, some roles are flat out better than others (the researcher for example makes the game far too easy). That being said, all the roles are well thought-out when it comes to approaching the narrative of trying to cure diseases and makes each player feel unique. The other slight issue is that luck can unfortunately be a bigger deciding factor than I would have hoped for some games depending on which cities get infected at a particular point. One note on the players' hands being open for all to see: while I like that players can really help each other out and formulate strategies together, it can make so that more experienced players (or who owns the game) tells others what to do on their turn. I don't think too much is lost by making hands closed, as players can still say what cards they have (such as how many of a certain colour) but there is an extra barrier in place so it is harder for players to dictate what others do on their turn. All that said, Pandemic is amazingly designed, very tense and its theme is so well executed that players really can get invested in trying to save the world.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

Quite well composed light EURO in the cooperative category however the strategies can be straightforward after some plays. Recommended only for real team players.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 6.5
Purchased 3/1/2008 $33.10 - Rated after one play (2-player, introductory game).  The game was pretty easy to win as we had only one outbreak during the three epidemics that came up.  Red (SARS) was eradicated, Black (plague) was rampant in Europe, Bird Flu was taking over the US, and we almost eradicated AIDS in Africa and South America, but couldn't get the last cube off and it reemerged strong.  We had the Scientist and Medic, which seems to be a great pair for two players.  Will need to play with 6 epidemics soon (or weaker characters).  2 Bogata Player cards, 2 Scientists, no Dispatcher, so yes there are assembly problems.  Update: Have now played with 5 epidemics and twice with 6.  With the exception of a game that no one could win (just bad card sequencing, using up all black cubes in the second turn when the first epidemic card was turned), we have won all games and only one got close to using all the cards in the deck.  It plays much like a baseball simulation--you set it up and make the "right" decisions during play and watch it all unfold.

For those who say it's straightforward, I believe that's only true after a couple of plays.  There aren't many options, but remembering the details (must play card of city to build a research center; cured diseases get the Medic privelege; etc) isn't perfect.  Those rules should be on a cheat sheet card as well.  Personally, I'm not sure I like the "variable powers" mechanic.  I wouldn't mind if you could pick your character trait to use every turn.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 1
I truly do not understand how people actually enjoy this game! First off its main game driving mechanism are two separate decks both of which need to be aligned in just the right way or you lose period. Yeah that's fun. When a games main mechanic can be so in favor of losing because a bad shuffle ruins the game it ceases being fun! I am not saying you should win every time or even half the time. I have played this crap game SEVERAL times and not won it once! Played it on my iPad, lost! Played it with my game group (who boasted they won 66% of the time) six times and lost every one! An utterly broken mechanic that only rewards good planning and problem solving a third of the time and even then its too easy for the game to beat you. For this experience its down to Forbidden Island for simpler card driven or Flashpoint Fire Rescue (dice are such a better randomizer than cards are) for me. I saw the redeeming value of Twilight Struggle and gave it a 4. I see NO redeeming value of this game whatsoever.

Remember this is just my opinion. All games are not for all people. This one just hit me absolutely the wrong way. I tried to like it, I really did because the theme is awesome. It's just a shame the game is so un-fun to me.

RATING: 6.5
I can see why so many people like this game so much: the theme is very good and the cooperative element is intriguing. None the less, I am not really satisfied about it:
 
- the play is too abstract (every disease is the same) and repetitive

- among the different options available you obviously tend to stick always to the same, because every character has a very useful "special power", and it's almost always pointless to try something different. 

In the end, all the play is just to plan your winning moves for the next turn or two, and then cross your fingers about the cards you will draw.

RATING: 3.75
Bought the game at Leisure Games. The mechanics and flow of the game are well thought out.Unfortunately, I had to rate this down because after playing it with different groups, I must admit that this heavily relies on the right people. Pandemic is very cooperative and there are not many mechanic-related interactions available, so all the discussing, negotiation, planning etc. is voluntary and if people don't go for it, the game feels pointless. I had players sitting around not "getting" the game because they refused to interact with other players, which renders your own options useless. Still, with the right people, good game.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: N/A
I feel like this game helped me get into board gaming. I bought it on Black Friday (Full price though LOL), and was fascinated by the Co-op aspect of it. Needless to say, I played it as soon as I could. It wasn't nearly as complicated as we thought it was, and won almost all our games. We DID find out that we were doing a rule incorrectly, which brought our win ratio down, but still won a lot of games. Recently, I won two back-to-back games on the hardest official difficulty. I guess we have to increase the infection counter next time. The first time we played was a blast, the second time was still pretty darn good. I just dislike how short the game feels with a decent amount of setup and space it takes. Also, the theme is lackluster, and doesn't impress a lot of people. The role cards are great, the components are nice, but overall I feel like this game just doesn't have enough for me. I can see why others praise this game so much though. It's a shame that the base game doesn't allow for more players; I don't think I will buy expansions for this anytime soon.

RATING: 8

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 6
I don't care much for co-operative games, but this was much better than I expected. Last co-op game I remember playing is Lord of the Rings, which is so horribly convoluted and has a badly implemented theme. (At least it has excellent artwork).

Because of my experience with Lord of the Rings, I was expecting something as equally convoluted with Pandemic. Refreshingly, Pandemic is very easy and light. Very well implemented theme; all the roles and actions make thematic sense.

Because the game is so simple, you don't have that issue with Lord of the Rings during which experienced players will dictate what the newbies should do, and the newbies simply follow blindly. In Pandemic, it's simple for newbies to figure out what should be done without much help from experienced players,

RATING: 9.5
I'm a bit of a fan of co-op games (not that there are many), and this is one of the best.  Played it about 20 times in 4 weeks, which is pretty much unprecedented for any game.  It has that real "just one more go" feel about it.

It would be a 10 for me, but I felt that I had to dock it half a point due to deck collation issues (sorted quickly by Z-mangames once spotted, but it's a widespread issue with it seems very few copies being shipped with two perfect decks of cards), and also the problem with the wooden bits.  They're very nice, but far too big (especially the player pawns and research stations), and I'd have preferred discs to cubes to mark the disease.

My rating has been revised twice since I first got the game, both times upwards.

RATING: 6
The upside:
-Tense moments are provided if you manage to the late stages of the game.
-How deseases spread makes sense, provide a tough challenge, and strategic decisions arise when you start to predict what will happen where.
-Variable player powers to best use.

The downside:
-The perfect play can be destroyed by luck.
-Very prone to one more experienced player to control everyone.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 4
An interesting co-op game that's at the right level of complexity to feel like a challenge, while still being accessible and enjoyable to those who are new to gaming.

It's like the first boss of a video game.  There are so many better games out there than Pandemic, but conquering it can open a newbie's eyes to what modern boardgames can truly offer, and give them the mental toolbox to go out and conquer bigger prey.

On its own, Pandemic isn't much of a game.  You struggle against a random card draw that evolves into a repetitive AI to cleanse the world of cubes.  
The randomness of the cards - and thus the AI - means that winning will oscillate between punishingly difficult and mindlessly easy, and the effort you put into the game doesn't necessarily translate into meaningful outcomes.

That Said, Pandemic does a good job instilling a sense of teamwork and camaraderie in the face of an implacable enemy, and it feels good when you see your unified struggle start to pay off if you make progress.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7.5
Sold to Juegamestore.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 9
Play this game with the background music from this youtube list: https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=DBY7FnkNI4c&list=PLD98304DDE0430113
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8
Original comment:
Fascinating mechanics and structure. I don't know yet if the "rigging" of the infections as to target the already-sick cities tips the game too much in the too-hard-to-win direction. But it's fun trying to win so far, and it's one of the only quick cooperative games out there, and could be used to introduce casual gamers into more strategic fare.

Years later:
IMO, Forbidden Desert upgraded this game in almost every way. It removes the finicky setup, removes the likelihood of a quick death by insta-Outbreaks amongst your first cities that got 3 cubes on them to start, and does everything Pandemic does but does it better, and cheaper.

Pandemic was a fantastic entry into the co-operative gaming genre, and simultaneously revolutionized and popularized it, but the years have passed it by (base game) as the designer's sequels surpassed the original in every way I care about.

RATING: 7
I was the odd person out at a recent gaming convention - Pandemic had spread. I've never seen a game out there as often as this one. But it contained too may elements I dislike in a game: awkward mix of negotiation and problem solving (almost like a puzzle, but far more random - the deck luck factor is too high) with too much discussion & not enough play. I drifted off half way through the game. As with all co-operative games, I actually enjoyed seeing us lose. Not sure what that says about me...

The last game I played was the first that sparked my interest - I think the negotations were brisk, which helped. Rating could rise...

RATING: 8
House Rules:

1. at the end of the turn, the players *may* take up to two player cards, they don’t have to. 
2. exchange of player cards does not require a player card of that city when both players are in the same city. 

Argument for those house rules:  The Player Cards represent "research", therefore it should be the players' choice whether they want to conduct further research or not.  I don't see why research data would get lost when two players meet to exchange data.

RATING: 7.25
Jugado a tres jugadores. El juego si nos transmitio esa sensacion de agobio en algunos puntos del mapa segun los brotes e infecciones aumentaban.
Jugamos tres partidas, cada una con una epidemia mas (aumento de dificultad), y la unica que conseguimos ganar fue la primera, aunque por la minima, ya que solo quedaban 4 cartas en el mazo de juego. Las otras 2 partidas las perdimos, una por fallo nuestro de organizacion y la otra, la mas dificil, por las epidemias y los brotes en cadena que generaron.
Se noto la diferencia de dificultad entre partidas, y nos gusto esa sensacion de derrota, pues nos incito a jugar mas. A gustado a todos.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 10
Cooperative game with the perfect balance between approachable, easy to learn gameplay and thoughtful, intentional strategy. Excellent for teaching and getting others into gaming. There are a few expansions that add different elements and mechanics in case the base game starts to feel dull. Most plays offer a good challenge with mounting tension as the game goes on, coming down to the wire whether you win or lose. Best with three players in my opinion but four is really fun as well. The variable player powers all add to an interesting experience and it is fun to try out different ones, finding which works best with the group as well as your playstyle. Art isn't amazing, but it is really good and components are good quality. All in all, a very well crafted game that never fails to be a fun time.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8
Losing to this game just makes you want to play it again and again. Its pretty quick.

The only negative I find is you all have to be working together or you are likely to lose. But working together usually means telling people how to play, which I don't like in coop games.

Great game.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 5
Great theme, simple to play, smells funky!
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 9
I resisted play Pandemic for a long time--probably because the theme doesn't exactly appeal to me.  I get nervous and clammy just thinking about those medical shows on TV.  One time I passed out in class when a teacher was telling an anecdote about a trip to the hospital.  However, there is too much strategic goodness to resist Pandemic.  I especially enjoy the different roles that each player can take because it means that different players have different mini goals even if the overall goal is the same.  

I can see that it would be possible to have one experienced player boss the other players around to the extent that the other players would just be pawns that might as well be painted pink, green or white, but that didn't happen in my game, and I would say that as long as all of the player were of similar skill levels, that this shouldn't be a problem.


***Update after playing with my boyfriend who likes almost none of the games I like***

I think I've finally found the holy grail game!  This is a game that has strategy, but doesn't leave us hating each other at the end.  Pandemic is a game that my boyfriend actually likes!  And I like it too.  A lot.  In the two or three player games that I'm likely to play at home, Pandemic is not going to suffer from dominate personality problems because we are all introverts and great at listening to each other!  Hooray!

My rating is raised from an 8 to a 9.

RATING: 6
A fun and quirky game filled with delicious tension and frantic decisions.  A well-done cooperative game that truly feels like the game is effectively working against you.  At times, this game feels more like a distributed solitaire game than a game where everyone is making autonomous decisions.  A great game to experience the first time, but not a lot of replay substance if you're actually looking for something to play.  Success requires efficient management and coordination of actions, but over-optimizing analysis can quickly drain the fun from the game.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 5
After playing Pandemic, it is hard not to compare cooperative games like this one to puzzles (or card games like Solitaire). It is possibly too soon to disregard the full cooperative/solitaire boardgames genre outright based only on this game and the cumbersome Arkham Horror, but I must say that, for me, Pandemic already ranks lower than at least one other game in the genre: Ghost Stories. Most cooperative games should begin with stealing/borrowing the no-talk rule from King of Siam to try to make things more interesting.

RATING: 7
I expected more, but still it's not a bad game. It's a euro-style co-op game, where the theme actualy works well with the mechanics.
The players should be always on the edge, losing to the board is common and the rare victories are very narrow. 
The "intensify step" is an instant classic mechanic, it's thematic and makes the games very tense.
Not one of my favorites, but if somebody would like to play it, I'm ready to save the world.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7
I really enjoy this game, but fear that it often turns into one person basically taking control of the game, due to its cooperative nature.  As I'm often that one person, it's something I'm a little sensitive to, because I don't want me dictating what everyone should do to ruin the gaming experience of other people that are playing.  I don't think this has happened, but I see the potential that it could.

I like that this game constantly feels on edge, where you always feel like you are a step behind, and disaster could strike at any moment.  The theme is really beautifully implemented in the mechanics of the game.

UPDATE: I lowered from an 8 to a 7 primarily because most games I have played have turned in to one person dictating the game to everyone else, who mostly nods in agreement.  I know this is a common problems with cooperative games, but it seems to happen here even more than usual.  To me this really highlights the importance of mixing things up with a possible traitor/cylon, it keeps everyone on their toes and gets them involved more.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

RATING: 10

Pandemic proved to be MY true gateway game since it did provide the oomph I was looking for with strategy, mechanics, player interaction and excitement. In the gateway game war between Pandemic and Ticket to Ride, Pandemic easily wins the battle in my opinion.

RATING: 9.5
Still one of the best cooperative games. It's simple to teach, and new players pick it up quickly, but the special powers and managed randomness of the epidemics keep it feeling fresh.

I love the way the tension builds to an exciting finish just about every time. It's a great gateway game, and regardless of prior gaming experience, almost everyone I've played with gets sucked into trying to solve the puzzle of the game.

Just wonderful. I also enjoy co-ops that are a bit heavier, but this one will remain a favorite for the foreseeable future.

RATING: 3
I've done an about-face on this game. The quarterbacking is simply unacceptable. It is a solo puzzle game that could support up to four people pretending to make their own decisions, but the reality is that the 'team' works together and there is no personal gain or loss to going against the grain. All in all, a good concept and a fairly good intro game for non-gamers, but I'd prefer other games like Carcassone for that role.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8
In my view the purest coop game with all it pros (we are a  team, hooray) and cons (alpha gamer problem). Even if there are now more complex coop games of the same type (no traitor; all information is public; enough time to discuss the actions) like Robinson Crusoe, you still get the same  experience out of this slim design. You have discussions what the best course of action is: Do you have to react to some imminent threat or is it better to improve your long term position. And all the time you fear to draw that one card, which will mess up your plans.

I like the mechanism that disaster always strikes, where you are most vulnerable (i.e. used city cards get put on top of city card deck, when epidimic card is drawn). I always  have a great time when playing this game.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

RATING: 8
Fun co-op, a little too long for a filler. Expansion makes better game but is not a must.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8.5
Players: 1-4
Time: 45-90 min.

A cooperative game in which players are trying to save the world from being overrun by disease. Players have to find cures for four different diseases. Finding the cures isn't hard, but it has to be done before the world is too sick to be saved. So players must choose between saving resources for the cure, or spending resources to move around the globe to treat affected areas before they get out of control. Random set-up and variable player roles ensure a different experience each time.

I have 5, 7 and 12 and finding a game of sufficient depth to satisfy the eurogame bug in me but at the same time, include the younger kids is a monumental feat. I can add that my wife enjoys it also (a little). The co-operative portion makes for a more peaceful family gaming experience and of the co-ops I've played, I like this one the best.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7
Dorado
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 9
We played this at UCON 2012

I am sure people have complaints about Pandemic, such as quaterbacking and damage control (which honestly you get tired of both after playing a few co-op board games these days).

This is my take: Pandemic is a more interesting version of Forbidden Island with a Risk-like element to it :)

I love Forbidden Island, and so also loved Pandemic.

It was hard to tell before playing it if I would like it or not- some reviews made me wary and others made me curious.

I think now that none of those people had played Forbidden Island or else they would have been forced to mention it. Pandemic IS Forbidden Island, stolen, re-imagined (slightly) and re-themed, and made bigger and a bit more board-gamey and relevant.

That is, a global virus spreading is more topical and relevant to us than... a magical island... sinking... which we can stop how? And we care because? Yea, I think you get the point.

So. Just like Forbidden Island, damage control, flood management, hand-size management, character placement management, set collection and timed tracks.

Also, the really cool over-flow mechanic which can set off chain reactions (which ended the world in our game). I liked the flight-by-cards and control-center-building mechanics too.

There is even an option for one player to be a bad guy bio terrorist and a 5th virus expansion. 

I liked Pandemic. Oddly, enough. It is now at the top of my to-get co-op game list. Can't wait till we can afford to buy it, oi :P


=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 5.5

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8
Excellent game. Even on lower difficulties, I've rarely had a winning game where victory wasn't coming down to the wire. Seriously, games are always close when you win. When you lose - it's possible to lose horribly and you can only laugh when the game really screws you over! :)

My only quibble with this type of co-op game is that it is common to breed a table captain. Then it just becomes a single player game, with one player telling everyone else where to move. I try hard to avoid that, as the more experienced player I find it better just to advise others what their character can do ability wise and then let them lead the discussion on their own turn.

The board and components are of nice quality. Artwork is all excellent. Game mechanics and turn structure are simple to learn but can offer great depth.

All in all, games are generally a fun, exciting and engrossing experience. I really recommend Pandemic.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

CONS: some roles are unbalanced

RATING: 7.5
Pandemic is just a great design for a simple co-op. It offers just enough theme to allow people who are so inclined to tell a story amongst themselves, and the cards-and-cubes hit a good balance between simple to learn for nongamers, and manipulation-friendly for gamers. It's true that Pandemic can get old and stale after awhile, but that's true for most games. This is one of those titles which is great to keep around for introducing new players or hosting mixed groups. And anything that can solo reasonably gets a half-point bump in my book.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7.5
31-10-2015. Rated after 1 play. So I finally played Pandemic. It's really, really close to something like Defenders of the Realm. I'm not sure what I like better, the lean design of Pandemic or the Fluff of DotR.

Regardless. Pandemic is a coop game set in a diseased planet Earth, where massive disease outbreaks need to be controlled by a team of medical doctors.

Each turn, each player has 4 action points to spend. By spending the points. These points you use to travel to locations, cure disease cubes, build CDC centers etcetera. At the end of your turn, you flip and resolve 2 cards that repopulate the board with disease. If there ever a 4th cube placed in a city of 1 disease, the disease has an outbreak and spreads to adjacent cities.

You win as soon as you develop a cure for the diseases in the game, and you discard a card by tossing 5 location cards while balancing the board for disease.

RATING: 7
----------

Pandemic is good for a co-op... but I don't like co-ops and would rarely suggest to play one.

I do feel that the game is very light; this is good for introducing to new gamers, but it's also a bummer for me because I don't want to make the decisions for the newbies and ruin their experience by dominating the play.  So, I only really have fun when playing with experienced players (I'd much rather use TtR or Catan as intro games because competition breeds excitement).  

I traded it off, but it's okay if I don't play it again.  It's fun, but 7 plays was enough for me to see that the game, while fun, doesn't have a lot of variety.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 9
Pandemic has recently stormed into my current top 3 games. Perhaps because it is the first cooperative game I've played. Yes, you and your friends join forces to defeat the game - a truly unique experience for those who have only played competitive games.

Though the luck factor is fairly high (on the harder settings, you can easily have games that are un-winnable), you undoubtedly continue clinging to hope even when (almost) all is lost. The gradual build of impending doom makes for a thrilling experience.

More than any game I've ever played, advanced players can easily play with newbies and still have a great experience - making this a great into to euro games.

Amazingly, Pandemic is also the best 1 player board game I've ever played.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8
Pretty good cooperative game.  I have played this game and both won and lost, so it's not too easy.  It becomes apparent what are the best professions to play with after a game or two.  With all cooperative games however, it's easy for one or two personalities to dominate the game and direct everyone's actions.  If you have any shy players, they may feel like they aren't playing.  Each game is different in that viruses will show up in random locations, but generally the games all have the same flavor since the board remains static and the route to victory is always the same.

RATING: 8
német, használt, 5000 HUF
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8.3
Solo Player Value = Excellent. Playing solo with a single character is rough. I like to use two characters. A single player can manage two character easily.

Two Player Value = Excellent. Pandemic scales flawlessly.


Pandemic is a very well designed cooperative game that scales nicely from being played solo to being played with many. With a single player the game is absolutely fantastic. The single player can play as a single roll or as multiple rolls allowing for more choices.

Essentially Pandemic has been built as a solo solitaire game that has a strong win or lose victory condition with the player fighting against the game itself. More players can play the game because the game is solitaire based and the players are cooperatively fighting against the game. 

This multi-player solitaire against the game works well in Pandemic and actually changes the games difficulty. The game gets more difficult with more players as each player then gets fewer turn. In the solo game this is the player playing multiple rolls.

Playing against the game is accomplished by a player taking a turn for himself, followed by taking a turn as the game; after which it is the next players turn to follow the same pattern. The game's turn is fairly scripted and pre-set making it easy and clean to run the game.

Since Pandemic is designed to be played as the players versus the game the players can strategically work together for victory. This leads to some wonderfully tight strategic choices for the players that can truly make the difference in victory or defeat. Every choice feels like it is important.


Pros - 
- Great design
- Scales well
- Excellent strategic choices for the players
- Suits many players from solo to four

Cons - None

Overall Playability = 8.0

Design = 9
Strategy = 8
Luck = 7
Artwork & Components= 6
Use of Mechanics = 9
Time of Play = 8
Fun = 9
Innovation = 9
Analysis Paralysis = 8
Theme = 7

**This game is scored using the expansion


[b]-------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------[/b]


Here I will discuss the Pandemic expansion [thing=40849][/thing].

This is truly a wonderful expansion.  If only all expansions could be this good.

This is the first expansion that I can remember which offers multiple expansion components inside the single expansion.  Basically, in this expansion are three separate and individual expansions that can be added to the base game in any combination.  This is a great idea and goes a long way to improve the game longevity.

Due to that I will discuss each piece of this expansion separately.  

------------------

The Virulent Strain is the first piece of this expansion.

With this piece a single disease becomes more powerful and deadly.  That particular disease then has extra rules to govern it which are somewhat random and unpredictable.  This does a lot to increase the difficulty of the game.  

This new difficulty makes the players re-think the games strategy.  The players must now come up with a way to keep the Virulent Strain from quickly spinning of control, while maintaining control over the other three diseases.  This is often much harder than it sounds as the Virulent Strain is designed to cause the players problems.

------------------

The Mutation is the second piece of the expansion.

With this piece a fifth disease is added to the game, called the Mutant Strain.  The Mutant Strain has half as many cubes as regular diseases which make it twice as deadly.  This really cranks up the games difficulty.

The Mutant Strain is governed by special cards which are in both the player draw deck and the disease deck.  This makes the Mutant Strain spread quickly.  Dealing with the Mutant Strain often take precedence due to its lethality, but players must still contend with the other four diseases as well.

------------------

For a real challenge players might want to play with both the Virulent Strain and the Mutant Strain together.

Dealing with both of these disease at the same time is both fun and challenging and offers a huge step up in difficulty.

------------------

The third piece of this expansion is the Bio Terrorist.

This is the first game I can remember that takes a cooperative base game and turns it in a competitive game.  Many games now offer this ability with expansions and I think Pandemic was ahead of its time in this manner.

In this expansion one player becomes a Bio Terrorist and works against the other players.  The Bio Terrorist controls the Mutant Strain and decides how and where the Mutant Strain moves and grows.  The Bio Terrorist gets a turn like normal players but has actions geared toward spreading the Mutant Strain and damaging the players.

While this is a fantastic idea, I think this fails in practice.  The actions the Bio Terrorist can take are limited and weak and somewhat diminish the potency of the Mutant Strain.

Also, this expansion has an element of Scotland Yard to it.  The Bio Terrorist remains, and plays his turns, hidden.  Finding and capturing the Bio Terrorist greatly slows him down.  I don't think this adds anything fun to the game and even confuses the other mechanics.  

-----------------

I think two out of the three new pieces are absolutely fantastic.  The third piece I simply do not like.

Because this expansion so greatly changes the base game I think I should re-score the game.


Overall Playability = 8.3

Design = 9
Strategy = 9
Luck = 8
Artwork & Components = 6
Use of Mechanics = 9
Time of Play = 8
Fun = 9
Innovation = 9
Analysis Paralysis = 8
Theme = 8


[b]-------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------[/b]


[b]Unique Component[/b] - No unique components.


[b]Unique Mechanic[/b] - From what I can remember this is the first real fully cooperative game where the players compete only against the game itself.


[b]Quick Thoughts[/b] - Fantastic game.  Easy to learn, but still offers deep strategy.  Scaling difficulty keeps the game replayable. 


[b]-------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------[/b]

RATING: 8
I definately enjoy  this game's version of coop play.  More so than in other coops I feel like this game can really go bad for you and its not through sub-optimal play.  Actions are always tight and you always wish you had just one more.  The different roles really maximize replayability and definately chang up the strategies.  Components are good if not great and are really added to by purchasing a petree dish for each cube color.  The game is definately easier with less players.  I've lost severl 4 player games (w/ 5 Epidemics) but the balance still felt right and the tension was always there.  If you drop down to 3 players I think you need a 6th epidemic to make it more tense.

RATING: 7.5
The pros: Solid cooperative game with an original theme, straightforward rules and surprisingly short playing time (even shorter, when you lose). Should appeal to casual gamers, too. The virus spreading mechanism is outstanding.

The cons: Can be easily dominated by an experienced player. Depends mostly on lucky card draw. Some of the roles are less useful than others.


Update: the new german version by Pegasus is slightly better in terms of components. BUT the translation of the rules is mistakable in some places, and the text on one of the special cards is simply wrong. Sigh... you can't have everything, can you?

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 10

RATING: 5
Loved it at first, fun diminishes over repeated plays. There is almost always a "BEST" move to make, and yet still not necessarily a possible way to win. =-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 6.5
Initially, I loved Pandemic. It was a simple, elegant design, that could be played by any and all with a theme that didn't turn off anyone. The fact that the game also played quickly gave it a chance to hit the table quicker - something to do in between events instead of waiting specifically for a "Game Night".

That said, each game leaves me slightly wanting more. I'm not begging for a traitor (I'm in the minority of actually not caring much for that mechanic); but it feels so rote - so demanding that the role you choose must be played in a particular fashion or everyone suffers.

Occassionally, I can still rise to the challenge. I want to be the (insert role here) and see if I can take on six epidemics; but with so many other games out there...as much fun as others have putting this on the table, I'd like to play something new.

Until something like Swine Flu twists me up...then it's a Pandemic Weekend Jamboree!

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 4
Solitaire multiplayer. Too easy for one or two veteran players to make the decisions for the other players in the game. At least with, say, Arkham Horror, a player gets to draw an Encounter card and play it out. Thematically, I find it annoying that the cards function like one part disease research solution and other part like... airline tickets. I *do* like how the gameplay changes depending on which roles are *not* in play. If you like solitaire games, this one's for you. I'd probably play this game when I'm in a mood to watch a game unfold, rather than meaningfully play it.

****

What I liked about Pandemic is that all five roles are critical to solving winning the game. And you only have four of them!

But that's about all I liked. Pandemic also reminds me of AH -- except that there's none of the Encounter card chrome (aka. "randomness") that puts a player in that amusing position of making a possibly human "sacrifice" for the team.

Arkham Horror:
"Hey, Beaver! Go into that Witch's House and get the Clue token!"
"No, way Whitey! There's a Gug there, and all I have is this crappy Dagger! I might get Injured, and Mom would be upset!"
"Oh, alright, Beaver. We'll meet in the street and I'll give you my Curse of Azathoth. But you'll have to give me $2 for it, because I'm low on Sanity and need to go to the Sanitarium."
"I told you, you shouldn't have read the Livre De Lion."
"Shut up Beaver, and sneak past that Gug!"

Pandemic:
"Okay, Beaver will remove two cubes in Mexico City, Dad will build a research center, and Mom will dispatch me to Beijing."
"Hey, Wally. You should let Beaver make a decision."
"No way, Dad! Last time he did that, there was an outbreak in Tehran!"
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

Even though it's a solved game, I still enjoy getting together with my friends and finding out if things will spiral out of control on us.

RATING: 9
Pandemic has just the right amount of rules to invoke the theme, but not too much to get bogged down. That's why it isn't that hard to teach to non- or light gamers (who are amazed at the existence of a game where you don't try to defeat the other players, but the game itself).

The down-time is almost non-existent due to the players being so involved in solving the puzzle (which eradicating the viruses to some degree is). There's a risk of a bossy player pointing the others to what they should do, but in a grown-up group, this shouldn't be too much of a problem.

RATING: 3
The first time I played this game I thought is was the best co-op game ever. Now that I've played it half a dozen times with different groups of people, I realize that the game is really meant to be played solitaire. If you've got a group of mixed experience the vets will end up "advising" the newbies on the optimal move. The result is the newbies might as well not be playing at all. There has to be better rules on interplayer communication than exist to make this game work multiplayer.
And who wants to play alone anyway.

RATING: 3
I like the theme of Pandemic, I like that it's cooperative. I think that the mechanics are good. I just honestly don't find it very fun. By the way, don't believe what it says about 30-90 minutes. You're at 90 minutes at least, assuming that you're actually taking the time to talk to your group about what you plan to do. Most of my games have run around 2 hours and 10 minutes. The game is a lot of fun the first time you play it, but after that it just becomes sort of boring, especially if you're playing with the same people. Not a consistently fun game, although mechanics-wise, it is great. It is just too long and too lacking in replayability really be a great game.

RATING: 7.5
A very tense, straightforward yet maddeningly difficult cooperative game that always seems to come down to the wire (through a number of possible means of defeat). Fun factor is very reliant on the personalities of the players (some people tend to "take over"), but with a cooperative group, this game is a wonderful experience. Trading cards seems to become an overwhelming necessity at harder difficulties, which makes for more of a dry, "puzzley" experience and can lead to annoying downtime as elaborate trades are plotted out.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 9
What more can I say about this classic? Love the intensification mechanism, and love the perfectly tuned balance between treating cubes and curing diseases (depending on difficulty level). I play the app solo a LOT.

I guess I can give my view on some of the complaints. Personally I don't have any quarterbacking issues as I think it's just as much a group problem, and my group ain't so bad. The people who claim it's "solved" and that there's always an obvious optimal move haven't played the harder difficulties -- at that level there's so much going on and a couple of wrong moves will finish you off. You can certainly get screwed by bad luck (say an epidemic hits a city with an outbreak cube) but one could also argue that you should have been more careful with outbreaks.

Amazing game that deserves its spot among the greats.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 9
Great suspense and brain burning together.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 9
Fun game that is very tense.  Seems friendly towards families as well.  Everyone I have shown this game to has really taken to it.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8
Visual Appeal: (4)
The board and pieces look really nice and streamlined. I have the older version, and from what I have seen, the newer one looks a tad better. One pet peeve is that the map has cities in some odd places. I suppose it is just to fit the words and other graphics comfortably, so I can get over it.
 
Components: (5)
I am playing every game with the first expansion now, and it really enhances some of the components. I love the petri dishes and the smaller pawns are a sensible touch. Cards all feel nice and they aren't wearing too quickly. I like the tracks on the board because they're easy to read and access for all players.

Theme: (5)
Best part of the game is theme. Unlike other games whose theme could be considered nerdy or boring, this one stands out as a player magnet. I can also dig the more-equal-than-usual gender representation in the game. Welcome to the modern age, boardgames, where women do sciencey things too; they don't just pose in futile chain-mail bikinis! Getting back to the topic at hand, the game does a great job making you feel like you are cooperating to save the world from certain doom. Even the likelihood of failure is well simulated. In case you haven't played the game, that is a very HIGH likelihood on harder settings.

Learning: (4)
This is on the list of many people's gateway games. I believe it is rightly on that list because it is easy to learn and fairly low pressure. I mean, the game is hard, but you don't have to worry about experienced players laying the smackdown on you. In fact they will be helping you. Which means, only a short intro is needed before you can jump right in and learn through experiencing the game. Difficulty settings are really well balanced for the casual and hardcore players alike. 

Gameplay: (4)
I only say 4 due to the ever present Alpha Gamer problem in co-op games. Really if you feel the need to control everyone's actions, you shouldn't be playing this type of game, but it happens. Sharing cards is a challenge and provides players with good points of discussion on how to use their actions the most efficiently.

Overall Fun: (5)
This game has been a huge hit with even my non-gamer or casual gamer friends. It is low pressure enough that everyone feels comfortable jumping in. I always enjoy teaching it and watching the horror on new players' faces as the realize how tough some decisions actually can be and what sacrifices need to be made to save the world! This is my go-to Co-operative game without a doubt. 
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7
First playthrough was enjoyable experience with my wife and I having a two player game.  Ranked the game an 8.

Played again and it seemed I was running the entire game and people were asking my opinion on what move to make.  I felt like I was playing solo with other's moving the peices.  Even when trying to get them involved in decision making it still felt like a solo game.

8 > 6.   I really don't ever want to play again.

Playing with people who want to play for the enjoyment of the game makes this much more fun.  Played a 4 player game and not once did anyone ask for advice, they just played their game.  Made it much more enjoyable, but I bumped up the rate by one.

Flash Point: Fire Rescue has replaced this game for my Co-Op joy.

RATING: 2
Looks more fun for schools, fostering teamwork, rather than regular recreational game play, which could get a little tedious and colorless after a few victories. In my case, after one victory. 

It's really not a multiplayer in that there is no hidden knowledge and no hidden agendas. The fact that you can say what's on your cards, but can't show them is a truly feeble, even disingenuous, attempt to make it seem otherwise.

And I don't think this even simulates how epidemics spread in this age of massive intercontinental travel.

Forbidden Island is more charming, fun, brief. Otherwise, I avoid co-ops and solitaire-designed games, RPG games excepted, of course!

RATING: 10

We own the 1st edition of the game and have inadvertently created our own house rules: you must find a cure at the research station in a city matching that disease colour, and when you run out of research stations, you can't place any more.

RATING: N/A
The weird rules about the (sort of) hidden cards are hard to execute. So I can't show you my cards, but I can tell you what they are. You forgot? Ok, I'll tell you again. Weird. At the same time, playing with visible cards leads to the most experienced player soaking it all in and telling everyone else what to do. I think I'd rather be "in it together" to save the world with the possibility of all losing together, while also tallying up my own set of personal glory points to be compared with others for placement at the end of the game. This was my first cooperative game experience. I have since determined that I simply do not like cooperative games, so I've removed my rating.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 6
Considered to be a very good co-op board game, I find this to be a bit like Solitaire where it's really the game letting you win by the distribution of infected cities at the startand the game not giving you a lot of epidemic cards in a row. There is a difficulty setting that can be adjusted (altered by inserting more or less Epidemic cards), but it seems a little futile sometimes. What I don't really like in the mechanics of the game, I do like in the theme of the game. It simulates spread of disease well and realistically and sometimes you just can't control the random events of what happens. Everyone gets their own special role and can contribute in their own way. It forces communication, but doesn't rid the problem of the overbearing co-op teammate. Overally, I like Pandemic, but not a game to play regularly. It is a good game to start other players on. Best played with 4 or 5

RATING: 10
In my opinion the best cooperative game out there. Gets even better with each expansion.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 4
A great game for gamers who like to table talk, because here you can plan and plot together against the plagues all you want. This game brings non-confrontational gaming to a whole new level. Missing the outright winner of Lord of the Rings, or the secret traitor of Shadows over Camelot, the game is all about beating the cards. Good co-operation, deduction, guesswork and (card seeding) luck will carry you along to ultimate victory or failure - everyone either wins or loses together.

Meanwhile... back at the ranch... well... I guess it'd appeal to gamers who like the social interaction and banter that goes together with a game like this. I feel it's more like some sort of corporate training course where the course instructor will give us a summary at the end of his/her observations of the behavioural traits of the participants - the aggressive, the passive-aggressive, the follower and all the other personalities a game like this can bring out.

My wife complained that it's not actually a game and could I please pack it away so as to make room on the table for a real game. I think that's a tad harsh - there's some fun to be had here - it's not always obvious what the best choice is, but it feels like it doesn't really matter if you're there or not - the whole thing can be played solo and it'd be much easier to agree on what to do in your turn(s). Ultimately, in the words of a wise friend - "I don't mind it." That said, couldn't we play a game instead?

I might be inclined to bump the rating up a notch when playing with the terrorist variant - a little human interaction to mess with the best laid plans goes a long way to making fun.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

RATING: 9
Easy, fun but not so deep.  A game based in an analogy of the drop that spills the water.  It is like [i]Outbreak![/i], the movie.  Players are trying to save the world from four contagious diseases, getting the antidote before it is too late.  Abstact, but paradoxically, very thematic at the same time.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8
Pandemic is one of the cornerstones of modern gaming.  The first co-op game I remember playing was Forbidden Island, and I was blown away by that.  Wanting to try something else like it, I heard Pandemic was pretty good.  You know what?  It really is!  The tension that builds as the viruses spread throughout the board, and knowing that another epidemic could strike at any time.  With players trying to coordinate between trying to eradicate a disease or fly to Paris to stop the blue disease, or build a research station in Hong Kong, or clear some yellow cubes in Lima... the choices and decisions to make get tough quick!  Though I would recommend Pandemic Legacy over this, standard Pandemic really is one of the most solid co-op games ever made.  It deserves its place as an all time favorite among gamers.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

An all-time favorite.  The game always changes, you never know what to expect.  Always a challenge.  Made even better with On the Brink

RATING: 8
Irtam egy beszamolot, de BGG rejtekeiben elveszett. A lenyeg, hogy jo a jatek de nem nyilt meg teljesen. Talan a legkozelebbi parti utan komolyabb beszamolo.Update1: Ujra nekifutva, marmint az irasnak. Izgatottan hallgattam vegi a jatekszabalyt es mar alig birtam kivarni a kezdest. Kozosen ugy dontottunk, hogy a kozepes nehezsegi fokozaton fogunk jatszani mert igy allitolag 40% esely azert van a gyozelemre. Kiosztottuk a karaktereket, es pont a doktor maradt ki ami allitolag a legerosebb az egesz jatekban. Szoval ezekkel a baljos elojekkel vagtunk neki a partinak. A jatek arrol szol, hogy 4 fajta virustorsz uti fel a fejet a vilag tobb pontjan es nekunk meg kell talalni az ellenszereiket mielott veglegesen tulszaporodnak. Nekem az a karakter jutott amivel eleg 4 egyforma kartya egy vakcina kifejlesztesehez az 5 helyett. Az elejen rogton ismertettem a tobbiekkel, hogy melyik fajtaju vakcinak kifejleszteseben tudok eredmenyre jutni a kezemben levo kartyak alapjan amire Misi rogton felajanlotta a segitseget, mivel neki a specialis kepessege az volt, hogy barhol at tud adni barmilyen kartyat a masiknak, nem kell a helyszin nevehez ragaszkodni. Ezzel a gyilkos komboval az elso korben megvolt az elso vakcina, aztan Feri is sikeresen kifejlesztett egy masikat es a negyedik korre megnyertuk a jatekot. Voltak izgalmas helyzetek, sot a vege elott mar rendesen el voltak szaporodva mar a virusok de eleg konnyunek tunt a gyozelem. Erzesem szerint pusztan csak szerencsenk volt, a jatek sokkal gonoszabb tud lenni ennel. Mindenkeppen igeretes darab es vannak benne jo otletek, peldaul az a megoldas, hogy mindig a gocpontok kornyeken terjednek elsosorban a virusok es csak ritka esetben utik fel fejuket uj helyen. A jatek kivitelezese es a komponensek elfogadhato kategoria. Kivancsian varom a kovetekozo partikat.Update1: Ujabb ket parti. Az elsot egy kicsit rosszul jatszottuk a sajat oldalunkat segitve es megis kikaptunk, a masodikat mar a rendes szabalyokkal es megnyertuk. A karakter huzason szerintem nagyon sok mulik, mert a atado-4 lapbol is kifejleszto karakter kombo mar masodszorra is a gyozelmet hozta, sot a harmadik gyogyito karakter meg hab volt a tortan. Minden esetben a legnehezebb fokozatban jatszottunk, szerintem nincs ertelme konnyebben jatszani. Rajottem, hogy a jatek igazi ereje az, hogy nincs foloslegesen elhuzva a jatekido, 30 perc alatt siman lejatszhato egy parti. Tetszik.

Pandemic is a true masterpiece of board gaming. RATING: 7
Decent cooperative game where players wrestle between healing the sick and finding a cure as the world succumbs to a dangerous contagion. Haven't played in a while because I've forgotten the rules and don't want to learn them again. :) As in many co-ops, one alpha player may try to take charge and tell everyone what to do. To a certain extent that can help a co-op game, but when that happens it drowns the fun-factor, so I try to deflate alpha players whenever I see that. For a lighter/faster co-op, see Forbidden Island.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 9
This is a fantastic co-op game, with well balanced roles for each person to take, and a good mechanism for adjusting difficulty. I like how the game really balances out between playing with 2 to playing with 4 people, as the number of special abilities and chance to cover the whole board increase, but the means for getting 5 cards of a color in one person's hand get more difficult. The game mostly has very good components, but sometimes I do feel myself wanting a little bit more theme as I go around chasing little cubes off the board.

Still, this game is always a great time, and almost every time I play it, the game ends with a nailbiter finish as we rush to cure the 4th disease while all the other elements of the game threaten to defeat us. That is exactly how any co-op game should play out in the endgame.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7
Having come back to Pandemic due to Pandemic Legacy, I can appreciate the design better now. When I initially tried it, the play dynamics kept me from enjoying the game very much. The biggest problem with Pandemic is that once you know you will win or can't win, all of the tension goes away. Pandemic Legacy fixed this issue by adding long term consequences, so even if you lose, you're still invested in damage control.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

I don't know, maybe I'm just too competitive and like beating other people with a superior strategy more than I like beating a piece of cardboard with a superior strategy, but I want to like this game more than I actually do.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7
This can be a very enjoyable game. It scales well from 1-5, though you need to increase the difficulty for fewer players. It's easy to learn, easy to teach, and doesn't take long to play. It's an excellent game to play with non-gamers. When you are in the middle of the game and things are getting out of control, it can be a wonderfully intense and immersive game to play. Unfortunately, those aspects peter out as you approach the end since you can usually see whether or not you will be able to win 3-5 turns too soon. At that point, you're just going through the motions to bring the game to it's inevitable conclusion. Win or lose, it's very anti-climactic. The only truly exciting ending is getting too many outbreaks, as that is an ending whose certainty cannot be calculated beforehand.  As a house-rule, I think it would be more enjoyable to remove the losing conditions for running out of cubes (the more cubes you have, the more likely you are to get outbreaks) and for exhausting the player deck (just reset the deck, re-seeded with Epidemic cards, and continue playing). I'm not sure how to make winning more enjoyable... maybe if the person who goes to the research station and plays the cards to cure a disease, and only that person, had to take an action to roll a die (I know, I know...) and get a 5 or 6 to succeed in producing the cure. Yeah, it adds luck to the game, but at least the ending would be exciting.... Honestly, if the anti-climatic end game could be remedied, this game would easily be a 10. As it is, I'm not sure how long it will hold out at a 9 rating.... 

Oh, and while the game does look good, the board tends to warp and the player pawns, research stations, and disease cubes are all far too large.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 9.9
A fantastic co-operative experience filled with tense discussions and risky moves that makes this one of the top games we own and the first to be pulled out with new players.
Highly recommended. 2 or more players.

RATING: 7

Might still be good to keep around to introduce new people to, but definitely not one that I'll suggest myself on a regular basis.

RATING: 9
Co-op can be pretty hit and miss for me.  This is definitely a hit.  Very tight.  Quick, tense and fun.

Always soooo cloooose.  This game has the most remarkable ability of any game I've ever met to turn everything upside-down where you are absolutely convinced that you've won and there's absolutely no way you could lose from here... then an epidemic arrives and the infection comes and it's exactly the wrong cities that get infected and within about 1 turn you get absolutely smashed!  No game has the ability to turn your overconfidence into your weakness like this - it really is amazing and fantastic to watch.

And so devastating when you think you're gonna win next turn... only to have all your hopes dashed.  It's frikkin great and really keeps you on your toes.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7.5
11/07/08: Tried a 5p game with 4 Epidemics. We won, pretty easily in fact. Also played 3p Heroic, and finished the game with all 4 diseases eradicated and not a single outbreak!

3/20/08: Played 2 games with 3 players on Heroic tonight, and it had a similar feel to 4 player Normal. I think I like it better with 3 players though, less waiting and fewer people to cause bickering.

3/17/08: Played 2 more 4p/Normal games, lost both soon before curing the 4th disease. Outbreak city!

3/15/08: We played x2 with 4 players on Heroic, and we got owned! Then we played 4 players on Normal and lost 1 turn from victory twice. Finally we played 3 player on Normal and won easily. I'm concerned about the percentage of games that are probably unwinnable from the outset, which I suspect is high with 4 players (especially on Heroic)

3/14/08: I've played about 4 times and have yet to really lose. This game seems kinda easy... maybe I'm just getting lucky. It seems like the game is either winnable or not from the outset, of course you don't know that. It could be the case that the game setup is simply unwinnable. I've not really lost yet, so I don't know how true that is.Pandemic is a very slick attempt at a cooperative game. The main problem with it isn't a problem with the game perse, it's a problem with the Genre. Some people complain that games like Race for the Galaxy are Multiplayer Solitaire... this game isn't Mulitplayer Solitaire, it's just Solitaire!All the cooperative games I can think of suffer from this same problem. One domineering, loud, or stubborn player basically plays everyone's hand. In fact, in order to maximize the chances of winning this is really the optimal strategy. Ideally, everyone collaborates to determine the best course for everyone, but that one loud guy can ruin the fun for the other players by saying "you do this, you do this, and you do this!" The best (or at least a sufficient) coarse of action can be easily constructed by any one person, there's no real need for collaborative input.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

Owned: Kevin

RATING: 10
I kind of expected my euphoria over this game to dissipate by now, but if anything it's gotten stronger. RATING: 7.835
2nd new Older edition obtained from Dice Tower Con 2016 at Flea Market for $10! New in shrink even!
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7

Love the game, but it really depends on who you play with. Since this is a cooperative game, control freaks who essentially try to play solitaire and boss you around, and on the other side of the coin, players who don't put much effort in and refuse to discuss moves, can ruin your game completely. With people you know well and at your skill level though, the game's really fun! A game between experts creates discussions that really make you feel like a brainy doctor as you calculate possibilities to do the most good with those preciously few 4 actions each turn. I love the mechanism of spending 4 action points per turn, the theme is popular, original, intense and immersive, and the rulebook is amazing. Wish it had cool figurines like those in Fury of Dracula, Shadows Over Camelot, Tannhauser etc, or even have the pawns labeled 'M', 'S' etc because I often have trouble distinguishing them from each other when I glance at the board, since the colors of each role are arbitrary. 

What I really love about this game is that if time is tight and 2-4 of us want a game, Pandemic will definitely finish within 45-60 minutes, even if there are new players. What I'm leery about is that there is a definite shelf-life to the game before things get much less intense and interesting (after you internalize all of the mechanisms and strategy), and I currently estimate this at 10 plays. But those first few plays are a BLAST.

5+2

RATING: 7
I love the mechanics and components of this game (perhaps more than the gameplay itself).  By reshuffling city cards back into the top of the deck after an outbreak, the tension builds and builds.  Just a very creative piece of work.  I also am astounded by how often the game comes down to just 1 turn - one decision can mean the end of the world or total salvation.  Now that's evidence of a well-balanced and play-tested game.  I wish that the board was a little bigger and/or the pawns smaller.  I tend to play this one solo, as I'm just not convinced that it works well as a multiplayer coop experience.  This game feeds off of my germ-paranoia.

RATING: 8.5
The game that started cooperative gaming for me. I quickly brought this game home to play with my family after playing it at a friends house. It was a bit overwhelming to them at first and I was a total alpha gamer just directing everyone's movements through the first couple play thoughs but now we all talk it out and I let them make plays even if they aren't the perfect play in my opinion. With the On the Brink expansion we've stepped up the difficulty and still enjoy it even if we don't win that often. The guys I play games with love this game too although we usually get into pretty heated discussions when you've got a bunch of alpha males at the table. The On the Brink Expansion is necessary for me since it adds so many roles and can up the difficulty significantly without making it impossible.

RATING: 3
Pandemic is definitely overrated. If you absolutely love coops, you might enjoy this one. If you only occasionally play a coop, there are much better coop games out there. It really has that "we're playing against a set of rules" feel to it and doesn't really feel like you're battling disease outbreaks. You're also supposed to randomly draw roles, but some roles are significantly more helpful than others (good luck winning without a medic). There are other coops that do a much better job of portraying their theme than Pandemic. I would get them instead.

RATING: 3.5
This together with Arkham Horror was my first buy and the first game I burned out on (but we still play and love AH). 

This is weekly Monday business meeting with charts and maps and there's a problem and now we have to delegate who does what to solve this mess. Each character does something better than the rest, so it's you who has to deal with it. Beware: vulnerable to alfa dog syndrome. 

If you compare it to AH, it's dry, but if you play it after a Knizia and the like it feels pretty thematic, intuitive and interactive. You have to talk! About game objectives! Yay. Upped the ranking by 0.5

So it's a puzzle co-op which works well with nongamers and eurogamers and creates a neat nonconfrontational experience if that's what you're after (and you keep your alphas on a leash).  

-----------------------------
Played again. I've realised that working togehter and making plans is something I prefer to do with competent people and not just anybody. So I prefer lighter co-ops which don't require as much skill and can be played just to illustrate what is the value of "working together" (Forbidden Island or Escape would be my picks.)

RATING: 8
1 parti alapjan nehez objektiv velemenyt mondani a jatekrol. Kozepes fokozaton kisse konnyunek ereztem a gyozelmunket, de lehet, hogy ebben kozrejatszott az is, hogy viszonylag kozel voltak egymashoz a fertozesek gocpontjai, nem kellett sokat utazgatnunk. Persze van meg egy nehezebb fokozat, lehet azon is probalkozni. Vegulis igeretes darabnak tunik, jol johet, ha az embernek epp nincs kedve masokkal konfrontalodni, es/vagy keves az ido egy hosszabb kooperativ jatszmahoz. Egy pontot maszott felfele az ertekeles, barmikor szivesen leulok melle egy parti erejeig.
