RATING: 6.5
A cooperative game that takes the best of other games and throws out the useless bits. Where Kniza's LOTR is overly fiddly (too many paths), this one streamlines it (players use 4APs to perform actions). Where games like Terra had too much infighting, this one forces players to fully cooperate as there is a sense of urgency.

The outbreak system works well and so do the role cards. The game will probably get a little stale after you manage to win it on heroic and also because strategies will become more obvious after multiple plays...BUT it will take awhile to get there!

We played three games of this in a row and it has been awhile since a game made me jump up with excitement.

Update: Game gets stale after beating it a few times. Some roles are stronger than others and the theme is thin once people get into a 'system' of trying best to solve the puzzle.

RATING: N/A
IMT_11/16
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7
Overall, my cooperative game crown still goes to Knizia's Lord of the Rings. But while Lord of the Rings is a co-op game that really requires a group of "gamers", Pandemic is a go-to game for any group of people.

The tension around the table is just palpable playing Pandemic, and the game plays in under an hour, so it's really perfect for a weeknight get together with friends. To succeed, team members must really plan things out together. If each player simply pursues his or her own "plan", then the group is sure to lose the game, especially on Normal or (god forbid) Heroic settings. Pandemic is an ultra-cooperative game. This is its greatest asset, but also the thing about it which I foresee will put me off a bit over time. There is little room for autonomy and self-determination. Success requires the closest sort of collaboration. So be warned: play this only with people you like! If you play it with someone you don't have a lot of patience with, you *will* want to throttle them. Pandemic throws very difficult situations right in the face of the players, and good brainstorming is required to win the game. If someone is being boorish and trying to "quarterback" the whole game, you will be driven to distraction. Likewise if someone is being an utter dolt and failing to grasp the plan that the group came up with.

Again, VERY tense. VERY exciting. LOADS of fun. But play it with the right people. Otherwise Pandemic possesses the potential to devolve into an exercise in frustration. It also shines with 3-4 players, but the tension is significantly less with only 2. This is because 2 players can tightly coordinate their actions, working as a team and moving more or less together around the world in order to cure the diseases. With 3 and 4 players, it's harder to get ahead of the intensity curve - the point where, after a few epidemics, you start infecting new cities without any disease (and hence a lesser chance of outbreaks). Because of this, I think 3-4 player games are actually slightly more challenging than 2 player games.

Components: the board is crap. The disease cubes, pawns, research stations, and cards are all just fine. But I'd shell out another $10 for a decent board. This one warps, wrinkles, smells funny, and peels up from the edge. I like the size of it, I like the art and design. It's the physical quality which is just dismal. That's a shame when it affects such a super game.

Update: this one has settled at a perpetual 7 for me. When I like it, I love it. But it's not really something I'm in the mood for any time, in plenty of situations I'd just rather not play it. You have to be in the mood to do the group-think thing, communicating extensively with the other players at every turn, in order to win. And sometimes, I feel that players can make all the right choices (optimal ones) and still lose due to luck and game balance. If this weren't so, it is true that Pandemic would lose some tension, as it would become a puzzle - solvable by an experienced group of players. That would be a shame, and a downfall. Yet the game falls down anyway, as once you ARE very experienced, it is frustrating to lose a perfectly played game. For some reason, this complaint doesn't arise for me when playing Lord of the Rings. The balance of choices in LotR maintains at least the illusion that your success depends only on your choices.

Anyway, despite my gripes I rate Pandemic a "strong buy" for its accessibility, tension, and short play-time.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 4
Pandemic is one of the most critically acclaimed co-op board games out there, but if you ask me this game is a snooze fest. The game is simply too simple. As a guy who does math all day this game comes straight down to probability once you have a solid basis of what you are doing, and that bothers me to no end. If you're looking for a game to introduce people to the co-op genre I suppose this could work for a bit, but with games like Zombicide, the Lord of the Rings Card game, and Arkham Horror out there, I'd pass on this one.

RATING: 7
A fun game if a bit simple. A game that started a whole series of similar games where you start your turn with several actions to hold the tide just for a bit longer, then you draw 2 cards looking to find a set of a single colour, and then something bad happens on the board. 

I can see how it might have looked amazing when it came out. In reality, these days there are much better alternatives, and Pandemic on its own feels very formulaic to me. I don't think I would ever say no if offered a session, but I'd never seek out to play it.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7
The idea of this game is awesome. Cooperating with your friends to rid the world of disease sounds like my kind of game. And to top it all off, every player has their own special skills to contribute to the team. I love it.

The thing that makes this game not fun are players like myself. I am a total Dictator. I'm the person who introduced the game to my friends and so automatically I fell into the teaching role, but, there's a fine line between teacher and dictator. I cross that line. I spend all game telling people what to do. Before people even take their turn I'm giving them "suggestions" and when they don't follow my "suggestions" I tell them how inefficient their turn was and how we will all fail because of them. I should just play this game solo. 

There needs to be some sort of rule or mechanic that prevents people like me from controlling the entire game.

RATING: 8
[2010-09-09]
Nagyon jó alaptörténetet találtak ki a játéknak. Vírusok terjednek a Földünkön, amit a csapatban dolgozó orvoscsoport próbál megfékezni az egész bolygón. Repülnek, egymásnak segítenek. Különböző szerepekkel rendelkező játékosok próbálják közösen a játék ellen bevetni minden tudásukat, amire szükség is lesz, mert a játék nehéznek mondható, bár mi az első játékunkat simán nyertük.

[2011-07-29]
A játékidő körülbelül 1 óra, ami akár újbóli vírusirtásra is lehetőséget ad. A játék jól súlyozható, a könnyen megtalálhatja minden csapat a saját izgalmas nehézségi szintjét. Változatos, a kártyák miatt mindig más egy-egy játék.

[2011-09-26]
Ketten is tökéletesen működik a játék, akár 45 perc is lehet egy-egy parti, rossz esetben még kevesebb. Nagyon izgalmas minden menet, még veszteni sem illúzióromboló ebben a játékban. A három nehézségi szint, a kiegészítővel még tovább növelhető, ezért szerintem nagyon magas az újrajátszhatósági faktora. Méltán van a kooperatív játékok legjobbjai között a Pandemic helye.

RATING: 7
Pandemic is the pseudo-grandfather of cooperative games. While it might not have been the first, it definitely made co-op a popular mechanic.

In its essence, it's a multi-player puzzle, with the players trying to out-smart a deck of cards. While that may not seem like much, the game is very good at inducing tension as the game progresses, which really makes Pandemic shine.

RATING: 10
Pandemic is my favorite game. I really enjoy the teamwork that comes out of the unique character abilities that each player has. The game is somewhat like a puzzle, but not one that is easily solvable. There are many paths a team could take and it's up to the group to decide how best to deal with each situation that comes up. In that way, the theme works very well. It's masterful design that really got me going in board gaming and has helped me introduce the hobby to many others.

RATING: 7
First of all, I didn't realize that this was a negotiation game where the goal is to try to take your turn the way you wish, rather than what everyone else is telling you to do.  This is an awesome exercise, though it ranks something along the lines of group Free Cell, where everyone debates the logistics of where everything should go.  It is a fun little experience and is really compelling.  I could very easily see playing this a couple times in an evening.  That said, I can also see getting burned out on it.

RATING: 7
Reviewed on Mounted Cloud
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8.5
Wow! Pandemic is really really good.  My group played for the first time last night and was just blown away.  It's the first new game that we've played in a long while that we've decided to play the game again after playing it once... and then we played it a third time, and were it not so late, would have played it a fourth time.

I'm not usually one for co-op games, but this has a great feel to it where all of the players are working together to use their respective abilities to best quell the infection and outbreaks.  

On our second game, we nearly lost because of our hubris of thinking we had the entire thing sewn up -- I was holding the cure for the last disease, I was within range of a research station, and there had only been two outbreaks for the entire game.  But, we didn't notice that I could only reach the station, and that I would be out of actions to cure... we thought all was well, except that an epidemic hit, which caused the hot zone in South America to have an outbreak... that caused another outbreak... that caused another outbreak... suddenly we were in a crisis situation because we were down to the last yellow cube... any further activity in that area would lose the game for us (not to mention that we had just kicked the outbreak counter up by 3-4).  We did end up winning, but it was so interesting that the game could turn on us so quickly.

I look forward to playing this one again soon.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

Someone point out to me that they liked this game because in a lot of other games people can sometimes get lost in thought and don't talk much during the game but this game forces people to interact and pay attention to everyone elses turns. On top of all that it's just plain fun.

RATING: 9.5
The favorite for my girlfriend and me to play together. The game itself is rather simple, but the decisions and strategies are often very diverse. Should we contain over here? Should we try to cure this disease, even though that disease is suddenly outbreaking vereywhere? Should I bother sunsetting this disease, or start working on containing that one infecting Europe? Always fun, and always a challenge. In fact, everyone I've introduced this game too has loved it — most of the gifts I bought for everyone in Christmas '08 were Pandemic games.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7
I have never played a cooperation game before so Pandemic was my introduction. It did not disappoint. I plays very quickly (under 1 hour) and has more table talk than China Town. Taking on one of five different roles, players try to cooperate and squash four different infections across the globe. Proper coordination is the key as you must work in harmony to get workers to the right places at the right time and tweak your engine. The Outbreaks make the game very very difficult and spread so rapidly its easy to get overwhelmed and subsequently pummeled. 
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8.5
Brilliant design. This is a game that truly meets the criteria "for non-gamers and gamers alike". Great two player or solo game as well. Very compact box, easy to travel with and sets up pretty fast. 

The real crux of the game, and why it is rated so highly by most, is the card driven mechanic that ramps up the intensity in a perfectly escalating trend of greater and greater alarm and sheer panic. Can be very intense and fun the whole way through. 

One criticism: the player pawns are way too big for the map. We use miniature figures instead of the pawns now anyway, so no biggie. Yes, i know the expansion fixes this.  

Note - changed rating from 9 to 8. Problem is that because of the luck of the cards, there are times when you just simply can not win. On the other hand, there are times that you win rather easily because the cards just came out that way. Still a wonderful game and an easy 8, but had to drop my respect slightly because this aspect of the game tends to frustrate one the more you play.

RATING: 10

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7
Played once.

This is a pretty interesting co-op game which, like most co-op games, has a nice narrative.  The board is a map of the world with regions delineated by color (East Asia is red, for example).  The presence of disease is noted by placing cubes into a city, and the placements are based on a somewhat random card draw at the end of each player's turn.  If a city ever gets more than three cubes, there is an outbreak, and all connecting cities get cubes of that color.  The game is over when players either cure all four diseases or there are more than nine outbreaks.  

On a player's turn, there are eight possible actions, some of which are made easier by the roles that are selected at the start of the game.  You need to move quickly around the board and clear cubes out in anticipation of the next outbreak.  There's also trading of cards between players to achieve a cure.  So the fun part of the game is working together to figure out the most efficient way for each player to spend their turn.

That said, most of the decisions in that regard are fairly obvious.  You do have some idea of what cities are likely to experience repeated infections, and which are less likely, so you can anticipate outbreaks.  It's also fairly plain that you can't afford to have two connected cities with three cubes each, since that would trigger a double outbreak, which cuts way down on the time you have to get cures.  

In short, this is a really straightforward game with a great narrative, about a 70:30 strategy to luck ratio, that can be taught and played in about 45 minutes.  It looks good and was pretty fun for my one play.  I'm a little unsure of its long-term replayability, but I can see some potential for expansions.  I'd particularly like to see some random event cards that were conditionally helpful or hindering, so you had more of a decision than to automatically use them.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7.5
I can see why this game is so popular! Easy to teach to new players, and serves as a good gateway game. My wife and I enjoy this game and it sees the table often enough.

I however do not find it as exciting as fist time players do. It has worn dry for me after a few plays.
 
The game with two players seems too easy, while probably best with 4 this causes another problem; This is where an issue for me comes in; the Alpha gamer syndrome. Eventhough I try and avoid this at all costs, when playing as a team everyone wants to win, and look to the most experience for "guidance"... It's almost unavoidable.

In the end it is defiantly a good game, especially if your group likes pure coops.

RATING: 8.75
This co-op game is nice in that it allows the players to control the difficulty.  If you're playing with a group of new players you may choose to use the minimum number of epedimic cards in the infection deck.  If you are playing with a group of experienced Pandemic players who want a real challenge then load up the infection deck with all of the epedimic cards...just don't expect to win.  Great fun for all, with multiple roles to choose from offering good replayability.

RATING: 10
The "shuffle the discards and put them on TOP of the remaining deck" is probably the single mechanic that lifted this to a "10" in my estimation.  Very appropriate to the way mutation works that the new strains (and therefore new outbreaks) come from the longterm diseased places.  This is not merely a theme tacked onto a game.  (MANY of my favorite games ARE theme-tacked-on games but this mechanic adds elegance and atmosphere to the game.  Play balance is great.  (I play Heroic Level; I generally lose...)

RATING: 7.5
The problem I have is that even if my fellow players and I have an optimal strategy, too much luck is involved in determining whether we win or not. The roles are not balanced, and difficulty is not scalable with more players. A Medic and Scientist with 5 epidemics is much easier than 4 players with 5 epis, or with 4 players and 4 epis. Who wants to play a game where you constantly fail only because of bad luck?
This can be fixed by forcing the epidemics to be in certain areas of the player's deck, but it should have been addressed in the game.

RATING: 8.25
One of the great co-operative games.  Very well produced - looks great when set up and playing, except for the dumb over-sized pawns. [We prefer to use appropriately coloured Meeples anyway - even after the OTB expansion replacements].

The game can be unforgiving of bad tactics (remember the victory conditions!), and even with good play the end-games can be very tense/exciting.  The different player roles add to interest and variety, and each has its uses if played right.  Rules are pretty easy to learn, and are very well set out.  Will appeal to most gamers, and non-gamers frankly - provided that the theme does not put them off.  VERY highly recommended.

RATING: 5
Great theme and design for a co-op, although I'm almost disappointed that our group won our first game. I suspect that this game becomes less interesting the better you get at it, which is the opposite of what I typically look for. Still, for what it is, and with the right group, Pandemic is fun. I'd be happy to play again in similar circumstances. But I don't see myself requesting it over a good competitive game.

After another play with a different group and another win, I feel the same as I did after my first play. I guess I should be playing it at the highest level of difficulty. Even so, I'm not sure how I feel about co-ops like Pandemic. You play against the system; you try to be as efficient as you can; and you hope that the cards don't kill you. True, there's some excitement in that, but it's sobering to look at the game from an analytical point of view and realize that ultimately your choices may not matter.

RATING: 5
Update after a few solo games on iOS
As a solo game (which, for me, is the only way most cooperative games should be played), this rates at least a 6.


----
A quick-playing cooperative game. Sometimes it's quick because it's impossible to solve! A fun activity, but more like a group puzzle than a game. It has the same silly rule as Lord of the Rings: players may share ANY information freely, but may not actually show each other their cards. I MUCH prefer Shadows Over Camelot. However, this game does have an interesting theme, plays very quickly, and has a very clever way of mimicking disease spread. It's also scalable, similar to Vanished Planet (add more Epidemic cards to the deck to increase difficulty). Players MUST work together -- each character's power can be helpful if used correctly.

But I don't like co-ops! For me, this is a 3/10 on the BGG scale.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 9
This is a brilliant game when it comes down to it. I would give it a 10, but it's been suggested to me before and I wasn't 100% on board to play so I'm tentatively going to give it a 9. So many great ideas. A scaling difficulty for replayability, it being co-operative, while not seeming like one person is actually making all the decisions and the goal feeling pretty good once you do accomplish it.

Beating it on the highest difficulty is a challenge.

All the sweeter when you do win.

Having played a few more times now the game is not as difficult as I originally thought, especially compared to some other cooperative board games.  You simply need to learn the best tactics which comes with repeated plays.  I'm just afraid that with that also comes a lack of interest as the game grows predictable and less challenging.

RATING: 6.5
Alpha gamer at it's best/worst. I get why people like this game and if it was just a single player game it'd be fine, unfortunately it's not. This means that people who have experience end up either leading the way or shutting up and letting the new players figure things out.  Either way this doesn't make for a very fun game most of the time.

Sometimes you'll end up with players of comparable skill and you'll get some interesting conversations about what path to take but generally there is a "right" move to make and while it may not pay off due to luck/chance it was still the correct move to make with the available information. 
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

Needs version

21/07/08

As I expected Pandemic turned out to be less fun with time. It's still a good catch for newbies though and that's something I have to underline here. My wife started to like/play games after Pandemic.

RATING: 6.75
An interesting concept based on curing diseases around the world. This game does rather have a huge "luck" factor to it as if you are able to avoid the epidemic cards, you can easily win the game. The variety of levels included makes the replay value increase.

Also, this game does require cooperative play - at times you may not even make your own decision as most moves later in the game are decided as a group rather than on your own.

RATING: 7
Co-op in its purest form, love the theme and always had a thing for world maps (cute that the German city is Essen). Since I played Forbidden Island first, I recognized many mechanics but I think they are executed better in Pandemic, the game is just more interesting, gripping and tougher to win so I take this over FI any day (though FI really is a sweet one, too). It is a very accessible game on top of all the good aspects!
I still think there is some room for 'more' in the field of cooperative games but would be happy to play Pandemic more.

RATING: 9
Ah, Pandemic. Bumped the score up a few times recently - it's another of those games that you can play with anyone - grannies and grandads playing over Christmas, and enjoying it every bit as much as I do. Great stuff. First time we played with wife's sister and her husband, we decided that the roles are named as follows - and it's stuck:

Dispatcher: George Fink
Scientist: Blessing Ekwale
Medic: Jose Delacruz
Operations: Mike Popowski
Researcher: Jean Biehn

"Goddamn it, Popowski, just do your job!"

EDIT: A year or so on, and it's still doing its job! 3 games in a row (with On the Brink) with dad and sister over Christmas - they're fans too!

EDIT 2: July 2011 had this at an 8.5 - bumping up as it's just still fab.

RATING: 9
The Scandinavian version is said to have very small text, due to Swedish and Finnish being squashed onto the cards. This is true, the text is very small on the role cards for example. The map has a few city names in both languages, maybe not the prettiest but I honestly do not care as much as I thought I would. I care more about the game =)

The small text on the cards you will likely not need to read after playing only a few times, so its fine really.

Also, we won the first time, and lost the second time we played! I would call that a very well balanced game in its "beginner" mode, well done!

RATING: 7
The first game i have purchased whilst it is still a novelty. And after 1 play i'd say it is fun, but not earth shatteringly great. Edit, we were playing it wrong...2nd play, there is tension as you race against the diseases and the cards, any longevity it may have will be because of the co-op play. Beautifully produced game, however there is something a little dry about the game, not naming the diseases was a mistake. This game also needs outgoing and gregarious players to be enjoyed, in fact it's a total misery without a good group. I think i prefer Shadows over Camelot [and BSG], however this is quicker and works well with 2 so both have their place. The more i play the more i look on it with admiration but not love. Great with family and non-gamers though.

RATING: 8.1
Pandemic is a little overhyped for me. 

Nice complexity to it, and you can feel the tenseness 
when virii break out all over the place. 
But the game too me is more a puzzle then a game. I have the same feeling about Ghost Stories. 

Somehow I miss the individuality of player turns. Sure players can decide what to do. But mostly it is a group effort to get to the most optimal solution. 

Playing with new players makes the game a hassle. 
Mostly it involves them asking and telling them what to do.

Don't get me wrong, the game is not bad. And i like to play it. It's just......not worth the hype it got.

RATING: 10
I am a student studying Epidemiology and microbial diseases and this game does an amazing job at simulating diseases in a simple, easy to learn mechanic that is a blast to play and easy to teach. The game builds tension and is different every time. Best board game I have ever played.

RATING: N/A
Copycat purchase.  many plays prior to joining BGG. after many competetive games of catan, carcassonne etc, tempers wouldn't necessarily flare but we needed something to take the edge off competition, so here comes pandemic.  still a very good game.  challenging and tense and things can spiral out of controll very quickly.  we have gravitated to having favored roles so many times we just pick who we want to play, sometimes have a random draw.  we like to cooperative aspect and has lead to purchases of mice & mystics, star trek expeditions, yggdrasil and a touch of evil(which can be competitve or cooperative).  so it opened a new world of gaming, the cooperative idea.  haven'f felt the need for the expansion since we haven't mastered the base game with all epidemics yet.  kids have grown into liking this as well so it will be well loved for many years yet.

RATING: 8

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7.5
Pandemic plays a bit like Arkham Horror, only you're stamping out infections instead of killing monsters, and finding cures instead of sealing gates. The difference is that Pandemic is far simpler and takes a fraction of the time to play, and is thus easier to get to the table with casual gamers. I'd rather play a meatier game when opportunity arises, but this is good fun to play with the family, and quite challenging when played at the Heroic level.

[edit] Now that I have Forbidden Island, Pandemic may be tougher to find time for. Forbidden Island is quicker, simpler and easier for the non-gamers, so will be chosen more frequently. Pandemic may become a "next step" game for Forbidden Island players that seek a bit more depth.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

some text, 60mins, 2-4 best with 4

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 4
:thumbsup: LIKE
+ Theme is pretty unique
+ Coop mechanics (infection, propagation) are well though out and accessible

:thumbsdown: DISLIKE
- Crazy alpha player syndrome
- Really swingy from too easy to impossible
- Theme is depressive
- Doesn't renew itself enough to justify repeated play

:star: VERDICT
The more I play this one, the least I like it. By the end of the game, you always know in advance if you're gonna make it or not, so it's just a matter of bringing to game to end
As for introducing newbies to games, it's bad because they won't take any initiative and they will follow up the more experienced players. 
Still, the theme is unique (but depressive too) and the coop play is fun and fast.
Forbidden Island is my Leacock go to coop game. So much better than Pandemic for me.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 9
I love almost everything about this game. It's got an interesting theme that fits well with the game. It's got good replayability due to the roles and the different levels of difficulty. It plays quickly and is fairly easy to teach, while still having some depth. I like the puzzlelike feel of the game, and it's a great option for solitaire play. My only little problem with it is that in some games, you can see a win or a loss coming before the end. These are balanced out, however, by a good number of nail-biting endings. One of my favorites.

Update: The game gets even better with the On the Brink expansion.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 6.5
There's no doubt that in the couple of co-operative board games I have played, players seem to be very much at the mercy of the cards that come up.  But the thing is, co-operative games are all about the experience, and that's what I love about them.  Pandemic definitely shines in this regard.  It is fun to strategize as a team, come up with a plan of attack, and sweat it out together as the odds seem to build against you.  It's theme is unique and very well-implemented, and while I would have preferred if they had named the diseases, I can see why they chose not to.  The components are basic and the board is a little small, but it all comes in a very compact and very portable box.  The game itself is remarkably easy to learn and is well-suited to playing with non-gamers.  I don't know how it will hold up with repeat plays, but so far I've played with 2, 3, 4, and 5 players, and we've had a lot of fun every time.  [Edit: I now know that, for myself at least, it doesn't hold up really well with repeat plays, and my rating has dropped.  I find myself fairly bored with this board game, yet it remains one of my wife's all-time favourites.  Go figure.  I'm interested to see if an expansion will revitalize my interest.]  Game design: 3.5/5  Personal enjoyment: 3/5  Total: 6.5/10
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

RATING: 9
In March of 2008, I played this new game that I had heard absolutely nothing about beforehand. A few folks saw some good reviews and I played it once.

28 game plays later, this is a great cooperative game.  The plays have slowed down a bit (we did obsess over it for a while!), but still is brought to the table often.

As with most folks, the winning record is below .500. Our team has won 11 out of the 28 games (all but a few at the Normal level). All but 3 of the losses were via 8 outbreaks. In about half of the losses, we were one to three rounds away from winning. (Truth in advertising - in most of our wins, we were one wrong card away from losing!!)
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7.5
We tried hard to like this game but we think it's the co-op mechanic and fiddliness that we don't enjoy. We find it hard to avoid the "follow-the-leader" strategy (one person makes a suggestion and everyone else complies). The unintuitive card setup and pawn movements also deter from the experience. But there is still something about it that makes me pull it out for the occasional session. I also don't think its as great a gateway as many people believe. We've had MUCH more success with TtR, Qwirkle, Blokus and Carc.  

UPDATE: Played for the first time with 4 players after only 2 player games previously. It plays much better with more...rating increased from 6.5 to 7.5.

RATING: N/A
Played this before I played Forbidden Island. I'd rather play FI. It's probably best with people you know, rather than a pickup game of strangers, because the play experience hinges on how everyone works with each other.

I found the rules fairly easy to understand, but the actual play to be challenging. Despite the rules discouraging it, there is a very strong tendency for the most experienced player to basically run the game; and to be honest, without someone directing the other players to act together, it seems pretty likely you're all going to lose. There were several times during the game when, if left without guidance, I would have performed what seemed to me to be "good" actions, which in hindsight would have doomed humanity.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7.5
[Z-man 2008 edition] {Pathology; variable-player-power, cooperative; scalable}  {4/5-Epidemic: 7; 6-Epidemic: 7.5} Pandemic is a thematic cooperative game.  The mechanic is familiar - players play cards for their own good and cards for the 'evil'.  It's not ground-breaking but it is very fun to play.

The game is engaging, esp. with more epidemic cards.  I prefer the 6-Epidemic setup.  It is just so exciting that epidemics happen again and again and players are busily cure the disease and yet finding cure in the same time.  However, it is anti-climax at late game when the result is almost determined.  There are nearly no surprise.  Essentially, it's a card collection game.  Players have the shared goal to collect 4 sets of cards with limited time and resources.  The challenge is how players can optimize their moves together to achieve the goal.  Comparatively short playing time and scalable with few players (2-3 players) are its selling point.

It is too easy to have a player (or leader) dominating the game.  This leader will instruct every other player to follow the best plan in order to win. That won't be fun at all!

Thematically, I think it can be expanded to include some hidden elements for the cure that the players have to hunt for in the game.

The components are quite nice.  The board is sturdy.  The cardstock is thick enough.  The card illustration is nice and effective, even though there are pieces of wrong information.  The pawns are too large but the cure markers are too small.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

Perhaps we're doing something wrong, but the game seems much easier with two players than with four: with two, the deck runs slower, and the cards you need to cure diseases are not scattered across four hands.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7
Amazing game. Best co-op I have played. It can be very frustrating though. I would rate it a 9, but losing and winning is just not that satisfying. A problem not with the game, but with the co-op genre in general.

UPDATE: Not as good as Flash Point, IMO. Rarely gets played anymore. Would not suggest it, as Flash Point will get the nod every time. I will play it, no question, if someone else wants to. Moves down from 8 to 7. 

UPDATE 2: Pandemic has regained its charm over time, and is equally as good as Flash Point. Pandemic is not as satisfying to play solo, but is the stronger strategic game. The roles are better implemented in Pandemic, IMO. Every role can be very useful and wont change your overall strategy too much (unlike Flash Point). Stays at 7.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8
This is a fun game that my wife and I enjoy playing together. She's a casual gamer and doesn't enjoy highly competitive or complex games so the cooperative gameplay is really appealing. Also, it's quite therapeutic and a good exercise in "team-building" as it forces players to work together for the same goals. Rules are easy to learn and teach and games last 30-45 minutes. The gameboard, cards and pieces are of good quality and the theme is really well done. Pandemic is a great choice for casual gamers and offers good replayability. When the time comes where we grow tired of the base game, there are several expansions that we can buy to extend it's life. I'd recommend this game to any of my friends looking for an easy to learn, enjoyable game to play.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 6
Since co-op games are a little odd, my rating is basically relative to LotR or SoC. Pandemic scores against these by having a more interesting theme, and requiring more movement in gameplay. LotR feels like walking down a road. SoC often feels like "I'll go over here and hang around for a few turns". Pandemic requires you to buzz around prioritising your actions; acquiring the cards to discover a series of cures while fire-fighting outbreaks. And all the while the clock is ticking. First four plays gave a couple of close wins (one turn from losing), and a spectacularly dreadful 17-minute loss when we failed to get to grips with an unlucky S.America setup. And we haven't moved beyond the beginers version yet. Very clever infection deck mechanism to re-infect locations.

Update: Rating reduced because after the first 5 plays, nobody has asked to play again.

RATING: 6
Mikael
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7
Fun co-operative game that provides a satisfying amount of tension. Players take the roles of a team fighting the outbreak of four different diseases worldwide. Each turn players have four actions to either move, cure a disease, build a research centre or transfer cards to other players. Each player has a unique roll (the medic can treat more diseases, the researcher can transfer cards more easily, the scientist doesn't need as many cards in order to cure a disease etc), and once all four diseases have been cured the game has been won. It can be a tense affair as the diseases begin to spread more quickly and areas have to be prioritised and it can also be a tough game to beat. Strategies are pretty obvious but this is a game where one mistake can lead to defeat.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 10
Laura's Rank (3/15) – 5 out of 5. Pros: I like cooperative games overall. The theme is played out so well that even competitive people will get drawn into beating the board. I love that you can control the difficulty with the epidemic cards. You can play it over and over and have it still be interesting and challenging. I love the components and how it looks when you are overwhelmed with diseases. Great player interaction. You have to work together as a team, which is not necessarily true of all cooperative games. So many ways to die. Just a great game. Complicated enough to think through strategies, but not so complicated that you can't have fun the first time you play.

Ryan's Rank (3/15) – 5 out of 5. This is a great game. Easily my favorite cooperative. Love the theme. Love the mechanics. Love that you really have to work as a team to beat the game. There are some tense moments that come in the game, and Laura and I tend to get into it. Our friends have also taken to it as well.

Overall Rank: 10 out of 10

RATING: 7

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7
Great, simple cooperative game.  Players play agents of the Centre for Disease Control and try to contain 4 different diseases spreading throughout the world.  Each player chooses a different role that has a different special ability.  Players have to travel throughout the world to contain diseases and eventually research cures for them.

This game is quite simple to play and yet quite fun.  It is easy to teach to new players.  I highly recommend this game to introduce new players to board games and/or cooperative games.

The game can be played with 2 to 4 players.  I find that it is easiest with 3 players and hardest with 4 players.  The difficulty level of the game can be adjusted to make it harder for veteran players.

I have the 2013 version.  This fixes some balance issues with one of the roles and adds a new ones.  It also removes one role (the Generalist) which is balanced, but somewhat uninteresting.  Overall, I find that every role is interesting to play and has a unique advantage to help win the game.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

Owned by Mike & Al

RATING: 9
Absolutely great game, very accessible. Together with Ticket To Ride, San Juan, Smallworld, 7 Wonders and Dominion VERY suitable as gateway game or game to play with non-gamers. Just make sure the most experienced player shuts up - as else he'll be running the whole game by himself. 

REMINDER TO ALL VETERANS:
Accept you might lose if you see others mess up. 
Pandemic excitement is also in learning how to win!
Give others that excitement too, don't spoil it for them by running the game on your own.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7
It's a fun, easy to play game that can be fairly punishing, as co-op games ought to be. However the curve isn't quite steep enough for my friends and I, and the theme doesn't click anywhere near as well as Ghost Stories which I prefer. It's a fantastic theme for a co-operative game and the infection mechanic (in particular the repetitive infection of the same cities over the course of the game) has it's heart in the right place. It just doesn't quite crack my top tier of games. It feels a bit too light for my personal tastes, which I recognize is exactly what makes it work for a lot of players especially infrequent gamers who still want a reasonable challenge without much complexity.

This is really Pandemic's strong suit: the game is incredibly simple to pick up and play, but you can get a lot out of that simplicity. It has a narrative that directs players more than most "abstract" games, but isn't very much divorced from that genre in terms of mechanics and presentation aside from the luck aspect.

Highly recommended for fans of co-op games, however, especially if you've tried Ghost Stories and found it too punishing.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: N/A
Best:4
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 10
Really incredible game design, building on an extremely simple foundation, giving a wide array of options for tactics by combining the special skills of each role.
I especially like how all the cards are basically just a city, and a color based on the same city, yet they play such a big part of any strategy. Will you play your card to travel to or from the city, build there, or trading it to your fellow player? You can only do one!
Fun, quick to set up and play, and terribly exciting.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 4
A little less than thrilled if I had to play this again, hence the 5 rating. It seems to boil down to one person who figures it out telling everyone else how to play it; which totally destroys the theme to me. While the mechanics seem quite different, they dont really convey the theme to me at all. THe idea of cracking a virus code has got to be more about hypothesis, and not about making melds. Same with the roles, they dont convey the theme. There needs to be the psychology of leadership, the psychology of mass panic and the puzzle of biology if this theme is to work. As is, the game pretty much upsets me as it falls flat in all these levels. It's not bad game at all for the right group and probably deserves its rating. But not for me.

RATING: 8.5
Played 2x 2-player games: fun! Very simple game with surprising depth for such a short game. The player roles are all not only useful but crucial; once the players have their roles, a strategy must be tailored to which roles are in play. Much of the game is about balance; maintaining a low risk of "outbreak" without detracting from the goal of curing the diseases.

RATING: 7.5
Sleeved
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 2
I know this game is widely loved, but I'm not a fan of co-op games if they're highly vulnerable to alpha player problems, and this one does absolutely nothing to counter that.  For me, it's not so much about one player taking over a game, it's about all decisions being made by committee.  It feels like each player is playing every role to some extent when that happens.  As an alpha gamer, I prefer everyone to make the most optimal moves, but I prefer co-ops that include mechanics that preclude 1) one person dictating the entire gameflow and 2) games where most or all decisions are made by committee.  This is a solo game pretending to be multiplayer.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 5
Only played once, but it suffered from one player telling others what to do.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8
An excellent co-op game, based upon an elegant puzzle, with a perfect theme.

The base game is a bit too easy once you have played a couple of times. Looking forward to playing more with the expansions.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7.5
tl;dr: a huge success with good reason

I remember this game being announced. There was NO buzz. I was working for a distributor or Z-Man titles at the time, so I ordered just a couple of cases. I had requested pre-orders from shops, there were very few. The day the games arrived though, the game was sold out. So I contacted Zev to order more. He had sold out. He told me he had printed 3000, a very normal print run at the time. So this game went from no buzz to THE hype of the moment in no time. And it seems to still be growing, with all these variations and expansions coming out.
In any case... I've never been a fan of co-ops. And I probably never will be. I don't hate them, but I just prefer some healthy competition. That being said, I think this is still my favorite co-op (of the ones I've played, duh!). I think it has the perfect balance of amount of rules, play time and complexity for all experience levels. Most co-ops have some variation of the if-this-happens-resolve-this-random-event-card-mechanism. Pandemic kind of has that with the epidemic cards, but other games like [thing=121921][/thing] have way more of that. If feels kind of like a lame way to throw problems at the players to me. But the (sparce) way it is implemented in Pandemic is perfect. There's only a little bit of it, but the tension it creates is great.
Also, this game is pretty streamlined and usually takes less than an hour.
All in all, very good, though not my favorite.

Rating: 7.5/10
BGG scale: 7/10

RATING: 7.5
Our first "real" board game outside of the typical Milton Bradley party games. We love it so far. While we have only played it with 4 Epidemic cards so far, it is a very challenging game. My wife enjoys that it is us vs. the game, and not us attacking each other. Very smooth mechanics that allow you to really think out some nice combos. I can see how the game can be susceptible to quarterbacking from a strong personality at the table, but I don't see that as a huge negative. Overall a very good game that feels refined and challenging that will surely bring a lot of replays.

RATING: N/A
#Players: 2-4
Time: 45 mins
Mechanic: Co-Op, Board Management, Disaster Assessment

Several different contagions are spreading across the globe. Join forces with other characters as you attempt to minimize the spread of these diseases while attempting to cure them. If too many infected are in one area, the disease will spread to other countries and soon be out of control.

RATING: 7.3
It's a nice option if you want to play with non-gamers. Easy to teach, cooperative and adaptable difficulty. However, do avoid the game if there is one person who likes too much to take the leader role. I think this isn't a game design problem... but it is clearly a problem with some groups.

That said, I don't really feel this is a great game for experienced players groups. After some games, all the games seem similar. It's nice if you want to play it from time to time. It isn't a game to play every week with the same people.

„ Pandemia”, czyli jak krucha jest ludzkość. 

Plusy : 
1. Wykonanie planszy i znaczników. 
2. Klimat. 
3. Grafiki. 
4. Poziomy trudności. 
5. Zróżnicowani bohaterowie. 
6. Proste zasady. 
7. Poziomy trudności. 

Minusy: 
1. Wykonanie kart (słabe, cienkie, od razu powinny wylądować w koszulkach) 
2. Pionki graczy wyjęte żywcem z chińczyka z lat 90. 

„Pandemia” to świetny tytuł co-op. Dobrze zbalansowany co pozwala się dobrze bawić graczom na różnym poziomie. Gra trzyma w napięciu. Tytuł potrafi wejść w krew jak wirusy z którymi mamy walczyć, i zmusza do ponownych rozgrywek. Polecam i oceniam na 7/10

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 6
A decent accounting game that reminds me of Risk, albeit in reverse. The manipulation of the infection deck is very clever (by this I mean the premature recycling mechanic), and the outbreaks do bring out the theme to some small degree, but overall, it is an ephemeral experience.
It is definitely more fun to play this abstract game as a team than solo, since interactions bring out the game's other mild thematic strength---the special skills of each character.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 6
Rather fun in the sense that each turn, players are trying to solve a logic puzzle together, although the player with the most experience tends to dominate the discussion. Love the Epidemic mechanic where the cards in the discard pile are reshuffled and placed BACK ON TOP of the draw pile - it truly reflects the virulent nature of diseased cities.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7

RATING: N/A
shared with MaFt
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 9.5
The best co-op game I've played. The epidemic mechanic where past cities get re-infected keeps the short-term goal of cleaning cubes from feeling totally random, giving you an actual sense of planning and purpose, rather than just mindlessly putting out fires as they appear (something I didn't like about Defenders of the Realm and something I fear I won't like about Flash Point: Fire Rescue). Downsides: games swing wildly along the spectrum from fairly easy to impossibly difficult, leaving a sense of dissatisfaction at either end. Also, some of the roles can seem totally useless, especially with a low number of players where you want to get the most out of the limited advantages you have.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 9
Fantastic coop game.  Can be quite challenging at times.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 9.4
Pandemic is an AWESOME game, especially if you're trying to get people into boardgames. One change we made is cards all face up, and NO TALKING whatsoever. It makes it so much more interesting trying to predict what your team-mates are doing based on their cards.

Especialy with four, there seems to happen too much between player-turns: The world will look completely different the next time it's your turn, so there's little chance to plan ahead.

A lot of the recent expansions look like they've added new mechanics and increased the difficulty of the disease to compensate (or maybe it's the other way around), but honestly I think the core is so weak that I'm not really willing to find out if the rest is better.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7
First time I played I walked away thinking winning was all based on luck. Too many car draws to get lucky or unlucky draws with. After reading some tips, I can see how some of this can be planned for, but I still think that luck is going to have a big impact on if you win or lose.

I think the my main issue with the game is that you don't have have many options for actions. Most of the actions are just ways to move. Then there's building research stations, healing people, finding a cure and trading knowledge. Cure is not an option for an action. If you can do it then you do, there's no reason to put it off. Healing people isn't really a decision because there's usually a few cities at 3 that need to be taken care of. So you move and then heal those areas that need it. It's mostly a forced action. Research stations waste cards, so you're really only looking to do that if the role that build them is out of the game. So the only real decision in the game is trading knowledge and IMO that's such an action waster that I would argue that it's best just to heal and draw cards and get the cures if someone gets lucky. We had to waste 3 people's turns to trade enough cards for a cure and that was with efficient planning. One of them was usually the medic so we were losing out on taking a lot of cubes off the board to get the cures. In the meantime we added 6 cubes to the board putting us closer to outbreaks which is how we lost in the end.

I'm wondering how many times people have won this have been either lucky card draws at the beginning of the game or people missing rules that restrict the researcher or sharing knowledge in general.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7
Very entertaining cooperative game, although it didn't give me the same "buzz" as Knizia's Lord of the Rings. Looking forward to trying it with four players. Rating could go either way with time.

edit: Lowered the grade. Luck when it comes to card draw seems to be a much bigger factor than skill. Still an entertaining game that appeals to non-gamers as well

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 6
This used to be THE Co-Op game but the base game is showing it's age. The quarterbacking issue where one player orders everyone around can be a big turn off, also some of the mechanics that were originally loved for being simple are just feeling boring now, like set collection and discard of five cards. However the expansions to this game really save it. There is a ton of variety to add to the game for anyone who originally loved it and wanted to refresh it, like myself. Also this game will still be great for new bright eyed board gamers as I'm sure it will feel just as fun to them as it did to all of us who played it when it first came out. I still recommend everyone at least give Pandemic a try and throw in an expansion or two when it starts to feel old.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

Great fun. Hard to beat with two players.

RATING: 10
Received in math trade

To me... this is just Pandemic with permanent expansions. So I am lumping Pandemic with Pandemic: Legacy.

With that said...WOW!

I have got a fever, and the only cure is more cowbell...and a medic,...and a eradication, oh and maybe a new role card and one quiet night and...

Absolutely addicted to this game. Seems like every time we play it comes down to one or two turns from victory and the world explodes! Occasionally, we can squeak out a win just in time. Awesome!

Numerous times I will come home from work and my wife and brother-in-law will have it set up on the table after 2 or 3 plays that day. Hmmm, stupid work! 

The ultimate co-op! We will find new good Co-ops like Flash Point, Ghost Stories, Tiny Epic Defenders, Legendary, Forbidden Island and Desert. However, we always come back to the Granddaddy...Pandemic!!!

RATING: 6
Very good co-op. All the roles are good and it is vital that you all work as a team. There are so many little highs along the way to victory - and therefore an awful gaping chasm if you blow it! Very emotional!

Update: as I play more co-ops I realise that actually this is the type that I like least as it has the puzzle co-op downfall that I dislike - unless every one of you knows the game well, it is vital that anyone inexperienced does as they are told, as one false step can bring the whole thing crashing down. It then has to be a case of the newbie(s) having every single move orchestrated for them for the 1st game or two.And I was taught the game by one of the nicest, patient gamers I have ever met - I really can't imagine what it would be like being instructed by a games tyrant or bully!

RATING: 9

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 9
Brilliant co-op with a rich theme, interesting choices, and a lot of challenge. I particularly love that you can adjust the difficulty with epidemic cards; we always won on the easy level, but have yet to win on heroic mode. There's definitely an imbalance in roles; for instance, the medic is nearly invaluable especially if you're playing on one of the higher difficulties. Still, the intensify and outbreak mechanics allow for extremely intense gameplay and all players stay invested and engaged throughout, so there's never any boredom. Overall, just a really cool game. 
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 10
(2013 edition) This game gets the most play, and is the best game I own as of writing this. I'm eager to try the expansions.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 6
A very compelling cooperative game that plays quickly and is consistently tense. The only thing that keeps this from ranking even higher are some minor fiddly aspects to the card and cube distribution. Overall, this is probably one the best cooperative game out there and representative of the new wave of cooperative titles (including Ghost Stories and Battlestar Galactica) that blow away the old generation (including Lord of the Rings and Shadows Over Camelot). Edit: Game has felt more abstract and dry to me as time marches on ... game doesn't hit the table and rating lowered to 6.

RATING: 7
Pandemic is not so much a game as a Rubick's cube:  the entertainment comes in being beaten by it, over and over again.  This is a snappy, fun cooperative that is almost clinical (pardon the pun) in its efficiency.  It's susceptible to quarterbacking, where one player tries to take over and direct the others.  Easy to learn, hard to beat.

RATING: 8.5
I see now, why it was so easy for us to defeat the game. We made one of the common mistakes. But I expicitly asked whether I'd have to get rid of my cards exceeding 7 right away or after my turn. The way we played it I was able to find the antidote for two diseases in one turn (playing the scientist) Good components, awesome because truely different theme - hey, it's mankind which is on the brink of extinction so you better get yourself together, a lot of interaction. I want this and I want to play it again. Badly! 

Have played it several times now and the fun/time/theme-ratio of this game is one of the best among all games I've yet seen. It takes about 45 minutes to play, 15 minutes to teach and it's a very tense experience. 

Today we played the supermegaheroic level of the game. We intended to play with 5 cards, cause we couldn't find the sixth epidemic card, so I figured it was lost. We build 5 stacks and gamed on, but the sixth card was still in the player cards pile ... Man, did we lose, because of drawing 3 epidemic cards almost in a row.

RATING: 10
Settlers of Catan and King of Tokyo peaked my interest in the hobby, but Pandemic sealed it.  I had never even heard of co-op board games before, much less played one, so this thing blew my mind.  And even after playing so many other games, this one still holds up.  It sounds crazy, but the thing I love most is the feeling of dread this game gives.  "Will there be an outbreak in San Francisco?  Can we avoid clearing out blue cubes for just one more turn?"  And with how difficult the game can be, it still always feels like we have a chance at winning.  I've introduced many friends to board gaming with Pandemic, and even my non-gamer friends like it.  Perfect 10!

RATING: 4
It's not a BAD game - it's actually pretty ingeniously designed - it's just that it gets boring after just a few plays. We did finally manage to luck out and beat the hardest difficulty once, but only once. And that's also a problem with it. Once you figure out the basic strategy to win with, you generally only lose on the hardest difficulty, which is just chock full of way-too-rapid explosion of the situation.

For the most part, the game is a logic puzzle, with some gambling, but at the highest difficulty level, you're unlikely to even make it back to your turn before there's another outbreak, because there just aren't enough cards in the deck to give you a chance.

RATING: 10
I have about 15 plays or more on this game, and I still feel like I haven't figured it out. High replay value. Really want On The Brink soon!

Edit: 40 plays later, and it's only started to get a little bit stale. Maybe that's because I played it ten times in the past week... :D

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 9.5
I played this once way back '07, then didn't play it again until seven years later. I wish I hadn't wasted those 7 years. I think this game does nearly everything right.

1) It looks good.
2) It accepts a pretty wide number of players and scales well through them all. Including solo!
3) The game is infinitely tweak-able to suit the challenge your looking for. The expansions only enhance this.
4) The theme is both unique and engaging.
5) It is accessible to many levels of gamers and non-gamers. Some of this is due to the theme. Some due to the tweakability mentioned above. Some due to a fairly simple rules set. Some is due to it being a co-op (it is less scary for some than competitive and you more experienced players can help you learn to play while you play).
6) It is well supported by quality expansions.
7) It has fun gameplay that is well integrated with its theme.




Suitability for Travel:

I have a 1 to 5 scale for four categories (1 is worst, 5 is best) in order of importance:

Portability (the less luggage space the better) - 1
Footprint (the less table space when playing the better) - 1
Scalability (the wider range of player counts the better) - 3
Learnability (the easier to teach non-gamers the better) - 3


Overall - 1.25

RATING: 8
Pandemic was definitely my introduction to great modern games.

I love the feeling that you're continuously one turn away from losing the game, especially in the bio-terrorist mode where you can see the outbreak coming and do a last ditch flight to the problem area before the terrorist destroys the city and ends the game.

It needs to be played with analytic people who aren't overbearing which can be a difficult to find combination in people but it's a wonderful game with the right players.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 5
The more  I play Pandemic, the less I like it.  I've concluded that it works best as a solo game, or as a two-player game, but only if those 2 people are close, with similar intelligence and experience. Every time I've seen it played, there are some people giving orders, and others that are just doing what they're told.  The people that are just listlessly moving their pawn around, following instructions, might as well not even be there.  What augments this problem, is the fact that the game has such a razor-thin margin for error, even at the beginning difficulty, that the team has to behave this way.  There's no room for an inexperienced player to do what he wants, or attempt to try different strategies.  If not for the interesting theme and epidemic mechanisms, this game would completely blow.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7.5

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8
The first co-op game I've ever played and it was kind of a revelation for me. I got this based on theme alone and ended up figuring out that it was also a great (and in someways ground-breaking) game. 

Nuclear weapons, pandemics, and wars... those are my macabre, academic fascinations. If it's themed after one of the horsemen of the apocalypse, chances the game will have my interest.

As much as I like this game, something feels missing. I wish the diseases had more character and individual traits. I wish more of a real epidemiological feel (an R0 value? immunity? etc) were involved in a more robust way. Now, if only someone would make a heavier, more simulation-style pandemic game (like Plague Inc for iOS)! 

I need to grab some expansions at some point. Also really looking forward to playing Pandemic Legacy
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8
I really like the co-op aspect for family play - and the little ones really enjoy it - though they are really just playing along with mom and dad, rather than 'playing' the game with their own actions.  As an adult strategy and group effort game, its an engaging and exciting trip, and the chain reactions can get out of hand fast! (Sometimes too fast!).

Really something - though the rules are a little phrenetic with everything going on.  Once we got the basics - there were a few situations that really got us tangled up until they were clear. (Cured diseases allow full city treatment rather than one block, cures requiring a research station for example.) Take the time to do a FULL readthrough of the rules before play - and it should be clear as milk when infection starts to spread. ;)

RATING: 7.75
Fantastic cooperative game that still seems hard to win at the introductory level after 9 plays.  Great tension throughout.  Even when we think we have everything under control, a new outbreak or epidemic can throw a serious wrench in our plans.  Plays great with young and old, it's popular with my nine-year-old, my high school students and my game group.  As I imagine is the case with most cooperatives, it can lose its fun if one player dominates the discussion of choices and tries to play the game as a multi-character solitaire.

UPDATE: After completing the full year of [gameid=161936], I'm not sure when this will ever get back to the table.  I suppose it still will have a place as a gateway game for the non-competitive, I just don't currently have a lot of opportunity to scratch that itch.

RATING: 8.6
This game is tons of fun.   I've played at least 3 dozen games now with my wife.  It's simple to learn, and has a good amount of strategy involved.  At the end of each game, we always reflect on things we could have done differently.     

The theme is also great.   You really get a feel for infection spreading, and we always make references to "outbreak" the movie while playing.  It's got a permanent place on the "to play" shelf.

This is not a good game for someone looking for complexity and obfuscated gameplay.  But if you're just looking to have fun, there's much to be had.

RATING: 5
Too easy to assess the best course of action in my opinion, making it a better solitaire experience.
Difficulty of the entire game is too strongly tied to the initial shuffle. Most times I play I feel zero stress as I am casually sweeping up the mess on the board. Maybe I don't play enough, but I feel that the initial shuffle tends to yield difficult to lose games most often.
Great gateway game though (teaches limited action selection, planning ahead, cooperation, risk-assessment, etc.). 
I prefer Forbidden Island.

Board > App. Shuffles ALWAYS go the worst possible way in the app, making it annoyingly difficult.

RATING: 8
A model co-op. 

Advantages:
- Strong theme well connected to the mechanics.
- It's hard to beat, impossible if you do not cooperate well. Still, variable difficulty welcomes newcomers.

Disadvantages:
- It's a classic co-op that can suffer from the Alpha Player problem.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7
I brought this game as a casual, gateway game for friends and family. I don't think this game is good for that purpose however, as all the times I've tried this with friends and family not into board games, I found they mostly let me make all the decisions. It's also pretty hard, even on the easiest difficulty.

That said, as a coop experience this game is good with more experienced board gamers. The fun often comes from the discussions of plans as you try and eliminate the viruses before they go pandemic. With the right group of people, the discussions over game plans, who needs to be where and when to use the character abilities is where this game is at it's best.

The game can get repetitive over multiple sessions, but I imagine the various expansions probably help with this. I only own the base game however, so can't comment on the expansions.

It's overall a solid coop game, but definitely not a gateway game. For more experienced board gamers only.

RATING: 7.5
A quick, easy and fun game that is entertaining enough for heavy gamers after a quick play, but not too difficult to put off more casual gamers. Plus it plays well two-player for me and my wife. Full review at: http://www.boardgamegeek.com/thread/307561
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 10
What I like:

-Short playing time but it doesn't sacrifice anything to get it
-Massive tension. It is very rare that I'm cheering so much for a single card draw as I am in this
-Very interesting and vastly different roles creating unique situations
-Value for money
-Works with so many groups and a totally awesome theme that almost everyone can get behind
-allows great strategic thinking  because of the discard pile you have a good idea of what you need to do and can prioritize accordingly. 

What I dislike: 
It is possible to have a bit of the alpha-gamer case with this one, as almost all information is shared if success is to be acheived. Especially if the level of experience varies between players. I found that this game works best if everyone wants to participate mostly equally in the discussion of every turn. 

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 10
Great game. Very intense, very fun. The clear plastics cubes look awesome!
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8
Nice difficulty level.  I am sure it will suffer the co-op fade over time.  I think I can get enough plays out of it to make it fun regardless.  Though, now that I think of it, good co-ops should suffer from the fade with increased play because it means skill is an integral part of the game. If it didn't have that fade, it would be too luck based and random to be worthwhile.  So I think this is my official go to co-op and when it starts getting stale..... there is always the expansion.

Still holding my interest after 30 plays, something I didn't think a co-op could do.  Rating changed upward.

On the Brink adds some variety, and I will use it going forward.  Its not the quite the life injector I had hoped it would be, but its still a must add.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 10
Fantastic game that allows the whole family to play together on the same team.  The children can win with their parents instead of always getting outsmarted by them.  My family is eagerly waiting for the expansion.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 5
1st game...well we decided to play the 'easy' route and owner of game set it up and we ran through it.  We won.  I'm usually not happy about a co-op game that can be beaten in the first play when you don't know the system well and probably are making some extra moves that don't need to be made. Well as it turns out we seeded the deck wrong...and actually had an "Ultra-easy" game on our hands as we played without 2 epidemic cards.  

Now for the game play. I love it.  You feel a real sense of urgency in this game it feels so important to get so much done in such a little amount of time.  This can be a brutal game if we'd have had even one of the extra epidemics in there I think we'd have lost.  Fun game very intense. 

I do feel this is one of those "expansions in mind" games and won't be surprised if we see an expansion for it sooner rather than later. 

UPDATE: Played it twice more both times this time we are on "Heroic"...I'm still at 66% win ratio.

RATING: 8
I was very skeptical of this game going in because of disappointing experiences with cooperative games in the past and the first play didn't really do much for me, but I've since had a chance to play it a few times, and I must say that it's really growing on me.  I'm considering buying a copy now so I can keep playing it more.  I'm not quite sure what it is about Pandemic that I enjoy, but I do know that I keep thinking about the game and revisiting it in my head, so it's probably worth picking up.  It's so very quick and packs a lot into a short amount of time, and it's so very brutal and difficult that it makes you want to try again and again.  The mechanics of the epidemics and intensifying just seem to work so well together that it really achieves the simplicity yet depth that I look for in games.

RATING: 6
A fun co-op game that plays quickly and has some neat dynamics to it.

As I anticipated, the replay of this title has dropped a bit for me.  The game seems to play itself a bit too much, with player responses somewhat pre-destined by the crisis at hand.

While I like the fact that you have to work together to get it done, Pandemic doesn't offer enough choice in HOW to get it done.  At the end of the day, it feels more like a puzzle than a game to me.

RATING: 7
The big brother for Forbidden Island.

It is also a pretty good cooperative game. The gameplay, though suffering a little with the fiddling with the cubes, is fast and smart, making the whole experience well worth it.

It is difficult without being hellish and true cooperation is a must to win. Pandemic can, however, be affect by the "follow my lead" - when one or two players, normally the veterans in the game, conduct the others. But this is not a problem of Pandemic, being something to look out in most of the co-ops. So, be aware to avoid this!

Anyway, a fine game. Enjoy!

My review (in portuguese) is [url=http://boardgamegeek.com/thread/835092/pandemic-resenha-em-portugues-review-in-portugue]here[/url].
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7
Compared to Ghost Stories the spatial considerations seem much deeper. I think I like it.

The opportunity cost of getting specific cards from one player to another seems awfully high. Found the logistics of this a little irritating as it didn't feel very productive overall.

...Seem to frequently lose by running out of cards to draw, which I find dissatisfying because it just means an arbitrary time limit elapsed, not that the state on the board is particularly dire.

...I respect this design enough that I probably won't lower the rating below 7, but I'm getting pretty frustrated with the situation that we think we're close to winning but then we run out of cards to draw. I don't think we have ever won since correcting a rule misunderstanding.

RATING: 9
Addictive game. Definitely my wife's favorite new game in a long time, and since it plays so well with two it has quickly jumped towards the top of my most played list in a very short amount of time. Maybe 3 other games in my game playing career have been played so often so quickly (Lost Cities, Settlers, Race for the Galaxy). However, while it is a very good game, I can't bring myself to call it one of my own faves. I keep fearing I'm playing it wrong because I have beaten it all but once out of almost 10 times, including a couple on "Heroic"...not only winning them but winning most of them without as much tension as I would like. I want to feel like I barely eak out a win. Still, there are times the game is gloriously nail-biting, and the mechanics are very cool and the theme sounds a bit strange but it's uniqueness and "real world setting" make it really stand out as a winner.

RATING: 10
This is simply the perfect co-op game for me. The tension is always there because even if are doing well, the game can turn quickly if the wrong combination of cards turn up. The decision-making can be gut-wrenching. Do I go over there and treat disease or go over here to share information for the cure, hoping an epidemic doesn't happen this turn? The theme is great, and it's simple enough to teach to non-gamers. I never get bored of this game.

RATING: 8
Pandemic can be a lot of fun. Sometimes it can be way to hard and sometimes way to easy, but over time, and with the expansion, my wife and I have figured out how to properly balance the game so that it's typically good and challenging and not swayed too far in either direction of difficulty. It's awesome that the game is co-op and fun. It's best played where everybody has good strategies. The fun factor can fail if one person makes or pushes all of their opinions, but that's probably true for any co-op game.

RATING: N/A

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8.5
One of my favorite movies is "outbreak."  Naturally, this is a fantastic co-op game for me.  You are part of the CDC and trying to cure, eradicate, and treat diseases that are popping up all over the world.  While I do feel that flipping the infection cards is a little redundant, if you have someone work the cards and know the locations to get it done quickly, it flows very nicely.  Everytime an outbreak happens the whole table always says "ohhh,,noo!"  Everyone seems to get into the game.  It is easy to understand and move around and get things done so new people can feel at ease playing it.

RATING: 10

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8
We finally got our own copy of this and have been playing it a lot thanksgiving weekend with great pleasure! It *is* a sort of team verison of solitaite -- and, unlike most competitive games, you can play it very well by yourself, since the players are not in competition. On the other hand, it is definitely even better with a team of people, trying to collectively decide on a strategy to merge their individual role-skills and cards most effectively as the menace grows ever larger. 

The theme is great and very nicely captured by the simple game mechanic. With the 3 player game (which is what we've played the most), the game seems very different each time depending on which 3 roles we use and how the cards turn out.

RATING: 8
Obviously a masterpiece design. Some friends HAVE to play at least one session when they come over--cool.

Added later: Well, yes and no. It's a masterpiece design, that much was true, but those friends now request other games when they come over. Pandemic might be slipping a little bit in my personal list of preferences, partly just because it's a co-op. I think it's good with constantly-changing gaming partners, but when you play with the same one or two or three people all the time, I think I prefer the history that builds up in competitive games. Still, brilliant game, obviously.
