=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8
While I do wonder about longevity, this is a good looking game, and almost anyone can join in and feel comfortable from the start. The lack of competition helps this, of course. This is a cooperative game that doesn't require your being comfortable with obscure mythos, sci-fi (Battlestar Galactica), zombies or gnomes. It has a theme that ordinary people at least understand. 

It is also not so complex that new players need to be told what to do all the time, without their understanding what it is that they are doing, or why they should be doing it. I love Arkham Horror, but suggesting that your sweet aunt Mathilda fight the Dimensional Shambler (not even going into the bonuses she receives for having a +6 Sword of Smiting) while you go through a gate to another world is quite different to suggesting that she catch a shuttle flight to Sydney to cure the red disease. Yes, I know, I shouldn't be playing Arkham Horror with aunt Mathila in the first place, but Pandemic allows you to play with (almost) anyone, with a fair chance that they actually enjoy themselves. That makes it a must have in my collection.

 
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8
You are specialists at the CDC/Atlanta where you watch several virulent diseases break out simultaneously all over the world. The team mission is to prevent a worldwide pandemic outbreak, treating hot spots while researching cures for each of the four plagues before they get out of hand.

Players must plan their strategy to mesh their specialists' strengths before the diseases overwhelm the world. For example, the Operations Expert can build research stations which are needed to find cures for the diseases. The Scientist needs only 4 cards of a particular disease to cure it instead of the normal 5. But the diseases are breaking out fast and time is running out: the team must try to stem the tide of infection in diseased areas while developing cures. If disease spreads uncontrolled, the players all lose. If they can cure all four diseases, they win.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 9
Pandemic is a cooperative game that doesn't relent. You and your medical team are assigned roles and thrust into a world with rampaging virii. Just when you think you have the upper hand an outbreak occurs infecting and possible reinfecting cities. Then the cards are shuffled and placed back on the draw pile. That's right, those cities are going to be visited by the virus threat again. I like how each person has a unique role. Teamwork is critical to success. Your actions have meaningful consequences to the game. It is up to all of you. Have fun and best luck!

RATING: 8
I like this much better than, say, Arkham Horror-- there's a lot more tension and the way the roles interact is neat. Best of all, when I go to a city to do something, it happens; in games like AH, I roll a die to see if it happens.  I get much more enjoyment out of this kind of randomness-- and the "back-on-top-of-the-deck" mechanic controls that randomness, makes it more purposeful.  Very elegant game that I'm digging so far.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8
Good:
-Unique roles
-Co-operative
-Puzzle
-Each role can make a big impact
-Great theme

Bad:
-An alpha player often dominates
-Some role powers aren't intuitive 
-When to use travel cards can be confusing
-Not a gateway game
-Players always start in Atlanta

Overall:
You're trying to save the world by solving a puzzle with your friends and this core experience is what makes you want to play it over an over.  The mechanics really unifies players in an us verse the game mentality.  In full disclosure, the alpha player issue became a big obstacle in my group and forced us to make a house rule that non-active player can only advise if the active player asks them a question.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

Almost every aspect of this game I love. The varied roles and difficulty levels make this game always a favorite in my house.

Hmmm...I'm having doubts about Pandemic...
Don't get me wrong, I loved the game when we played it...And I'll keep on wanting to play the game, until we win (I'm a bad loser ;-)

The thing is that I feel that once you "win" the game I reckon I will get tired of it instantly...It's sort of breaking a code that opens a lock or something. Once it's open, it's open...why close it and try again??

I must admit that I'm one of those guys that (almost) never replays a videogame after I've beaten it (shame on me) and Pandemic feels the same...

RATING: 7.5
Seems to be ground zero for modern cooperative games.  Solid rules and an innovative theme captures first time players.  Most really enjoy it.  Watch out for the bossy types, they can take over more timid personalities.  It does lose some appeal after a while and feels more like a puzzle.  So...don't play it too often and enjoy for years to come.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7
Too bad the looks of this game are a bit too abstract, because what lies underneath is a great game. It is surprisingly fast and tense, easy to explain and with very little downtime (especially for a co-op!). We can easily squeeze multiple sessions in on a regular gaming night. Best of its kind, even a little bit better than Ghost Stories and Forbidden Island (which I also like very much). Could be due to the fact that it requires more planning (to get the right cards to the right person for example).
Only drawback for me, is that it is still a co-op game. As such, I feel its replayability is limited by default.

RATING: 7
12/2008:7.5
Pandemic is good co-op game, not great. Good. Co-op games are generally quite difficult to balance, but Pandemic seems like well-integrated, light family game. I like it that it goes quick, with two players, it seems like an easy job. But certain role combos are much easier to play than others. The jury is still out there. I need more plays to form a better judgment.  So far, I give it a 7.5 based on two plays. 

Updated: It is definitely really tightly balanced. Thus far, the two player games have been excellent with loads of tension. Best mechanic in the game is the epidemic reshuffling of the discard pile back into the deck. Without this mechanism, there would not be enough tension in the game.

Small rule mistakes make a difference to this tight co-op game.

When you think you're doing great job with stoping pandemic, the game punches you in the face, and basically, destroying everything you've done so far. Cooperation, and synergy between players is required to win in this game.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7.5
Some weird things happened to us in this game. We played this we three players six times so far. 

First three times were relatively easy wins. Is this game perhaps too easy? The fourth time we played too slowly and only won on the last possible action of the last player before we would have lost (for lack of cards to draw). Pfff... close one! Game finaly teaching us a lesson?

Hilariously, we then played our fifth time, all three of us drawing an Epidemy on our first turn, so that at the end of the first round... all having played just once... it was game over already, since we ran into our eighth Outbreak... (with more Outbreaks actually coming in, had the game not ended there). Ouch! So unfair! Was this a case of exceptionally bad RNG? Wondering how rare this occurence really is, it would seem bound to happen every now and then... Game six we then won as we had done the first three times.

Having hit both the highest (game 4) and the lowest (game 5) possible, back to back, I still rate this game not higher than I do, since coop games just don't satisfy my competitive needs.

RATING: 6.5
This game is too much of a puzzle and not enough of a game for me. It was fun a few times.

If you know the game and you're playing with people who don't, there is no right thing to do. You can tell them what to do, which means they're not really playing, or you can leave them to their own devices and watch as you all lose.

I also feel like once you've got the roles figured out, it's very easy to tell early on whether you're going to win or lose, and if you're going to lose, exactly how and why.

I've heard that the expansions fix many of the problems, but I want a game that is solid out of the box. I don't mind expansions enhancing the game, but they shouldn't have to fix it.

I know lots of people love this one. We gave our copy to some friends who did.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8
Very impressive cooperative game. A set collection game at it's heart (the only way to win is to complete a set of each of the four colours - however one player must have all five (or four) cards in their hand at the time, must be at a research station and must use an action to "cure" that disease) complicated by several built-in timing mechanisms - if the card deck runs out, if all of one colour's cubes are exhausted, if eight outbreaks have occurred - the game is over. The game appears to be more difficult with more players and the different combinations of player roles can change the dynamics of game play considerably. Z-Man has done an excellent job with graphic design and production, with one caveat - the player pawns are far bigger than they need to be. A slight quibble for an outstanding game experience.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8
starting to loose it's luster.  easy game to teach others, but every game seems to go the same.  Plus, the "alpha" person (or more experienced) person seems to run the ship causing an experience with very little real interaction.

playing against the system just isn't for me I think, I have similar feelings towards Arkham.

I'd rather play Agricola, TTR, or Tikal to name a few over this one.  still not a bad game, but not as great as I expected...

RATING: 1
Ok.  I've got 8 plays under my belt so I feel it is safe to comment on this game.  I would say the best way to describe this is that the win-loss seems to be like solitaire -- you don't necessarily know if you are going to win when you begin, but it certainly feels like it is pre-ordained before you even begin.  It's through playing the game that you even know if you stand a chance.  Further, the game really seems to lend itself to players that are power control freaks.  Rather than each player trying their best, it seems that one person needs to dictate specific strategies to get anywhere -- and the likelihood of you winning can be nil if the (bad) luck of the draw screws you over.  Not fun.  We've won 1 game out of 8.  If you like to lose and move your pieces at someone elses behest, then this game is for you.  Otherwise, I recommend moving along.

UPDATE:  Wahooo!!  I traded this game off to someone.  Thank goodness for BGG! :)  I'm now the lucky owner of a Mah Jong set.

RATING: 7.5
Pros: cooperative game, highly thematic, random roleplaying with special skillsets, highly tactical

Cons: prone to quarterbacking, limited strategic options, high degree of luck

The co-op game that defined co-op games, at least for me. Perfect level of difficulty due to a great balance between luck & decision-making. If players are able to figure out the most strategic, valuable decisions to make each turn, they are rarely rewarded with defeat. Fun roles for each player increase replayability.

RATING: 9
Maybe the best cooperative board game out there, as each player has a different role, and collectively they try to stop disease from taking over and covering the planet. Important: there are two editions of Pandemic. If you want to get the recent "On the Brink" expansion, you have to get the 2nd addition of Pandemic, not the original. Downside: if exactly one player is an intense strategist, they'll end up figuring out the best moves for everyone, and all the other players will end up simply taking orders. Otherwise, the game plays very well.

RATING: 3
Only slightly more fun than H1N1.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7
The prototypical cooperative game. Different roles work together to cure all the diseases in the world. The plays are basically playing against the board and racing against the clock to get diseases cured by running around the board removing cubes from cities and building research stations to eventually find a cure, etc. The game can definitely snowball on you as you draw more and more bad cards. 

I think this game is best played where you can't share information from your hand with other players. Like Shadows over Camelot you have to speak vaguely. Otherwise you'll get prone to planning moves way ahead of time and getting analysis paralysis. The worst problem is definitely quarterbacking though. If you have played it before and others haven't, make sure you really tone back the telling people what to do. It's helpful to give hints, but not to straight up plan peoples moves.

I like this game. It's definitely quality. But it's not my favorite, or even my favorite coop. I'd recommend playing it though.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8
Excellent use of teamwork and promotes a lot of discussion to win the game.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 10
I really like Pandemic. Full of tough decisions with real meaning and a lot of change from game to game.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 6
We've played with 2 players, both with us each controlling one and with us each controlling 2.  It's a hard game either way, though probably easier with each controlling 2.  In several plays we have yet to actually beat the game, but it's fun enough to keep us playing anyway!

Looking back I wish we had gotten one of the other versions, just for thematic purposes.  However, if you are new to Pandemic this is not a bad way to go.  Just beware the difficulty level is steep and would probably be discouraging to children or non-gamers.  Rules aren't too hard, but I would still not consider this a gateway game.  If you want to make it easier, maybe toss out an epidemic card or two.

RATING: 5
Simple and appealing to light gamers and nongamers, but really not my cup of tea.  The theme is an interesting one, and the gameplay is obviously derived from it to a certain extent, but there are clear sacrifices to playability and gaminess that quickly make the actual gameplay about counting cubes.

My biggest gripe is that the deck has the biggest impact on whether the players win or lose.  Perfect play won't beat a bad draw, and bad play will do just fine with a good draw.  It's remarkably frustrating, and I don't exactly feel like I'm getting much better at this game, because it's pretty easy to hit the initial threshold of good play.  From then on, you're just along for the ride as the game decides if it's winnable or not.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 9
After three plays, I can see why this is so popular.  A fun, easy-to-teach euro-style co-op game with a fun theme.  What's not to like?

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 9.4
Simply the best co-op ever made, and one of the best games period. Challenging, and scales excellently for all possible players, from 1 to 5. I love the puzzle solving aspects of the game, as you collectively work out a plan to win the game. 

I really don't believe in the so called "one person runs the game" criticism. One: if you're the guy attempting to control everything, just shut up and listen to what others have to say. Two: if you're playing with someone like this, SPEAK UP! Say what you think is the best move, if you disagree. No one can control the game on your turn except you. If you think it's the best move, MAKE IT. Regardless, it's silly to blame the game for your game group problem.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

So I guess this is the insanely hard version of Forbidden Island? Not sure which came first. Anyway, should be a lot of fun but I have never been in a group that beat the disease. Even on easy level. UPDATE: We finally beat this game, by the skin of our teeth. Beating the game has had a strange effect. Now that we know it is beatable, we want to play it a lot more. Every time we lose we want to try again immediately. Still insanely hard, but we have found hope!

Hey! We beat it again about 100 plays later! We didn't eradicate anything, just kept the outbreaks in check. Totally counter to what I thought was the best strategy. I wonder if we keep playing like this if it will be easier to win...

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 9.5
One of my all-time favorite cooperative games.  The theme is strong and the tension/difficulty is great.

Some games self adjust based on the players' performance.  If the players do well, the game 'punishes' them by becoming harder.  If the players are doing poorly, the game 'helps' them by becoming easier.  That helps games stay interesting, but it discourages trying really hard to play well (since it just makes life harder)!

Pandemic is not like that at all.  Good teamwork and diligence pays off.  Some sloppy play early on will be punished.

The biggest issue with this game is that one dominant/alpha player can easily start dictating what other players do on their turns.

Overall, it's an exceptional game that requires players to work closely together, utilizing each role's specialties.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 6.5

It seems to work best with 4 players.  With two, it seemed much easier to beat the diseases.

RATING: 6
I loved this game when I bought it. And since I felt enamored by it, I played quite a few rounds of it. I even bought the app during my winter holiday because my sis didn't want to play anything and I was feeling desperate! With the app I could play solo.

And so I grew bored of Pandemia. Seriously bored.

This is why it now only has a rating of 6.5 from me. Without any expansion the sessions begin to grow repetitive really fast. In order to help myself - and this game - I've bought one expansion thus far: 'The State of Emergency'. In reality I would have wanted to buy 'In the Lab' but it requires 'On the Brink' which is sold out. Plus, 26 € is a lot less than 35 € + 35 €.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 9
The game plays very quickly. There is a lot of table talk and this can cause some players to have their turns practically played out for them. As long as it is a group discussion and everyone agrees on the plan of action I don't see this as a problem. Much of the fun of the game was running through different scenarios which would play out several turns in advance to beat the game. But then the game throws a curve ball and it's back to the drawing board. We played 2 beginner setup games and lost the first one (minus the researcher) and won the second (minus the medic). I'm looking forward to playing with the standard setup next. 4 more beginner games (1-3). We won the one without the operations expert. *UPDATE* 5/13. My friend (dispatcher) and I (Op.Spec.) beat Heroic level. It helped that we didn't pull any black cities in the initial 9 and that area was the first to be cured and sunshined. *UPDATE* 5/20 BEat heroic level again. This time with scientist and medic. We sunshined Blue and Red fairly quickly.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 6
Interesting.  I can see this being much more replayable than other cooperative games, what with the way the roles and the infected cities come into play.  I can also see it falling prey to the "Meathead" effect, where the most experienced player dominates the decisions made by the group, but I think it's less pronounced than with other games in this category.  I think it's important for ANY cooperative game to allow players to discover it on their own.  A good leader can direct play without being pushy.

It took a while to begin playing the game correctly, but even during that time, it had a lot of appeal to it, and it has that "tickle" effect, where it settles in the brain for further analysis.  It's not a deep game, by any means, but I can see it being enjoyable, and easy to teach.  And because of the trickiness to remembering the rules, be aware that if your first game seems too easy, you're likely playing it incorrectly.

4 plays: 1 player
1 play: 2 players
2 plays: 3 players
4 plays: 4 players

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 6.5
Honestly Pandemic isn't really my cup of tea. I decided to go ahead and buy it after a few years of looking at such high reviews. The first time I played this game in a group of 3 it was not bad. Towards the end it was getting a little crazy but it was all calmed down in the end. The second time I played it in a group of 4 and that time around I decided to make the difficulty harder since there was an extra person. Yet that turned into the easiest game I have ever played in my life. We all just kind of took our turns without a care in the world. The outbreaks never got anywhere near out of hand, each virus was controlled, and we found a cure for them all without any stress inhibiting situations. We won the game yet there was no satisfaction for winning. We all just sat around the board asking, "That's it?" Maybe I'll give the game another chance sometime later down the line but for now it will definitely not be one of my go to games.

RATING: 9.85

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 6
I know this game is very popular and I can understand how that is.
I on the other hand find it punishingly hard and for no good reason.  What comes across as a strategy game in which players work together to cure the world of 4 spreading diseases, is in fact a luck-based game in which the order of cards in the draw deck pretty much dictates whether you will win or lose.
Furthermore, a well-thought-out theme of research centers, players with specialized roles, and an efficient system where disease spreads across borders falls apart with an awkward mechanic of "playing 5 cards" to cure a disease.  With such detail put in to creating methods to lose, the only method to win is the least thematic of them all.
In the end, it feels like a game that was simply written to be hard.  Change one number in the rule book (such as number of cards needed to cure a disease) and you'd have a completely different game on your hands.
Lastly, realize that Pandemic is a solitary game.  The number of players you have is completely irrelevant.  You can take each turn yourself, or share with a friend - there's really no difference.
I've played several times, and had the same challenges each time.  The game doesn't change much, play after play - it just comes down to which cards are drawn when to determine if you'll win.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 9
单从娱乐的角度来说，这游戏非常不错，我很喜欢。期待更多扩充。

RATING: N/A
You are specialists at the CDC/Atlanta where you watch several virulent diseases break out simultaneously all over the world. The team mission is to prevent a world-wide pandemic outbreak, treating hotspots while researching cures for each of the four plagues before they get out of hand.
\13\\13\
Players must plan their strategy to mesh their specialist's strengths before the diseases overwhelm the world. For example, the Operations Specialist can build research stations which are needed to find cures for the diseases. The Scientist needs only 4 cards of a particular disease to cure it instead of the normal 5. But the diseases are breaking out fast and time is running out: the team must try to stem the tide of infection in diseased areas while developing cures. If disease spreads uncontrolled, the players all lose. If they can cure all four diseases, they win.
\13\\13\
The board shows earth with some big population centres. On each turn a player can use four actions to travel, cure, discover and build. Cards are used for this but the deck also contains Epidemics...
\13\\13\
Note: Pandemic: On the Brink expansion is store in the base game box. The expansion allows a 5th player.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 6
Pandemic is one of those games that I enjoy more for the cleverness of the design than the actual gameplay. Don't get me wrong, I do think it's a lot of fun. I just feel that it is more of a puzzle than a game and that winning or losing is often as much of a function of the randomized deck or the order of roles as it is of playing well. Normally this would turn me off, but I am truly fascinated by the mechanisms that drive the game. Stacking the discard pile on top of the draw pile to intensify disease outbreaks as the game goes on and having the outbreaks that are left untreated start to cascade around the world map are both ingenius ideas that add loads of tension and excitement to what is otherwise a pretty dull set collection game. I'm not sure how well it will hold up to repeated play, as it seems to me that once everyone at the table knows what they are doing, the game will sort of play itself. Like solitaire, winning or losing will probably have already been determined by the shuffle.

Amazing design though...Hats off to Matt Leacock.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

Adrian

RATING: 8
The scalable difficulty level, quick and easy to grasp rules, well-integrated theme, and quality components all combine for an excellent gaming experience.

My only real complaint is one of scale.  The pieces are too large for the board.  They don't fit in the city spaces - it's very easy to over-fill a city enough that pieces look like they're in an adjacent city instead of the one they're supposed to be in.  The pieces need to be shrunk (except for the cubes; they're okay), and the board enlarged slightly.  This is the second printing, too.  I thought there were enough complaints about this the first time around that it was going to get fixed.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 6
2013-02-27
With a group that works together (even if debating the best course of action), this game is incredible. Every card draw is tense and every move walks the fine line between success and failure. Defeat encourages you to try again; victory encourages you to see if you can keep the streak going. I played this 7 times in two days with the same group, and we never got tired of it.

2013-09-02
After having a lot of plays in just a few other co-op games, I can see that there is much less cooperation involved in Pandemic. Yes, each player has their own specialized roles that help the group, but the only thing that can be accomplished on your own is removing disease cubes (a minor task, overall). Because of this, the game doesn't come down to working together so much as putting everyone's ideas to a vote. I have to lower my rating from a 9 to a 6, since it's no longer my first choice in co-op games.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

RATING: 7
This is an extremely well-designed game with a unique and clever theme that I just don't enjoy all that much.  It's absolutely worth playing if you like co-ops though, just because it's so dang smart.  

The best example of cleverness in this game is that, unlike in so many other co-ops, the bad stuff that happens to you is not [i]completely[/i] random.  After each epidemic, the cities that were infected last round get shuffled and placed on top of the deck.  This means that the same cities will be infected over and over again.  This not only makes the situation more desperate (building tension), but also means that you can really strategize around the cities that you [i]know[/i] will come up (just not exactly when).  Everything seems to be designed around these basic tenets of controlled randomness, building tension, and partial information.

Clearly, I respect this game a lot.  I just don't love it.  The biggest problem for me is an extremely petty one: I hate preparing the deck before each game--shuffling the cards, dealing out the hands, dividing the rest into little stacks, shuffling an epidemic card into each stack, and stacking them all on top of each other. Blah!  If someone else would take this job off my hands, I would like Pandemic much more.  This is evidenced by my greater like for Forbidden Island, which is very similar without the deck building business.

The second problem is that the game just feels "samey" after a while.  Everyone I've introduced it to loves this game, so we play it fairly often, and it just always feels very similar.  The consistency of the game is part of what makes the design so smart, but ultimately it hurts it a bit in my eyes.  You never play a game of Pandemic and say, HOLY CRAP THAT HAS NEVER HAPPENED BEFORE!!!  I'm hesitant to say this is because the game isn't random enough because it's true that you get fluky situations like 5-6 of your first cards all of one color (leading to a quick loss).  I think it has more to do with how constraining the game is in general, leaving not many opportunities for truly creative play by the players.

The expansion does help mix things up quite a bit, and it breathed a bit more life into Pandemic for me.  And of course, as I've already stressed (and is reflected in my score), I think Pandemic is a very smart game in a lot of ways.  I just don't have enough fun while playing it.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

- The way how you really have to plan together for giving each other the cards needed to win
- The way how you have to balance not losing (cleaning up the diseases and manage time) and wining (curing the diseases).

RATING: 6
One of the first games I purchased when I discovered BGG. Drove two hours one way to pick it up from another Geek because it was still out of print at the time. Fun game, but haven't played it much lately. Maybe it's because I'm always teaching and end up practically playing the game by myself. Though it's great to see the game 'click' with new players.

Info for Traders:
I want to be upfront about this game. It's a first edition copy so there is slight warpage that doesn't affect play. It's something that afflicts many (if not all) first edition copies, I'm not sure about more recent editions. Also, I have not yet sent in my 'Operations Expert' card to Z-man for the 'linen finish' deck, yet. I'm waiting on news for them to be available.

RATING: 10

I love the theme, the various loss mechanics, and the tension that happens naturally when the world is on the verge of collapse from disease. Fantastic game that I will always want to play.

RATING: 8
Several virulent diseases have broken out all over the world! You are disease fighting specialists whose mission is to treat disease hotspots while researching cures for each of four plagues before they get out of hand. You must work together and  plan your strategy to mesh with each of you special strengths.
A game of tough choices, strategy and teamwork.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7
It used to be an "8", but now I have to say that it won't be easy to go back to this version of Pandemic after playing Pandemic Legacy. It is "too basic" and doesn't have that much to offer when compared to its bigger brother. It's a solid game, but now I feel that it requires some expansions in order to stay fresh and interesting. 

Still, if you've never played Pandemic Legacy you should enjoy this basic version of Pandemic quite a bit. It's a cool co-op game with simple rules and involving gameplay. The theme comes through really nicely. I strongly recommend playing with 4 players - this game is all about teamplay and table talk, therefore it loses a lot of charm when played only with 2.

RATING: 8
Mmmm...diseases.  Now all they need is to have a bioinformatician role...

Very good coop game.  Very clean design, controlled randomness.  Somewhat more of a puzzle than a game,  but a good (and tough!) puzzle.

You can see a guaranteed win from a couple turns away sometimes,  which is anti-climactic.  Actually,  the ability to predict the probably state of the board a couple turns into the future is both a plus (long term coordinated plans are very possible) but also a minus (by the end of the game, there are no real surprises,  just "unlucky draws") 

But when the system has you over the barrel,  you can end up sweating bullets as you flip the cards.

RATING: 7
As far as co-ops go, this one is very good.  I have found it to be either too difficult, or too easy.  We can't quite find a sweet spot.  If you decide to teach this game to new players, here's a word of advice:  Don't coach too much.  I had a new player once tell me he did not like to game because he didn't really play, the other three players just told him what to do.  So either teach the game to all new players at once, or be able to sit back and let them make their own decisions even if you know they are not the best.

RATING: 7
This is an 8 after two 3-player plays of the Intro Game. Will update after more plays. But for now, I'm hooked! I just love the pressure and the pretty convincing feeling that doom is slowly spreading all over the globe. And it's fast, too!

Production values are so-so: cube and pawns are very rough, and the cards have next to no coating. Use card sleeves if you don't want the cards to soak up any and all moisture.

[EDIT] After 30 plays, I'm still having a ton of fun with this one. Winning remains very difficult, even at "normal" level (five epidemic cards). Looking forward to more games of this.

RATING: 8

RATING: 8

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 9.5
This is one of my favorite co-op games.  The theme of the game is great.  The game has a couple of adjustments that can be made to scale the difficultly of the game.  On the most intense level, it can be a challenging game to win.  You can play it however you like.

The challenges of this game for some are that it is a co-op game.  My wife enjoys game for the competition and she can't get into it as well when the competition is with the game and not another player.  Also, since this game is a co-op, it lends itself to an "alpha gamer" situation, where one player might talk through all of the decisions and actually be the only one playing the game.  You have to be in a group that is either tolerant to having an alpha gamer situation, or with players that can restrain themselves from being an alpha gamer.  

With that said, it is a great game.  I always have a great time playing this game.  It just doesn't seem to fit as well with as many gamers as other games might.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

RATING: 7.5
A nail-biter, teeth-clencher, and billfold-emptier - all at once.

Tight rules and excellent cooperative gameplay, but the game can spiral out of control (billions killed, whoops!) through absolutely no fault of the players.  There's not a high-percentage chance that it will happen, but it's certainly possible.

If one player is more experienced than the others, it's best for that person to pipe down and let the others enjoy themselves.  A backseat germ-killer barking out orders can spoil everyone's fun.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 4
I like Pandemic but I think that it fails as a cooperative game. There are two important reasons for this: abstraction and necessity.

The game of Chess is an abstraction. The players are representative of two noble parties in feud as they compete over a given plot of land. The land itself is represented by a logical map and not a physical one. The individual pieces move in accordance with abstract rules, only loosely in keeping with the roles for which they are named - while it is true that a King relies greatly on his subjects or a mounted Knight might be afforded greater mobility, the nature of a Bishop's movement speaks more to play mechanics than it does any interplay between theology and monarchy. Similarly, games like Go and Checkers and even Tic-Tac-Toe are abstractions; they are oppositional games of strategy and tactics. Theme in these sorts of games is superfluous because the players are primarily engaged in left-brain activity.

Despite its dressing, Pandemic is also an abstraction. The theme of epidemiology might easily be substituted with one of farmers faced with the spread of weeds among their crops. The map, while seemingly more realistic than a chess board, remains a logical representation governed by arbitrary rules. Each player, assigned an appropriately themed identity, is granted unique abilities - and these abilities are incorporated to facilitate (or force) player interaction, not because they engender a personal relationship between each player and his or her given role.

The appeal of Chess is not diminished by its abstraction for two reasons: it pits players against one another and, further, it does not necessitate communication among players on the same team.

When you eliminate the opposing player, an abstract game is more akin to a puzzle. There remains no emotional investment of pride. The incentive of winning is reduced to the exercise of skill; and the challenge becomes merely a question of comprehension and complexity.

When you take an abstract puzzle - such as I characterize Pandemic to be - and you introduce the pretense of teamwork, you're going to run into trouble. People don't rally under abstraction. It takes necessity, language and sometimes even symbolism for people to unite.

Simply put: Pandemic allows for two-to-four players, but it only requires one. In fact, the aphorism that two heads are better than one doesn't even apply. Each additional player only introduces additional frustration.

The mechanics of Pandemic are not exceedingly complex. Many have already attested to the fact that on any given turn there exist only a few - sometimes as few as one - reasonable actions of play. Because of the manner in which played cards are reshuffled, a careful player can very easily anticipate and preempt imminent obstacles. The more you understand the mechanics, the easier the game becomes; and by extrapolation, a general solution can be devised and applied.

I approach Pandemic the same way I might approach Sudoku. Both are abstract puzzles, though they initially appear to be otherwise (beginners often mistake Sudoku for a math problem, however, the numbers could just as easily be substituted with the first nine sequential letters of the alphabet).

I suppose you could attempt to solve a Sudoku puzzle with a partner. Having identified the right number for a particular cell you might then explain to your partner why it is so. But your ability to communicate why it is the right number and, further, your partner's ability to understand you has no bearing on the solution itself. The number is either right or it is wrong, and the deciding factor is not dependent on a consensus of the players. What's more, to communicate this way for each cell would become exceedingly tedious.

Pandemic is cooperative in the same sense that Sudoku might be cooperative if you and your partner took turns with the pencil. A given player is no more or less empowered with respect to whose turn it might happen to be; the game is simply played by whomever identifies the next best action.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 10
Awesome cooperative game that gets better every time we play it.  I still love this game even after more than 60 plays, so it deserves a full 10 rating.  The OTB expansion is a must-have.

The difficulty level can be scaled up or down dramatically based on the number Epidemics you put in the deck and the number of players you have.  In both cases, more = more difficult.

All of my recorded plays from 10-12-09 and later include OTB in some way (new roles and special action cards).

Current W-L records:
[color=green]- 4 Epidemics (Standard): 11-7*[/color]
[color=brown]- 4 Epidemics (VStrain): 3-1[/color]
[color=purple]- 4 Epidemics (Mutation): 2-1[/color]
[color=green]- 5 Epidemics (Standard): 14-9[/color]
[color=brown]- 5 Epidemics (VStrain): 1-2[/color]
[color=purple]- 5 Epidemics (Mutation): 2-1[/color]
[color=green]- 6 Epidemics (Standard):  3-5[/color]
[color=black][b]- 7 Epidemics (VS + Mutation):  0-1[/b][/color]

(Overall: 36-27)

*Wins for Bioterrorist: 1

RATING: 8
This coop board game is a fantastic and brutal glimpse at how quick a disease can spread.  Your game will be a slow but thoughtful hour as you carefully utilize your friends' roles to stop multiple outbreaks. Losing can be anti-climatic, unfair, or awkward at times, but finding all four cures is a rewarding experience and will hook you to play more.

RATING: 5
Kind of dry, a little too predictable in some ways.  When I first played this, it seemed great.  But after a few plays, you realize there aren't a whole lot of real meaningful choices, exacerbated by a misplaced use of randomness.  It's not a bad game, but it really became less appealing the more I played it.  Plus, it has some of the more horrible pitfalls of coops (eg domineering players), without providing some of the more charming aspects of coops (eg traitors).  Great for "non-gamers," but not much that I can see to satisfy those who want some more heft to their games.

RATING: 9
I like this game a lot for multiple reasons, but the primary reason is that it is simple enough to play with my parents and complex enough to engage me.  The difficulty level is also easily modified too.

Additionally since it is cooperative, people of varying levels of board game experience can play, and as they gain experience, you can add more difficulty (epidemic cards).  If you add the expansion you can add even more complexity and difficulty.

I have to confess, that I love cooperative board games so remember that when reading my comment.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8.5
Great gateway game to introduce people to the co-op genre.  The theme is fantastic and the differing roles really give the players a unique perspective to bring to the table each game.  The game really culminates well as your team is getting closer to victory, yet so is the board!  

Lots of fun to be had here.  Game does have some problems; most notably being very prone to a One Man General type syndrome where someone can ruin all the fun of discovery for the group.  The game really feels like a puzzle you are trying to solve with your team and is unique each game.

RATING: 8

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 6.75
I haven't played Pandemic since the beginning of 2013 and I believe that there are a number of reasons for it. The first being that this is a brutal coop. I know that there are people that say that it's "easy" and that they have expansions to make it more difficult but I believe that my win percentage is well below 50%... and that's just the base game. I recall playing a few games with my wife where we were just destroyed and having her say that she "played games for fun and this just wasn't fun". While I don't agree with that statement 100%, I do understand where she was coming from. The game sets you up for failure and, depending on the card draws, and beat you down to a pulp. If you're not in to that style of game where the game itself is trying to destroy you, I can see how it wouldn't be "fun".

The next knock against it is that you really need to play with a full compliment of people and/or play with two people using two roles each. It seems like the game was designed to work this way as certain combinations of roles seem vastly superior to others.

And the final knock against it is that it can suffer from the alpha-player syndrome (as many coops can). I don't know how you can negate that concern other than trying not to be the alpha-player, but it's a concern and something that needs to be taken into account.

While I think that it's a great game to introduce people to newer types of board games as you're working together to beat the game, it isn't something that I'm chomping at the bit to play again soon.


=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

RATING: 7
Ah, Pandemic... How you have enthused both me and my fellow players. In essence it's so straightforward, yet offers a gripping experience to save the world! Going all rescue rangers to rid the world of harm isn't something many other games can replicate in such an elegant way as Pandemic can. Everytime you come up with a plan together based on the latest events. "Are you gonna build that station there? Why not there? Or maybe you should do an entirely different action!" It's a game that provokes discussion among players. It's funny sometimes how people have different ideas to tacke a certain problem. It's psychology at its best.

RATING: 9
This game recently went from a game that I like to a game that I love. 
My mom and I were playing and were celebrating as we were a turn away from curing the fourth disease and winning. The player deck was less than half gone, so we thought we had it in the bag. Because we were so close to winning, we were not worried about all the accumulating disease cubes in Europe. Just then, there was a massive chain reaction outbreak and we lost. I was so impressed by how the game sneaked up on us and have been pulling it out more frequently ever since. 
Great game. I like the cooperative element. I play it with my non-boardgame playing family and they genuinely enjoy it.

RATING: 7

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 9
A couple comments on the components. The cubes and research stations are a little large. The cubes are easier to manage because there will never be more than three of one color at one city. However, if you get three cubes and three pawns and a research facility all in one city, spillover will occur. It isn't that big of a deal, but makes it kind of fiddly. The infection cards are black and I worry about them standing up to repeated playing. They certainly do look sharp though.

The infection / epidemic mechanic is interesting. There are a couple of threads discussing the details. By reading the rules, it does seem counter-intuitive, i.e. drawing off of the bottom during an epidemic. However, through playing it does make sense as this introduces a completely new city to contend with, along with intensifying the need to control the cities currently that have been infected.

A couple of thoughts.  First, this game is accessible to all. The rules are well-written, well-illustrated and don't leave many questions. For some, it may initially appear intimidating, but the system is very elegant. I also believe that being a cooperative game makes it less intimidating - everyone is working together. Second, I am wondering if three people is an optimum number. This gives three roles available in the game and doesn't dilute the player deck too much. Third, I can't see how you can win this game without the researcher. Every game I have played has included the researcher and that player has been the key to getting information to the right players. The medic is nice, but without the medic the strategy becomes controlling the cubes rather than eliminating them. The scientist can be helpful, but usually there are enough cards to pass around that one less isn't a deal breaker. The dispatcher, in my opinion, would be the second most important role. The operations expert is the weakest, and needs a secondary power such as immediately being able to move to any research station from any other city. Finally, the game isn't over until the final cure is reached. Games go from being won in two turns to being lost due to having no more cubes in stock due to outbreaks.

After a couple more plays I have increased my rating of this game. It is fun, and I enjoy playing it. In addition, my wife is already trying to figure out when the next time we will have people over so we can play. I reminded her that we can play with two, and she was ready to set the game up right then.

Includes ArtsCow unofficial expansion [url=http://www.boardgamegeek.com/thread/415257]Threat Level 6[/url] and [url=http://www.boardgamegeek.com/thread/456868]End Day[/url]
Includes [gameid=40849]

Plays after 10-26-09 include some or all of [gameid=40849].

RATING: 9
最適遊戲人數:2-4
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 10
I've heard it said that Pandemic is the embodiment of the Alpha player problem. I reject that utterly. The alpha player is the problem. Not the game. If you are willing to stand up for yourself and tell the alpha that they are running the game for others then it will stop if they are a reasonable human being. If they dont stop then why in the world would you play games with that person?

I've also heard it said that Pandemic can be played solo, as though there were some problem with games that have 1 player variants. Can you play it alone? Yes. Is it more fun playing it with others? Yes. What is the problem?

The length of the game is great, the theme is awesome, the game mechanics are fantastic, it is a truly cooperative experience, the replayability is good, the learning curve is incredibly small. This game is incredible.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 9.25
This is an excellent co-operative board game. Not only is it well-balanced, it is also thematically very apt. Game time is under an hour and that makes it suitable as a family game. The artwork is reasonably well-done as well.

A small concern is the low winning percentage which may turn away some gamers. This is especially so if you draw an early Epidemic card. My Significant Other and I, fortunately, do not fall into this category.

RATING: 8
Fantastic game! I love the cooperative aspect of the game. The components are great. I love how crowded the board gets as more and more infections hit, and when you get an outbreak it's turns downright scary. Just a great game.

On the Brink is an essential expansion, it gives you so many new fun options.

Thoughts on Difficulty Level:
The number of Epidemic cards is obviously the main thing that increases the game's difficulty, while the Virulent Strain is fun, it is mereley a slight increase in difficulty, and the same applies, but perhaps even more so to the Mutation.

I think that the Virulent Strain, and the Mutation may be equal to perhaps 1/3 of an Epidemic Card, so just a small boost in difficulty. I also think that in a 2-player game it is very hard to win a game with 6+ Epidemic Cards.

RATING: 7
Great gateway game for its relatable theme and co-op decision making. New players can contribute or make as many or few decisions as they want and the game still progresses. This saves us from "brain burn" and "analysis paralysis."

Scales well and has various difficulty levels making it very versatile for many gamers/levels.

*Update* After more plays, I find the "Dictator" effect to be in full swing with many play groups. This ends up breaking a lot of co-ops for me. I think co-ops with specific role knowledge/hidden information help mitigate this potential issue.

RATING: 8
I love cooperative games, unfortunately most of them either pit one side against the other, or there is a chance to become a traitor or switch sides.  This game is 100 percent cooperative.  You either all win or all lose.

Great co-op game. Works great with two players. Great theme. It's probably because the wife and I work in health care that we enjoy this one so much. Looking forward to owning the expansion.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7
I always love a good co-op game, but unfortunately a lot of them usually take way too long for my liking (i.e. Shadow Over Camelot and Arkham Horror), so Pandemic's promise of a 45 minutes play time is definitely something to look forward to.  I will however admit that I was unimpressed with the mechanics when I first read the rules.

Many of the reviews and session reports claimed that Pandemic was brutally tough on the players.  Some even went as far as to warn people not to expect to win in their first few games, so imagine my surprise when we claimed our victory with a comfortable margin (the city draw deck was still half full and the outbreak was only at 4), so much so that my reaction was a "is that it?"  Granted we didn't play with the advance rule, which I think is an addition of two more epidemic cards, but we did beat the game without the use of a medic, and that was a pretty big accomplishment if I do say so myself.

Ultimately, I did appreciate the tension and urgency one felt periodically throughout the game, especially during an outbreak.  Yet there were still lulls during the session in which I'm just going through the motion while waiting for something interesting to happen; would it be weird if I said I wanted epidemic to occur more often?  I like Pandemic, especially how quick it is, but my fear is that it won't stand up to heavy replays.  Considering there are only 5 roles available, I imagine that each game would be very similar to another outside of the combination of the roles randomly selected.  So the jury is still out for me on this one.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

Lots of fun,  very challenging.

RATING: 7
This one can definitely give you an ulcer!

I picked this one up after the recommendations I received and I was pleasantly surprised.  

The game play is very intense and challenging.  It is nice to own a game that offers so many playing variations and this very much adds to the high replayability factor.

This one is truly difficult to beat. I like that!  You never know how any session will turn out.  You can refine your strategy every time and still be knocked down flat!

I have gotten a good grasp of the strategies involved to be victorious, but it isn't easy.  When you win, it truly feels like an accomplishment.  With the right group of people, this one could easily become a favorite.

The components are top notch and very nicely done.  I do feel I received my moneys worth.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 2
There is way too much randomness for my taste. Especially finding cures is a pain, since there's rarely time to draw (or trade) enough player cards of the same color. We never won with five or more epidemics, which really drove me away. The best feature is the demand for player interaction. However, the whole course of the game is determined by how the card decks happen to get shuffled - which sucks. Gameplay is very mechanic and lacks interesting decisions or possibilities for alternate strategies.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7
Nice co-op game with surprisingly good tension going on. You're struggling the whole time with the feeling that there is no time to save the earth from all consuming plague of pandemic viruses and yet still have that slight ray of hope that your struggles aren't in vain, that your actions will matter in the end. I like it. After 4 games with standard difficulty (with 1 win), I would definetly like to get this game. Although there is a slight worry back in my mind that how long this game will live with repeated gaming.

RATING: 6
Hmmm. I was very excited to try this game out. I've been looking for an entry level coop for those not ready for the full-on Arkham Horror experience. Being a science geek, the biology theme was very appealing.

After a solo and a 2-player game, I'm left yawning. Pandemic feels like little wooden cubes placed randomly on a grid at the whim of a deck of cards - and thats it in a nutshell. The theme evaporates as the game begins. The only real strategy seems to be in efficient movement.

I'll give it a couple more tries to see if the highest difficulty evokes the sense of chaotic doom that I seek, but Arkham is calling me home...

RATING: 10
I can see why so many people love this game. A tense and well balanced game. And the cooperative nature is great for those who are wishing to get into the hobby but worry their friends will just gang up on them.

This way, the game gangs up on everyone. 

You do have to be careful of the alpha-player problem, but that's usually resolved by ensuring the issue is addressed early on. Or so we've found. But we have pretty strong personalities and that may help.

Pandemic Legacy just takes this whole thing up a notch.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 9
UPDATE2: On the Brink really did breath life into this, and the adjustable difficulty really keeps things interesting too. 2-player is also surprisingly fun, even when playing with just two roles.

----

UPDATE: Still enjoy the odd game of this. Tweaking the challenge level and using the added twists in On the Brink is fun. It works unexpectedly well as a two player game, since it makes sure you'll always be involved in the discussion of what to do next. The role-switch event card also becomes a lot more important and interesting.

----

The shine may be coming off this one. It's neat watching the diseases grow and putting out fire, but it may be a case of luck dominating the game once the basic set of necessary actions to take is figured out. Might turn around on this if some kind of deeper play is evidenced in future games. But the artificially separated cooperative element is also holding it back. Maybe there needs to be a better mechanic than "you can tell everyone what cards you have, without limit, but you just can't show them". Perhaps you can show one face-up card and that's it.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 6
5/26/08: Dropped from an 8 to a 6 after repeated plays.  Sorry, Pandemic.

3/2/08: (4 plays so far 1:3 w/l ratio)I get a kick out of playing on the same side as my friends when playing games.  Pandemic does a nice job of generating interesting ways for players to work synergistically, which is a key factor in assessing a co-op game's goodness.

RATING: 8

RATING: 7.5
R
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7.5
A solid game that I am usually willing to play, but one that has never (and likely will never) sucked me in. I wish I could love it instead of like it, but it's simply too obvious. Odd choice of words? Let me explain. Pandemic has a very clear turn order, and it becomes obvious what MUST be done on every turn. If one deviates from this, if one, in essence, chooses to play the game his/her own way, the game could very well be lost. Not my idea of fun. With Defenders of the Realm or Arkham, for example, a certain degree of failure is accounted for due to the randomness associated with the game. I prefer that sense of freedom and variability.

EDIT: 12/30/12
Just got back from a vacation where I had the opportunity to play this with a few kids (13-16). I'm bumping the score a half a point after seeing how great this game works with non-gamers. Finally found a solid use for it.
